HEADLINE: Arts Abroad;
Maybe Spain's 1898 Defeat Was No Great Loss After All

BYLINE: By Al Goodman

DATELINE: SALAMANCA, Spain

 BODY:
Heading diligently into the centennial of the Spanish-American War, Spain is ready to feel less pain when remembering the Maine. A new spin on history says the loss of Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Philippines was not such a disaster after all.
The three colonies were not vital to the nation, goes the argument, part of the latest debunking of Spanish textbooks. Further, many scholars now contend that writers like Miguel de Unamuno and Pio Baroja, of the literary group known as the Generation of '98, fretted less over the end of the empire than was widely believed. Rather, they were busy worrying about more important things, the scholars say. 
 "There has been a very simplified vision of the Generation of '98 linking it to the loss of the colonies," said Victor Garcia de la Concha, a literature professor at the University of Salamanca. "Today we have a distinct vision."
The new interpretation is strong in this medieval university town, about 130 miles west of Madrid, where Columbus visited the cavernous stone buildings before the conquest of the New World began. Those buildings have lately been outfitted with modern heating, computers and professors unwilling to accept the usual explanations about the Spanish-American War's impact on Spain and its writers.
The Generation of '98, they point out, was not even considered a literary movement until a Madrid newspaper article in 1913, a full 15 years after the war. And the group's half-dozen disparate poets and novelists, ranging from political progressives to conservatives, were unhappy at being lumped together.
Their criticism of the image of a decaying, inward-looking Spain started several years before the United States battleship Maine exploded on Feb. 15, 1898, in Havana harbor, the event precipitating the war that made heroes of Teddy Roosevelt and his Rough Riders.
After the war, the Generation of '98, which included Antonio Machado, Jose Martinez Ruiz (known as Azorin) and Ramon Maria del Valle-Inclan, wrote little specifically about it and indeed expressed virtually no anti-American sentiment. Later, one of Unamuno's daughters even taught Spanish in the United States.
In their novels, plays, poems and essays, the writers explored existentialism, spirituality or literary themes, managing to challenge Spain's sense of identity.
Unamuno, the bearded, stern-faced philosopher who was the most prolific writer of the Generation of '98 and also the rector at the University of Salamanca, unleashed some of his sharpest barbs in the postwar period.
"We Spaniards have intolerance in our blood, it has been said and repeated, and there is something to that," he wrote in 1902. "It is not Catholicism that made Spaniards intolerant, but Spaniards who made Catholicism intolerant."
Baroja, a novelist whom Hemingway admired, addressed Spain's difficulty in accepting its status as a more modest country after the end of the empire.
"Before, without a doubt, it was quixotic country, which thought of itself differently from what it really was," Baroja wrote in 1927. "Before, in the period of adventures, Spain was led by Don Quixote. From now on, it would be directed by Sancho Panza."
These comments typically came in newspaper articles or minor essays, not their more well-known works, like Unamuno's "Tragic Sense of Life in Men and Nations" (1913), about absolute faith, and Baroja's trilogy of novels, "The Struggle for Existence" (1904).
The group's literary output was tied less to the war than to the perceived moral, esthetic and philosophical crisis affecting Spain and Europe at the turn of the century, said Manuel Perez Lopez, a Salamanca literature professor.
Still, the Generation of '98 will be dissected, along with the war, at numerous centenary symposiums and expositions planned for 1998 in Spain as well as the United States, the Philippines and Puerto Rico. The University of Salamanca alone has scheduled seven conferences, with a major one in June about Unamuno.
He was the Generation of '98 writer most deeply linked to Salamanca, having spent more than half his life here. The city remembers him devoutly, with three statues and a street, a cafe and two schools named for him. Unamuno's home, with his personal library of 5,500 volumes in a dozen languages, is a research museum, visited by professors and schoolchildren alike.
The rest of Spain is bound to think about Unamuno this year, too. A dozen new books on the war and the writers already have been published, with more scheduled for release, not to mention the television specials.
"We live for commemorations," said a Salamanca history professor, Antonio Morales. "It's a good time to get funds and a good opportunity to publish."
Despite the revisionism, the Generation of '98 label seems in little danger. "It's in all the books, impossible to avoid," said Mr. Perez. Even those who criticize the term have to use it, he said, "contributing to its permanence."
The changing attitude about the Spanish-American War, and the writers tied to it, has been gaining adherents since Spain's transition to democracy in the late 1970's. Some historians now argue against viewing Spain mainly as an oddly romantic and dramatic country, for despite the flamenco dancing and bullfights, they say, it is developing an economic and political structure like its European neighbors, though at a slower pace.
"The thesis of Spain as a failure as a nation was strong in the Generation of '98," said Juan Pablo Fusi, a University of Madrid historian. "Now, most people aren't so pessimistic about Spain."
Certainly not Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar, who spoke here in April at the inaugural session of the state commission for the centennial. He urged Spaniards "to flee from a sense of being victims, and not connect the events of '98 with the lament over territorial loss, which forced Spain to live realistically its destiny."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of the three statues of Miguel de Unamuno in Salamanca, Spain. (Al Goodman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Immigration Is Fueling Cities' Strong Growth, Data Show

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The Census Bureau today offered fresh evidence of the impact of immigration on the country's population in this decade, reporting that several major metropolitan areas -- notably New York, Los Angeles and Chicago -- grew strongly even as many longer-term residents left for other parts of the country.
The influx of immigrants helped turn these areas, as well as the Washington, San Francisco, Seattle, Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston regions, into some of the biggest gainers in population in the country. Growth in those regions was also aided by high numbers of births, another side effect of immigration because immigrant families are more likely to be of child-bearing age, and immigrant women tend to have higher birth rates than their American-born counterparts. 
 "If you look at some of the Frost Belt areas like New York and Chicago, international immigration is very important," said Marc Perry, a demographer with the Census Bureau. "Their population increases aren't coming from domestic migration."
Two year-end studies, containing figures for 1990 through 1996, and interviews with demographers indicate that two years from the end of the century, Americans are a people in motion, willing to move often and across long distances in search of better jobs, a more enjoyable or less expensive life style or a strong support system of family and friends.
The data, from the Census Bureau, will undoubtedly add to the debate over whether increased competition for jobs in areas where immigrants have clustered is pushing out people who are already living there, or whether those who depart would have left anyway, lured by better economic prospects elsewhere.
The impact of immigration on population patterns was derived from two studies released today: one on population changes state by state and the other on changes in the country's 273 metropolitan areas -- cities and their surrounding suburbs.
Sifting through the Census Bureau's data reveals three trends that have dominated population shifts in the 1990's: Growth remains strongest in the Sun Belt states of the South and West, which contain the 50 metropolitan areas with the fastest rates. Las Vegas, Nev., fueled by the economic engine of the gambling industry, is the fastest-growing metropolitan area in the country. And the impact of immigrants has been profound.
Perhaps most striking of these involves immigration.
The Census Bureau report on metropolitan areas indicated that 3 of the 10 areas experiencing the fastest rate of growth -- McAllen-Edinburg-Mission, Tex.; Laredo, Tex., and Brownsville-Harlingen-San Benito, Tex. -- are in the Rio Grande Valley and are gateway cities for many immigrants from Mexico.
The report also noted that of the 10 metropolitan areas that have gained the most people, 8 -- Los Angeles, Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, Washington, New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Seattle -- have benefited from high levels of immigration.
Even as some of these regions gain population over all, their central cores continue to lose people. In New York, for example, Census Bureau demographers estimate that although the metropolitan area gained nearly 389,000 people from 1990 through 1996, more than 900,000 migrated out from the core area of New York's five boroughs, plus Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties. The Census Bureau considers the New York metropolitan region to be this core area, Long Island and parts of Southern Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
In California, more than 1.2 million people left Los Angeles County from 1990 through 1996. But because of immigration and a high number of births, the Los Angeles metropolitan area gained 963,626 people, making it the biggest gainer in population of all the country's metropolitan areas.
The same held true last year for California as a whole, according to the report on state-by-state growth. Last year, the state added more than 410,000 people, far and away the largest numerical increase of any state. Census Bureau demographers say that increase is the result of births and immigration, because California continues to experience the strong levels of domestic out-migration that it has throughout the 1990's.
As depicted in the Census Bureau reports, the experiences of the Los Angeles metropolitan area and of Las Vegas graphically illustrate the difficulty in determining whether immigrants are displacing longer-term resident in some cities.
According to the Census Bureau, Las Vegas has been the fastest-growing metropolitan region in the 1990's, increasing by 40.9 percent. Las Vegas' growth far outpaced the city in the No. 2 spot, Laredo, which grew by 32.7 percent.
Las Vegas' growth rate is based on job growth tied either directly or indirectly to the area's ever-expanding gambling industry. The rate of population growth is even more stunning considering that, unlike Laredo, which is a relatively small area, Las Vegas started out the decade already a large metropolitan area. In 1990, the region's population was 852,646. By July 1996, it stood at more than 1.2 million.
"That just jumps out at you," Mr. Perry said. "It's grown nearly 41 percent in six years. And it's not starting from a low base."
But unlike Los Angeles, roughly 80 percent of the growth in the Las Vegas area comes from movement of people already in the country, Mr. Perry said. And many of those people come from Southern California.
A study conducted by the Department of Comprehensive Planning in Clark County, Nev., showed that in 1993, 29 percent of the people who moved to the county that year were from five counties in Southern California -- Los Angeles, Orange, San Diego, Riverside and San Bernardino. All five of those counties have seen heavy flows of immigrants in the 1990's.
Such a pattern has caused some demographers, like William Frey of the University of Michigan, to speculate that low-skilled and low-income whites and blacks are leaving some major cities in the face of increased competition for jobs from immigrants, or when they see other economic opportunities elsewhere.
"This is what happens to the native born," Mr. Frey said in an interview today. "They have other options. When they see increased competition, they go somewhere else."
But Mr. Frey acknowledges that it is an open question whether those leaving an area like Los Angeles are being forced out by competition from immigrants, or lured away by the expanding economic opportunities in Las Vegas.
"There's both pushes and pulls for people who leave," he said.

HEADLINE: Not Just a New Year: A 100th Birthday for a Unified City

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY

 BODY:
When the ball dropped above Times Square last night, it not only ushered in 1998, but it also marked the 100th anniversary of the consolidation of the five boroughs into the city that is now New York.
To celebrate, more than 200 cultural institutions across the city were planning a yearlong string of events, large and small. From historic walks through Queens and the Bronx, to special film screenings to a host of lectures and symposiums, the central theme is to remind New Yorkers, a species consumed by present and future, also to think about their past. 
 "You could walk out your door any day in New York during the coming year, and there is something about New York's history and heritage happening," said Marie Salerno, the president of New York City 100, the nonprofit group coordinating the different birthday events. The group's founding sponsor is The New York Times Company Foundation.
Ms. Salerno said that prospective events, which depend on the success of fund-raising effort, include a light show in each borough and two outdoor concerts. Among the scheduled events are historical exhibits, walking tours and discussions on topics like the City Charter.
Advocated a century ago by Manhattan's business class, the consolidation of the five boroughs was far from universally beloved when it occurred on New Year's Day, 1898. Overnight, it increased the city's population to 3.4 million people from 2 million, making New York the world's second-largest city then, behind London. But many residents in the other boroughs worried that their interests would bow to those of Manhattan.
The hotbed of resistance was Brooklyn, and even now, similar sentiments can be heard in a statement this week by the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden. "If the consolidation had not taken place," he wrote, "it seems clear that continued independence for Brooklyn, Long Island City or Queens and New York City would have fostered intense competition among the municipalities, resulting in dynamic economic growth and an even stronger metropolitan region than we have today."
But the historian Robert A. Caro contended that it was far too soon to forswear consolidation. He admitted that many outlying neighborhoods have suffered from centralized power, particularly places torn apart by immense city works projects like highways. But Mr. Caro, an advisory board member of New York City 100, said consolidation has allowed New York to become "a canvas" for a huge influx of immigration that has made the city what it is today.
"Because of the consolidation, they are all pouring into the same place, not five different places, not five different cities," said Mr. Caro, the author of "The Power Broker," a biography of Robert Moses.
When New York is many more centuries old, Mr. Caro said, "historians looking back on the history of New York will then see it would not have become as great as it became had it not been unified."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge's Ruling Could Allow Baby Bells to Expand
A Federal judge in Texas ruled yesterday that major sections of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 are unconstitutional, threatening the system created by Congress to deregulate the $200 billion telecommunications industry.
If the decision by Judge Joe Kendall of the United States District Court in Dallas is upheld, it could eliminate barriers that up until now have prevented regional Bell telephone companies from offering long-distance service. Page A1. 

Moderate Slowdown Seen
The index of leading economic indicators recorded a second consecutive rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in November even as a majority of its components fell, the Conference Board said. In another report, the Chicago Purchasing Management Association said its manufacturing index, a national bellwether, slipped to 58.1 from 59.5 in November. The two reports were consistent with predictions of a moderate slowdown. D2.
 
Gene-Based Cancer Test Approved
The Food and Drug Administration approved the first gene-based test for predicting whether a cancer will return. The test, made by Oncor Inc., looks at how many copies of a particular gene a patient has and uses that information to say whether breast cancer is likely to recur. A10.
 
Bonds End 1997 on High Note
Bond prices rallied on the last day of the year, strengthening prices and leaving yields on the widely followed 30-year Treasury issue near the lowest level in more than four years. The long bond's yield fell to 5.92 percent, down from 5.97 percent Tuesday and substantially lower than its 6.64 percent yield at the end of 1996. D14.
 
Dollar in Year-End Rally
The dollar gained in light currency trading from purchases by traders who expect further dollar gains as Japan and other Asian countries struggle to revive their economies. The dollar settled at 1.7987 marks, up from 1.7894 marks on Tuesday and up 16.7 percent for the year, and at 130.42 yen, up from 130.13 yen and up 13 percent for the year. D11.
 
Coffee and Silver Prices Fall
Coffee futures prices fell on signs that roasters are amply supplied, while silver prices tumbled in thin trading. D11.
 
Airlines Begin New Screening
Airlines nationwide will begin using a computerized screening process today to determine which passengers should have their baggage checked for explosives and whether the passengers who are singled out actually boarded a plane with the bags. The new system has been criticized on the grounds that it will lead to discrimination against members of some religious or ethnic groups. A13.
 
Indonesian Credit Rating Cut
Indonesia's foreign-currency debt rating was cut to junk bond status by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, reflecting the nation's deteriorating financial condition. D4.
 
Nationsbank Plans Florida Job Cuts
Nationsbank says its expects to eliminate more than 6,000 jobs in Florida as it takes over Barnett Banks Inc. Many of the cuts, about 19 percent of the banks' combined work forces, will come through attrition. D4.
 
Quaker Oats in Radioactive Accord
More than 100 former Massachusetts students who ate radioactive oatmeal as unwitting participants in an experiment in the 1940's and 50's will share a $1.85 million settlement from Quaker Oats and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. A19.
 
Markets Closed
All financial markets in the United States are closed today for New Year's Day. Most markets overseas are also closed. Tomorrow, the Treasury market and other United States markets will hold shortened sessions, but the stock market will have regular trading hours.

HEADLINE: And for Giuliani's Second Act . . .

 BODY:
I always pass on good advice," Oscar Wilde wrote a century ago in "An Ideal Husband." "It is the only thing to do with it. It is never any use to oneself."
With that in mind, we pass along to Rudolph W. Giuliani this counsel as he begins his second term as Mayor of New York. Sure, it's a lot to ask, but then again, he has four years to do it. We presume. 

Floyd H. Flake, minister of Allen African Methodist Episcopalian Church in Queens.
New York, like most other urban centers in the United States, approaches the next millennium with a list of critical needs that must be addressed -- crime, poverty, social decay, race relations, poor education and economic stagnation.
New solutions, however, must not follow the pattern of the last 30 years, where government support was the primary vehicle for change. The future will depend largely on job creation in inner-city neighborhoods. The inner city must be transformed into a stable community providing opportunities to those coming off of welfare. There must also be major investments in all forms of education, whether public, private or parochial, to assure that there is a competent work force for the future.

Stefanie Syman, co-founder of the on-line magazine Feed.
The Mayor should outlaw the phrase "Silicon Alley," however handy it may be to describe the sundry Web site developers and digital publishers based in New York City. The phrase implies that Manhattan's young industry could grow up to be just like Silicon Valley, land of chips and million-dollar stock options. But the name has given rise to expectations that contravene reality. Few, if any, of the New York companies have reached profitability in 18 months. None make silicon chips. By exacting penalties for use of the phrase, Mayor Giuliani might temper outsized hopes for this new industry. If he introduces a viable alternative, he may even receive a plaque somewhere on Broadway.

Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, husband-and-wife comedy team.
Thanks to Mayor Giuliani's personal dynamism, New York is once again visitor-friendly. The challenge now is to become neighborhood-friendly. New York could be the first city to create a program that celebrates neighborhood history. The city could sponsor events with historians and performers, who educate and entertain. That would allow us to cross into each other's backyards so we can better understand our different cultures.

Lisa Schiffren, former speechwriter for Vice President Dan Quayle.
Now that the Mayor has been safely re-elected, he should abolish rent regulation. There is no single policy change that would have as quick, long-lasting and positive an effect on the city's quality of life. Builders would build more housing; rents would come down; the grubbiness that characterizes great swaths of the Upper West Side would be polished away; tax-paying families would be less financially stretched if they didn't have to subsidize those who can't afford to live here. Doing this would also correct the unfortunate impression that he values political muscle too highly, and political principle too little.

Charles B. Rangel, Democratic member of Congress.
The Mayor should try to be a nicer person. New Yorkers really want to be fond of the Mayor, and he has to give them an opportunity to do that.

Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission.
Because history says New York's economy is likely to contract sometime during the next four years, I hope the Giuliani administration prudently invests any budget surplus generated by the past year's economic growth. And because great cities need free and open political systems, I hope the Mayor forsakes his efforts to silence civic organizations that sometimes criticize his policies.

George Stephanopoulos, former senior adviser to President Clinton and visiting professor at Columbia.
The headline "Studies Show That New York Has Greatest Income Gap" should be taped to Mayor Giuliani's desk. His mission statement for the next term? Make New York a middle-class city again. Recent studies show that in New York State, the top 20 percent earned nearly 20 times more than the bottom 20 percent -- a wider disparity than anywhere else in the country.
Global trade, the decline of manufacturing and new technology all play a part in New York's dilemma. The Mayor can't single-handedly stop these trends, but he can prevent further reductions in low-income assistance programs, insist on strong job training and placement for welfare recipients, and put more resources into the public schools.
Even more important is the Mayor's broader opportunity. He should lead a national campaign to reverse the income gap in the United States. As a Republican who has made New York a safer place for the middle class to live, he can now focus on making all American cities places where the middle class can make a living.

Alanna Heiss, director, P.S. 1, Contemporary Art Center, Queens.
 The firm beat of Rudy's inner heart
 supports new outerborough art.
 Our hope for 1998?
 His heartbeat does not syncopate.

William J. Bratton, former Police Commissioner.
The New York City turnaround does not have to be temporary. What Mayor Giuliani has learned is that for 30 years, we may have had it all wrong. Crime and disorder are not necessarily the result of social deterioration; rather, they were among the principal causes of the city's decline.
Mr. Giuliani has the historic opportunity to prove once and for all that this most diverse and complex of American cities can effectively address crime, drugs, education and racial tension. Continued optimistic political leadership and community policing can make the dramatic changes of the 90's a reality in the next century.

Hugh Fink, a comedian and writer for "Saturday Night Live."
Mayor Giuliani claims credit for improving the quality of life. The quality of life on the Upper West Side, however, is rapidly deteriorating -- not because of crime or noise, but because of something more terrifying: the increasing number of babies in strollers. I can't even buy a Cohiba Siglo at the local cigar bar without being harassed by them. The Chinese Government's one-baby-per-household policy should be applied to all couples residing near Columbus Avenue. Or at least the Mayor should provide a baby path, to be shared with Rollerbladers.
Also, the Mayor should continue with his apparent push to make sure there is at least one Banana Republic on every street corner. I will certainly rest easier knowing that at any given moment I'm within walking distance of a ribbed V-neck sweater. Unless, of course, I get mowed down by a baby stroller first.
 
Lyn Pentecost, executive director of the Lower East Side Girls Club.
The day before Thanksgiving, a 15-year-old girl was pushed/fell/ jumped from the roof of the housing project across the street from my office because a crack deal went bad/she owed someone money/she was depressed about her life. No one knew the exact details.
Just another senseless tragedy on Avenue D. This one hit particularly close to home because the dead girl was the cousin of two girls who attend my after-school program. These two, 10 and 12 years old, are so bright, so eager, so ready to embrace life. Yet statistics -- school test scores, teen-age pregnancy rates, drug use, family violence -- tell me they are at risk. And the time to intervene is now, before they stick their toes into the turbulent waters of adolescence.
To the Mayor and every other adult in New York City who wonders why so many teen-agers are so destructive to themselves and others -- particularly when we have so many programs for teen-agers -- I can only say: too little, too late. Safely navigating adolescence is a learned skill. Every New Yorker should take time to help a pre-adolescent find his or her path.
 
Ned Regan, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
Mayor Giuliani should take advantage of the first months of his new term, when citizens and civil servants are open to change, to focus his strong management skills on reforming inefficiencies in the city bureaucracy. Work rules and regulations, in place through collective bargaining or legislative acts, are seemingly impervious to frontal attacks. But they become vulnerable if the Mayor sits down with shop stewards and City Council members to decide which rules neither help workers nor improve the quality of life for the people of the city, and then works to eliminate them. American businesses have become the envy of the world as efficient producers of goods and services. Now it's the government's turn.

Donald Trump, real estate developer.
Fighting crime, educating our children, lowering taxes and helping to create a productive workplace are all elements that should be pursued by Mayor Giuliani. Keeping the Yankees, bringing back the Jets, working with the Mets on a new stadium in Queens and perhaps bringing the Olympics to New York are also worthy goals.

Mitchell L. Moss, director, Taub Urban Research Center at New York University.
New York City cannot afford to enter the 21st century with antiquated land use and economic development policies. Our zoning regulations separate work and housing, despite the fact that many individuals prefer to live and work in the same building. With self-employment and small businesses on the rise, flexible living arrangements will be as important as skyscrapers were in the early 20th century. Furthermore, now that New York is a safe city, we need to make it an affordable place to live as well. The Mayor should stimulate housing construction in lower Manhattan and on the waterfronts of Queens and Brooklyn so that the middle class doesn't move to the suburbs.

Geoffrey Canada, president of the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families.
With crime down, the stock market up and New York reclaiming its position as tourist capital of the world, New York City should rediscover its children. We could give three gifts: health care for the more than 300,000 children in the city without it, child care for all the families that need it, and a safe place for every child to be after school.

Marcella Ross, founder of the Romanian Information and Referral Center, in Queens.
As a Romanian New Yorker, I have worked with newly arrived immigrants from Romania and other East European countries for the past decade. Many of them are educated and have marketable skills and professions. However, because of language and cultural barriers, many have trouble gaining housing, education and employment. We need to do better in engaging new arrivals and helping them negotiate the system. This will give them the chance to become independent and self-sufficient.

Bella S. Abzug, former Democratic Congresswoman.
Mayor Giuliani should remember that bullying and belligerence do not equal leadership. You can't be a kinder, gentler or better Mayor -- much less help those left out of New York's economic boom -- without toning down the macho posturing. Cross-dressing isn't convincing enough. Besides, who wears full makeup and formal dress without a hat?

Gabe Abelson, head monologue writer, "Late Show With David Letterman."
If you decide to run for President, Mr. Mayor, just remember: It's not easy to run in heels.

HEADLINE: Sandra W. Meyer Dies at 60; Pioneer Marketing Executive

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY

 BODY:
Sandra W. Meyer, a pioneering marketing executive who was part of the inspiration for the long-running Broadway drama "The Sisters Rosensweig," died on Tuesday at New York University Hospital. She was 60 and the cause of death was breast cancer, her family said.
Mrs. Meyer held senior-level executive positions at some of the nation's largest and best-known companies at a time when women worked mainly in the administrative ranks. 
 She became the first woman product-group manager at the General Foods Corporation, in 1969; the first woman president of a division of the American Express Company, in 1980, and the first woman senior officer to run corporate affairs at Citicorp, in 1989.
Mrs. Meyer, who lived in New York, was known as a brilliant marketer and strategic thinker. At General Foods, which merged with Kraft Foods in 1995, she ran marketing campaigns for some of the biggest brands, including Maxwell House coffee. She joined American Express in 1976 as head of worldwide marketing for the credit card and was later promoted to president of the communications division.
At Citicorp, as senior officer for corporate affairs and a member of the company's senior management team, Mrs. Meyer was widely credited with restoring the reputation of the banking company after it had gone through a financial crisis. In 1993, Mrs. Meyer left the position Citicorp created for her to become a senior partner at the Clark & Weinstock management consulting firm, a position she held until her death.
Mrs. Meyer had also been a managing director of Russell Reynolds Associates, a corporate search firm.
Her life and work were part of the inspiration for the Broadway play "The Sisters Rosensweig," which was written by her sister, Wendy Wasserstein.
The play revolves around Sara Rosensweig, a twice-divorced Jewish-American banker who is visited on her 54th birthday by her two sisters. The middle one, Gorgeous, the group leader of the Beth El Sisterhood of Newton, Mass., is ostensibly a happily married mother of four who is trying to start a career as a radio talk-show host. The youngest, Pheni, is an international travel writer who also struggles to write serious books and fights with the man she loves -- a bisexual theater director.
Mrs. Meyer served on several corporate boards, including Anchor Hocking and Horizons International Foods. She was managing director of the Metropolitan Opera Association and a member of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. She was also one of the founding members of the Committee of 200, a group of the most senior executive women in the country.
Mrs. Meyer graduated cum laude from Syracuse University with a bachelor's degree in history.
In addition to her sister, Wendy Wasserstein, of New York, Mrs. Meyer is survived by two daughters; Jenifer Schweitzer, of New York and Samantha Schweitzer, of San Francisco; another sister, Georgette Levis, of Manchester, Vt.; a brother, Bruce Wasserstein, of New York, and her parents, Lola and Morris Wasserstein, of New York.

HEADLINE: A Night the World Comes to the Crossroads of the World

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
Bill Grant had New Year's Eve choreographed to the smallest detail.
Eight months ago, he booked a room at the Hotel Edison for himself and his girlfriend, Mary Smith, for the New Year's holiday. It was to be her first trip to New York City. Yesterday afternoon, he escorted her to Central Park for a hansom carriage ride -- and a marriage proposal. And last night, he took her to Times Square -- to usher in 1998 with 500,000 screaming, happy strangers before the eyes of the world. 
 "It's been unbelievable," said the soon-to-be Mrs. Grant, who, like her fiance, is 24 and from Columbia, S.C. "I don't want this to stop. This is a suspension of reality."
Suspension, indeed. A collapsed building just a block away? Falling bricks on Madison Avenue? Pedestrian barriers on Fifth Avenue? Nordic temperatures and a wind chill factor of up to 15 degrees below zero? Bah!
For many people, only one thing mattered, said Darryl Terranova, who had just arrived from a suburb of Buffalo named Holland.
"It's New Year's Eve, and we've got to be in New York City," said Mr. Terranova, 22, who with his brother, Travis, and some other hometown friends was en route to the All-Star Cafe in Times Square for some pre-ball-dropping carousing. "The other 364 days, we're in Holland -- the town, not the country."
There were many people like the brothers Terranova, who descended on Times Square last night to bid adieu to 1997 and welcome 1998. But this year, perhaps more than in years past, many of the revelers were out-of-towners visiting New York for the first time, encouraged by a booming economy and a burnished image of the city -- and Times Square -- as a safer, cleaner, almost Disneyfied kind of place.
As in the last several years, security was tight, with Seventh Avenue and Broadway closed to traffic from 57th to 39th Streets. The New York City Police Department (the department would not say how many officers) appeared to be in full force to maintain order, and 4,600 barricades were in place. As in years past, those people who said they had theater tickets or dinner reservations had to prove it to police officers.
At one point, revelers mingling at the intersection of Ninth Avenue and 42d Street blocked four of five lanes of traffic, prompting a cacophony of car honks and kazoos. But the police soon imposed order, and some visitors appreciated the effort.
"Everyone back home said we'd be mugged and robbed, but people have been friendly so far," said Emily Shipe, 18, who arrived yesterday morning from Industry, Pa.
It was Ms. Shipe's first trip to New York, and she and three friends from Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, freshmen all, had staked out a spot near 44th Street -- at 1 P.M. "We want to get on TV," she said. "We want to be on Dick Clark."
"It's an awesome experience," said Dimitri Vladimirov, who was taking in the scene at Times Square with three friends from the University of California at Davis. "You've got to do this at least once in your life."
At least once in your life: The Dobbs family of Bethpage, Tenn., repeated that phrase as they waited patiently behind a police barricade on Seventh Avenue. It was, Debbie Dobbs said, the first time that any of her party of six had come to New York. In previous years, they had been scared off by the city's reputation; this year, she said: "We just took a chance and said, 'Why not? We have to do it once.' "
Mrs. Dobbs said her family was having a wonderful time. But it was chillier than they had expected, so two of her sons, Cory, 21, and Brian, who will be 25 tomorrow, scurried to buy some long johns. Temperatures dipped to 16 degrees by midnight, with the wind-chill factor in the concrete canyons of Times Square making it feel like 15 degrees below zero.
"I've got one word for you," said Lauren Olicker, 20, of Wilmington, Del., who -- surprise, surprise -- was also making her maiden trip to New York. "Layers."
Ms. Olicker arrived in the city shortly after noon yesterday, having taken the train with her friend Wayne Matthews. Everyone on the train, she said, was in a celebratory mood. But one person did not make it to Times Square: he had already started his own private drinking party and was so drunk that the conductor forced him to get off at Trenton.
It was a message that the police hoped would not be lost on the revelers who did make it to Times Square. They reiterated their policy that anyone caught drinking in public would have their drink confiscated and be issued a summons.
Early this morning, the police said they had not finished tallying the number of arrests or incidents. But police officers in Times Square said there were several arrests, and eyewitnesses reported seeing at least two people removed from the scene in ambulances.
For some New Yorkers, Times Square was a place to avoid. Frank Scutaro, a marketing manager at a pharmaceutical company who lives on the Upper East Side, said he would be spending the evening with perhaps a dozen friends in Chelsea.
"This year, a lot of people had a good and busy year," he said. "There was a lot of energy, and business has been great. Maybe people are like, 'I can get the crowds anytime I want and I should take a day off to veg out and just relax.' "
Indeed, for some, the New Year's Eve celebrations were just the finale of a good year. Louise Hardy and Vincent Derrick of Holcombe, England, had originally planned to visit New York -- first-timers, too -- to celebrate Christmas. But then they decided to get married, and invited their friends Phil and Rebecca Southern to witness the ceremony.
So yesterday afternoon, they were married in their suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and planned to attend the hotel's Grand Ballroom Gala to dance to the songs of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons.

HEADLINE: Judiciary Report: Congress Is Prodded

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the 1997 Year-end Report on the Federal Judiciary by William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice of the United States: 
 As I review the state of the judiciary this year and compare it with the 11 previous years I have served as Chief Justice, I am impressed by the degree to which our relations with Congress have dominated 1997. Congressional responses and initiatives on judicial issues ranging from funding to salaries, and from Federal jurisdiction to judicial vacancies, all have had a significant influence on the judiciary over the past year.
The results have been mixed, which is scarcely surprising, and therefore we will face some of the same challenges in 1998 that confronted us in 1997. Despite the work that remains to be done, I am encouraged by the judiciary's ability to perform its essential role in our constitutional structure of Government. . . .
I first would like to express my gratitude to Congress for its financial support of the judiciary. In a time of scarce resources, Congress responded favorably to the careful financial plan adopted by the executive committee of the Judicial Conference of the United States. These moneys will be used wisely and economically. The judiciary supports fully the national goal of eliminating the budget deficit and has instituted a formal process to identify and implement initiatives to reduce or avoid costs. . . .
In general, Congress has declined to eliminate the disparity between resources and workload in the Federal judiciary by an expansion of the number of judges. There have been instances, however, in which Congress wisely has acted to reduce this disparity by enacting laws that in effect decrease the number of potential filings in Federal court. In 1996, Congress enacted the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act, which streamlined habeas corpus procedures for both state and Federal prisoners, and the Prison Litigation Reform Act (P.L.R.A.), which did the same for prisoners' civil rights actions. . . .
With limited degree of hindsight available to us -- and keeping in mind that there are many variables that could affect the future rate of prisoner filings in Federal court -- the Effective Death Penalty Act and P.L.R.A. appear to be promising examples of how Congress can reduce the disparity between resources and workload in the Federal judiciary without endangering its distinctive character.
Unfortunately, Congress's effort to enact legislation of this type have been sporadic and inconsistent. I therefore call on Congress to consider legislative proposals that would reduce the jurisdiction of Federal courts. For many years, diversity of citizenship cases have been identified as one such area in which Congress could enact some very useful reforms.
Should Congress, conversely, consider expanding the jurisdiction of the Federal judiciary, it should do so cautiously and only after it has considered all the alternatives and the incremental impact the increase will have on both the need for additional judicial resources and the traditional role of the Federal judiciary.
If Federal jurisdiction remains at its current level -- or, worse, increases -- judicial vacancies will aggravate the problem of too few judges and too much work. Currently, 82 of the 846 Article III judicial offices in the Federal judiciary -- almost 1 out of every 10 -- are vacant. Twenty-six of the vacancies have been in existence for 18 months or longer and on that basis constitute what are called 'judicial emergencies.' In the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, the percentage of vacancies is particularly troubling, with over one-third of its seats empty.
Judicial vacancies can contribute to a backlog of cases, undue delays in civil cases, and stopgap measures to shift judicial personnel where they are most needed. Vacancies cannot remain at such high levels indefinitely without eroding the quality of justice that traditionally has been associated with the Federal judiciary. Fortunately for the judiciary, a dependable corps of senior judges has contributed significantly to easing the impact of unfilled judgeships.
The institutions that have the constitutionally assigned powers of nominating and confirming judicial nominees bear some of the responsibility for the current situation, but structural aspects of the appointment process also contribute to the existing high level of vacancies. For example, a larger judiciary increases the average number of retirements per year and the corresponding number of nominees. The additional burdens placed on the appointment process by such an increase may slow it down.
An appointment process that might work well to fill the vacancies of the 700-member judiciary might struggle with a judiciary of 800 or 850 members. Accordingly, increasing the size of the Federal judiciary so that it can handle expanded workloads might have the unintended effect of increasing the vacancy rate, perhaps leaving unaffected the gap between resources and workload that motivated the initial increase in the number of judges. This ironic result strongly supports the common-sense conclusion that, in this country, a bigger Federal judiciary is not necessarily a part of a solution for every public-policy question.
Whatever the size of the Federal judiciary, the President should nominate candidates with reasonable promptness, and the Senate should act within a reasonable time to confirm or reject them. Some current nominees have been waiting a considerable time for a Senate Judiciary Committee vote or a final floor vote. The Senate confirmed only 17 judges in 1996 and 36 in 1997, well under the 101 judges it confirmed during 1994.
The Senate is, of course, very much a part of the appointment process for any Article III judge. One nominated by the President is not "appointed" until confirmed by the Senate. The Senate is surely under no obligation to confirm any particular nominee, but after the necessary time for inquiry it should vote for him up or vote him down. In the latter case, the President can then send up another nominee.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: The Year of Living Smugly

 BODY:
Perhaps the most striking thing about 1997 was its power to divert. The robust economy, the continued decline in crime and the blessed respite from terrorist violence on home soil gave the nation an opportunity to focus on intensely personal news events with little overarching import -- the death of Princess Diana, the "nanny" trial and the birth of American septuplets.
It seemed, in many senses, the best of times -- even the prosperous, placid 1950's had been overshadowed by the cold war. Now, the United States is the planet's only remaining superpower. Its most ambitious hopes for furthering Middle Eastern peace or smoothing China's emergence as an economic and political power may not have been realized, but 1997 was still a year marked by uneasy peace in places where the mere absence of armed conflict must be counted as achievement. At home, the stock market rose more than 20 percent for the third straight year, and it was no surprise that Wall Street traders ended 1997 by releasing balloons in honor of the new horde of millionaires the market had created. 
 But balloons eventually pop, and the very fact that the news seemed so relentlessly positive was a bit unnerving. If the economy in 1997 was as good as it gets, did that mean that 1998 was bound to be worse? The end-of-the-year financial chaos in Asia, still threatening the world's 11th-largest economy in South Korea, seemed to some an unsettling omen of grimmer times to come.
Every glowing statistic had a second, sobering face. Crime was down, but more police officers were dying in the line of duty -- 156 in 1997, compared with 116 the year before -- and experts said one of the reasons was more powerful weaponry on the streets. In New York City, the epicenter of the war on crime, spectacular new brutality cases put a pall over all the Police Department's genuine accomplishments. The economic boom produced little benefit for the poor. Welfare rolls plummeted, but thousands of disabled children lost their Federal benefits, and many hard-working legal immigrants were forced into the soup lines after losing their food stamps. In Washington, Congress patted itself on the back for balancing the budget for the first time in 30 years, rigorously avoiding all the evidence that it was the surging economy rather than the lawmakers' self-discipline that did the trick. Congress's overall public image continued to be abysmal, largely because of its contemptuous disinterest in reforming the campaign finance system. The Justice Department's failure to act on strong evidence of illegality in the Clinton-Gore re-election campaign did nothing for public confidence either. But the controversy turned Vice President Al Gore's drive for the 2000 Presidential nomination from what looked like a sure thing to a question mark.
The President, for his part, could point to high popularity in the polls, but the substantive record was mixed. He reacted angrily to charges that he had become a caretaker chief executive, coasting toward retirement on a surging economy, the Dwight Eisenhower of the baby boomers. He could point to some real achievements, particularly in extending health coverage to more poor children. But his loss of the fast-track legislation -- postwar America's most serious renunciation of its historic trade leadership -- was a blow. Many of Mr. Clinton's friends predicted a rebound in 1998. Some speculated that he has simply been suffering from midlife golf obsession or, more likely, the funk that plagues many affectionate parents when their only child leaves the nest. While Mr. Clinton has over half his term to go, 1998 will be the year that determines whether he will be remembered for anything more positive than ending the welfare safety net.
Most Americans would be happy just to see the next 12 months bring more of the same. Our wish is more ambitious. May continued prosperity inspire the nation and its leaders with more generosity toward the people who have no reason to send up balloons in honor of their financial fortune. Americans face enormous challenges in improving opportunity for poor children, in protecting the least able from the full brunt of an unforgiving marketplace. Instead of being a waiting room for the new millennium, 1998 could launch a spectacular, compassionate finale for the epoch.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Announcing The Arrival Of the Airport

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IN the good old days, Newark Interna tional Airport was How to put it? -- "How about rinky-dink?" Amy Miller said. "That's what I used to say."
Ms. Miller, a psychology student at Rutgers, was feeling greatly nostalgic for those rinky-dink days as she waited for her boyfriend's arrival on a Continental Airlines flight from Jacksonville, Fla. She was slumped like a sack of laundry on a window ledge in Terminal C, braced against the New Year's Eve crowds. Travelers were slumped similarly all around her, overpacked and unfit to bear their loads. The lines at the Continental ticket counters were thick and messy, people were whining to beleaguered baggage handlers and two babies were screaming as if the world were coming to an end. 
 "I used to love this airport," said Ms. Miller, who lives in Westfield, N.J. That's a 20-minute drive that took twice as long with yesterday's traffic. "I remember when there were no lines," she said. "No waiting. Just in and out."
It wasn't so long ago. Newark used to be the sleeper airport, the one where you could get in, get out and take off without feeling as though reaching the plane was a trip in itself. A pre-ticketed traveler from, say, Hoboken, could leave the house an hour before the flight, get to the airport in a half hour, tops, and sashay to the gate for boarding with time left to buy a Snapple.
Then came the terrific economy, Continental's tremendous expansion and a wide-bodied monorail that makes going from Point A to Point B feel like a ride in the World's Fair. Now, Newark airport is no longer a local secret, the one thing New Jersey travelers could lord over New Yorkers. Now, the same traveler from Hoboken has to do what New Yorkers have had to do for years -- leave a couple of hours before the flight just in case there's traffic, which there usually is, and in time to secure the seat in case the airline overbooks the flight, which it often does.
"Newark is huge," Ms. Miller said. "Just say it's gotten too huge."
How huge is it? Port Authority officials project that the airport, the fastest-growing airport in the region, will set a record for its number of passengers in 1997, with 30.8 million. That's up from 29.1 million in 1996, 26.6 million in 1995. The day after Christmas, for the first time ever, all the airport's parking lots, from the hourly to the daily to the remote long-term lots that require a bus ride to the terminals, were full. That's over 15,000 parking spaces, all taken. The scurry for spaces backed up traffic around the airport for hours.
"We attribute that, at least in part, to the coinciding of Christmas and Hanukkah," said Bill Cahill, an authority spokesman.
Port Authority officials, perhaps anxious to appease Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who has complained that the agency has favored Newark over New York, took pains to point out that Newark's growth has not come at the expense of Kennedy and La Guardia airports.
ALL three airports are experiencing a healthy growth," said Robert Kelly, the Port Authority's director of aviation. He said Kennedy International Airport was also expected to set a record for passengers in 1997, with 31.3 million, making Kennedy and Newark about neck and neck. "We've got a great economy and it's making it great for air travel," he said.
The Port Authority, he added, is hoping that the Federal Aviation Administration will announce its approval in the next few weeks for an elaborate plan to ease congestion at Kennedy airport that should prove as attractive as the monorail at Newark (which is also being expanded).
Mr. Kelly said that Newark's passengers come from New Jersey while New Yorkers still go to Kennedy and La Guardia. But anecdotal evidence suggests otherwise.
Scores of yellow cabs with New York plates drop off passengers at Newark airport every day. There were dozens of the cabs at Terminal C alone yesterday, suggesting that at least some of the New Yorkers who have been complaining about all the tourists in Times Square are making their late holiday escape over the Hudson.
Sandrine Betances and Kevin Mitchell, plopping out of a yellow cab with two carry-on bags for a New Year's Eve trip to Boston, were two of them. Yes, they said, they had abandoned Kennedy about a year ago.
"We live on the Upper West Side, so it's actually faster to take a cab across the bridge than it is to take it across town to go to Kennedy," Ms. Betances said.
"Jerseyites probably don't want New Yorkers coming here, right?" Mr. Mitchell said. "Well, turnabout's fair play."

HEADLINE: Cable Giants Aren't to Blame for Rising Prices

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Behind Your Soaring Cable Rates" (editorial, Dec. 29) is flawed. Congress has forced cable operators to raise their rates through the "must carry" law. That law, which you supported (editorial, April 2), requires cable to surrender channels to local broadcasters. Thus pre-empted from competing for further advertising revenue, cable raises its rates. 
 In lamenting the dearth of satellite broadcasters, "wireless" cable operators and telephone companies, you ignore fundamental economics. Satellites will never reach anyone who has no south/southwest "look angle," as in most multiple-unit dwellings. Wireless has little channel capacity, and telephone companies prefer to expand into local or long distance rather than invest heavily in cable replanting.
As for your suggestion that the Federal Communications Commission force cable to bundle sports channels separately, what would you say if the Government required your sports section to be sold separately, to let nonsports fans get your paper more cheaply?
 
JAMES B. FRANCIS
Washington, Dec. 29, 1997

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise At Year's End; '98 Promising

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The bond market ended 1997 on a high note yesterday, strengthening prices and leaving the yield on the most widely followed United States Goverment security near the lowest level in more than four years.
Traders said the outlook for further bond market gains in 1998 remained favorable. 
 The 30-year benchmark Treasury bond increased 19/32 to a price of 102 21/32 in an abbreviated New Year's Eve session. . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction to price and is a barometer of interest rate trends, fell to 5.92 percent from 5.97 percent on Tuesday.
Yesterday's yield was near the 5.87 percent low for the year reached Dec. 23, which was the lowest since October 1993. It was also sharply below the 6.64 percent at the end of 1996. The high yield this year for the 30-year bond was 7.17 percent, reached April 14.
Traders were emboldened to buy bonds yesterday partly because of economic data that continued to suggest that economic growth is slowing and inflation remains benign. The December Chicago Purchasing Managers Index, a bellwether of a nationwide report on domestic manufacturing to be released Friday, fell to 58.1 compared with 60.5 in November. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators for November showed a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent, the same rate of gain as in October.
Dave Shabelman, a market analyst at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said the Chicago purchasing index for the entire fourth quarter was well below third-quarter readings and "modestly below average readings for the year."
Mr. Shabelman said the broader index from the National Association of Purchasing Management is expected to drop as well and "fall in line with this healthy, but moderating trend."
David A. Levy, director of forecasting for the Jerome Levy Economics Institute in Mount Kisco, N.Y., said that despite the ample evidence of economic strength going into the new year, he foresees a slowdown and lower inflation in 1998.
"Businesses, households and government are approaching 1998 almost bursting with confidence," Mr. Levy said. "However, it is not wise to admire the future through a rear-view mirror. The economy does carry impressive momentum into 1998, but it will encounter several hindrances and perhaps financial landmines."
He said the dollar's strength, as well as weakened overseas demand, could depress American corporate earnings.
In other bond market news, the Treasury announced that it planned to auction $8 billion of 10-year inflation-indexed notes on Jan. 8.

HEADLINE: $319.5 Billion in Securities Offerings Sets a Record

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL

 BODY:
Wall Street completed a record year for underwriting financial securities with a turbulent but robust fourth quarter. The securities industry raised $319.5 billion in American stock and bond offerings despite the qualms caused by the spreading financial crisis in Asia.
The volume of securities issued in American financial markets during the three months ended yesterday represents a 22 percent increase from the $261.7 billion raised through stock and bond offerings in the final three months of 1996. But it was a decline of 14 percent from the levels for the three months ended Sept. 30, when underwritings raised $371.8 billion before significant credit problems in Thailand, Malaysia and South Korea emerged. 
 During the last three months, Merrill Lynch & Company retained its position as the leading manager of new United States securities issues with a 16.7 percent market share, followed by Salomon Smith Barney Inc., a unit of Travelers Group Inc.; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Lehman Brothers.
The record amount of company mergers in the quarter, which were concentrated in the telecommunications, banking and investment industries, helped buoy the market for securities offerings. During the three months ended yesterday, there were $336.9 billion of mergers and acquisitions, according to the Securities Data Company of Newark, up sharply from $162 billion in the period a year earlier. During the year, mergers totaling $919 billion were announced in the United States, an increase of almost 50 percent from 1996, when mergers totaling $626 billion were announced.
"It was a very robust quarter even with the onslaught of the Asian flu," said James Birle, a managing director in equity capital markets at Merrill Lynch.
The challenge of the Asian crisis may even have helped the biggest firms, Mr. Birle said. "After Oct. 27, the ability to distribute securities really mattered," he said, adding that firms like his, which have the ability to distribute securities to both individual and corporate customers worldwide, were able to "really differentiate themselves," from their domestic competitors because of their broader reach.
But firms without big global businesses also pronounced themselves pleased with business in the last three months. "It was a good quarter for us," said Daniel J. Schaub, senior vice president and director of corporate finance at A. G. Edwards & Company in St. Louis, but he added that business had slowed down earlier than usual. "It appeared institutions locked their profits in early," and took off for a slightly longer vacation than usual, he said.
The healthy market for stock and bond offerings, Mr. Schaub said, continued to be driven by "a lot of consolidation in industries," by low interest rates and by the buoyant equity markets. "We have had an economy that has been very robust," he said, "and it has been very pleasant to people. Consumer confidence is at record levels, people feel good about the economy."
Those with the most international business seemed to see more of the volatility. "It's been an incredibly volatile quarter," said John Massad, the head of debt syndication at J. P. Morgan & Company. "There was a strong market tone going into the quarter, then we had the trigger from Asia, and almost a complete reversal of the market's tone. Investors almost stepped away from the market completely."
Jeffrey Chandler, managing director and head of Merrill Lynch's global debt business, said, "It turned from a seller's market in credit markets to a buyer's market after the Asian meltdown." The Asian crisis, he added, had increased interest margins for debt issues and had also led to a greater spread between the rates paid by high-quality borrowers and others. "The Asian crisis also caused the postponement of quite a number of deals," he said. "That delayed volume will re-emerge."
The Asian crisis certainly cooled the market for issues from emerging economies.
"We saw the bond we issued in September for the Korean Development Bank, a four-year issue that was issued at 99.7, trade as low as the low 60's in mid-December," said Mr. Massad at J. P. Morgan, "but since then it has recovered today to roughly 80 percent in terms of dollar price. That's a measure of the volatility we have had."
The year as a whole though set a record. "It is a year when corporations, like consumers, were taking advantage of low interest rates to refinance debt and to issue equity securities," said Richard J. Peterson, a spokesman for Securities Data. Companies issued about 47 percent more debt in 1997 than they did in 1996, he added.
"One thing that helped make it a record year," Mr. Birle said, "was the number of billion-dollar-plus transactions," including several enormous privatizations, like that of France Telecom, and big capital raisings for companies like Fleet Financial, Household International, Teleport Communications and Hewlett-Packard.
What kept the markets so robust, Mr. Birle said, was "the continued flow of funds into the equity markets from mutual funds, asset-allocation adjustments, the continued cross-border flows of capital" and "the vast number of privatizations."
The securities' industry's disclosed fees for underwritings, however, declined slightly despite the record volume. The industry's disclosed fees totaled $8.4 billion for 1997 compared with $9.3 billion in 1996, according to Securities Data. That was partly because of a decline in the volume of initial public offerings, which are among the most profitable offerings for Wall Street firms. Such offerings totaled $42.6 billion in 1997 compared with $48.99 billion in 1996.
As for the future, Wall Street is betting that securities markets will continue to become more international and that the skills honed in the American securities industry will become more valuable in foreign markets as overseas nations deregulate their securities industries.
"The Wall Street mantra has been global for a while, but this year it truly was global," Mr. Chandler of Merrill Lynch said, "with European Monetary Union coming, and Japan's big bang, we expect that trend to continue. The deregulation of global markets should allow a lot more cross-border financings."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Yen and Mark, Capping Strong '97 Showing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar jumped to a three-and-a-half-month high against the German mark and rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, capping a year in which the dollar thrived on the strength of America's economy.
The dollar gained in light trading from last-minute purchases by traders who expect further dollar gains as Japan and other Asian countries struggle to revive their economies. 
 Traders normally try to diversify their holdings to start a new year, but the dollar has too much momentum going into 1998, said Sean Bovenizer, head of foreign exchange at Norddeutsche Landesbank.
"We'll push onwards in the first hours and maybe first days of trading in the new year," Mr. Bovenizer said.
The mark suffered as traders continued a selloff to rid themselves of holdings that built up in a flight from Asian currencies in the autumn.
European currencies traditionally do well at year-end, Mr. Bovenizer said, "and we haven't seen that trend at all in the last week."
The dollar was quoted in late New York trading at 1.7987 marks, up from 1.7894 late Tuesday, rising to its highest level since reaching 1.7990 on Sept. 10. The dollar settled at 130.42 yen, up from 130.13.
The dollar finished at a two-and-a-half-month high of 1.4625 Swiss francs, up from 1.4543. It rose to more than a three-month high of 6.0230 French francs from 5.9865 and reached a two-week high against the British pound, which settled at $1.6517, down from $1.6552. Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, suggested that British economic growth would slow in 1998.
For the year, the dollar finished 16.7 percent higher against the mark after scaling back from an eight-and-a-half-year high of 1.8815 on Aug. 6. Traders preferred America's stronger economic growth in 1997 and worried about the stability of Europe's planned common currency, which is scheduled to appear in 1999 and would supplant the mark as Europe's dominant currency.
Against the yen, the dollar ended the year 12.5 percent higher, though slightly below a five-and-a-half-year high of 130.78 on Dec. 16, as dealers fled from Japan's shaky financial markets and low interest rates. Against the pound, the dollar ended the year 2.7 percent higher.

HEADLINE: Data Suggest Another Year Of Expansion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The uninterrupted economic expansion that began with the end of the Persian Gulf war -- already the second-longest in peacetime this century -- is almost certain to reach its seventh anniversary in early spring, analysts said today in assessing the final batch of statistics published in 1997.
"The economy will grow at a good pace, but slower," said Paul W. Boltz, chief economist at T. Rowe Price, a leading mutual fund management company in Baltimore. He predicted total output would climb 2.9 percent in 1998, substantially slower than the estimated 3.8 percent for the year just completed. 
 Many analysts had called the 1997 rate unsustainably robust. They said the two reports released today were more consistent with predictions of a moderate slowdown.
The Conference Board's leading index, intended to foretell turning points in the economy, posted a second consecutive rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in November even as a majority of its components fell.
Chicago-area purchasing managers -- corporate officials who buy everything from fax paper to heavy machinery -- reported a modest slowing of a regional manufacturing index for December, to a still-strong 58.1 from November's 59.5. The Chicago purchasing index is widely viewed as a bellwether of a broader index to be released Friday by the National Association of Purchasing Management.
"The economic fundamentals such as subdued inflation, low long-term interest rates, strong job growth and solid income gains will allow the economy to continue growing next year, albeit at a less spectacular pace," Robert Barr, deputy chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in a year-end statement.
The chamber's poll projected that the Mountain states would post the fastest growth, at 3.8 percent,
Although their estimates vary, economists agree that Asian currency and economic problems constitute the chief unknown in the 1998 outlook. They contend that exports will fall, cheaper imports will repress inflation and there will be big losers and big winners among American companies. The magnitudes, however, are mainly guesswork.
"The big question mark for 1998 is the possible impact of the shocks abroad on domestic business and consumer behavior," said John Youngdahl, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. But he pointed to an economy now operating at a high level with what he called "a lot of financial underpinning" for continued solid expansion.
About two-thirds of the rise in the Leading Index over the last three months was accounted for by a jump in the M-2 money supply, which includes money market funds and short-term deposits as well as currency and checking accounts.
For December, the biggest positive factor was a surge in new orders to factories for nonmilitary capital goods. Money supply growth was second, followed by an expansion of the average work week and slower deliveries by industrial suppliers.
The most significant of the negative forces was a rise for the month in first-time claims for unemployment insurance. The others were fewer building permits, lower factory orders for consumer goods, a decline in stock prices, a further narrowing of the difference between short-term and 10-year interest rates and a slight decline in still-high consumer expectations.
The expectations component comes from the University of Michigan's survey for November, not the Conference Board's survey that on Tuesday showed a very sharp increase for December.
"The leading indicators point to a continuation of the expansion through at least the early part of 1998," the Conference Board said of its report today.
Companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators each climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in November. The coincident index is composed of indicators that usually move at the same time as the economy at large. The lagging index, which includes the prime rate and the cost of consumer services, moves after a delay.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Helping Hand Replaces Hands-Off Role in Asia

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Financial crises that threaten to melt down countries by the fistful are becoming a standard feature of the global economy. And as they occur, the governments of the big industrial countries find themselves dragged into the role of rescuing a market system that in theory at least is supposed to cure itself.
What the international response to the Asian crisis makes clear is how far governments have moved away from the dominant view of the Reagan and Thatcher years: that intervention hinders rather than helps in the marketplace. 
 "The idea that governments can just stand aside does not work; the costs are too great," said Barry Bosworth, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a research group. "The new view is that you cannot tell private parties you won't bail them out and they have to suffer the consequences of the marketplace."
That approach is evident in Asia. The acute debt-repayment problems of Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and others emerged barely six months ago, and already the United States and other big nations have committed more than $100 billion to bail them out, mainly through the International Monetary Fund.
Compare that with Latin America in 1981, when Mexico defaulted on tens of billions of dollars in debt, and Brazil, Argentina and other countries followed suit. In that troubled period, it took eight years before the United States Government intervened directly. The circumstances were different, of course, but out of that Latin American crisis a new role for governments in international financial crises began to evolve, shaped along the way by the savings and loan debacle in the United States in the late 1980's and the Mexican peso devaluation and debt crisis of 1994 and 1995.
A key tenet of the new approach is quick response -- offering bailout money almost immediately, usually in the form of loans channeled through the I.M.F. "We did that in Mexico in 1995," said Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s deputy managing director, "and within two years that money was repaid and Mexico was on the move again."
The international environment was radically different in the Latin America of 1981. Syndicates of American banks were the big lenders. The borrowers were Latin American governments, not the private sector. And Walter Wriston's view of the world held sway. Sovereign governments do not default, Mr. Wriston said flatly, and he was chairman of Citicorp, the biggest lender. The loans flowed out without great regard for the high cost of repayment.
American banks often made new loans to finance repayment of the old ones or at least the substantial interest due on those loans. And when the defaults unexpectedly came, the banks agreed to new loans to get the Latin American governments to agree to new repayment schedules.
Writing off a substantial portion of the more than $200 billion in Latin American debt was viewed, at first, as unthinkable, a disaster for the banks. But over the years, the banks gradually did just that. When they finally acknowledged that the Latin American debt was uncollectible in its entirety, the Bush Administration stepped in -- the first government intervention in the unfolding drama.
"The initial reaction was that the only way to contain the Latin debt crisis was to deny that it existed," said Anna Schwartz, an economist at the National Bureau for Economic Research. "Just loan more money to maintain the fiction that these were performing loans. And this went on until 1987, when Citibank took the lead in facing the truth."
Mr. Bush's Treasury Secretary, Nicholas Brady, then offered what came to be known as Brady bonds. If the banks and the Latin American governments would agree to payments of, say, 50 cents of each dollar still owed, then the Bush Administration would guarantee such settlements by selling Treasury securities to the debtors equal to the discounted amounts the debtor countries had agreed to pay. The securities guaranteed repayment over a period of years, and so far the arrangement has worked.
But until the Brady solution, lending for new projects to many Latin American countries dried up and economic growth slowed, hurting American exports to the region.
The quick-response tactic so evident in the Asian crisis reflects a desire to keep those economies humming, which strengthens that of the United States, too. But even before Asia, two other debt crises, one domestic and one international, drew the American Government into an interventionist role, using public money to bail out investors.
The first, in the late 1980's, was purely domestic, the failure of hundreds of savings and loan associations that had lent huge sums heedlessly, mainly for real estate projects that failed to generate enough income to repay the loans. The Government, using Federal deposit insurance and additional taxpayer money, reimbursed all the depositors, closed the most damaged institutions and seized hundreds of billions in property that had been put up as collateral for the bad loans. Over the years, the Government sold the property to reimburse itself, and in the end, the net loss came to about $150 billion in taxpayer dollars, a huge sum but a relatively small proportion of an $8 trillion economy.
"The trick in all this is to stabilize the situation quickly," said Robert Glauber, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard who played a big role in the savings and loan bailout as an official in the Bush Administration.
The Mexican crisis two years ago gave the Clinton Administration similar confidence in quick government action. A sudden and big peso devaluation scared off American lenders who had bought Mexican notes and bonds that paid double-digit interest in the mistaken confidence that devaluation would not wipe out their earnings. Once the I.M.F. and the Administration put in place more than $43 billion in bailout loans, American lenders renewed their lending. Mexican workers paid a price in frozen wages and higher unemployment, but Mexico repaid the bailout money.
"Because what President Clinton did was right, we have avoided far greater difficulties," Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Treasury Secretary and an architect of the bailout, told Congress two years ago, justifying what was at the time an unusually aggressive intervention by the Government in a financial crisis. "The right lessons are being learned."
The Asian crisis, set off by similar devaluations, is different in several respects, particularly from the Latin American crisis. While that lending was mainly by American banks to governments, the Asian loans came more from Japanese and European banks, with American lenders in third place. And the loans were not to governments but to private borrowers like real estate speculators and manufacturers.
Most important, the Latin economies could not generate enough income in the 1980's to repay their debt. They had to negotiate debt reductions incorporated in the Brady bonds. But the more powerful Asian economies, particularly that of South Korea, are considered capable of generating enough income for full repayment as long as the debt is spread out so that $34 billion -- 22 percent of the total owed abroad -- does not have to be repaid by next December. The I.M.F.'s bailout is intended largely to assure repayment of these loans.
"Korea has made it very clear in the current negotiations with its lenders that it has no intention of not paying," Mr. Fischer of the I.M.F. said. "It wants to get the short-term loans lengthened. And once that happens, there is a very good chance of everything being worked out without any interruption in payment."
