HEADLINE: Holiday Sales Varying Less Among Regions

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
While the holiday shopping season usually means strong sales in one area of the country and terrible disappointments in others, this Christmas was oddly consistent from region to region, new figures show, reflecting in part a strong national economy.
For general merchandise retailers, sales at stores open at least one year -- known in the industry as same-store sales -- are not expected to rise sharply this year. Still, retailing experts say that areas of great strength and profound weakness were not nearly as evident this year as in seasons past, which economists say is unusual. 
"There hasn't been a year when regional differences have been so low since 1984," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, based in West Chester, Pa., which has kept holiday selling data since 1970.
Mr. Zandi said he expected the difference among the percentage changes in sales from region to region this Christmas would average only about 1.75 percentage points, below the 25-year average of 3.3 percentage points and just slightly higher than 1984, the last time regional sales were so undistinguishable at 1.54 percentage points. "You are hard pressed to find a time when regional economies look so much like each other," he said.
For example, Visa USA said that the average rise among credit card sales between Thanksgiving and last Sunday was 16 percent from a year earlier, and the only area of the country that came in more than two percentage points higher or lower than that figure was the Great Lakes region, where charges rose 13 percent.
At the same time Telecheck Services, the check acceptance company, found that sales rose 2.2 percent this season, and the only two regions that differed greatly from that average was the Southwest, where the company said check writing fell two-tenths of 1 percent, and the Southeast, where check writing rose 4.6 percent from 1996.
Tactical Retail Solutions, a retail consulting firm, said holiday sales rose 2.8 percent this Christmas but that it found only two places in the country where changes in sales stood out significantly: Phoenix enjoyed sales gains closer to 7.9 percent, while Galveston, Tex., had a gain of only nine-tenths of 1 percent.
"It is unusual to find so many regions of the country doing so well," Mr. Zandi said. "And that is reflected in relatively healthy sales gains."
Indeed consumer confidence, as measured by the Conference Board, a New York business research group, is at its highest in three decades, and national unemployment fell to 4.6 percent in November, the lowest level since 1973.
Most analysts think that same-stores sales for major retailers will rise around 3 percent, which will not make merchants happy because they are used to strong economies offering up bigger sales gains.
But such gains are a result of low inflation, which is strongly reflected in prices of general retail merchandise, and the fact that there are still far too many retail stores for the number of shoppers in this country.
"I think you can see that pattern that like politics all retail is local," said Isaac Lagnado, president of Tactical Retail Solutions, "and things are pretty much equal these days."
Regions that last year had yet to catch up to the low unemployment rates and high consumer confidence figures of the rest of the country stepped up this season, while areas where growth was tremendous last year calmed down a bit, helping to smooth these shopping patterns.
Consider the Northeast. Visa said that shoppers spent $7.8 billion with their credit cards this season, an 18 percent increase for that region from the previous year. Telecheck recorded a 2.2 percent sales gain in the Northeast, while last year sales in the region rose a mere eight-tenths of 1 percent, dragging behind an overall 5.7 percent rise nationally.
Visa's numbers are probably a more reliable indicator of the retail life in the Northeast, where consumers are more prone to paying with plastic than zippig off a check.
"My guess is that the Northeast gains reflect the fact the Christmas was good for high-income households," Mr. Zandi said. "And the Northeast is the wealthiest region in the country. And the Boston and New York corridor benefited from financial service and markets and a booming high-tech sector in Boston, which is doing fabulously."
Conversely, Telecheck found that sales in the West rose 1.4 percent compared with last year, when they grew 5.9 percent. "As we listen to the different retailers," said Jay Meltzer, director of Johnson Redbook Services, which compiles retail data, "they are saying that California has been good but not as good."

HEADLINE: Another Year Of the Bull; Dow Up 22%

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
When the closing bell sounded yesterday afternoon, it signaled the end of a spectacular year on Wall Street -- the first time the Dow Jones industrial average had ever registered three consecutive superb years in its 100-year history.
By almost every measure, 1997 was a year for the record books. If winning on Wall Street is really about exceeding expectations, what investor, small or large, could complain about the year just passed? 
 All the major stock market indexes showed strong returns, adding $2.6 trillion worth of wealth to the market. Even with a dip of 7.72 points yesterday, the Dow average closed at 7,908.25 -- leaving the index with a gain of 22.6 percent on the year.
It was the first time the Dow had ever gained 20 percent or more for three consecutive years. Put another way, if an investor had placed $10,000 into the Dow industrial stocks at the end of 1994, that investment would be worth $20,620 today.
Few had thought such a gain was possible. The consensus on Wall Street at the end of 1996 was that the stock market might rise only slightly, or even fall sharply into a bear market in 1997, as had happened before after two great years.
"In the last century, there has never been a case where the market has done well three years in a row," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "So most people went into 1997 with that bit of lore on their minds."
In 1927, for example, the Dow rose 27.7 percent and in 1928 it rose 47.7 percent, followed by the crash of 1929 that left the Dow with an 18.7 percent decline. In 1985, the Dow gained 27.7 percent and in 1986 it gained 22.6 percent, then came the October 1987 crash, which left the Dow only 2.3 percent higher for the year.
In percentage terms, the last three-year period's cumulative gain of 106 percent is the second-best ever for the Dow average. The best was 1933-35, when it recorded a cumulative gain of 140 percent. With the 1997 gain, however, the Dow average has risen for a record seven consecutive years, racking up a gain of more than 300 percent in a decade.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- a broader measure of large stocks -- did even better than the Dow average in 1997, gaining 31 percent. The Wilshire 5000, a measure of the entire universe of United States stocks, rose 29 percent.
Among the main reasons: the economy grew robustly, unemployment fell to just 4.6 percent and corporate earnings grew by nearly 12 percent, but inflation fell to the lowest level in a generation -- advancing at an annualized rate of just 1.8 percent in November.
Economists and Wall Street analysts call this the "goldilocks economy" -- not too hot, not too cold, just right. Some also call it nirvana, or the best of all possible worlds.
"Two years ago it would have been inconceivable to talk about a 4.6 unemployment rate and a declining rate of inflation," said Elizabeth J. Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear Stearns. "But the single biggest positive surprise was the budget deficit going away."
The shrinking deficit meant the Treasury issued fewer bonds to finance the Government's needs. As a result bond prices rose and yields dropped, making stocks more attractive.
Indeed, investors on Main Street continue to believe stocks are the best of all possible investments. For the second consecutive year, they poured more than $200 billion into stock mutual funds, by far the best two years in history.
"The power is in the flow of funds," said Steven Leuthold, head of the Leuthold Group, a research and money management firm. "The key is whether the public continues to believe in the stock market."
How likely is it that investors will have another spectacular year? Not very likely, many analysts say, while noting that they used a similar line last year.
But while some feared that raging inflation would dismantle the stock market in 1997, many now believe the financial crisis in Asia will hurt corporate profits and perhaps create a deflationary environment in 1998.
"The earnings estimates for the first time in many years are going to have to be revised down," Ms. Mackay of Bear Stearns said. "The Asia issue may linger."
Charles Hill, director of research at First Call Inc., which tracks corporate earnings, already notes a sharp downward revision in fourth-quarter figures. In September, analysts expected a 13 percent gain; now they expect 8 percent.
Few, however, are predicting a bear market. The consensus for 1998 seems to be moderation after three great years.
Abby Joseph Cohen at Goldman, Sachs, one of the most widely followed stock strategists, says investors ought to expect more modest corporate profits next year, and equally modest stock gains.
But Ms. Cohen, whose buy recommendations after the market plunged Oct. 27 are credited with helping the bounce back Oct. 28, said she does not see an Asia crisis toppling the bull market.
"We have incorporated lower numbers in our profits and we still come up with a bullish posture," she said. "Asia will not be as dismal as many expect."
Mr. Wien at Morgan Stanley says the Dow could reach 9,000 early in 1998, but then inflation and wage pressures may catch up with the market and finally halt its streak.
"Interest rates will rise," he said, "and we'll find Asia isn't a big deal and the economy is a bit too strong."
The Asia crisis, however, remains an underlying nerve. It is one reason the stock market slowed in the second half of the year.
Although no one knows the Asia impact, expectations are clearly tempered. In fact, Barton Biggs, a global strategist at Morgan Stanley, says that the Asian crisis could foretell a far worse future for stocks.
"If this has been a year of moonlight and roses," he wrote recently, "next year I expect is going to be sackcloth and ashes. In other words, the huge brutal hug of a bear market will squeeze some."
But one strategist who expects another year of roses is Laszlo Birinyi, who heads his own research firm. Mr. Birinyi, who accurately predicted that the Dow average would reach 8,000 in 1997, and then close slightly below that level, said that in 1998 the Dow could reach 10,000.
"We think the market will have a good year, to the chagrin of everyone," he said. "Sentiment has historically been a good indicator, and we're seeing a lot of net buying, even when prices slip."
Despite all the good cheer about stocks, in 1997 about 90 percent of money managers trailed far behind the S.& P. 500, a traditional measuring stick, which means that people who invested in index funds that mimic the S.& P. 500 did much better than those who asked an expert to handle their investments.
Few could have lost by selecting stocks in the S.& P. 500. Among the nation's 500 largest companies, about 4 out of 5 stocks rose, and nearly 300 had gains exceeding 20 percent.
Out were stocks that invested in metals, paper products, chemicals, tobacco and gas exploration -- companies that helped build America. In were technology, telecommunication, banking, retail and financial services stocks -- companies that say they are rushing into the future.
Big-company stocks once again bested smaller-company issues, but there was much more parity this year as even the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks gained 20 percent.
The best big stock of the year: Dell Computer, up 216 percent, on surging market share in personal computer sales. The worst: Echo Bay Mines, down 63 percent, a gold producer trying to get along in a world that no longer seems to value gold.

HEADLINE: S.A.T. Has the Power

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Eugene Garcia (Op-Ed, Dec. 26) says that by the mid-1980's the University of California was placing equal weight on Scholastic Assessment Test scores and grade point averages. However, the majority of applicants have G.P.A.'s in a narrow range (3.5 to 3.8), so that most of the variation among applicants is determined by S.A.T. scores. Thus, even if the S.A.T.'s role were diminished, it would still dominate admissions decisions. 
 Mr. Garcia correctly notes that women have higher college G.P.A.'s despite their lower S.A.T. scores than men. But this is not useful evidence in evaluating the predictive value of S.A.T. scores. Men score higher than women only on the math section, and as this would predict, fewer women pursue majors that have a math emphasis. Since these majors have not had the grade inflation of education and the humanities, in which women disproportionately major, it is not surprising that the college grade point averages of women are higher than those of men.
 
ROBERT CHERRY
Brooklyn, Dec. 28, 1997
 
Prof. of Economics, Brooklyn College

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Metropolis: Glimpses Of the First 100 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Happy birthday to us. New York, New York, is a century old as of yesterday. On New Year's Day 1898, after decades of negotiating, infighting and deal making, as well as some fairly close votes in both general elections and the State Assembly, "The Greater New York City," as it was initially called, came into being.
It was created by uniting under a single government New York City (which consisted of Manhattan and the Bronx), Brooklyn, Queens, and Richmond (also known as Staten Island). The vote was closest in Brooklyn, a thriving city in its own right, and the country's third largest, where one of the biggest motivations seems to have been gaining access to Manhattan's water supply and other utilities. 
 Some parts of the city, notably Manhattan, have benefited quite a bit more than others. The consolidation, or annexation, continues to be lamented in many quarters, particularly on Staten Island, where in 1993 voters approved a nonbinding referendum to make the borough an independent city.
Over the next year, New York's first century will be observed in different ways around the city. Sometime this spring, the Brooklyn Historical Society plans a dramatic presentation about the consolidation, and the Brooklyn Academy of Music will have a play-reading series devoted to 20th-century works set in Brooklyn, starting with "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."
At the moment, several exhibitions inspired by or coinciding with the centennial are on view in Manhattan, with others arriving soon. The current shows range from displays of historic documents and photographs concerning the unification, at the Museum of the City of New York, to a show about the lighted signs of Times Square, at the New-York Historical Society, as well as several other related displays at both institutions.
Downtown, there are three exhibitions of photographs of New York -- at the Parsons School of Design, the Howard Greenberg Gallery and Gallery 292 -- that span several decades of photojournalism and the city's street life.
It would be stretching things to say that these exhibitions, taken as a whole, come close to doing the life and history of New York justice, or that they account for much of the art, architecture or literature that it has inspired or nourished. Still, one is grateful for their vivid, informative glimpses of both the city's past and its present, and they supplement one another in unexpected ways.
 
Museum of the City Of New York
On this occasion, the Museum of the City of New York, which is celebrating its own 75th anniversary, is living up to its name big time. It has spiffed up its famous toy collection and filled itself nearly to the brim with temporary exhibitions. A visit can take more than half a day.
The centerpiece is "The New Metropolis: A Century of Greater New York, 1898-1998," which tells the story of the consolidation and illuminates important moments in the years since. This show is overburdened with glossy text panels and somewhat short on visually striking material, which ranges from vintage photographs to political cartoons to campaign buttons, and its layout is confusing. But if you begin with the excellent documentary film at the show's center, things make much more sense.
Together, film and exhibition outline an elaborate tale of the different entities and how they became one, revealing the political machinations, the power brokers and the economic conditions that drove events. One can learn such specifics as the populations and total area of the five boroughs in 1898, or consider the thick volume titled "The Charter of Greater New York." More poetically, a copper-lined bathtub symbolizes the advent of indoor plumbing in Manhattan in the 1880's, while a rugged barrel and ship's wheel represent the busy harbor, the running of which was another impetus for consolidation.
In the art column, there's Abraham Walkowitz's 1913 Cubistic charcoal of dancing (or collapsing) Manhattan skyscrapers; Joseph Pennell's nocturne of lower Manhattan, and Paul Manship's model for the seal of the new city. Photographs document the growth of the Manhattan skyline, as, in different ways, do souvenirs of specific skyscrapers, like the mug decorated with the Flatiron Building.
Less cheerful developments are also referred to, as in a display of petitions, handbills and protest postcards by which the Crotona Park Tenants Committee opposed, unsuccessfully, the razing of their neighborhood to make way for the Cross-Bronx Expressway. There are photographs of the master builder Robert Moses, who refused to consider a less devastating alternative route. And the departure of the Brooklyn Dodgers and the demise of Ebbets Field is once again documented, and mourned.
"New York From Above: An Aerial View," a second exhibition at the museum, has a higher ratio of art to information. It begins with a smattering of 19th-century panoramic depictions of the city, most notably John Bachmann's "Bird's-Eye View on Manhattan Island and Its Environs Taken From the South," of 1859. This tinted lithograph has "fish-eye lens" perspective that distorts the city into a globe: confirmation for those who think New York is not just the center of the world, but is, in fact, the world.
The main galleries of "Aerial View" contain the work of Spelman Evans Downer, a 43-year-old contemporary artist who lives in Jersey City and is fascinated by the cartographical New York, his main subject for nearly a decade. He replicates, or more accurately expands upon, existing maps to a highly refined degree, drawing in and texturing wet oil paint to indicate roads, buildings, topography and foliage with a skill that even cartographers, a famously picky bunch, might respect.
In red lines on expanses of pale green, Mr. Downer accounts for all the expressways in and around New York City. In various color combinations, including white on white, he give Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island paintings of their own and portrays Central Park in grisaille. Elsewhere, he turns comparative, juxtaposing painted versions of the city map of 1898 with that of 1998. An especially dramatic effort juxtaposes maps of the northern Harlem River before and after it was manipulated, showing in white, pink and ringing blue how the river lost its serpentine curves and Manhattan lost Marble Hill, the only Manhattan neighborhood that is actually in the Bronx.
Mr. Downer's paintings may not do everything you want art to do, but the best of them fuse beauty and fact with dazzling efficiency.
Additional exhibitions and displays await viewers with stamina. "A Dream Well Planned: The Empire State Building" follows the building, once the world's tallest, from the drawing board to its present incarnation, and finally divulges the symbolism of the various color combinations that light its crown during the year -- all of them.
"Revisiting the Scene: New Evidence, New Discoveries," a new permanent display of 19th- and 20th-century paintings of New York, contains several little gems, among them, "View From the Queensboro Bridge After a Snow on St. Patrick's Day," painted in 1910 by Sebastian Cruset, whose studio was in one of the finials of the bridge. And return visits should be planned for "Bridging New York," an exhibition opening on Jan. 31 that will bring together all kinds of images, from paintings to postcards, of some of the city's 2,027 bridges.
 
New-York Historical Society
"Signs and Wonders: The Spectacular Lights of Times Square," the main event at the New-York Historical Society, is almost the inverse of "The New Metropolis." It examines a single subject, in this case an under-appreciated commercial art form, but stirs up all sorts of local history in the process. Vintage photographs convey the progressing complication and beauty of the signs themselves, starting with the 1917 Wrigley spearmint gum spectacular, with its lacy fountains, peacocks and 16 "spearmen."
The foundation of the early spectaculars was the clear light bulb, soon overtaken by colored lights, flashing lights and the neon tube, whose flexibility led to animated signs like the one that showed a kitten tumbling around with a ball of thread, demonstrating that Corticelli thread "does not knot." Theater marquees are joined by movie marquees, their lighted signs custom-made for each new movie. Flamboyant advertisements for liquor, cigarettes and ladies' underwear are joined by those for film and cameras and the dramatic patterns possible with computer programming of lights. Coca-Cola, though, is a constant.
Along the way, the exhibition traces the development of advertising; the ebb and flow of the area's businesses; the birth of the Municipal Art Society, which opposed the signs, and the rise, fall and Disneyfication of Times Square.
This exhibition is not without its text panels, but the reading is worth it. Having absorbed all this information, one can always visit the real show already in progress, 20 blocks to the south.
Two other displays here also focus on Times Square. "The Deuce" presents Andreas Feininger's gritty photographs of the area in the 1970's, during its heyday as a sex district. The pictures are so dense with signs they often look like collages. "Times Square Then and Now" documents architectural progress with photographic comparisons, showing how specific buildings in the area have been demolished and replaced, altered or left to decay. It should not be surprising that the "after" is rarely better.
Two other shows circle back to "The New Metropolis." "To Hell With Reform: The Race to Become Mayor of Greater New York" reviews the platforms and campaign literature of the four men who competed in the first election, in 1897, to be the mayor of all New York. "Before Central Park: The Life and Death of Seneca Village" documents the fate of a small, but thriving community that was destroyed to make way for Central Park, one of the earliest examples of urban renewal in the city. On May 1, the Society will open "A Century Together: Creating and Recreating Greater New York," an exhibition that will examine the see-sawing of power between the city's central government and its constituent communities.
 
SoHo Galleries
"1930's New York" at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo, brings together impressive groups of work by photographers famous and less well known: Berenice Abbott, Joseph Kaplan, Sol Prom and Liborio Justo. It is a study in the power, both reportorial and abstract, of black-and-white photography, as demonstrated by four very different sensibilities. Abbott's rigorous images concentrate on the city's architecture and geometry: the forms of its building and the spaces they define, the pervasive grids of windows, the vanishing points of its endless streets. Kaplan lets in more of the human presence, but keeps his distance, shooting men on the street from above, like Rodchenko, or children playing in the snow in Central Park from such a distance that they become animated hieroglyphics. Mr. Prom is the humanist of the group, moving close to individuals of all kinds: Bowery bums, a shoeshine boy, six beautiful young women on a bench. And the ecumenical Mr. Justo is all over the place in both his forms and his sympathies, photographing people rushing to work from odd angles, a protest march in Union Square or the looming facade of Rockefeller Center.
Next door to Greenberg, Gallery 292 has mounted a small, but vivid show of vintage photographs taken in the late 1940's by Rebecca Lepkoff. Judging from these 20 images, Ms. Lepkoff seems to have been equally drawn to the city's people and its architecture.
She photographs well-dressed professionals in "Early Morning Rush Hour," the heated action of a stickball game in "Lower East Side" and a cool basilica of space defined by the legs of the El. But her real subject may be light itself, splintered and rearranged by New York's buildings, shading a scene with gentle grays or turning figures into dramatic silhouettes.
 
Parsons School of Design
"Living for the City: 20 Years of New York Street Photography" at the Parsons School of Design brings us up to the present. Spend much time in this densely installed exhibition of work by 17 photographers, and you may begin to feel the city closing in on you, exciting and oppressive at the same time. You will also know that street photography is alive and well.
Nearly every photographer here acts as a tour guide of a different subculture. Geoffrey Biddle photographs the rough-and-ready youths of Alphabet City. A. Roy Greer attends to the West Village, concentrating on gay men; Sylvia Plachy patrols the perimeters, as in a silhouetted image of bench-sitters on the Brighton Beach boardwalk.
Richard Sandler, curator of the exhibition, and Arlene Gottfried prowl the subways, while, above ground, Steven Hirsch finds a reluctant subject in a man with a fistful of snakes. In his wittily titled "Hats and Hats Not" series, Jules Allen traces headgear through all kinds of life styles and economic strata. And Sid Kaplan and Jeff Mermelstein stick, quite literally, to the streets. Mr. Kaplan records the ongoing competition between cobblestones and asphalt. (His work looks like a Robert Smithson.) Mr. Mermelstein photographs a pigeon standing, wounded in the beak, at shocked attention on a curb, your average New Yorker, bloodied perhaps, but unbowed.

HEADLINE: Financial Services Consolidate, but Regulation Is Still Fragmented

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
In April, Bankers Trust, the nation's seventh-largest bank, agreed to buy Alex. Brown & Sons, a securities firm. That deal initiated a buying spree on Wall Street, culminating in the announcement in September that Travelers Group was buying Salomon Brothers Inc., adding more clout in bond trading and investment banking to an already flourishing combination of brokerage and insurance businesses.
Those combinations worry some lawmakers, who note that the current regulatory structure for financial services was devised when securities firms were securities firms, insurers sold insurance and banks acted like banks. As a lowering of the financial services industry's traditional legal walls and competition for the consumer's dollar give rise to ever-bigger financial supermarkets, concern is rising about safeguards for investors and the financial system. 
 For many experts, the trend cries out for a corresponding consolidation of the regulatory structure, with the creation of a new umbrella organization that looks at financial services companies comprehensively rather than bit by bit.
Historically, financial services have been regulated category by category. Brokerage houses have been the domain of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Banks have been looked over by the Federal Reserve and several other agencies. And insurance companies have been monitored by state regulators.
But increasingly, these businesses are coming under one roof, blurring the lines. In March, banks were permitted to expand further into the securities business, and a month later Bankers Trust announced that it was buying Alex. Brown, a major regional stock brokerage firm based in Baltimore. Following that deal, BankAmerica agreed to buy Robertson Stephens, and Nationsbank agreed to acquire Montgomery Securities.
The linkups could also go the other way. Several big financial companies, including Travelers and Merrill Lynch, have expressed interest in owning commercial banks. And these companies continue to spread further around the world in their quest for greater revenues.
"The concern is that somehow one of these institutions might run into difficulties and that the individual regulators won't see it coming," said Bert Ely, a Washington financial consultant. "You have to look at the corporation in its entirety to see how well it is managing its overall risk. Do the various risks magnify each other or neutralize each other? At what point does the balance tip?"
Consumer groups are concerned, too, as financial companies increasingly intermingle banking, securities and insurance offerings. Money market mutual funds, for example, provide investment returns similar to savings accounts, yet they are regulated as securities and sold through both banks and brokerage firms. Yet in contrast to bank savings accounts, the money market funds sold at banks are not covered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; neither are other securities now being sold by banks.
Groups like Consumers Union say banks do not always explain the distinctions and the risks. Consumers Union is campaigning for more complete disclosure by banks and to require securities and insurance to be offered at different counters from traditional banking services.
Consumer interests are also cited by supporters of comprehensive oversight of financial services, though there is no consensus on how best to proceed. Regulators do not want to cede authority to a superpower and no industry wants another layer of regulation. Travelers, for example, favors the status quo of having "each relevant regulator regulate that part of the business," said Mary McDermott, a company spokeswoman.
Some proponents of umbrella supervision envision a kind of college of cardinals made up of the heads of the current regulatory bodies. But many see that as cumbersome and, instead, favor endowing one agency -- the Federal Reserve Board, say, or the Treasury Department or the S.E.C. -- with superior powers. But the extent of those powers has been a fundamental sticking point.
Some, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, argue that an umbrella supervisor should not actually regulate -- or have greater authority than the individual regulators -- but should try to coordinate oversight and encourage sharing of information. Others, including Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, contend that for an umbrella supervisor to have any effectiveness, one of the current regulators, probably the Fed, must be given some degree of authority over companies and other regulators.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, sees his organization as a natural for greater powers. His argument grows out of the idea that the Fed already has overriding authority over bank holding companies, like the new Bankers Trust-Alex. Brown combination, though the S.E.C. still monitors the company's securities business.
Mr. Greenspan's view encompasses the widespread belief that when Congress eventually permits bank-securities-insurance combinations, the organizing structure will be the bank holding company. The House Banking and Commerce committees came close to a compromise in November, but decided, as the session ended, to continue negotiations early this year. In an expanded bank holding company, the thinking goes, the Fed would need oversight of the securities and insurance operations to carry out its role of insuring the financial health of federally insured banks.
For his part, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the S.E.C., contends that the agency would be the logical umbrella supervisor in financial conglomerates dominated by securities business.
That suggests that in a situation in which insurance is the main business, an insurance regulator would have the paramount role. But just how that might work is unclear because insurance is regulated state by state and it is difficult to envision Federal regulators becoming subordinate to state authority.
The securities and the insurance industries fiercely oppose umbrella regulation. Securities firms want to avoid what they regard as the more intrusive style of regulation of the Fed. And the insurers are concerned that broader regulation will lead to increased -- and they say unfair -- competition from banks and securities firms. The insurers have already lost some ground to the banks since the Comptroller of the Currency ruled in 1990 that banks could create and sell annuities and the Supreme Court, in 1995, agreed.
Many financial experts argue that insurance regulation is the weakest link in the system. Generally, the state insurance regulators have tiny staffs and tiny budgets compared with the enormous companies they oversee. Moreover, there is a clubby relationship between many regulators and the industry. Regulators are often from the industry and often return to insurance jobs after a stint in government. Some career regulatory employees look forward to a few lucrative years with an insurance company after retiring from government work, with the proviso that they not immediately deal with regulatory matters.
Neil D. Levin, New York's top insurance regulator and a newcomer to the field, takes a critical view of the system. Mr. Levin, a former investment banker who was appointed Superintendent of Insurance last February after serving as Commissioner of Banking, says that unless the state-by-state system of insurance regulation becomes much more "effective, efficient and coordinated," the creation of a Federal insurance regulator "is going to start to look pretty compelling."
Charles W. Quackenbush, the elected Insurance Commissioner of California, said at a recent insurance industry conference in New York that particularly with the increased blending of banking and insurance, it is "inevitable that the Federal Government will expand its role in the regulation of insurance."
Some critics argue that umbrella supervision would do little more than add another layer of bureaucracy. "These are complex businesses and it is not clear that an umbrella regulator would have any idea of what he was looking at," said Gilbert Schwartz, a Washington banking lawyer who advises the American Council on Life Insurance.
Others, like Lawrence J. White, an economics professor at the Stern School of Business at New York University and a former member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, argue that a super-regulator with ultimate authority might stifle some of the independence of the present regulators and "end up having some degree of monopoly power."
For Mr. White, umbrella regulation means redundancy. "If you're worried about the bank lending too much to the insurance company, that's something the bank regulators have plenty of power to deal with," he said. "If you're worried about the insurance company lending too much and putting the insurance claimants at risk, the insurance guys have the powers to deal with that."
As the debate continues, financial experts say there are signs of compromise that could, indeed, lead to the creation of an overarching supervisor of financial conglomerates. But even the strongest proponents say it is likely to have modest powers.
"What is appropriate," Mr. Leach said from his House banking office in Washington, "is certain protection of shareholders, for public treasuries and the economy at large. You don't ever want to establish a hubristic super-regulator."

GRAPHIC: Charts: "MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS"
The consolidation of the nation's financial services industries is epitomized by the growth of the Travelers Group. The company now known as Travelers has its roots in a troubled consumer loan company called Commercial Credit, which the Wall Street veteran Sanford I. Weill bought in 1986. In 1988, Commercial Credit bought Primerica, which owned Smith Barney, and took the Primerica name. During 1992 and 1993, Primerica acquired Travelers, then an insurer, and, again, adopted the acquired company's name. In 1997, Travelers made its biggest acquisition yet, adding Salomon, one of Wall Street's biggest firms, and joined it with Smith Barney.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Climb in Australia

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Australian bonds rose in the first trading session of 1998, amid optimism that cooling Asian economies will take the heat off domestic growth, and keep any risk of accelerating inflation at bay.
"The bond market will do well" from Asia's financial turmoil, said Anthony Robson, chief fixed-interest trader at Westpac Bank in Sydney. 
 Asia, and the effect it is seen having on demand for Australian exports, "is going to be the dampening spot for our economy," he said.
The benchmark October 2007 Government bonds added $6.04 Australian ($4 United States) today for each $1,000 Australian ($650 United States) face value. The yield fell 7basis points, to 5.98 percent.
The gains in Australian bonds were underpinned by a report in the United States this week that suggested that the American economy was growing with little inflation.
Even as Australian growth picks up -- aided by a jump in retail spending during summer vacations and more people finding full-time employment -- price increases by Australian producers and retailers are seen as restrained.
Helping to bolster optimism that inflation will be subdued were comments this week by the investor George Soros, who said the world was on the brink of international deflation as a result of the economic turmoil in Asia.
"What started out as a minor imbalance has become a much bigger one that threatens to engulf not only international credit but international trade," said Mr. Soros, chairman of Soros Fund Management and the primary investment adviser to Quantum Fund, in an article in The Financial Times on Wednesday.
Investors viewed Mr. Soros's comments as bullish for bonds.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Rise a Bit

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose this week to an average 7.03 percent from 6.99 percent the previous week, the Federal Home Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, said today. The rate on 15-year mortgages also rose to an average 6.61 percent in the week, up from 6.57 percent. One-year adjustable-rate mortgages fell to an average 5.50 percent from 5.53 percent the previous week. Freddie Mac is chartered by Congress to buy mortgages from lenders and package them into securities for investors.

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Ruble Is Streamlined, Trimmed Down by 3 Zeros

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 1

 BODY:
This is not the way Lena Usikova planned to usher in the new year. Clutching a fistful of dollars she had rescued from a hiding place in her three-room apartment, the bleary-eyed schoolteacher pawed the fresh snow as she waited for her grocery store to open for business.
"I don't know which rubles to use," she wailed, crossing her gray eyes in disgust. "The old ones are bad, but could the new ones possibly be any better? I'm using dollars. At least you can't go wrong with them." 
 Actually, you can. But given Russia's bitter history with new bills, shaky banks, and anything having to do with money, who can blame her? At midnight, mostly for reasons of convenience and national self-esteem, Russia lopped three zeros from all its rubles. A subway fare that cost 2,000 rubles on New Year's Eve now costs just 2. An American dollar, which on Wednesday bought 5,960 rubles, won't even buy six today.
This is the third time in less than a decade that the Russian Government has tried to revise its battered currency. Past results have been grim. This cosmetic change, announced last August, is essentially psychological. There is nothing radical, surprising or scary about it. Old rubles will be accepted along with the new ones for a year, and as a way to keep everyone calm, the pictures on the new bills have hardly changed at all.
But when it comes to cash, Russian history has a nasty way of repeating itself. And there has never been a ruble reform that didn't end up punishing the people who least deserve it. In 1991, the waning Soviet Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev decided to change all 50- and 100-ruble notes to reduce the money supply. People had three days to exchange their money. Panic whipped through the country, there was a rush on the banks, and those who held onto their old money saw it turn overnight into meaningless strips of colorful paper. A similar reform in 1993, when Mr. Yeltsin withdrew all Soviet-era rubles, was almost as painful.
Federal banking officials say nothing so drastic is possible this time. And they note that although a stampede was widely expected in 1995 when new 100-dollar bills -- the single most important monetary instrument in Russia -- were introduced by the United States, the shift was relatively painless.
But that does not mean this one will be. Long lines at banks and currency exchanges have again become common, and in the last two weeks, banking officials say, Russians converted twice as many rubles to dollars as they did in the previous two. Most consumers will hold onto those dollars until sometime next week, just in case their worst fears are once again confirmed. That means many people will have paid a commission to take their money out of the bank and a commission to exchange it, and beginning today there is a new 2 percent tax on money converted from dollars to rubles. The safe bet on the almighty dollar will cost most people about 7 percent of the money they are trying to hoard.
"We understand that to battle fears that have built up in Russian people who have lived through 75 years of very unpleasant currency reforms is hard," said Irina Yasina, the chief spokeswoman for the Russian Central Bank, which has mounted an exceptionally detailed and patient public relations campaign in an attempt to convince people that this time there is nothing to fear from change.
"We continually assure people that nothing bad will happen," she continued. "But we know that only our actions on Jan. 1, 2, 3 and beyond can prove that there are no hidden tricks or traps."
At the urging of economic advisers who said that currency reform would increase the confidence of investors while making most Russians feel better about their money, President Boris N. Yeltsin announced the change last summer at a time when the economy looked as if it was finally about to emerge from years of deep depression. With the annual inflation rate having fallen from more than 1,000 percent in 1992 to under 14 percent today, the new currency was to have been the signature symbol of better times.
But the second half of 1997 brought a new round of bad economic news for Russia: tax revenues became so anemic that the International Monetary Fund decided -- for a while -- to suspend loan payments. The crisis in Asian economic markets hurt Russia badly because many skittish investors reacted by pulling out of all emerging markets. Predictions of economic catastrophe -- absolutely common here from all sides of the political spectrum -- began to take on the ring of truth.
As with most economic issues in Russia today, public opinion polls suggest that young people are far more open to the changes than their parents. More than three-quarters of people under 40 interviewed in one recent poll suggested that the change would mean nothing to them. For those over 60, who trust the Government less than anyone else and have been hurt most by the harsh pace of reform, the percentages were nearly reversed.
"We've been tricked so many times, I just don't feel like I can trust it," said 73-year-old Tatyana Sergeyeva, a pensioner and first-grade teacher, who continues to teach despite having long passed the age when she can retire. Viktor Birikov, 46, an engineer, said that he couldn't care less about the new bills. "It'll just be three zeros less," he said. "It's the same bills with the same pictures and the same color, just three less zeros. "
There may be more to it than that. The good news is that 3.6 rubles seems to most shoppers like a better price for a loaf of bread than 3,600. People are likely to have more respect for the currency as a result. The bad news, already evident on the street -- where official prices must be posted in old and new rubles -- is that price rises are almost certainly going to be one result of the change.
"If I am charging 96,000 rubles for an item I may decide to charge 100 rubles in the new system," said the proprietor of a new computer store in downtown Moscow. "I don't think most people would notice the difference."
Asked if he really thought that people would fail to notice an immediate 4 percent price rise, he laughed.
"I think people are going to have enough on their minds just dividing the prices," he said."

HEADLINE: Some Lush Vineyards, but No Yield

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia

 BODY:
Back in 1993, it looked like a perfect opportunity: a marriage between Napa Valley vintners and an ancient wine-making industry that had recently been liberated from Communism and the former Soviet Union.
The group of eager investors included Eric Wente, a top executive of the Wente Brothers winery in Livermore, Calif., and George P. Shultz, the former Secretary of State. The group invested about $1.5 million in a privatized winery here called Sameba. Mr. Shultz, who was strictly a passive investor, even clinked glasses here in a celebratory toast with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister who is now President of Georgia. 
 The appeal was obvious. Thanks to a warm climate and rich soil, this former Soviet republic has been producing wines for nearly 5,000 years. The hillside villages and vineyards look as though they would fit better in the lush Tuscany region of Italy than in Central Asia. Sweet or dry, red or white, Georgian wines enjoy a special cachet in Russia and much of Central Europe. While not in a league with the fine vintages of France or California, they can be competitive internationally in a moderate price range, the investors believed.
But today the joint venture bears witness to the difficulties of transforming a former Communist hinterland into an American-style business opportunity. A string of American managers here have variously quit or been dismissed; the last one left after the Georgian partners threatened to literally throw him out of their offices. Discouraged and disillusioned, the American investors do not expect to see any return on their money.
"They don't answer our telephone calls or our faxes anymore," Mr. Wente said in a telephone interview. "It became increasingly obvious to us that their agenda was not to build a company but to preserve a life style."
The experience is hardly unusual. Six years after the Soviet Union collapsed, Russia and former Soviet republics like Georgia have rushed to embrace capitalism and Western investors. But as often as not, companies have balked at conventional Western business practices and slipped back toward the habits of cronyism and self-dealing that pervaded the old system.
Western investors know this, at least in principle. But the allure of a historic turnaround opportunity can be irresistible, and there have been few sweeter turnaround possibilities in the former Soviet Union than Georgia's wine industry. From Warsaw to Moscow and even among some Western aficionados, the wines here are beloved for their warmth, variety and character. Indeed, bottlers from places like Moldavia and parts of Russia routinely try to pass off their wines as "Georgian."
Vintners here have their own distinctive approach to fermenting: the grapes along with their skins and some of the stems are fermented together in giant clay casks and later separated out.
After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Georgia's wine industry seemed to have nowhere to go but up. Government mismanagement had left most wineries with antiquated bottling and pressing plants. The industry's traditional markets in Russia and Central Europe had been devastated by economic depression. Georgia was itself bogged down in several civil wars. To people like Mr. Wente, new equipment and modern marketing could go a long way.
To be sure, some Westerners have thrived here. The Dutch wine bottler Royal Cooymans has teamed up with entrepreneurs in Telavi, a town northeast of Tbilisi, in a successful joint venture with local entrepreneurs called Georgia Wine and Spirits. The Dutch company has overhauled most of the wine-making process, imported all the supplies for bottling and increased marketing efforts. Sales have doubled from 1.5 million bottles in 1996, at a wholesale price of roughly $3 a bottle, to 3.2 million bottles in 1997.
But for the Americans who bought into Sameba, things have not gone so well. The company remains in full production, based in a vine-covered villa here in the Georgian capital. But the Americans say they ran into conflicts with their Georgian partners from the first moment, and those problems were only made worse by Georgia's struggles with civil war and economic turmoil. It did not help that a founder of the company killed himself after having seen his two sons killed -- one in a gangland vendetta.
The Georgians insist they still relish their partnership with the Americans, but that they simply can not get "competent" American managers.
"It was one thing to go into a joint venture and put money in, but something quite different to work here and come to these burdens here every day," said Zourab Tkemaladze, Sameba's general director, in an interview at company headquarters.
Under the original deal, the American investors formed an organization called Georgia Wines that acquired a 50 percent stake in the Sameba Company. Mr. Tkemaladze, 53, had been part of the company's original management and had helped turn it into a private corporation.
The Americans invested $1.5 million over the next several years, while the Georgians contributed their existing stocks of wine along with their equipment. The Americans, who received three out of five seats on the company's board for the first few years, were entitled to install American managers.
The Americans were able to exercise effective control, and conflicts began almost immediately. They complained that they could not make sense of the Georgians' accounting. Some objected strenuously to Georgian plans for hiring workers at nearly slave-labor wages of $10 a month. And the local managers found themselves worn down by a place where telephones did not work, corruption was still rampant and basic supplies were often impossible to secure.
Hughes Ryan, a wine maker from St. Helena, Calif., who was hired to manage the precise wine formulation, said he got into regular arguments over just what the company was putting in its bottles. Mr. Ryan suspected that much of the wine was from old stocks of substandard produce, and complained that the company's books made it impossible to figure out exactly what the company was selling. He was dismissed two years ago.
"They never really adopted the Napa Valley attitude, which is that bad wines hurt everybody," said Mr. Ryan, who is back in California now but is about to start a new wine company in Georgia.
Mr. Tkemaladze said he dismissed Mr. Ryan because he was "not very qualified." A barrel-chested man who wore a bright blue sport shirt during a recent interview, Mr. Tkemaladze said he remained grateful to the American investors for their support at a crucial time and was still "optimistic" about hiring another American manager.
"Our partners came despite civil war in Abkhazia and Ossetia, and despite a big crime problem in Georgia," he said. "How can I say anything but wonderful words about people that came in at that time and were willing to help us?"
Meanwhile, the American investors have lost control. Though they theoretically still own 50 percent of the Georgian joint venture, their agreement stipulated that the Georgians would get a majority of seats on the company's management board after the first few years. Even if the Americans had stayed in Georgia to vote, they would be outvoted every time.
Mr. Wente is chalking up the venture to experience. "The wines have great possibility, because you can grow some very good grapes there," Mr. Wente said. "But there are a lot of cultural differences. If I were going to go back there, I would want majority control."

HEADLINE: NYC;
Hand on Bible And Eyes On the Prize

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
NEW YORK had all its lame ducks in a row yesterday.
"The Full Monty" aside, it was hard to remember the last time anyone had seen so many able-bodied people gathered together with minds focused on possible new lines of work. It wasn't a situation that city officials talked much about yesterday, not in public anyway. Yet it may well have been the most intriguing aspect of a numbingly cold Inauguration Day. 
 Thanks to term limits, New Yorkers were graced -- a word used here ironically, in case you didn't catch it -- with a constellation of elected leaders whose attention was wandering even as they swore on Bibles to fill their present offices with unswerving devotion.
The City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, is looking to run for mayor in 2001, when the coast will be clear because Rudolph W. Giuliani must move out of Gracie Mansion. The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who will take the oath for his final term next week, plans to run for governor this year. The Public Advocate, Mark Green, has his eye once more on the United States Senate. And Mr. Giuliani? He has not actually said he is seeking higher office, but you don't hear Sherman-like denials from him, either.
Not to be impertinent, but is anyone around here committed 100 percent to his job? Is this what New Yorkers thought they were buying when they endorsed a limit of two terms (with the meter starting in 1994) on major officeholders, including the entire City Council?
Now comes the test of whether the voters were wise or, as some suspect, they bought a popular but dubious nostrum for all that ails government.
"I don't think this is a good situation," said William B. Eimicke, who runs a program on politics and public policy at Columbia University. "It encourages grandstanding. It focuses them on their new ambitions. They're appealing now to a broader constituency than the one that elected them, and that makes them not fully responsive to the people who elected them."
Mr. Eimicke was referring to all the ambitious souls at City Hall, but inevitably the public's gaze was, is and will remain on the Mayor. If he runs for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's seat or seeks a spot on the Republican national ticket in 2000, it will be interesting to see how he broadens his appeal beyond New York without sacrificing the interests of this city, which, for all his feel-good "Capital of the World" proclamations, remains decidedly unloved in many parts of the country.
It was Mr. Giuliani's show yesterday, of course, although a few New Yorkers may remember the day more as the 100th anniversary of the consolidated city, and others, with eyes glued to their pocketbooks, as the day they started getting 11 subway and bus rides for the price of 10 -- possibly the only good thing in New York Rudy hasn't taken credit for.
There certainly were few good things that he didn't take credit for in his inaugural address and no mistakes that he felt obliged to acknowledge. He will never be known as Mayor Culpa.
BUT inaugurations are usually like that, and Mr. Giuliani was entitled to a free shave on his big day, even from someone who would quarrel with his boast to fellow New Yorkers yesterday that "you and I have changed the direction of the city more than in any four-year period in history." (Crime was already going down and the economy bouncing back when he was elected in 1993. By contrast, Edward I. Koch, the last mayor to be inaugurated for a second time, had reinvigorated a city that was supine in finances and spirit when he took office in 1978.)
You might think that Mr. Giuliani, as an avowed enemy of old-school politics, would use his lame-duck status to advantage. This is the moment, for example, to fill his cabinet with Manhattan Institute types, people who would privatize hospitals, reorder municipal finances, turn over social services to nonprofit institutions and try breaking the grip of strangulating union rules. For all the improvements in city life that the Mayor can claim, reinventing local government is not one of them.
"Reform has to take place within the limits of the Mayor's personality and governing style," said Fred Siegel, an urban-affairs specialist and history professor at Cooper Union.
In other words, if he really wants to shrink government, one thing Mr. Giuliani must do is yield a measure of power to others. Some find it hard to see how that will happen on the watch of a l'etat-c'est-moi incumbent.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Energy for a Power Source;
Coal May Become A Better Choice

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: GILLETTE, Wyo.

 BODY:
Amid the rolling hills of northeastern Wyoming, a towering five-story plant is using heat and pressure to turn the low-grade coal that abounds here in the 9,700-square-mile Powder River Basin into high-quality fuel -- and, in the process, make that coal less a hazard to the environment.
The $60 million experiment by KFx Inc., a small company that has received help and money from some giants of the energy industry, is in the forefront of a broad effort to extend the life span of one of the world's first, most widely used fuels. 
 In the debates over pollution and global warming, coal has been labeled a prime villain. Coal has long been under assault as a leading contributor to smog and acid rain. And it could be dealt a severe blow if the proposals to cut carbon dioxide emissions made at the recent talks on global warming in Kyoto, Japan, are eventually adopted.
Even in the face of all that, though, some in the coal industry remain decidedly bullish. Coal, they argue, is too deeply entrenched to allow any quick, drastic changes. After all, coal-fired plants produce fully 57 percent of this nation's electricity.
And on the pollution front, coal is rapidly cleaning up its act. Many plants have been upgraded with expensive pollution controls, and new processes -- like those KFx is using -- promise to cut pollution further. And part of the process has the potential to cut carbon dioxide as well.
In other words, the world may be stuck with coal at least for a while, but that may not be the disaster it might appear.
Many utilities regard coal plants as their crown jewels. As the cheapest, most reliable source of electricity, these plants, which now often run far below capacity, are expected to play a sizable role in bringing rates down as the industry deregulates.
Coal-fired plants could, in theory, be converted to use some other fuel, but that would be prohibitively expensive. The Edison Electric Institute, which represents most of the nation's investor-owned utilities, has estimated that it would cost close to $30 billion to convert coal plants to use natural gas, which produces less pollution and carbon dioxide.
Cleaner fuels, like natural gas, will surely make inroads, but even if utilities are forced to stop using coal, it is doubtful that enough natural gas could be brought into production to displace coal in the near future.
In addition, any big shift would cost tens of thousands of jobs, a possibility that seems remote any time soon, considering the political influence of the highly unionized coal industry. Britain learned this lesson recently, putting a halt to issuing new permits for natural-gas-fired plants, whose construction was surging, while it determines the impact on its battered coal industry.
In developing countries, coal's future seems even more solid. Coal is expected to merely hold its own in the United States, with the Energy Department predicting 1 percent annual growth through 2015. But China and India, knowing that their own coal is cheap and plentiful enough to last for centuries, plan to build hundreds of coal-fired plants.
In the developing world, the Energy Department predicts, coal use will rise about 3.3 percent a year though 2015, nearly doubling the 2.2 billion tons those nations burned in 1995.
"Coal is going to be used especially by countries that have lots of it," said Robert H. Gentile, an Assistant Energy Secretary in the Bush Administration and now an executive with KFx.
Nations like China, India and Pakistan argued in Kyoto that they should not have their coal use limited because it represents the cheapest way to supply their rapidly growing demand for energy.
They want nations like the United States, which has just 4 percent of the world's population but produces about a fifth of its carbon dioxide, to take the first steps to cut emissions.
Under the Kyoto agreement, industrialized nations would have to cut carbon dioxide emissions 5.2 percent below 1990 levels. The United States would be required to cut them 7 percent from 2008 through 2012.
To be sure, the coal and utility industries do not have their heads in the sand. They fully understand that concern over global warming is bound to intensify.
That is why KFx and similar ventures are trying to go beyond cutting pollution to try to address concerns on global warming.
After some setbacks, KFx restarted its plant several weeks ago, taking coal from the local mines here and heating it to about 725 degrees under intense pressure to remove almost all the water. This process upgrades the coal, enabling utilities to burn about half as much to get the same amount of electricity -- and cut pollution and carbon dioxide emissions in the process.
The plant, built at a cost of $40 million, is expected to process 500,000 tons a year of this coal, which the company calls K-fuel.
The effort is the brainchild of a group of entrepreneurs led by Ted Venners and his brother John. After making a small fortune in Powder River Basin coal in the 1970's, they decided to risk everything and invest $20 million in the 1980's in this process, developed by an inventor named Edward Koppelman.
Mr. Koppelman, who also developed the mechanism that de-ices airplanes, found after years of trial and error that by careful control of time, heat and pressure, the efficiency of coal could be increased.
The Venners stand to profit handsomely if their gamble pays off -- if, that is, they can convince utilities in the East and Midwest that they can cut pollution and carbon dioxide and increase plant efficiency by paying top dollar for KFx's upgraded coal.
KFx's coal matches the quality of the higher-grade coal mined in the East. But the higher-sulfur Eastern coal, which has a considerably greater energy output in terms of B.T.U.'s, sells for $18 to $25 a ton, while Powder River Basin coal sells for as little as $3. After KFx processes it, it hopes to sell its fuel for as much as the Eastern coal.
The KFx process, though, reduces nitrogen oxides by about half and sulfur by up to 20 percent, making it attractive to utilities, which are under pressure to cut these emissions. Powder River Basin coal is already a low-sulfur coal, but the KFx process reduces the sulfur even more, making it far cleaner than Eastern coal.
It can also have an impact, though a more limited one, on global warming. The process has the potential to cut carbon dioxide emissions by about 6 percent, even allowing for the coal used to create the upgraded fuel, since less coal is needed to produce the same amount of energy.
The initial investors in KFx persuaded the Thermo Ecotek Corporation, a unit of Thermo Electron, a Waltham, Mass., company that specializes in bringing new technology to market, to invest $60 million.
Also, the Kennecott Energy and Coal Company, a unit of the RTZ-CRA Group of Britain that has become a leading producer of coal, spending about $1 billion since 1990 to buy up reserves in the United States, has provided technical aid.
Kennecott will also help finance the building of plants using the KFx process if it proves viable.
Customers are starting to appear. American Electric Power, a big coal-burning utility that serves 2.9 million customers in seven states in the East and Midwest, has committed itself to buy 167,000 tons a year from KFx.
For American Electric, that is a drop in the coal bucket. As the nation's largest purchaser of coal, it buys about 58 million tons annually. Of that, about 10 million tons is lower-grade coal from the Powder River Basin and other mines in the West, and it wants to see if it would be economical to use the KFx fuel and to what extent it would cut pollution and carbon dioxide.
Even if controls are put on carbon dioxide, said Charles A. Ebotino Jr., the utility's senior vice president for fuel supply, "coal is going to be a large piece of the action."
At the KFx plant, things did not start off smoothly. A fire a year ago forced it to shut for repairs. An error by an engineer led to months of further delay and added cost.
The Venners, however, remain undaunted, convinced that the utility and coal industries will have to try out new technology.
"It's going to be a mixed bag of solutions," said Ted Venners, KFx's chairman. KFx's method for cleaning up coal before it is burned is only one of four basic approaches.
One process now becoming widespread is to suspend crushed coal on a jet of air and mix it with limestone; this cuts emissions of sulfur dioxide, which contributes to acid rain. This method also means the fuel burns more efficiently, reducing overall emissions.
The most common approach, though, is to treat the emissions after the coal is burned with expensive scrubbers to cut down on sulfur dioxide and particulate emissions.
There have also been efforts at coal gasification, in which coal is turned into a gas similar to natural gas. This gas is then used to run power plants. So far, however, the output of electricity is very small. Such approaches should increasingly come into play as utilities do all they can to keep their coal-fired capacity.
Just a few miles from the KFx plant is the Wyodak power plant, a prime example of why utilities are reluctant to phase out coal.
About 90 tons of coal, extracted from a strip mine next to the plant, are burned hourly to produce some of the nation's cheapest electricity.
The coal, often selling for less than $3 a ton and easily mined by huge power shovels, is expected to remain the backbone of many of the nation's power plants for decades to come.
The Wyodak plant is one of many owned by Pacificorp, a huge utility in Portland, Ore., that transmits power throughout the Northwest.
Pacificorp has $4.6 billion invested in its coal-fired plants. They produce power at an average of about 1.5 cents a kilowatt hour, one of the lowest levels in the nation.
"We work very hard to keep our costs low," said William Edmonds, a regional affairs administrator for the utility. "We operate our coal-fired plants at high capacity."
With deregulation opening major markets like California to competition, Pacificorp has geared up to be a big supplier of low-cost power. And coal is a vital part of its strategy.
It is such powerful forces that give Ted Venners the will to persevere in an industry that some perceive as on the way to extinction.
Driving his big Chevrolet truck along the highway on the way to the plant, he pointed to the rolling hills and said: "There's enough coal there for 200 to 300 years. It's so cheap to take it out of the ground."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1536 words

HEADLINE: For Clinton Health Care Planner, a New Drubbing

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
For more than two years, Ira C. Magaziner had managed to keep his head down.
Once a favorite target of Republicans, a symbol of White House overreaching and arrogance for his role in drafting an ultimately failed national health care plan, Mr. Magaziner, as gaunt, rumpled and intense as ever, had been laboring in studied obscurity, devising the Clinton Administration's approach to regulating the Internet. 
 The health care plan he once proposed would have remade one-seventh of the nation's economy. But in his second, quieter life in the White House, he championed industry self-regulation, urging President Clinton to let the Internet alone.
Then, two weeks ago, Mr. Magaziner's telephone rang at his home in Washington and plunged him back into the health care morass. How, a reporter wanted to know, did he respond to a Federal judge's ruling that less than two months into the Administration's first term, he submitted a dishonest affidavit about the health care planning?
Mr. Magaziner had thought that a United States attorney's inquiry into that matter had exonerated him more than two years ago.
"He was right on the verge of emerging as someone who was a serious player on a serious issue," one sympathetic White House official said of Mr. Magaziner's work on Internet policy, "and this thing was a blind-side tackle."
But his many critics outside the Administration were less surprised to see his health care work catch up with him. John E. Berthoud, president of the National Taxpayers Union, noted that the health care debate helped produce the Republican landslide in 1994 and changed Mr. Clinton's approach to governing and campaigning. So "it's not surprising," Mr. Berthoud said, "that there should be prolonged and profound effects on Ira Magaziner" as well.
Mr. Clinton is standing by Mr. Magaziner, who attended Oxford with him as a Rhodes scholar and participated with him over New Year's at Renaissance Weekend, in Hilton Head, S.C., the earnest annual gathering of policy makers, scholars and their groupies. (Mr. Magaziner helped lead a panel discussion there on "the 'wired' society.")
In a statement issued through an aide on Wednesday, the President said: "I've known Ira for 30 years. He's a good man. And he's doing a good job."
Mr. Magaziner, 50 years old, quiet and austere, stands out among the backslapping politicians at the White House. He rarely attends meetings of the senior staff these days, and when he does he almost never speaks. But within the White House he is seen as having done well with the Internet project, despite the shadow of the health care debacle.
"He continues to labor very quietly and very nonobtrusively," one official said, "so much so that there are times that he seems like Banquo's ghost, drifting back and forth."
Mr. Magaziner, senior adviser to the President for policy development, says that he offered to resign after the health care plan failed in 1994 but that Mr. Clinton asked him to stay. He went to work identifying ways to increase American exports, even as the lawsuit that would lead to the damaging judicial ruling two weeks ago began taking more of his time. Within the White House, he is seen as having been protected in particular by Hillary Rodham Clinton, whom he served as right-hand man in the health care effort.
He says he has been pleased with the reception given his work since health care.
"The health care thing, I obviously took a battering," he said. But with the Internet project, he continued, "I've been able to build a lot of positive relationships -- positive, even, news accounts and so on."
"And till this thing came on," he said of the judge's ruling, "I was feeling pretty good about the things I was able to do."
The case that produced that ruling is evocative of the heady early days of the Administration, when Mr. Clinton dreamed of creating more sweeping Government programs than he has sought since. Along with the First Lady, Mr. Magaziner was at the center, feverishly assembling a team of hundreds to expand Federal regulation of health care.
The project was an extraordinary opportunity for a self-assured policy disciple like Mr. Magaziner, who as a college student had persuaded Brown University to change its curriculum radically and as a business consultant had tried to convert Rhode Island, his home state, into a laboratory for his theories on industrial policy.
Mr. Magaziner and Mrs. Clinton tried to conduct their team's deliberations in secret, maintaining that confidentiality was the only way to keep the plan from being picked apart by interest groups before it was even completed. But that effort contributed to an appearance of high-handedness. One group sued the Government, arguing that because not all participants were Government employees, Federal law required that meetings of the health care planners be open to the public.
It was in response to that suit that Mr. Magaziner, on March 3, 1993, submitted his 13-page affidavit, a dense description of the Administration's planning stuffed with references to bodies like "the infrastructure/integrated health plans cluster." The affidavit described the role of outside consultants in that planning but, in what proved a fateful sentence, said, "Only Federal Government employees serve as members of the interdepartmental working group."
In December 1994, after discovery proceedings had produced numerous White House documents detailing the health care planning process, the judge, Royce C. Lamberth, called Mr. Magaziner's statement "misleading, at best." Judge Lamberth asked Federal prosecutors to investigate whether Mr. Magaziner had committed perjury or criminal contempt of court.
The resulting six-month inquiry was led by Eric H. Holder Jr., then a United States attorney and now Deputy Attorney General. In an 18-page filing with the court in August 1995, Mr. Holder wrote that he had found "no significant evidence" that Mr. Magaziner's declaration "was factually false, much less that it was willfully and intentionally so." He also said the contested sentence about the membership of the working group was not significant either to the Government's defense or to a related ruling that Judge Lamberth had issued earlier.
Mr. Holder criticized sloppy White House paperwork that, he said, had failed to document that people from the private sector had become Government employees to contribute to the health care project. And he was scathingly critical of White House lawyers, saying their failures had included not explaining how the health care planning system had changed after Mr. Magaziner's statement.
In a recent interview, Mr. Magaziner defended himself by noting pointedly that he was not a lawyer and saying he had relied on White House and Justice Department lawyers in creating the health care task force and in drafting his affidavit. That defense may pose problems for the lawyers who assisted him, notably Beth Nolan, a former deputy White House counsel who is awaiting Senate confirmation to head the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel.
Mr. Magaziner and other White House officials say they assumed that his legal troubles were over with Mr. Holder's filing. But on Dec. 18, Judge Lamberth weighed in for what he called "hopefully the final time," to determine penalties and attorneys' fees sought by the plaintiffs.
Where Mr. Holder had seen fuzzy language and sloppy paperwork, Judge Lamberth saw a deliberate effort by high-level Administration officials to deceive the court.
The judge called Mr. Magaziner's testimony "dishonest," but he was far more upset by what came later.
"The most outrageous conduct by the Government in this case is what happened when it never corrected or updated the Magaziner declaration," he wrote, declaring that the Government should be "accountable when its officials run amok."
Mr. Holder and Judge Lamberth had previously disagreed about the substance of Mr. Holder's filing. In a letter to the judge on Aug. 30, 1995, which was was supplied to a reporter by the White House, Mr. Holder wrote that on reviewing some of the court's comments about the investigation's results, he "became concerned" that he had not been clear enough. He repeated his findings, among them that there was no significant evidence that Mr. Magaziner had lied.
Although Judge Lamberth's broadside of Dec. 18 was directed at several officials, critics of the Administration have so far focused on Mr. Magaziner, arguing that he, and not taxpayers, should pay the penalty of $285,864.78 that the judge imposed on the Government. (The Justice Department is considering an appeal.)
Mr. Magaziner seems to regard the case as Lamberth v. Magaziner.
"I've been controversial in my life for my political views, that's fine, that's, you know, democracy," Mr. Magaziner said, speaking in staccato bursts. "But nobody, even opponents in the things I did before, ever questioned my integrity."
"And to have this judge come back and do this with no evidence," he said, makes him "livid."
Apparently embarrassed by the heat of his remarks, he added: "That's why I'm probably being too passionate. So I apologize. But this is just wrong."
