HEADLINE: Detroit Braces for the Rerun Of a Divisive Murder Trial

BYLINE: By JACK LESSENBERRY 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 1

 BODY:
Nearly five years ago, residents of Detroit were deeply divided by a highly publicized, racially charged trial in which two white police officers were accused of beating a black drug user to death.
The authorities here worried about the outcome and braced themselves for the possibility of riots like those that swept Los Angeles in April and early May 1992 after four white policemen were acquitted on all but one count in the beating of Rodney G. King, a black motorist, in March 1991; the beating was videotaped and shown on television newscasts. More than 50 people were killed and 2,000 injured in the weeklong riots. 
 But in August 1993, after months of testimony, the Detroit police officers, Walter Budzyn, 51, and Larry Nevers, 57, were found guilty of second-degree murder in the slaying of Malice Green, a 35-year-old unemployed steel worker, on Nov. 5, 1992. The officers were sentenced to long prison terms, and Detroit's streets remained calm.
Now the authorities here may face it all again. New trials have been ordered for both men. On Tuesday, Judge Lawrence P. Zatkoff of Federal District Court in Detroit overturned the verdict in the Nevers case, saying prejudicial pretrial publicity and errors during the proceedings, like allowing jurors to see the film "Malcolm X," which opens with video footage of the beating of Mr. King, prevented Mr. Nevers from getting a fair trial.
Five months ago, the Michigan Supreme Court similarly overturned the verdict against Mr. Budzyn, also citing the "Malcolm X" movie, along with the fact that information had been leaked to the jury stating that officials in Detroit, where a race riot in July 1967 left 43 people dead, were preparing for new disturbances if the former policeman was acquitted.
The court upheld the conviction of Mr. Nevers, however, on the ground that the evidence against him, unlike that against Mr. Budzyn, was overwhelming; Mr. Nevers had admitted striking Mr. Green, who died after being hit on the head with a heavy metal flashlight.
"I look forward to complete vindication," Mr. Nevers told reporters when he arrived at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on New Year's Eve for a reunion with his wife, Nancy, and daughter, Kelly. "I certainly look forward to a new trial if that's what it is going to be."
Asked if he might plead to a lesser crime, Mr. Nevers replied: "I'll never take a plea bargain, never. I might plead guilty to assault and battery, but that's it."
Today the Wayne County prosecutor, John O'Hair, said "absolutely not" when asked whether an assault-and-battery plea would satisfy him.
"The position of the prosecutor's office hasn't changed a bit," Mr. O'Hair said. "In this vast world of litigation, there are some cases that just have to be tried, and these fall into that category."
The prosecutor said he would meet with his staff to discuss appealing Judge Zatkoff's ruling to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati. If that fails, he said, he will press for a new trial for Mr. Nevers.
Mr. O'Hair also said he would vigorously contest the claim that the former policemen "couldn't get a fair trial in Wayne County."
Mr. Budzyn's new trial is to begin on Feb. 10. Although both men were tried together before separate juries in 1993, that is not likely this time, Mr. O'Hair said.
Judge Zatkoff said the 1993 trial should have been moved from Detroit because of the highly charged and prejudicial atmosphere. Indeed, Coleman A. Young, then Mayor of Detroit, said on television that Mr. Green "was literally murdered by the police." Mr. Young, Detroit's first black Mayor, granted a $5.25 million settlement for Mr. Green's family and dismissed the two policemen before any legal proceeding began.
Defending those actions, he said: "I was in no hurry to win back the riot championship of the world from Los Angeles. My charge was to convince the people of Detroit that I was on their side."
Despite the four and a half years that has elapsed since the first trial, the case still has a polarizing effect on Detroit, where nearly 80 percent of the city's one million residents are black and 90 percent of those who live in the city's suburbs are white.
A mostly suburban group, the Budzyn and Nevers Support Team, raised money for the former officers' appeals and tried unsuccessfully to defeat Mr. O'Hair for re-election in 1996 for prosecuting the case against the two men.
But in front of the boarded-up hair salon near where Mr. Green died, on Warren Avenue a few blocks from downtown Detroit, flowers are often placed before a chalk mural of the dead man.
On Wednesday, when news spread that Mr. Nevers was being released, dozens of people, some carrying signs, gathered at the site despite freezing weather and icy winds. "A Man Is Dead," one sign said. "Where Is the Justice?" asked another.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larry Nevers, a former Detroit policeman, boarding a flight to Detroit from Texas on Wednesday after his release from prison. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

South Korea Over a Hurdle To Stabilize Weak Economy
South Korea has cleared a crucial hurdle in its effort to stabilize its battered economy, paying off or extending a large portion of debt it owes foreign banks. 
 Still , the situation continues to look grim. The Government has asked citizens to donate any gold that they possess, like jewelry, to help the nation resolve the debt crisis. And in a New Year's address, President-elect Kim Dae Jung warned his people of "many unimaginable hardships" this year. Page A1.
 
New Russian Rubles Create Havoc
For the third time in less than a decade, the Russians have tried to revise their battered currency. Russia lopped three zeroes from all its rubles, creating a little confusion and new prices. A subway fare that cost 2,000 rubles on New Year's Eve now costs just 2. An American dollar, which on Wednesday bought 5,960 rubles, will not even buy 6 today. A4.
 
A Wine Venture Yields Little
A group of Napa Valley vintners invested $1.5 million in a Georgian Republic winery five years ago. Now they are discouraged and disillusioned, and do not expect to see any return on their capital. After the collapse of the Soviet Union it seemed that Georgia's wine industry had nowhere to go but up because Georgian wines enjoy a special cachet in Russia and much of Central Europe. But the Americans ran into conflicts with their partners. D2.
 
A Lackluster Fourth Quarter
The fourth quarter of 1997 will long be remembered for the decline in Southeast Asian markets and currencies. The yen fell 14.7 percent, but that still made it one of the best performers. Thailand kicked off the action, and ended the quarter with a 44.4 percent drop in the baht; Malaysia's ringgit declined 33.8 percent, and South Korea's won fell 42 percent. Stock markets in Europe and North America did not react to the turmoil in Asia until it reached Hong Kong in late October. Exchanges plummeted Oct. 27, rebounding the next day. Market Place. D3.
 
Product Samples Come Home
Marketers of packaged goods have always delivered samples directly to mailboxes of potential customers. But now they are selecting whose mailbox gets that product by identifying households by age or size or buying habits or wealth. Advertising. D4.
 
Exchange Fights Heart Attacks
The stress on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange as well as the poor diet, lack of exercise and frenetic jobs have caused many heart attacks. A defibrillator to revive victims is now on the exchange floor. D2.
 
Mortgage Rates Rise This Week
The rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose this week to an average 7.03 percent from 6.99 percent. The rate on 15-year mortgages rose to an average 6.61 percent. D3.
 
U.S. Markets Reopen
Financial markets in the United States will reopen today after being closed yesterday for New Year's Day. The New York Stock Exchange will observe a regular schedule, but the Treasury market and other United States markets will hold shortened sessions. Most overseas markets were closed yesterday and will remain closed today.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: THE AGENDA;
A Replay Of Themes That Won An Election

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Standing coatless at a turning point in his mayoralty yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani chose to take a customary path into his second term, reiterating the very issues that have proven so useful in propelling him to national prominence over the last four years.
Those who were elated with his first-term success at reducing crime, cutting taxes and moving people off welfare are likely to feel just as strongly about his second term, judging from the themes he chose to emphasize in his inaugural address. Those who were looking for firm indications that he would build on his popularity and move beyond the issues so closely identified with him may well be disappointed: the speech contained few details that would indicate a broadening of the mayoral agenda. 
 The Mayor said nothing new on issues that have long bedeviled him, such as education, housing and unemployment. He said the city's welfare centers would soon be known as "job centers," but did not explain how that would help the city to move welfare recipients into real work at a time when the Federal Government is requiring the city to slash its assistance rolls even further. There was no talk of government innovation or worker productivity.
With the city and the nation watching, he made a clear political decision to play to his strengths, providing plenty of words and one remarkable action about fighting crime. In the only major new initiative in the speech, he announced plans to hire an additional 1,600 police officers, bringing the size of the force to an unprecedented 40,000 at the very moment when crime is at its lowest point in decades. He acknowledged that action might seem counterintuitive to some people, but made it clear that law enforcement would remain his top priority.
"First and foremost as our city enters the 21st century, we have to build on what has worked for us, and what has turned us around," he said. "We have to continue to make this city safe and improve its quality of life."
New directions and fresh programs may yet emerge in subsequent speeches later this month; the Mayor has lately been carrying around what he says is a list of 62 undisclosed initiatives. By using his most carefully scrutinized address to focus on the familiar, he sent an unmistakable message to the city and to voters outside the five boroughs who may one day find him on their ballots: these are the themes that brought him to power, they worked and he has no intention of abandoning them now.
"Stay the course, don't change your style," said Peter J. Powers, the former First Deputy Mayor, explaining his old friend's thinking. "There are people who criticize his style, people who applaud it, but at the end of the day, it has produced results, and he has got to be what he is."
In the final weeks of his re-election campaign last year, Mr. Giuliani had begun talking about a broader vision, fully acknowledging what many black and Hispanic leaders had been telling him for years: his successes were not reaching the entire city and had in fact bypassed many communities. In his victory speech on election night, he said his second term would be dedicated to making sure that improvements reach everyone, including those so far left behind. He seemed to be saying that he wanted a legacy more expansive than just reducing crime.
He touched briefly on that goal yesterday, but did not emphasize it or provide details. Instead, he concentrated on the idea of changing the city not just for a few years, but in the long run.
Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's communications director, said he believes that the cumulative effect of his policies is to "liberate" New Yorkers from government dependency and other ills. "He's made so much progress, and now he's showing the courage to go in for the really big win," she said. "It's not just the battle, but for the whole war, really making things permanent."
In a city that routinely takes the wrecking ball to the stone monuments of its past, it is hard to imagine that any political agenda will truly remain a permanent fixture of New York. But as Mr. Giuliani demonstrated yesterday, the agenda is very likely to remain the permanent foundation of his career.

HEADLINE: Comfort vs. Style in Town Clash on Porches

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: WILSON, N.C., Dec. 30

 BODY:
All Deborah Thompson really has is time, and a place to spend it.
She lives in a tiny house in a part of town where the paint peels and the corner store still sells coal by the sack, and the funeral home is the nicest structure around. She does not have a social calendar, cable television, or a car. 
 What she has is a front porch that catches the weak winter sunlight just right, and an old chrome and vinyl couch where she can relax and watch life spin by, or at least as much of life as she can see from the corner of Carroll and Vance Streets.
"I watch the cars go by, and I say 'Hey,' " Ms. Thompson said, taking a rest from raking the dormant grass in her front yard. "I sit there to keep from sitting in the house. It gets lonely in the house."
She finds it hard to believe that, soon, that could be against the law here in Wilson, an image-conscious tobacco and factory town of 40,000 people located less than an hour east of Raleigh. It is not the porch that may be declared illegal, only her choice of furniture.
In what many people here see as a clash of the classes and an assault on the amiable rhythms of Southern life, the City of Wilson is expected sometime early this year to ban old sofas and other indoor furniture from porches and yards. Southern historians see that proposed ban as an attack on a tradition that predates Naugahyde.
For generations, some Southerners, unwilling to throw away a perfectly usable piece of furniture just because of a few rips or stains, have made room for new couches and chairs by dragging the old ones outside. Like some old dog that can no longer hunt, the yellow plaid loveseats and sagging Barcaloungers live out a few, last years on the porch.
Often, the people who carry on this tradition cannot afford wicker or other fancy outdoor "patio" furniture, furniture favored by the gentility.
"This must be the ultimate yuppiefication of the South, to ban porch furniture," said Dan Carter, professor of Southern history at Emory University in Atlanta.
While such a move may make a neighborhood more cosmetically presentable, removing such traditions can perhaps, Professor Carter believes, help destroy one, by hampering the way people in a community interact.
As in most such confrontations between the classes, the poor people are expected to lose.
"This is not junk," the 33-year-old Ms. Thompson said, pointing to her sofa. But the idea that the sight of it would offend anyone does not seem to anger her nearly so much as it puzzles her.
It is the same on Viola Street, where Elizabeth Best sat reading a book in her overstuffed chair, and on Oak Street, where Carlos Andrades stood near some old furniture watching his nephews play in the yard, and on Woodard Avenue, where William Riggins shared his porch with a crippled recliner. People here say they will comply with the ordinance if it passes -- no one wants to have to pay a fine over a 20-year-old La-Z-Boy -- but they see it as one more instance of the rich and powerful telling the powerless how to live their lives.
"They don't want to drive by it," Moses Scriven said as he tried to get a reluctant chain saw to crank over on Vance Street. "We don't have the power that the people with money have. It's aggravating, but there's nothing to be done about it."
"They've been trying to make Wilson a model community," Mr. Scriven said, even if that means "stopping us from enjoying what little bit we have. They can afford to buy something for their porches."
City officials in Wilson, including the town's Planning Director, Jim Bradshaw, have emphasized that the porch ordinance is just part of a series of new housing measures intended to improve the overall quality of life in the town, and they deny that it is a battle between the classes.
"This is not one side telling the other what to do," Mr. Bradshaw said. "At least I don't see it that way."
The proposed ban on indoor furniture outdoors is "just another tool to bring about improvements to the neighborhood," he said, "whether it's an abandoned vehicle or indoor furniture all over the yard. They all contribute to the blight of the neighborhood."
Blacks and whites alike support the ordinance, he said, including some people who live in the neighborhoods -- mostly black people and Hispanic migrant workers -- most affected by the proposed ban.
But poorer residents here, the ones with the indoor furniture on their porches, say that the ordinance would not affect upper middle class people, that wealthier blacks support the move but that poorer ones just want to be left alone.
It all began last spring, when the Wilson Appearance Commission, an interracial panel, recommended that the indoor furniture, prone to get water-logged and moldy when rain blows in under the eaves, amounted to a public nuisance.
It was also suggested that the furniture represented a health hazard, giving rats and fleas a place to breed.
"There could be some family health problems from the weatherization of the couch," said Mr. Bradshaw, who is admittedly sensitive to the attention his town's proposed ban on the furniture has drawn.
Others here echo his explanation of why the indoor furniture must go, and these are the people who make up the committees that will consider the proposal before it becomes law.
"People who say I want to keep my couch are looking at it from a very narrow perspective," said Sarah Rasino, a member of the Wilson Appearance Committee and a cosmetologist at Redken Laboratory. "Those become weather-beaten, and I don't think there's anything pretty about that."
But to other people here, the ban flies in the face of common sense. In others, it pricks their pride.
"Why are they messing with poor black folks around here?" Mr. Andrades asked. "Why don't they deal with the real issues?"
That is what Mr. Carter, the Emory professor, is wondering.
"There's nothing more inviting than an old front seat from a 1957 Chevrolet sitting on a front porch," he said, and while he laughed as he said it, he was not kidding about the symbolism that such things hold down here.
"I think people have totally gone berserk," he said. "Think about all the things we need to be concerned about: 50 million people with no health insurance and 30 percent of minority children in this country living in poverty, and what are we concerned about? We're concerned about banning porch furniture."
Wilson is conscious of its image, but in that it is little different from most towns.
Travelers coming into town from the east, from the flat, muddy tobacco fields dotted with tumble-down drying sheds, are greeted by a sign welcoming them to "Wilson, a community committed to educational excellence, economic growth and cultural fulfillment." A sign just down the road announces the Carl B. Renfro Bridge, even though all it crosses is railroad tracks. Most small towns do not name their overpasses.
On Raleigh Road, the main drag coming into town, the road is lined here and there with beautiful, towering homes, with red brick and massive white columns.
But just a few blocks away, Mexican migrant workers live in houses that are little better than shacks, and elderly black women heat houses with coal-burning stoves.
It is in neighborhoods like these where the people use indoor furniture in their outdoor lives.
"My grandma has me drag her big chair out every weekend," so she can visit with passers-by, said Mr. Scriven, who drives a fork-lift in a tobacco warehouse. On Sunday night, he drags the chair back in again. His grandma does not visit much during the week.
It is much easier to disappear inside, to music or videos, if there is not a soft place to sit outside, people here said. It is more important to the poor, because, as entertainment goes, it is about as cheap as it gets. Talking does not cost anything.
City officials in Wilson have made it clear that they are not banning porches, only indoor furniture on them. But for people here, and elsewhere in the South, the furniture is part of that culture.
"I hate to make it sound like banning porch sofas is going to be an act of community destruction," Professor Carter said, "but I think it's totally consistent with it. That is, that people who would propose such a thing have no sense that this is something worth keeping or valuable at all. I'm making this sound like social science. It's not. It's just friends and neighbors."
What it all boils down to, in Wilson, is that there are two distinct Souths, two distinct ideas of what is tradition, what is not.
To Ms. Rasino, there is "nothing Southern" about a ratty sofa, water-logged and leaking cotton ticking.
To Ms. Thompson, "it's how I get to know people in my neighborhood."
John Shelton Reed, a professor of sociology at the University of North Carolina, says it is the sitting, not what one is sitting on, that makes it a Southern thing.
"I've got a sister in northern Vermont, and if the weather allowed it, I'm sure her neighbors would" sit on their porches, visiting, Professor Reed said. "But there's not much point in it, in Vermont."
But Mr. Carter sees the indoor furniture as a part of the South's past that, however tasteless it might seem to some, is still superior to the rigid gentrification that seems to be its future. Houses in new, planned communities are being built with porches, to promote that sense of community, but custom, zoning and the simple fact that those new houses will be occupied by more affluent people will probably mean that only wicker and other tasteful outdoor furniture will be used.
Meanwhile, Southern towns and cities continue to be eaten up with garish neon strip developments.
"I find nothing more depressing than to ride down one of the strip streets with thousands of neon signs," Mr. Carter said. "I think that is ugliness on a mass scale. I have much less objection to individual, idiosyncratic 'tastelessness.' "
Ms. Thompson knows her vinyl couch is not beautiful, but nor, as she said, is it junk. It is only a place to sit on the warm days and wave at cars.

HEADLINE: Hurdles Ahead for South Korea

 BODY:
Two events this week may help South Korea climb out of its financial hole. Large private banks in the United States, Europe and Japan agreed to let Korean banks and business firms postpone repayment of their overseas loans. These banks might even agree to extend new loans. If the agreement holds, it will ease South Korea's repayment burden, thereby eliminating an immediate threat of default.
Separately, the South Korean Parliament agreed to stiffen oversight of its banking sector in line with conditions imposed by the International Monetary Fund in exchange for a $57 billion bailout. The vote reassures foreign investors that internal politics will not scuttle the fund-led bailout. 
 These events do not guarantee South Korea that it can avoid default or escape serious recession. But finally, some of the news from South Korea is good.
The decision by the large banks to roll over short-term loans was hardly altruistic. They knew full well that had they collectively demanded repayment, South Korea would have run out of dollars and defaulted -- imposing huge losses on them and, in the bargain, freezing South Korea out of international capital markets. But by giving South Korea the time to recover, they can expect to retrieve most, if not all, of their original investment.
Three hurdles remain in South Korea's way. Some small overseas banks are refusing to join in the deal negotiated by the large banks. The small banks are threatening to grab their money while, they hope, their larger peers are stuck propping up shaky Korean borrowers. If this continues, the agreement could unravel. Western governments will need to pressure all banks to go along. Meanwhile, the large overseas banks are pressuring the Korean Government to take responsibility for repaying the foreign loans to its private sector. This is a bad idea that would bury Seoul in debt that could take decades to repay. The large banks have enough incentive to roll over their loans without government guarantees. Besides, Korean acquiescence would send a destructive signal to foreign investors that Seoul stands ready to bail them out of reckless loans.
The final hurdle is the fund-imposed bailout. Its conditions clamp down hard on the economy and threaten to shove it into recession. The fund's terms need to be eased. The bailout agreement was supposed to reassure foreign investors that their Korean loans would be secure. But who wants to invest in an economy that is headed for the tank? So far individual investors continue to withdraw their money, the exchange rate continues to plummet, domestic banks refuse to make loans and unemployment has begun to take off.
The monetary fund says that its program will only slow economic growth, from about 6 percent a year to under 3 percent. But fund estimates have seriously erred in Argentina, Bulgaria and, most recently, Thailand. The fund promises to remain vigilant and renegotiate terms if the Korean economy needs resuscitation. That is a promise that the United States and South Korea's other trading partners ought to make sure it fulfills.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
It was a quartarius horribilis for Asian stocks but a wash in America and Europe.

BYLINE: By Patrick J. Lyons 

 BODY:
What do Pacific Rim investors and New York Giants football fans have in common? They both should have headed for the parking lot after the third quarter.
 Or maybe skipped the game entirely this year. While the North American and European exchanges ran up big leads in the first three quarters (as did the Giants on Saturday), Asian stocks were flat or sliding all year. 
Then came the horrific fourth quarter. Japan's decline of only 14.7 percent in yen terms through Dec. 30 made it one of the Asian league leaders, while some Southeast Asian markets were losing from a fifth to nearly half their value. (And the Giants lost their playoff game.)
 Most of the damage was done by currency crises that swept the region, imperiling creditworthiness and undermining investor confidence.
 Beginning in Thailand and then ricocheting through Malaysia, Indonesia and South Korea, speculators bet that overextended national treasuries and highly leveraged banking sectors would be unable to withstand runs on currencies pegged to the dollar or kept within a limited band.
 Hong Kong managed to hold its own against the speculators and keep its currency peg intact, but its stock market was sent wildly gyrating with each new day's headlines and finished the year off by nearly a third from Sept. 30 levels.
 Simultaneous sharp falls in exchange rates and stock prices became a double whammy for foreign investors in Pacific Rim stocks. In dollar terms, more than half the value of Indonesian, Korean and Thai stocks was wiped out in the quarter, and Malaysian stocks did little better.
 Stock markets in Europe and North America showed little reaction to the Asian turmoil until it reached Hong Kong in late October, and then woke up with a start. Exchanges around the world plummeted on Oct. 27, only to rebound the next day. In the industrialized West, most stock markets regained by the end of the year nearly all the ground lost in the October plunge, but developing countries were rarely so lucky. Some, like Brazil, were plagued by fears that they were next on the currency speculators' hit lists and were whipsawed by events in Asia to the end of the year.
 American stocks posted a modest gain on the quarter, as did stocks in several major European markets measured in local currency. Others saw small losses, and nearly all were off in dollar terms.
 Results for smaller European markets varied from weakness in Sweden and Finland, which were hurt by Asian turmoil, to continued strength in Russia and Turkey, where investor enthusiasm has been buoyant all year.

HEADLINE: Call Us Unpredictable

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris is a social psychologist and the author of "The Mismeasure of Woman."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Not long ago, while momentarily suffering from end-of-century fever, I agreed to give a talk on "sex and gender in the next millennium." Of course the assignment was preposterous, considering how dramatically the rules of sexuality have changed in this century alone.
Who, in 1897, could have predicted Dennis Rodman, Madonna, sex-chat rooms on the Internet, muscled women running marathons and ponytailed men changing diapers? Who could have predicted the pill, cloning, the gay rights movement, legions of women entering business, politics and the military, and legions of Christian men marching on Washington, promising to be faithful and also to wash the dishes? 
 Nowadays it's hard to make predictions for the next year, let alone for the next 1,000. Most turn out flat wrong because we extrapolate the future from the way things are now, unable to imagine the event or discovery that will change the world.
At the end of the last century, for instance, city planners in New York predicted that traffic would soon come to a standstill. There would be far too many horses, and too many tons of horse manure, for anyone to be able to move. Throughout history, many experts who should have known better have likewise succumbed to the temptation to predict.
In 1895, Lord Kelvin, president of the Royal Society in England, said, "Heavier-than-air flying machines are impossible."
In 1929, Irving Fisher, professor of economics at Yale, said, "Stocks have reached what looks like a permanently high plateau."
In 1958, Thomas J. Watson, the chairman of I.B.M., said, "I think there is a world market for about five computers."
And my all-time favorite: In 1899, Charles H. Duell, Commissioner of the Federal Office of Patents, proposed that the office be closed, on the ground that "everything that can be invented has been invented."
Predictably, predictions haven't improved over time. According to the Skeptical Inquirers annual review of New Year's predictions by psychics, 1997 was supposed to be the year that Mick Jagger became a member of Parliament, Congress suspended the baseball season after a brawl left dozens of people dead or wounded, Hillary Clinton got pregnant again, and Rush Limbaugh became a liberal Democrat after talking with Barbra Streisand.
Considering these dud forecasts, I sometimes think the only thing anyone can predict with confidence is that human beings will continue making predictions, because we are a naturally anxious and insecure species that wants to know what the future holds.
Today, especially, the world seems to be spinning out of control. How are we supposed to fight the impersonal corporate decisions that affect our daily lives, when we can't even cope with the those infernal voice-mail menus? No wonder so many people seek to restore a sense of control over life by reaching for the simplified explanations and forecasts provided by demagogues, gurus, psychics and pseudoscientists.
Even sophisticated urbanites are not immune. Last year, an article in Smithsonian magazine reported that hundreds of New Yorkers and other "urban New Agers" were using dowsing rods to decide "everything from stock market buys to whether they should respond to an ad in the 'Personals.' " If New Yorkers are dowsing for stocks and dates, we can be sure that anxiety about money and love is up (and scientific literacy is down).
Pseudoscientific predictions are more appealing than the sober predictions of science for two reasons. First, pseudoscientists speak in the reassuring tones of certainty: This will happen. Scientists speak in the annoying language of probability: It is likely that this will happen.
Most scientific predictions apply to groups or trends, not individuals or specific events. Thus, scientists can predict with great accuracy that smoking will increase the likelihood of earlier death, but they cannot predict that any given smoker will get lung cancer. But most individuals want to know what, specifically, will happen to them. Science can't say.
Second, pseudoscientific predictions are appealing because they are based on intuition, faith, compelling anecdote or individual experience. That makes them as unreliable as guessing, although they seem accessible, personal and dramatic. Scientists rely on statistical probabilities derived from objective evidence. That makes their predictions often highly accurate, although they seem tentative, remote and encumbered with qualifications.
Of course, it's harmless and fun to make silly predictions at the end of every year. But the larger question -- on what basis should we make predictions for ourselves and believe those made by others? -- is serious, because it affects so many decisions, big and small, that we make about our lives.
Perhaps the major difference between scientists and pseudoscientists is that the former know what they can't predict, whereas the latter will predict anything you ask them to. On that note, care to join me in making any predictions about sex and gender in the next millennium?

HEADLINE: Prof. Richard Allen Lester, 89, Expert in Wage and Labor Issues

 BODY:
Richard Allen Lester, an economist who specialized in wage and labor issues, and a dean of the faculty, emeritus, at Princeton University, died on Tuesday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 89.
Professor Lester is known for his basic research in wage determination and minimum wages in the 1940's. One early theory, called the "range theory of wages," offered an alternative to the prevailing view that workers in similar jobs were paid the same wages. Professor Lester said that one implication of his theory was that because wages were indeterminate an increase in the minimum wage would not necessarily result in reduced employment. 
 Professor Lester also studied the labor movement, unemployment and employment discrimination. His textbooks include the "Economics of Labor" (1941) and "Labor and Industrial Relations" (1951).
During World War II, Professor Lester served on the National War Labor Board and the War Manpower Commission and in the Office of the Secretary of War. His role as Government adviser and mediator continued throughout his career. He was an arbitrator, under the Railway Labor Act, of labor disputes involving the locomotive engineers' union in 1954 and 1961.
Professor Lester advised the Kennedy Administration on employment, wage and labor issues, and served on several Federal and state advisory boards.
Professor Lester earned a bachelor's degree at Yale University in 1929 and his Ph.D. in economics in 1936 at Princeton University. He taught at the University of Washington and Duke University before returning to Princeton in 1945. Starting in 1948, he served several terms as chairman of the economics department; from 1966 to 1968, he was an associate dean and the director of the graduate program at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton.
In 1969, he became dean of the faculty, where he worked to attract women and minority candidates to the faculty. He retired in 1974, when he was named dean emeritus.
Professor Lester is survived by his wife, Doris N., of Hightstown; two daughters, Margaret L. Wing of Mendham, N.J. and Harriet L. Tarver of Atlanta; a son, Robert A., of Charlottesville, Va.; a brother, John W., of Hamburg, N.Y., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Portfolio Manager Quits a Russian Fund, Best Performer in 1997

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The best-performing mutual fund of 1997, the Lexington Troika Dialog Russia fund, has lost one of its two lead portfolio managers, signaling further turmoil at the Moscow-based company that oversees the popular fund.
Nancy Herring, who began managing the $140 million fund in late 1996, resigned on Thursday because of what she called a contractual dispute, conflicts of interest among members of the portfolio management team and her own discomfort at the new owner's plans for Troika Dialog, the brokerage and asset management company that guides the fund's investment portfolio. 
 Ms. Herring, previously chief investment officer for Troika Dialog, is the third senior executive to resign since the Bank of Moscow agreed to buy the company in October. Peter Derby, chairman, founder and majority owner of Troika Dialog, resigned after selling his interest in the company to the Bank of Moscow, whose majority owner is the Moscow municipal government. The same month, Sergei Zenkin resigned as head of investment banking to join Merrill Lynch as its director of investment banking in Moscow.
The latest defection could create uncertainty in the United States for Lexington Troika's shareholders and for the Lexington Management Company, the Saddle Brook, N.J., company that helps to manage the fund and that oversees its marketing to American investors. The Lexington Troika fund has been one of the few bright spots recently among Lexington's lineup of about 15 stock and bond mutual funds.
Lawrence Kantor, a managing director at Lexington, said yesterday that Ms. Herring was "part of a team" that oversaw the fund's portfolio. Because "other members of the team continue to be in place," he said, the fund's operations should not be affected by her resignation.
But fund analysts say that specialists in emerging markets like Russia can often be hard to replace.
The Lexington Troika fund gained 67.4 percent last year, making it the top performer among the 4,700 mutual funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. for the tables that appear in The New York Times. Most of those gains were compiled in last year's first three quarters, during which the fund produced a total return for investors of more than 130 percent.
In the final three months of 1997, however, as emerging markets weakened around the world in the wake of the Asian currency crisis, the Lexington Troika fund lost nearly one-quarter of its value. And because two-thirds of the fund's investors bought their shares in the third quarter, after the fund compiled its gains, most of the fund's shareholders have lost money on their investments despite the fund's stellar record.
In an interview from Buenos Aires, where she was vacationing, Ms. Herring said she was unable to reach agreement on an employment contract with Troika Dialog after the brokerage firm's new management made "changes unacceptable to me" in the makeup of the firm's executive committee. In addition, Ms. Herring said, she had "ongoing concerns" about potential conflicts of interest at the firm.
Specifically, she said, "difficult issues of conflicts of interest" were created by Gavin Rankin, who, in addition to being listed in the fund's prospectus as co-lead manager of the Lexington Troika fund, served as director of research for the Troika Dialog brokerage firm.
As co-manager of the fund's portfolio, Mr. Rankin would be partly responsible for choosing investments for the fund, while as research director for the brokerage firm, he was responsible for recommending investments for brokerage clients. Those roles could come into conflict if the fund's investment decisions overlapped with those of the brokerage firm's big clients.
Mr. Rankin gave up the brokerage job last month, according to a supplement to the fund's prospectus filed on Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Ms. Herring said the potential conflict of the two roles had led her for most of last year to try to limit Mr. Rankin's involvement in choosing investments for the portfolio. Recently, however, Mr. Rankin has taken a more active role in the fund, while still working for the brokerage firm.
Changes have apparently been afoot at the fund for some months, although shareholders would have been hard pressed to realize it. The fund's most recent prospectus, filed with the S.E.C. in May, lists Ms. Herring and Mr. Rankin each as a "lead manager" of the fund, but a proxy statement filed in November gives only Mr. Rankin that title, naming Ms. Herring as one of two "other members of the portfolio management team."
In addition, the proxy statement lists Richard M. Hisey, a managing director at Lexington, as "portfolio strategist" for the fund; previously, he had been an adviser on Russian affairs to the fund's directors.
Ms. Herring said she was unaware of the changes in her title contained in the proxy statement. She added that she was primarily responsible for the fund's performance last year. "I made all of the decisions on the fund," she said. "The likelihood that any of the others knew even 20 percent of what was in the fund is in question. Their only interaction with the management of the portfolio was retrospective -- my catching them up on what I was doing and what things were likely to be like going forward."
Mr. Kantor, of Lexington, disagreed. "Nancy did a good job, but I don't think any one person was responsible for the success of the fund," he said. In addition, he said any potential conflicts of interest were resolved when Mr. Rankin gave up the brokerage position. Mr. Rankin could not be reached; Troika Dialog's offices in Moscow were closed for the year-end holiday.
Tricia O. Rothschild, international funds editor for Morningstar Mutual Funds, a publication of the Chicago fund-tracking company, said that investors should take note when any of the primary managers of an emerging markets fund resigns.
"The company can't go out and easily find another manager who has a lot of experience following equities in Russia," Ms. Rothschild said. It is worth noting, however, she added, that in young markets like Russia, "broad market movements often play more of a role than individual stock picks" by a portfolio manager.

HEADLINE: Crisis in Asia and Rail Delays Hurt Manufacturing in December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz., Jan. 2

 BODY:
Manufacturing activity slowed in December as the economic crisis in Asia and rail traffic delays in the United States hurt orders and production, a report released today showed.
The report, compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Management, said that the industry group's main index declined to 52.5 last month, the lowest reading since January 1997, from 54.4 in November. Analysts had expected the index to decline during December, but only to a level of about 54. 
 A reading of 50 or more indicates that manufacturing is expanding.
As 1997 ended, manufacturers were wary about the economic outlook and concerned about "weakening in new orders, the strength in the dollar, Asian demand and railroad delays," said Norbert Ore, chairman of the association's survey committee and an executive of the Sonoco Products Company, which makes packaging products.
Slowing economies in Asia are curbing demand for exports from the United States. At the same time, the dollar's strength against Asian currencies, and other currencies, has made American products more expensive in terms of those currencies.
In this country, problems continue to plague the nation's largest freight railroad, the Union Pacific Corporation. Last Tuesday, Union Pacific said that delivery delays lengthened for a second consecutive week as crew shortages offset efforts to resolve a six-month freight logjam.
Delays on the line are the worst in more than 25 years, costing retailers, manufacturers, mines and agricultural shippers more than $100 million a month, according to recent testimony before a Government panel.
Today's report also said that the association's price index fell to 50.3 in December from 51.9 during November, indicating that inflation remained under control.

HEADLINE: Dollar Is Broadly Higher; Asia Fears Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to its best level against the Japanese yen in more than five and a half years yesterday and ended sharply higher in other foreign-exchange dealings, strengthening on the first trading day of 1998 amid fears over Asian economies.
"The dollar is being sought across the board," said Stephen Flanagan, chief dealer at Erste Bank. 
 The dollar also rose to a nearly four-month high against the German mark and reached a two-week high against the British pound.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar traded at 132.55 yen, up from 130.42 yen, its highest level since May 1992. Financial markets in the United States were closed on Thursday for New Year's Day. The dollar sold for 1.8043 marks, up from 1.7987 marks, the highest settlement price since Sept. 9. It rose against the pound, which fetched $1.6440, down from $1.6517 on Wednesday.
Weaker Asian currencies fell further, and the growing problems of the Asians -- which are important Japanese trading partners -- added to the market's already deep worry about Japan's prospects for reviving its economy. "The yen is continuing to gain a confidence problem," Mr. Flanagan said.
Dealings were thin as Japanese financial markets were closed for a holiday, Exchange Day, and trading rooms in Europe and New York remained lightly staffed. But dealers said the dollar was likely to quickly move higher even when markets returned to a full pace on Monday.
The dollar's strength against the mark and other European currencies partly reflected lingering worries about the planned European common currency.
Traders said the dollar also retained some momentum from comments on Wednesday by the president of Germany's central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, that seemed to dim prospects for higher European interest rates before the the single currency is instituted in a year. Higher rates tend to increase the demand for a currency.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 3; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 2023 words

HEADLINE: How a Marxist Hotbed Eased Right;
Recalling New York's Intellectual Life as Contact Sport

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK; David Margolick is a contributing editor at Vanity Fair.

 BODY:
"I became radical because I thought I had good reason to become radical. I became liberal because I thought I had good reason to become liberal. And then I became conservative because I thought I had good reason to be conservative. It seems to me perfectly natural."
That is how Irving Kristol describes his ideological odyssey, one that took him from the left-wing hothouse of City College of New York in the late 1930's to the center of the Reagan revolution four decades later. Three other Jewish sons of New York's poorest neighborhoods and City College, Nathan Glazer, Daniel Bell and Irving Howe, took similar journeys at the same time on the same ideological subway from left to right, though each hopped off well before Mr. Kristol did. The stories of these four men, of the extraordinary intellectual milieu they occupied and how they evolved within it, all while looking over their shoulders at one another, are told in Joseph Dorman's documentary, "Arguing the World." The film opens Wednesday at the Film Forum, 19 stops south on the IRT Broadway local from their alma mater. 
 All four men were the products of a vanished intellectual era in New York, a time when ideas were debated ferociously, when politics was more than a spectator sport, when what happened in Madrid or Moscow reverberated around Union Square and the Upper West Side. Their careers encompassed and were shaped by the epochal events of their generation: World War II, the McCarthy era, the student protests of the 1960's, Vietnam, the Reagan era. Three of them evolved from fringe leftists to centrist or right-wing figures; through their scholarly work and in magazines like The New Leader, Commentary, Dissent and The Public Interest, all remained vitally interested in what governments can and cannot do, should and should not be.
Fellow film buffs warned Mr. Dorman that most documentaries about ideas are deadly. Even Mr. Howe, who died in 1993, had his doubts. "How could a film about us possibly be of any interest to anyone?" he asked during the shooting. Watching these men at their word processors is, in fact, not very exciting, but recalling their intellectual interactions with one another and what was happening around them -- how their theories coincided or collided with reality -- is. So is the novelty of their bygone world, along with their intelligence, charm and occasional contrition. "There were so many ideas to cover that the film constantly threatened to fly out of control," said Mr. Dorman, who has produced several previous documentaries for public television. The welfare state, Marxism and Stalinism, and the useful and destructive forms of social action were the leitmotifs of their lives.
"Arguing the World" opens with newsreel clips from City College circa 1936. Against the backdrop of the school's familiar Gothic castles (fabricated, appropriately enough, from schist dug up during the construction of the nearby subway) are hoards of earnest-looking, dark-haired and bespectacled young men in jackets and ties milling, laughing, talking, eating, hamming it up, waving banners. "Schools, Not Battleships," states one. "Down With Imperialist War," proclaims another. On the soundtrack is the simulated hum of intense conversation plus nerve-jangling modernist music signaling what Mr. Howe described as the "atmosphere of perfervid, overly heated, overly excited intellectuality" that then characterized the campus.
 
The Excitement Was in the Cafeteria
 For the most part, education at City College took place not in class but in the cafeteria, more specifically in particular corners of the cafeteria, where students, self-divided by ethnicity and politics, ate brown-bag lunches and argued endlessly about politics and everything else. "It became a kind of heder," said Mr. Bell, referring to Jewish religious schools built around disputation. Shaped by poverty and economic calamity, hungering to escape their claustrophobic ghettos but retaining Jewish notions of justice, having little sense of themselves as Americans, the four young men were drawn to left-wing ideology. They were divided only over whose Marxist vision held out the prospect of the most glorious future.
Some, including the four men portrayed in the film, frequented what was known as Alcove 1, the domain of radical leftists disillusioned with Stalin's Soviet Union: Trotskyists, Lovestonites, socialists. The far more heavily populated Alcove 2 next door belonged to card-carrying Communists and fellow travelers. "Someone made the wisecrack that the only place where the fight between Stalin and Trotsky could be conducted freely was in New York City," recalled Mr. Howe. In fact, the two groups loathed each other and rarely interacted; the divide was literary as well as political. "We prided ourselves on reading Joyce and Thomas Mann and Proust -- maybe not completely, but at least dipping in -- whereas they were reading palookas like Howard Fast," Mr. Howe said.
World War II made such distinctions irrelevant, at least for a time. It also helped transform all of the men into Americans, which in turn helped transform their ideas and politics. Two of them, Mr. Howe and Mr. Kristol, became soldiers, exposing them to the world beyond the five boroughs. "I was a New York Jewish kid," Mr. Kristol recalled. "I didn't know anything about America. I didn't know anything about most ordinary people." They, along with Mr. Bell and Mr. Glazer, saw a new side of the United States; a country that fought Fascism was one to which they could truly belong.
The process of assimilation only accelerated after the war, when they began to enjoy the fruits of American capitalism. Suddenly, miraculously (at least to him), Mr. Kristol could afford to own a car, get married and move into Manhattan ("The City," as it was then known) rather than live with his in-laws. Of the four, only Mr. Howe remained an unreconstructed leftist. The others moved right, particularly as the Soviets occupied Eastern Europe and more about Stalin's atrocities became known.
 
Tough Choices And Consequences
 Their thoughts, bandied about in the soirees of Partisan Review, were lofty, but they sometimes involved tough choices and tougher consequences that are rarely seen today. During the McCarthy era, when political demagogues and opportunists championed a more primitive version of the anti-Communism they had long espoused, Mr. Kristol, Mr. Bell and Mr. Glazer were forced to weigh competing principles: their hatred and fear of Soviet Communism and their professed civil libertarianism. More often than not, the former concerns prevailed: they said little when fellow leftists lost their jobs, fled the country or worse.
Nearly 50 years later, Mr. Kristol, still convinced that these liberals merely paid the price for their naivete, is unapologetic. "I referred to McCarthy as a vulgar demagogue," he said. "I thought that was enough." Mr. Bell contends that when Congressional investigators asked the writers, artists and academics they had summoned before them whether they had ever been Communists, they should have fessed up rather than fudged. For Mr. Glazer, it isn't so easy. Throughout "Arguing the World" he is an ebullient spirit, laughing easily amid his memories. But asked about the McCarthy era, he pauses, shakes his head slowly and bites his lower lip. "Even at the time and also in retrospect we never managed to figure out a good position, one that was respectable and moral and responsive to all the complicated issues raised," he says in an affecting moment. "I still don't think we have one."
Former radicals are forever being faulted for selling out, for abandoning their principles, for ceasing to remain radical enough. That is what Mr. Howe, in the mid-1950's, accused his colleagues of doing, forsaking their principles for an uncritical patriotism and conformity. "I lived in the same building with Irving Howe; talk about conformism," countered Mr. Kristol, whose omnipresent cigarette seems as dated as his one-time Marxism. "What was I conforming to? To what? I could never get an answer to that question."
In fact, in their time and place, these men may not have been very radical at all. Among the Jewish students at City College in the 1930's, Republicans were rarer than passenger pigeons; Karl Marx would have gotten far more votes than Alf Landon or Wendell Willkie. Rarely did these men venture beyond the world of ideas. Their notion of direct action seems to have consisted of cutting class; when they took to the streets, it was usually to head to a bookstore. Barely 20 years later, immersed in their cerebral lives, seeing universities as sacred sanctuaries, strikingly forgetful of their own romantic student days, they had little tolerance for the more strident protests of the next generation.
 
Dancing Activists, Armchair Liberals
 As moderate as the Free Speech Movement in Berkeley, Calif., came to seem (its leaders wore coats and ties to protests and did Israeli folk dancing while occupying the school's administration building) and as legitimate as its grievances were (until then, political protests on campus had been banned), Mr. Glazer, then a member of the Berkeley faculty, still condemns what he called their "enthusiastic and euphoric rejection of forms and norms." To Jackie Goldberg, then a student activist, now a member of the Los Angeles City Council, Mr. Glazer and his ilk were control freaks. "The liberalism they espoused was an armchair intellectual liberalism," she told Mr. Dorman. To them, "protesting" was sending a letter to a Congressman.
A few years later, Mr. Bell, teaching at Columbia, tried to negotiate with the students who had shut down the university. When that failed and the police came in, he walked home to Riverside Drive -- and cried. Mr. Howe, editor of Dissent, remained spiritually closest to the new crop of protesters. But a summit meeting off Central Park West between Dissent editors and the leaders of Students for a Democratic Society, led by Tom Hayden, proved disastrous. "They didn't appear to be doing anything," Mr. Hayden recalls. To Mr. Howe, meanwhile, Mr. Hayden conjured up the very figure he'd most loathed. "We could see the commissar in him, and that put us off," he says.
 
Speaking in Sadness, Speaking With Glee
 In The Public Interest and in their own academic work, Mr. Glazer, Mr. Bell and Mr. Kristol outlined their skepticism about the Great Society and liberal government in general. But still resolved to make a flawed philosophy work better, Mr. Glazer and Mr. Bell speak with sadness in the film; Mr. Kristol, who was a member of the Young People's Socialist League, speaks with glee. In the end, Mr. Glazer and Mr. Bell remained Democrats; Mr. Kristol enlisted with Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan, championed the religious right, condemned liberalism and embraced the free market. To his critics, he had come full circle, abandoning one orthodoxy for another.
"The fact that we were together 50 years ago doesn't stir the faintest touch of sentiment in me," Mr. Howe said of Mr. Kristol. "I wish him well personally -- a long life with many political failures, I hope." For his part, Mr. Kristol boasts of never having read Dissent. "It didn't exist on my horizon," he said. But as Mr. Dorman spoke to him, he spotted Mr. Howe's "World of Our Fathers" on Mr. Kristol's bookshelf. The intellectual and emotional crosscurrents between the four men are deep and complex; that no two of them are ever seen together in the film is, one suspects, not simply a matter of logistics.
And yet for all their philosophical differences, for all their great successes, there is a kind of wistfulness in reflecting on this lost era. Even when he chastises Mr. Kristol, Mr. Howe has an impish, almost affectionate grin. The very evident enjoyment with which all the men recall their lives among "New York intellectuals," betrays how much they all shared, how much the world they loved has largely disappeared, how sorely they miss it. And how nothing seems poised to take its place.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally After Bonds Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, bolstered by a rally in the bond market.
The rally in bonds was set off by a report showing restrained growth in United States manufacturing activity last month. The prospect for continued mild inflation and low borrowing costs emphasized the fundamentals that have fueled the stock market's strong three-year rally. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 56.79 points yesterday, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,965.04, bringing its gain for the week to 285.73 points, or 3.7 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 4.61, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 975.04, and gained 4.1 percent for the week.
Trading slumped below recent levels as many investors took the day off following the New Year's holiday. The lack of buyers and sellers made for a volatile day that saw the Dow rally 45 points early on, fall 30 points and then take off again. About 367 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, below the three-month average of 559 million shares.
Shares of AT&T dropped 2 1/2, to 58 13/16, shaving 10 points from the Dow. On Wednesday, a Federal judge in Texas struck down parts of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 that hindered the regional Bell telephone companies from offering long-distance phone service to customers in their region. Some investors said AT&T was poised to fall, given its 53 percent return in 1997.
"If the judge's ruling stands, it lets the Baby Bells provide long-distance services, and that's the last thing AT&T needs," said Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage. "Those companies would be strong competitors to AT&T."
The regional Bell telephone companies gained after the ruling. BellSouth rose 7/16, to 56 3/4; Ameritech jumped 1 3/8, to 81 7/8; SBC Communications rose 1 11/16, to 74 15/16, and U S West Communications Group rose 1, to 46 1/8.
Shares of other long-distance providers fell. MCI Communications dropped 1/8, to 42 11/16; Worldcom slid 5/16, to 29 15/16, and the Sprint Corporation fell 5/8, to 58.
"This is the first salvo; it's not a Supreme Court decision," said Bill Bane, head of sales trading at Stephens Inc. in Little Rock, Ark. "This is not the end of the story."
Late yesterday, AT&T, MCI, Sprint and others jointly asked the Texas court to delay the decision from taking effect, an AT&T spokesman said. The United States Government is expected to make the same request on Monday.
Computer stocks rose, sending the Nasdaq composite index up 11.18, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,581.53. Investors snapped up shares of companies whose stocks have been battered in recent months.
Compaq rose 3 1/8, to 59 5/8; Hewlett-Packard jumped 2 3/16, to 64 9/16; Dell Computer climbed 1 3/4, to 85 3/4, and Apple Computer increased 3 1/8, to 16 1/4.

HEADLINE: Kia Motor Opens 11 Ohio Dealerships

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Jan. 2

 BODY:
A South Korean auto maker hopes that opening 11 Ohio dealerships will help pull the company out of its financial difficulties.
The Kia Motor Corporation, battered in recent months by slow sales and an uncertain national economy, is opening six dealerships in the Cleveland area and five others around the state this week. 
 It is the second Korean auto maker to announce plans to enter the Cleveland market. On Dec. 19, the Daewoo Motor Corporation said it would open a factory-direct store this summer in Cleveland.
Kia is concentrating on the Midwest and other American markets because of slipping sales in South Korea and the weakness of the South Korean currency.
In October, the South Korean Government announced it was placing Kia under court receivership, assuming majority ownership through a state-controlled bank and installing a temporary new management team.
Kia has more than 320 dealerships in 32 states.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Rise Sharply On Prediction Of Slowdown

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose sharply on expectations of slower growth yesterday, after a manufacturing survey suggested that Asia's financial crisis was beginning to drag on the United States economy.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 14/32, to 104 8/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.82 percent, from 5.92 percent on Wednesday. But the gains came on light volume, a day after the market was closed for New Year's Day. 
 Bonds rallied yesterday after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its manufacturing index declined to 52.5 in December -- the lowest reading since January 1997 -- from 54.4 the month before as slowing growth in Asia and railroad snarls hurt orders and production. The association's prices-paid index, an inflation gauge, also declined.
The purchasing managers' report, some analysts said, provided some early evidence that the economy may be losing steam.
"The early stages of the Asia effect are beginning to show," said Patrick Dimick, bond strategist at UBS Securities. "It's favorable for the bond market."
Also helping bonds yesterday was the dollar's climb to a five-and-a-half-year high against the yen. A strengthening dollar increases the allure of United States bonds by increasing the returns overseas investors receive once the proceeds are converted into their own currencies.
Yet not everyone is sanguine about the inflation outlook, or convinced bonds will keep rallying.
"If you believe they will patch up this situation in Asia, the long bond could back up 40 basis points from here," said Ken Woods, who manages about $350 million for Asset Preservation Advisors in Atlanta, referring to the yield on the 30-year bond. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
With interest rates at their lowest levels in four years, activity is expected to pick up in the corporate market.
"With rates as low as they are, companies should start marching in" to the corporate bond market, said Glenn Davis, who helps manage $1 billion in fixed-income securities at Boston Partners Asset Management.
Century Telephone Enterprises Inc. is preparing to sell $1 billion of bonds after investor presentations Jan. 7 to Jan. 12 in what appears to be the year's first major corporate bond sale.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Asian and Rail Problems Slow U.S. Industry's Pace
American manufacturing growth slowed in December, reflecting the impact of Asia's economic crisis and railroad bottlenecks in this country, the executives who do the buying for the nation's factories said yesterday in a widely followed monthly survey. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's main index, derived from survey results, fell to 52.5 last month, from 54.4 in November and the weakest reading since January 1997. Page D5.
 
Treasury bonds rallied and yields dropped on the purchasing managers' report, which the market viewed as a sign that inflation will remain benign because of slowing economic growth. The yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year issue fell to 5.82 percent, a new four-year low, from 5.92 percent Wednesday. Financial markets were closed Thursday for New Year's Day. D15.
 
Stocks rose, bolstered by the bond market's advance. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 56.79 points, to 7,965.04, for a weekly gain of 285.73 points, or 3.7 percent. D5.
 
Foreigners to Buy Korean Banks
The South Korean Government said it would acquire the nation's two biggest insolvent commercial banks next month and sell them to foreign investors. The plan is part of a promise by South Korea to open financial businesses to outside ownership in return for billions of dollars in emergency loans from the International Monetary Fund. D3.
 
The dollar strengthened to its best level against the Japanese yen in more than five and a half years and ended sharply higher in other foreign-exchange dealings on fears about Asian finances and economies. D4.
 
The Malaysian ringgit plunged to a record low and the Indonesian rupiah neared a record low in a major selloff of Asian currencies. D3.
 
As Asian economies slump and more people miss loan payments, work is expanding for local debt collectors. D3.
 
AT&T Shares Fall on Ruling
Shares of AT&T and other long-distance companies fell after a Federal judge struck down provisions of the Telecommunications Act that kept the regional Bell companies out of the long-distance market. The F.C.C. said it would appeal the ruling, and the long- distance companies, as expected, filed a motion to stay the ruling. D3.
 
Indy 500 of the Showroom
The biggest automotive race of the year was held nationwide last month, but which car won will remain unknown until Wednesday, when auto makers report final 1997 sales. The results will determine whether Toyota's Camry or Honda's Accord, sharing the lead through November, can claim the title of America's best-selling car, a coveted marketing distinction that lasts for an entire year. The five-time champion Ford Taurus, shown above, will get bumped to third place. D2.
 
Optimism Bolsters Apple Stock
Shares of Apple Computer rose 24 percent on optimism that the troubled computer company might shock the market with some good news next week at the MacWorld Expo in San Francisco. At the last such exposition of Apple technology in August the company surprised the industry by announcing a surprise alliance with Microsoft, its longtime nemesis in personal-computer software. D11.
 
Energy Prices Fall
Energy prices dropped in the commodity markets yesterday on predictions of warmer weather in the Northeast and Midwest, the biggest consumers of heating fuel. Natural gas for February delivery fell 11.1 cents, or 5 percent, to $2.153 a thousand cubic feet. D11.

The Czech Republic's new Prime Minister, Josef Tosovsky, took office and pledged to "renew the pace of economic reform, including privatization," Mr. Tosovsky, an economist, replaced Vaclav Klaus, whose privatization process many now believe was largely illusory. News Analysis. A4.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
South Korea to Take Over and Sell 2 Big Insolvent Banks

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The South Korean Government will acquire the nation's two biggest insolvent commercial banks next month and sell them to foreign investors, under a plan announced today aimed at helping satisfy a promise to open financial businesses to outsiders.
The institutions to be taken over, Korea First Bank and Seoul Bank, were overloaded with bad debts and effectively collapsed in recent weeks, contributing to the financial crisis that has devastated the value of both South Korea's currency and stock market, caused a wave of bankruptcies and raised the fear of default on tens of billions of dollars in foreign loans. 
 Korea First recorded $2.67 billion in unrecoverable debt; Seoul Bank had $2.14 billion.
Under a plan disclosed by the Finance and Economy Ministry today, the Government will take a controlling interest in the banks early in February by sinking the equivalent of $738 million into each before putting them up for sale.
South Korean news media said today that Citibank, a Citicorp unit, had expressed interest in buying at least part of Korea First, and that Chase Manhattan was considering an investment in Seoul Bank.
Citibank has repeatedly denied any interest in either bank. Chase officials in New York declined to comment.
As part of South Korea's efforts to meet requirements imposed by the International Monetary Fund, which agreed last month to provide as much as $57 billion in loans to prevent default, the Government is opening tightly controlled financial institutions to foreign investment. As of Dec. 20, South Korea's foreign debt totaled $153 billion, most of it in short-term loans.
Deputy Finance Minister Chung Duk Soo reiterated earlier this week that Seoul would comply with I.M.F. conditions by introducing more disclosure requirements for financial institutions and doing whatever was necessary to revamp ailing banks.
Big banks in the United States, Japan and Europe have agreed to a reprieve for South Korean banks on more than $10 billion in short-term debt, effectively reducing the danger of default at least for a few weeks.
Yet some smaller foreign banks have been unwilling to extend loans. Though South Korea owes much less to these smaller banks, their resistance is complicating international efforts to arrange a moratorium on loan repayment.
Smaller banks may ultimately join the effort, but their apparent willingness to pull their money out of the country or to take losses rather than participate in the effort demonstrates some of the hurdles still facing the architects of the South Korean bailout.
There were some reports today that the I.M.F. might delay disbursement of $2 billion to South Korea beyond a Jan. 8 target date unless it saw more progress in debt restructuring talks among banks. But fund officials in Washington discounted the reports.
Representatives of major banks met today at Chase's New York headquarters to talk about Korea. No details were disclosed.
Negotiating even the preliminary steps to resolve the crisis involves delicate talks with hundreds of banks that have lent various amounts.
The Government has already paid off $1.5 billion of Korea First Bank's bad loans and $1.2 billion of Seoul Bank's unrecovered debt, or slightly more than half in each case. Finance Ministry officials have said that they plan to fully repay the two banks' liabilities before selling them.
The needs of South Korean workers remain an important sticking point. When Parliament here passed a package of laws last week aimed at easing restrictions on foreign investment, a notable exception was any agreement on the scope and mechanics of dismissing employees of Korean financial institutions that are put up for sale.
So while many companies here now look like bargains to foreign buyers, particularly with the steep drop in the currency and stock prices in recent weeks, militant labor unions remain a consideration. Early Saturday, the currency, the won, was quoted at 1,600 to the dollar in spot trading. Korean stocks rose 9.18 points, or 2.4 percent, to 385.46, in a half-day Saturday session.
One of the significant changes will allow foreign banks to open retail branches in South Korea this year. But it will likely be far more cost-effective to take over an existing bank that already operates a large network of branches than to open new branches. Bankers have said that a foreign takeover of a South Korean bank could assume the form of a joint venture with a local conglomerate.
For South Korea, one of the few positive consequences of a depreciated currency is the way it makes exports cheap overseas, while making imports much more expensive.
That was reflected in trade figures reported today, showing that the country accrued a $2.32 billion surplus in December. With the currency dropping so sharply, imports tumbled 24.7 percent, to a value of $10.24 billion, while exports increased 2.8 percent, to $12.56 billion.
For all of 1997, South Korea's exports increased 5.3 percent, to $136.6 billion, while imports decreased 3.8 percent, to $144.6 billion -- an $8 billion trade deficit, compared with a $20.6 billion deficit in 1996.

HEADLINE: Suspense Is Rising in Israel Over Impasse on the Budget

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Israel shut down for the weekend today in high suspense over whether Foreign Minister David Levy, who has threatened to resign from Israeli governments eight times in the past, would finally make good on his vow this time.
There was no indication today that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had made any progress in satisfying Mr. Levy's demands for more spending on social programs in the 1998 budget, or even that any talks had been held between aides to the two men. As he has in his past crises, Mr. Levy returned to his home city near the Sea of Galilee and refused to make any comment. 
 The new crisis forced Mr. Netanyahu to postpone a vote on the budget until Monday, when Israel will also learn whether Mr. Levy is to go or stay -- and if he goes, whether the Government will go with him.
Israeli television reported that the Government had been in touch with Dennis B. Ross, the special United States mediator for the Middle East, to see if he would postpone a visit scheduled to begin on Monday. According to the report, Washington declined.
The Clinton Administration has pressed Mr. Netanyahu to come up with concrete ideas to revive the negotiating process with the Palestinians, including a specific proposal for a further Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank. Mr. Ross is to prepare the way for Mr. Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to hold separate meetings with President Clinton this month and, if possible, to agree on resuming their negotiations.
Mr. Netanyahu has already delayed making a commitment several times, often because of the incessant crises in his Government. But the television report indicated that Washington was not prepared to agree to another extension.
Israeli television also reported that Ehud Barak, the leader of the opposition Labor Party, had contacted Mr. Levy with the offer of a senior post in a future Labor government if Mr. Netanyahu's Likud Government fell. Neither Mr. Barak nor Mr. Levy confirmed the report, but it fed speculation that the Foreign Minister might have a stronger incentive to quit the Government and thus raise the likelihood of early elections.
The withdrawal of Mr. Levy's five-member Gesher faction would not be enough by itself to bring down Mr. Netanyahu's coalition, which controls 66 of the 120 seats in Parliament. But the consensus among politicians was that its withdrawal would quickly prompt some other small parties to follow suit.
Mr. Netanyahu, for one, appeared to take the threat seriously. His aides were quoted as saying that if the choice was between Mr. Levy and Finance Minister Yaakov Neeman, who was said to be resisting making any more concessions on the budget, he would stay with Mr. Levy.
Mr. Levy and Mr. Netanyahu have a long history of rivalry and even enmity, including a time when they both worked in the Foreign Ministry but did not speak to each other. Mr. Neeman, by contrast, is a close associate of the Prime Minister. But Mr. Neeman is not a politician and has no constituency of his own, while Mr. Levy, a Jew of Moroccan origin, has a sizable following among poor Jews of North African descent.
The latest crisis followed furious haggling in the coalition over the 1998 budget, during which religious and ethnic parties managed to exact a long list of expensive concessions for their pet projects. On the other hand, social programs for which Mr. Levy had been promised money in July got nothing.
At a news conference on Thursday, Mr. Levy waved the written promises Mr. Netanyahu had made him in July, declaring that he would vote against the budget and quit the Government. Mr. Levy's demands include benefits for the unemployed, help for poor cities and rundown areas, a longer school day, more housing for lower-income families and support for needy students.
Although Mr. Netanyahu publicly announced a delay in the budget vote in order to meet Mr. Levy's demands, Israeli newspapers said there was considerable anger in the Prime Minister's office toward Mr. Levy. Many officials privately regard Mr. Levy as a vain man whose resignation threats are staged not for his purported causes but to help his image.
The rivalry between the two politicians dates back to years when Mr. Netanyahu was a rising star in the last Likud Government and often overshadowed Mr. Levy in public. In a well-known incident, Mr. Netanyahu accused his rival of threatening to make public a videotape that showed him in an adulterous affair. Mr. Levy angrily denied the accusation.
Since Mr. Netanyahu was elected Prime Minister in May 1996, Mr. Levy has threatened six times to resign, most recently after the bungled assassination of a Hamas official in Jordan. In addition to low funding for social programs, he has been frustrated by his exclusion from key security deliberations and contacts with Palestinians, as well as the halt of the peace negotiations, for which he largely blames Mr. Netanyahu.
For many Israelis, the sight of their Government locked in yet another crisis -- moreover one centered not on national security but on a battle for tax money -- was clearly disheartening.
In a Gallup poll commissioned by the newspaper Maariv, 45 percent of those questioned thought new elections were the best way out of the current political situation, and 30 percent wanted a "national unity" government with Labor. Only 23 percent wanted the current Government to continue. The poll also showed that if elections were held today, 41 percent would vote for Mr. Barak, 33 percent for Mr. Netanyahu.
Most press commentaries were heavy with disdain.
Yoel Marcus wrote in Haaretz, "It is not only the coalition partners who have lost all shame: the Prime Minister himself, who is willing to pay any price to stay in office, has as well."
