HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Unabashedly Continental With Feeling

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY 

 BODY:
RESTAURANTS that have opened in recent years on the Island tend to be narrow, specialized, targeted. They are not Italian anymore but Tuscan, Sardinian or Sicilian. American spots often define themselves as Californian or Southwestern. It is therefore a mild surprise to find that Hugo's, a newly opened restaurant in the Southdown Shopping Center in Huntington, is unabashedly Continental.
The menu has listings in Italian, French and English. New York sirloin, pollo scarpariello and l'assiette de veau au chatelaine all rub shoulders. The keen-eyed may spot a Spanish paella or even notice the restaurant's Argentine connection. 
 Its owner, Hugo Garcia, is from Argentina and proud of it. A logo of tango dancers can be found on the menu, the business card and even etched in a decorative window at the restaurant's entrance. Coffee-table books on Argentina and the tango are artfully arranged in the front window.
No one will be more surprised by Hugo's than patrons of Nina's, the former restaurant at this location. Nina's was a casual, 26-year-old, neighborhood favorite. Hugo's is a formal, white linen spot with draped poof shades, gold-framed mirrors, a spectacular chandelier and vases that hold a single, xotic bloom on each table.
Hugo's prices are at least as upscale as the surroundings. More than half of the meat and fish entrees cost more than $20. Pastas are more reasonable, tagged at $12.95 to $18.95. The most common price for appetizers is $9.95; a couple are $12.95. Soups and salads are a bit more economical. The lobster bisque, a creamy mahogany brew loaded with seafood, is a standout at $5.95.
Mr. Garcia, who is also the maitre d'hotel, lights up the dining room. He is well known in Huntington, having been a waiter for many years at various restaurants. He greets numerous diners as old friends but also makes first-timers feel special. When we admired the chandelier, he offered the manufacturer's brochure. Our enthusiasm for the flavored oil, served with the bread, elicited his mother's recipe (grape seed oil imported from Argentina, chopped parsley and whole garlic cloves).
He also has a generous spirit. On each visit we were offered a complimentary after-dinner drink (as were many tables around us). An appetizer of escargots boasted six shells, each filled with at least two snails bathed in a terrific brandy-herb-garlic butter. When a diner could not extract one of the snails from the shell, Mr. Garcia whisked out a plate of six more.
The sturdy Italian bread is a great accompaniment for those fantastic escargots. Another fine starter was a special of mushrooms filled with a light seafood mixture glazed with cheese. Also special were bruschetta topped with tomatoes and crab.
Less rewarding were a too-vinegary seafood salad, a seafood crepe that was tasty but diminished by the mushy texture of its filling, and clams and oysters Rockefeller that were overloaded with spinach.
The best salad sampled was the classic Caesar. Grilled vegetables with a centerpiece of portobello mushroom was skimpy, and its melted goat cheese topper was crumbly not creamy. Also less than abundant was a composed salad of sliced beets, potatoes, green beans and hard-boiled egg.
Top picks at entree time are the marinated lamb chops in a Madeira wine and porcini mushroom sauce, the impressive veal chop stuffed with mozzarella and prosciutto and crowned with shiitake mushrooms, the combination of grilled pork tenderloin and rosemary-scented chicken breast and the velvety filet mignon topped with a dab of Dijon mustard sauce and a sprinkling of pink and green peppercorns.
Also earning high marks were the creamy risotto covered with an avalanche of wild mushrooms and a special of flaky Chilean sea bass in a light broth flavored with tomato.
Skip the penne alla vodka harboring overcooked shrimp, and the lobster tail weighed down by a gummy crab-meat stuffing.
Most of the desserts are made elsewhere but are of good quality. The creamy cheesecake, rich Mississippi mud cake and addictive cappuccino pie with toffee crust were the favorites at our table.
Wines are less expensive than food. There are 75 of them, running from $18 to $215. Most are in the teens, 20's and 30's, including little-seen selections from Argentina, South Africa and Spain. Try the fleshy 1995 Rodney Strong Old Vines zinfandel ($28) with its explosively ripe fruit. The only Long Island wine here is made from local chardonnay grapes in upstate Washingtonville. It is a 1996 Little Cobb Road ($18) that is bold, rich and appley.
 
Hugo's

Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction to food, ambiance and service, with price taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.

HEADLINE: Are H.O.V. Lanes Speeding the Rush-Hour Traffic?

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
THE high occupancy vehicle lanes on the Long Island Expressway can be great when they work and frustrating when they do not, said Gerald S. Schwartz, president of G. S. Schwartz & Company, a public relations business.
"I live in Manhattan but have a home in Quogue and many clients on Long Island," Mr. Schwartz said. "So I am on the Long Island Expressway quite a bit and I use the H.O.V. lane a tremendous amount. 
 Overall, he said, traffic moves faster today than it did 30 years ago, when the expressway was known as the world's largest parking lot. "During the rush hours," Mr. Schwartz added, "traffic moves at a good clip in the H.O.V. lane, traveling at 55 or 60 miles an hour, while traffic to the right does no more than 50."
Business groups, traffic experts and the state agree that the lanes have been beneficial in moving rush-hour traffic, encouraging car pooling and reducing the number of cars on the road.
But drivers who travel in the regular lanes -- one driver in a car -- fail to see much difference, since their lanes remain clogged. And some Long Islanders, among them David E. Lerner of Jericho, president of the investment firm David Lerner Associates in Syosset, object to the use of tax dollars to build restricted lanes.
"The state creates a terrible inconvenience while building these lanes with my tax dollars and then tells me I can't use the road when I drive alone," said Mr. Lerner. "That's wrong from a legal and moral point of view."
He argued that H.O.V. lanes were outdated because they were a brainchild of traffic engineering in 1973. "We're not having an oil crisis where the price of gasoline is forcing people to car pool," Mr. Lerner said. "And they are making the assumption that people on Long Island work in factories that shut down at 4:15, let people wash up and leave.
"We live in a service area that does not run from 9 to 5. If my employees were to run out at 5, I'd have a problem. The service industry does not lend itself to car pooling."
He added: "The vast majority of cars on the road carry one person, and that is what people want."
The lanes, 12 miles in both directions between Exit 49 at Route 112 and Exit 57 at Route 454, opened in May 1994. Only cars with two or more people, as well as buses can use the lanes. Traffic in the lanes has increased 6 percent a year since they opened, in line with expectations, according to Wayne R. Ugolik, director of travel demand management for the Long Island region of the State Transportation Department.
"We have not done any areawide studies," Mr. Ugolik said. "But in surveys of H.O.V.-lane users taken in early 1997 we estimated that at least 10,000 people formed some sort of ride sharing for some of their trips in order to use the H.O.V. lanes. And there were more than 100,000 people in car pools on Long Island already, formed by people who live and work in Nassau and Suffolk.
"National surveys have shown that car pooling as a national trend has gone down since the late 80's. But in areas where there are H.O.V. lanes that trend has been reversed."
Mr. Ugolik said new figures showed that in "peak usage hours there are 1,000 car pools and buses carrying about 2,500 people at the speed limit, compared to 1,900 people carried in a general purpose lane."
"People have a misimpression about the H.O.V. lanes because they do not see as many cars using them and therefore they think they are not popular," he added. "But what is important is the number of people using those lanes. The lanes are managed to make sure cars travel at the speed limit, because if they did not there would be no incentive to car pool."
Because of the perceived success of the H.O.V. lanes, the state is extending them eight miles west, to Exit 40 at Route 25. The state plans to open that section in the summer.
The eastern end of the lanes are planned to be extended 10 miles, to Exit 64 at Route 112, the next year.
"By late 1999 there should be 32 miles of H.O.V. lanes in place, one lane in each direction," Mr. Ugolik said. "By the year 2004 another 10 miles of H.O.V. lanes should be opened between Exits 40 and 30, the interchange with the Cross Island Expressway."
Several legislators from Queens, however, are challenging the plans in court, contending that extending the lanes would create congestion and inconvenience for Queens residents and benefit only Long Islanders.
Mr. Ugolik said Gov. George E. Pataki's decision in October to scrap plans to build an H.O.V. lane on Interstate 287 in Westchester "in no way means H.O.V. lanes aren't successful or warranted in other parts of the state."
Mr. Pataki said people feared that an H.O.V. lane on the Cross Westchester Expressway would have had "negative economic and environmental impacts, while further dividing the community over how to solve its traffic problems."
Mr. Ugolik noted that the Westchester lane would have been reversible, unlike those on the L.I.E., meaning that it would have been more complicated to operate.
The American Automobile Association said a survey conducted a year after the lanes opened had found use "well above acceptable levels," according to an A.A.A. traffic engineer, Mark Kulewicz.
"Our expectation is that it would take a period of time for H.O.V. to build up a head of steam and grow in usage," Mr. Kulewicz said. "We expect -- and there is nothing to make us think otherwise -- that it will carry more and more people as it is accepted and extended east and west. The longer the lane the more attractive it is to potential users and the larger the area it can draw from."
Mr. Kulewicz said he did not foresee further widening of the expressway despite continued building and resulting additional traffic.
"There has been a tremendous population growth on Long Island since the 1960's," he said. "But the roads have not kept up at all. We see H.O.V. as a compromise solution to the traffic nightmare we face on Long Island. We view it as a chance to add capacity, which is clearly mandated because of what cars do to air quality, the quality of life and mobility."
Mr. Kulewicz added that the state was studying introducing H.O.V. lanes on the Southern State and Meadowbrook State Parkways.
A vice president of the Long Island Association, Mitchell H. Pally, said: "We think that when fully completed, they will provide a meaningful alternative and reduce the number of vehicles which would otherwise be on the expressway. When the lanes are extended next year, that will be the real test, because it will give more and more people an opportunity to use them for an extended period of time.
"H.O.V. not only provides a benefit to those who use it, it eases congestion in the general-use lanes. If you just opened the H.O.V. lane to everyone all the time there would be no benefit. We're trying to move people, not vehicles."
Mr. Kulewicz pointed out that H.O.V. lanes were highly popular in other regions. The Katy Freeway in Houston, a city with an extensive H.O.V. network, increased the minimum number of riders, from two to three, because the H.O.V. lanes were becoming congested.
"If we could double the use of the H.O.V. lane on the L.I.E.," he said, "it would do a lot to making a dent in our traffic problem. Looking into a crystal ball, we anticipate that ride sharing will flourish over time."
State and Federal money subsidizes the so-called 110 Clipper, an express bus that begins picking up riders in Selden and drops them off at industrial parks along Route 110 after using the H.O.V. lanes. Suffolk County Transit operates the line from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M. and charges $1.50. There are no monthly or weekly tickets.
"The 38-mile trip takes 50 minutes from start to finish," the county's Director of Transportation Operations, Gerald V. Cronin, said.
The service, which shaves about 15 minutes from a trip without the high-occupancy lanes, started with three passengers in January 1996 and now carries 60 to 70 a day, Mr. Cronin said.
The operation, with subsidies of $500,000 a year, is to continue through at least next year. Extending the H.O.V. lanes could lead to new subsidized bus routes, Mr. Cronin added.
The state, Mr. Ugolik said, could take a year and a half to evaluate the express buses.
Mr. Schwartz, who said he used the H.O.V. lanes frequently, said he was annoyed by drivers who used the lane when they travel alone.
The Transportation Department pays a special group of officers to patrol the lane after their usual shifts. Five officers work during the operating hours, from 6 A.M. to 10 and 3 P.M. to 8. The number of summonses has increased in recent months, after having steadily declined after the first 12 months of operation, according to Lieut. Larry E. Fuller of the Suffolk County police who is in charge of the highway patrol unit on the Long Island Expressway.
"It's hard to pinpoint a cause for the change, because in each 12-month period we assigned a different number of people to patrol the lane," Lieutenant Fuller said. "I feel that people simply comply to a point, and then the numbers pick up again."
The police figures show that the number of accidents in H.O.V. lanes is significantly lower than the other lanes.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Next Role for Otto Kahn's 126-Room Mansion: a Spa

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: COLD SPRING HILLS

 BODY:
IT is the second largest private residence ever built in the United States. Yet the 109,000-square-foot French chateau-style castle known as Oheka, which stands high on a hill here off Jericho Turnpike, is in so secluded a setting that even many local residents are unaware that it's there. Surrounding it is an enclave of about 300 houses and a 168-acre golf course.
Only the 175,000-square-foot Biltmore House in Asheville, N.C., built by George W. Vanderbilt in 1895 and turned into a thriving museum, surpasses Oheka in size. Now, after years of uncertainty and controversy, this 126-room Long Island landmark, which Otto H. Kahn, a financier and patron of the arts, built in 1917, also has a more hopeful future. 
 Last month, following a public hearing, the five-member Huntington town board voted unanimously in favor of allowing Gary Melius of Carle Place, who holds a 114-year lease on the property, to turn it into a 50-suite luxury health spa. A small portion of the building will be permanently set aside as a history and exhibit area open to the public.
Without that approval, the building, once ravaged by vandals but now partially restored at a cost of $15 million, might have faced the same vandalized fate again because its vast size makes it economically impractical for most uses.
Mr. Melius said $20 million was needed to complete the restoration work. The building also costs $500,000 annually, including $110,000 for taxes, to maintain.
Built of concrete and steel with walls that are 3 to 5 feet thick, the mansion -- designated a landmark in 1991 -- would cost millions to tear down.
Most neighbors -- whose homes were built on land once owned by Mr. Kahn -- supported allowing a commercial enterprise to move into their residential community, although there were dissenters who said it would bring additional traffic and noise.
"To allow Oheka to be vandalized once again was unthinkable," said Karen Friel, the chairwoman of the 197-member Cold Spring Hills Civic Association.
The civic group sent the town board 324 petitions from surrounding homeowners supporting Mr. Melius's commercial-use application. At the public hearing, 18 people spoke against the application.
"It's a very special structure with a unique identity on Long Island as well as in the nation, and it's right in the heart of our neighborhood," Mrs. Friel said. "Of course there were concerns over traffic, but some commercial use had to go there or the building might have been lost."
THE Kahn estate originally consisted of 443 acres, which included a private 18-hole golf course, a farm, a race track and even an airstrip. Only 23 acres remain with the house. The golf course was bought by the private Cold Spring Country Club, and 256 acres were developed for housing.
"It was our mission to save the castle and to ensure that it remains open to the public for generations," said Edward J. Owen, who is president of Friends of Oheka, a group formed two and a half years ago independently of the developer to find ways to save the building.
Mr. Owen, a former assistant town attorney for Huntington, said he was motivated because "the minute I walked in, I fell in love with the place."
In today's dollars, Oheka cost over $100 million to build. "There is no one alive who has the inclination to spend that kind of money on a house, not even Bill Gates" of Microsoft, he added.
He said he and his group helped save the castle by prevailing on the town to pass a historic overlay district ordinance adopted in 1996 that permits owners of historically significant residential properties on 15 or more acres to apply for them to be used commercially.
Two other examples of adaptive re-uses of large residences in Huntington, Coindre Hall in Huntington and the Vanderbilt Museum in Centerport, are publicly owned and must be supported by taxpayers.
"We think we have developed a model solution to problems like Oheka," Mr. Owen said. "You give a private owner the right to engage in a specifically-defined commercial use to generate the kind of funds needed to restore and maintain these exceedingly expensive mansions of a bygone era.
"In exchange, the owner gives public access to at least some portion of the building so that future generations can learn of the life style that occurred in the '20's and '30's."
The town imposed conditions to address some of the concerns surrounding homeowners had, said Frank P. Petrone, who is the Town of Huntington supervisor.
For example, traffic patterns, parking, the number of events that can be held and the use of signs are all spelled out. Casino gambling is forbidden. A recent controversy over fire and safety codes was resolved when Mr. Melius installed a $500,000 sprinkler system.
"Huntington is a very historical town, and we pride ourselves on that," Mr. Petrone said. "And had we not worked with Oheka, the surrounding community certainly would have experienced a real problem."
Under an agreed-upon timetable, Mr. Melius must complete a full restoration of the building by 2005. Weddings and other functions, which have been allowed to take place in the building for the last two years on a temporary basis, can still be held, as can designer showcases, while the restoration is under way.
In a showcase, designers are invited to display their talents in a residential building. They leave behind permanent improvements like fixtures, carpeting and wall, ceiling and floor decorations that are usually worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.
SHOWCASES will probably be held at Oheka twice a year over the eight years, with designers decorating portions of the building piecemeal starting on the third floor.
Arlene Travis, who with a partner, Carole Aronson, has been running designer showcases in prominent Long Island houses for 26 years, said Oheka would generate national interest because of its size and scale. Their Greenvale company, Mansions & Millionaires, is among those being considered by Mr. Melius to hold the showcases.
Designers would have to be faithful to the building's history, and at the same time keep the future and end use of the building in mind, Mrs. Travis said.
Designed by the architectural firm of Delano & Aldrich, , the three-story mansion sits on an artificially-created hill 90 feet above sea level.
The formal gardens with their reflecting pools were designed by the Olmsted Brothers, landscape architects for many major Long Island estates and sons of Frederick Law Olmsted, one of the designers of Manhattan's Central Park. After Mr. Kahn's death in 1934 the building was sold to the New York City Department of Sanitation, which used it as a rest home for workers. A subsequent purchaser in 1948 was the Eastern Military Academy, which occupied it until 1978 when the school went bankrupt and moved out.
Mr. Melius bought the castle in 1984 for $1.45 million, sold it in 1989 partly restored to a Japanese businessman for $22.5 million, and in 1993 took back control of the building with a 114-year-lease that was conditioned on getting the health spa approval.
Mr. Melius is a commercial and residential developer, but Oheka has become his passion, he said.
Sitting in the library, which has been restored in impeccable detail, Mr. Melius reminisced about the vandalism, the rats and the general decay of the building he bought in 1984.
It took 300 trailer trucks to carry out debris. Four hundred doors and windows had to be replaced. He set up a shop in the building to replicate the missing paneling, moldings, stair and balcony railings, balustrades and other details that had to be replaced. Of the 39 fireplaces in the building, 38 work, but all except two -- including the one in the library -- lost their mantles because of theft or vandalism.
For the slate tiles needed to restore the roof, the developer went to Rising & Nelson in West Pawlet, Vt., the company that sold the original tiles.
Myths persist that Mr. Kahn kept lions in the basement. The cages people thought they saw were 20-foot wide wind tunnels he had built as a natural air-conditioning system.
Among other major rooms already restored is the 70-foot long ballroom where Enrico Caruso once sang for Mr. Kahn, who was chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera. The Olmsted-designed gardens and reflecting pools Mr. Kahn created for his castle once again glitter in splendor.
"It's like a great book, a great painting, a great orchestra with which you fall in love," Mr. Melius said.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Park Hill, Yonkers;
Vintage Homes on a 300-Foot Plateau

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
ONE day while driving up Broadway looking for houses, Steven Green, a Manhattan developer, made a right turn and found a neighborhood in Yonkers he had never seen before. "I don't want to make it sound like karma or something," Mr. Green said, "but I don't know what caused me to turn that way."
What he found after his car climbed the steep hill from Broadway was a neighborhood of stately turn-of-the-century homes on winding streets, sitting on a 300-foot plateau one mile back from the Hudson River. Many houses are on the edge of cliffs and have sweeping views overlooking the rest of the city as it slopes down to the water. 
 In his search, Mr. Green found himself in front of a Gothic Revival mansion that just happened to be for sale. "The sign was halfway off its hinges," Mr. Green recalled. "I sat in my car and called the realtor, who came right over."
Five years later, Mr. Green is now something of a legend in Park Hill, a neighborhood of vintage single-family homes east of Broadway in southwest Yonkers. In addition to buying and restoring one of the neighborhood's premier properties, a 12,000-square-foot 21-room mansion, he has bought several other properties and restored them. As head of Green Realty Management Corporation, he also owns several apartment buildings in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan and two shopping centers in Yonkers.
And he is also known for his parties. "This was the first New Year's I didn't have a party since I moved to Park Hill," he said. "Last year, I had 300 people and flew in the Captain and Tennille from Reno. One other year, I had the Boys Choir of Harlem."
Parties, it seems, are never in short supply at Park Hill. "There are numerous gatherings in people's houses every month," Mr. Green said. "It's amazing." The tight-knit community is host to four chamber music concerts a year, held in different homes. Such events, Mr. Green said, give Park Hill its special character. "It's not traditional suburbia," he said. "Here there's really an opportunity for people to get to know each other."
In the early 1980's the neighborhood began attracting artists, filmmakers and others in the arts interested in the large supply of 19th-century houses at reasonable prices and in living in a progressive, diverse community with easy access to Manhattan.
Richard Haas, the muralist, and his wife, Katherine, were among the early artist residents, moving to the neighborhood in 1980. "At that time, there was an elderly population who were all leaving," Mr. Haas said.
The couple had never intended to move to Yonkers or live outside Manhattan. They were renting a loft when they saw an ad for a five-story house, built in 1896, selling for "less than an ugly loft we were looking at in SoHo," Ms. Haas said.
"It was at a down time for Park Hill," Mr. Haas added. "It didn't have the vitality the neighborhood has today. A lot of the houses were in terrible shape. A tremendous amount of people were bailing out. It was a great time for house hunters."
The Haas's house is built on a sheer cliff. An oval sun room, the centerpiece of the main floor, has a sweeping view of the city and the river. "We fell in love with the house," Mr. Haas said, "but we really had no idea where we were." As if to ground himself, Mr. Haas incorporated images of Yonkers history into the design elements of his home. Over doorways and on his kitchen tiles, he has painted historic Yonkers buildings, many no longer in existence.
Park Hill was developed in 1888 by the American Real Estate Company. In its original advertising, it boasted of the neighborhood's "healthful environment," saying the altitude of 300 feet "insures a salubrious climate and cool nights." The name was first Parkhill, the middle name of Robert P. Getty, a prominent businessman who owned property in the area. Before being subdivided, the hilly rugged land was wilderness characterized by huge rock outcroppings and mature trees. The planners tried to work around and preserve as many natural features as possible.
They also left room for parks and green spaces, including Pelton Field and Sullivan Park, which have ball fields and basketball courts, and the wooded Sutherland Park, which overlooks the Hudson River.
"It's a single-family planned community going back to the turn of the century," said Lee Ellman, Yonkers's director of planning. "The neighborhood is comprised primarily of these imposing turn-of-the-century middle-class houses. Later on some 1950's and 60's raised ranches were put in cheek and jowl next to 1880's shingle-style houses."
Today house prices range from $180,000 for a small three-bedroom home to $750,000 for a six-bedroom Georgian colonial. There are also three co-op complexes, where prices range from $27,000 for a one-bedroom to $65,000 for a three-bedroom.
In its earliest days, Park Hill was a magnet for people in entertainment. The English actor Richard Bennett and his daughters, Joan and Constance, were residents, as was Dennis O'Brien, the corporate counsel for United Artists, who gave parties at his Park Hill house where guests included Charlie Chaplin, George M. Cohan, Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks. One of Park Hill's main streets is named for the drummer Gene Krupa, who was a longtime resident.
The Park Hill Country Club, established in 1892, was a galvanizing force in the community in those early days. It eventually changed its name to the Racquet Club, and the original building was destroyed by fire in 1962.
It was subsequently replaced by a new building, which still serves as a kind of community center for Park Hill residents. With four clay tennis courts, two swimming pools, four bowling alleys, a clubhouse, ballroom and catering hall, it is a year-round gathering spot open to nonresidents as well. Dues for a family are $1,350 a year.
Despite such amenities, Park Hill retains an urban feel, which is very attractive to many residents. "I still feel like I'm living in Manhattan," said Gini Reticker, an independent filmmaker, who moved to Park Hill from Manhattan three year ago. "It's not some homogeneous suburb. Culturally it's still related to New York City."
Its diversity of housing is matched by its population, said Jane McAfee, a sales agent with Prudential Ragette. "While people think of Park Hill as this artistic community, we also have plumbers and policemen," she said. "The people who look in Park Hill often value that kind of mix."
Also valued is its proximity to Manhattan. Dennis Williams, a member of the Metropolitan Opera chorus, lives with two roommates in a 1939 house in which each bedroom has its own bath. Mr. Williams had been living briefly in the northern Westchester community of Goldens Bridge, but the commute was too long. "I'd heard about Park Hill from a colleague who absolutely loved it," he said. "Now I'm 25 minutes from the Met. And I have a big yard and trees. It's perfect. I can be near the city, and indulge my love of gardening."
Before moving to Park Hill 12 years ago, G. Mac Brown, a movie producer, was on the verge of buying a loft in Manhattan. "Then we discovered my wife was pregnant with our second child and we were going to need more room than we could afford in Manhattan," he said. He and his wife, Cherri, found a 100-year-old, five-bedroom Victorian, with two porches, for $139,000. "It needed $100,000 in repairs," Mr. Brown said. "But the loft we were looking at, with 1,800 square feet, was $225,000 at the time. So we thought this was the better deal."
Mr. Brown said he loves the neighborhood. "We have several gay families, mixed-race households and older couples who have lived here for generations," he said. "It's all these different kinds of people, yet it's a real neighborhood."
ONE downside, Mr. Brown said, is the schools. "When we moved here, we visited the public schools and decided they were not going to be an option for us," he said. "The buildings were rundown and unattractive. It wasn't what we wanted for our kids." His children, Ben, 13, and Nick, 12, attend Riverdale Country Day, a private school; many Park Hill children attend private schools. Money saved from lower house prices and taxes makes private school a viable alternative, Mr. Brown said.
The Yonkers public schools, however, have some local boosters. Ellis E. Cousens, a member of the school board, views the public schools as an asset, not a liability. "There are some outstanding options, like the Montessori and Pearls programs," he said. Both his children attend Pearls, which stands for "Program for Early and Rapid Learners," at the Hawthorne School, less than a mile from Park Hill.
Children must pass a qualifying test for admittance to Pearls, which covers kindergarten through sixth grade, according to Reginald Marra, schools superintendent. "It offers students an enriched core curriculum," Mr. Marra said. "It stresses academics and creative thinking."
Yonkers schools offer magnet programs, meaning parents can select any school in the district if space is available. Two schools are in Park Hill. At one, the Scholastic Academy for Academic Excellence (pre-kindergarten to sixth grade), students wear uniforms and follow a traditional academic curriculum, according to Mr. Marra. There is also the Burroughs Junior High School, for grades 7 and 8, which focuses on environmental science and technology.
"In the next few years, I think people are going to start viewing the Yonkers schools in an entirely different light," Mr. Cousens said. "In some of the schools, the performance of the children is equal to that of PEARLS. We have a new board now, with a higher level of expectation. We're really poised now to make some strides and change people's minds about the schools. And, of course, it will also improve our property values."

SCHOOLHOUSE AMBIENCE: On the outskirts of Park Hill, on McLean Avenue, an abandoned Yonkers school building once known as School 13 is scheduled to be converted into 38 rental apartments, incorporating turn-of-the-century schoolhouse architecture.
The 34,000-square-foot building, completed in 1900, was purchased for $300,000 by Steven Green, owner of Green Realty Management Corporation, who is a Park Hill resident. "There will be duplexes with 13- to 17-foot ceilings and some lofts," Mr. Green said. "We plan to keep the oak floors, the school-type hallways and as much of the original architecture as is economically feasible."
Mr. Green estimates the cost of conversion at about $4.5 million. Rents are expected to range from $875 for a one-bedroom to $1,500 for a two-bedroom with a den. Construction is to start this summer and be completed by late 1999.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Bombs Away! A Story of the Suburbs

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
COLIN McKERNAM, making some extra money working as a land surveyor over his holiday break from Colorado State University, stomped a boot on the frozen mud and turned away from the tripod that held his scope. Just up the hill, a light snow had frosted the trees that still made a natural barrier around the small, cleared plateau where missiles had once been hidden on their launchers, waiting for nuclear doomsday.
"When you're a surveyor, you tend to be aware of the land under your foot," said Mr. McKernam, 23. "When I took this job, they said it was up at an old Nike missile base. I said, 'What's that?' But then I looked up the old plans, and wow, it hit me what this place was once, and what it's becoming now. I really got into the history." 
 It was heartening to run into someone with a sense of the history of this ground, deep in the Ramapo Mountains of northern Bergen County, where expensive new houses are sprouting in the hills. It was interesting, moreover, to encounter it in a young man who grew up at the tail end of the cold war, in a generation that is said to regard history only as what happened in the previous episode of a television show.
"Hey," Mr. McKernam said, chuckling, "isn't is strange that this is how the cold war ended? With all these big new houses going up on some base that was built to keep the Russians from nuking New York City?"
Economics, not warfare or even politics, won the cold war. The decisiveness of its victory can be sensed in the triumphant bellow of capitalism roaring across these rolling hills, where bulldozers carve neat rectangular building lots across land once valued for its strategic location as a nuclear defense installation in the Jersey highlands northwest of Manhattan.
The old Mahwah Nike base was one of more than two dozen missile and radar complexes built in New Jersey in the 1950's, in locations like East Hanover, Livingston, South Plainfield and Wayne, to form a defensive half-circle around New York City. The idea was that the missiles, some armed with nuclear warheads, could be launched from their secluded spots against any Soviet nuclear bomber attack on New York. Forget the fact that the Soviet Union's resorting to long-range airplanes to obliterate New York was not likely, given intercontinental nuclear missiles. Once the military bases had been built, they were lifers that remained staffed and operational till retirement.
When the Nike base in Mahwah was finally abandoned in 1991, suburbia already had established a solid beachhead in the area, which had once been dotted mostly with farms, summer bungalows and the occasional country estate. Just north of the base, on 435 hilly acres that had originally been part of the estate of George Crocker, heir to a railroad fortune, and later became the site of the seminary where the Newark Roman Catholic Archdiocese trained its priests, a development called Rio Vista Estates had already opened, offering new "estate houses" on one- and two-acre lots.
The woods soon reclaimed the adjacent missile site. Just down the hill, vandals ripped into the 24 abandoned two-bedroom ranch houses that had once housed the base's military workers. In 1994, the area's affluent new residents had a scare when the Governmentturned the base over to a group that wanted to use it for low-income housing and a drug-abuse center. But that plan fell through, and the land was sold to a developer who plans to build luxury homes.
Now that Interstate 287 has sliced up into the misty northern hills, affluent suburbanites are pouring in. The clutter and bang of new construction is everywhere.
"It's only about an hour and a quarter by train to New York City for my husband," said Susan Augosto, the administrator of the homeowners' association at Rio Vista, where houses now cost from $650,000 to well over $1 million. The association recently renovated parts of the seminary complex for clubhouse and recreational facilities. The former chapel, with its soaring vaulted ceiling, is now used for parties and other community events.
"It really is beautiful country, the most rural place I've lived in my life," said Mrs. Augosto, who grew up in New England and on Long Island.
A young land surveyor doing his job may well marvel at the fact of missile bases' being beaten into luxury suburbs, as swords might once have been beaten into plowshares. But in the new houses with those magnificent vistas that sweep to the horizon where the lights of the far-off city can be seen twinkling faintly at night, the newer settlers would just as soon not dwell on that.
"Well, let's just say it's a curiosity of history, and leave it at that," Mrs. Augosto said.

HEADLINE: '98, Year of Growth Based on the Past

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
RACING toward the millennium, five successful executives took time to reflect on the past. What does it take to start a business and, more important, what does it take to keep it growing through economic cycles, demographic shifts and changing markets?
The heads of well-established but disparate Westchester companies who have been in business for 25 years or more offer some thoughts. What they have in common is that none of them have remained static. All have survived and prospered by being flexible and adapting to changes in the marketplace.
Martin Berger, chairman, R.M.C. Development Company, Elmsford: 
 Robert Weinberg and I founded the Robert Martin Company in 1959 when we started out as home builders in Westchester. We were fortunate enough to grow our business and rapidly developed over 25 single-family home subdivisions during the 1960's and 70's, 2,000 condominiums during the 70's and 80's, and 5 million square feet of office and industrial space throughout the county in the ensuing years.
We have survived several severe recessions and remained a viable and strong business, which merged a substantial part of our real estate portfolio into a real estate investment trust last January, which is now named Mack-Cali Realty and is one of the largest REIT's in the nation with a cap value of $3.5 billion.
We continue to privately own and operate several apartment houses and shopping centers and a portfolio of undeveloped land, which is being processed mostly for sorely needed residential housing. We are bullish concerning the prospects for the real estate economy in Westchester over the next few years, as our county will follow both Manhattan and Fairfield, where real estate values and office occupancy and rents have soared during the past two years. We are still young at heart, have a seasoned core of professionals retained on staff and have every intention of continuing developmental activities under the Robert Martin flag well into the 21st century.
As for the immediate future, in my opinion the stars are properly aligned for continuous prosperity in the commercial and residential real estate industries in Westchester.
Reasons: The national economy is relatively strong. Interest rates are very moderate showing that inflation is under control. New York City and New York State are in very strong economic condition thanks to the financial services industry that is headquartered in the region. We also have a very popular governor who is business oriented. And the leaders of most Westchester communities are also business oriented.
Abigail Kirsch, founder, Abigail Kirsch Culinary Productions, Tarrytown:
Flashback to 1972. We have just opened a 600-square-foot storefront kitchen in Chappaqua with one employee. Chicken a la king, spinach crepes slathered with cream sauce topped with cheese and strawberries Romanoff with layers of whipped cream are the rage. Cholesterol and calories don't count.
It's the late 70's. We are now in our 6,000-square-foot commissary in Bedford Hills with 40 employees. A menu without beef is unheard of. "Vegetarian" applies only to the one vegetable that enhances the entree. Crepes filled with sweetened whipped cream topped with hot brandy chocolate sauce are a must.
During the opulent 80's and early 90's we are at Tappan Hill, a 25,000-square-foot mansion, with 70 employees. Clients expect a trained, impeccably dressed staff, one that is knowledgeable about wine and food. Requests for our "Dinner by the Bite" grazing menu are constant.
Today, still comfortably ensconced at Tappan Hill, we have a beautiful new venue at the New York Botanical Garden. Our on-location business thrives. Over 100 full-time and several hundred part-time staff are on board. Vegetarian and fish-only menus are popular, as are the tantalizing flavors of Southwestern, Thai and Malaysian cuisines.
I believe the catering industry will grow simply because in the ensuing years virtually every family will be a two-income family and domestic help will all but disappear. Yet family life-cycle events and celebrations will be strong as ever. And people will need to hire caterers for all these occasions. If anything, the catering industry will grow faster than ever."
"We look forward to opening our 30,000-square-foot catering facility -- Pier 60, Chelsea Piers -- in New York in September. It is designed for every type of social and corporate function, seating 1,200 and accommodating more for receptions."
Carl Austin, president, Austin Corporate Properties, White Plains:
We began our company in 1971 in a one-room office with a one-line dial phone, a desk and a coat rack. However, we believed then, and we believe now, that complete market knowledge, total attention to detail and solid personal relationships are the fundamentals in every successful transaction.
We were first selected by Joel Halpern to represent the corporate center that he was developing in Tarrytown. In his words, "I could have had any big New York City broker, but I wanted the undivided attention that a small firm would give." We lived with each other seven days a week, and we'd talk through issues at 2 in the morning. We learned then that total engagement in a client's business leads to success.
While our transactions grew in volume and complexity, we made a decision to remain small in size and to focus exclusively on Westchester.
Our current activities include representing Reckson Associates Realty, a REIT, in their acquisition of Halpern Enterprises' portfolio totaling 935,000 square feet, valued at $83 million, and their acquisition this month of Royal Executive Park, 540,000 square feet, valued at $81 million. We are under contract with Cohen Brothers Realty in their acquisition of the Kraft Foods complex in White Plains totaling 623,000-square feet. We are also completing our leasing campaign for Cigna Investments at the Gateway Building office tower at the White Plains Metro-North Rail Station. Additionally, we represented Centennial Golf Properties in their acquisition of 350 acres for their 27-hole golf course to open in the spring of 1998.
While our brokerage industry has gone through a period of consolidation, creating larger and larger companies covering wider areas, we believe a counter trend is developing. Many highly capable executives of these brokerage giants are splitting off and starting their own market-specific firms. As corporate clients require individual attention, this trend to the smaller specialized companies should continue.
Merritt K. Mitchell, president and owner of Merritt Associates, Larchmont:
Merritt Associates was established in Larchmont in 1930 during the Great Depression by my grandfather, a builder and developer who started it for his daughter, my mother Mabel Merritt Mitchell, in order to give her a business of her own that would generate extra income. It was an unusual position for a woman at that time. Until World War II, the real estate brokerage field was dominated by men.
In the years since my mother started in the business, residential real estate brokerage has seen many changes, both in personalities and service. But the basic aspects of the profession have changed little. Up through the mid-70's real estate brokerage was very provincial. Since then we have seen localization, regionalization, national and worldwide networking, franchising and consolidation, and yet the essence of the industry has not changed. The greatest change, I believe, has been the intensity of the high-tech, high-litigious environment that agencies have had to move in.
As for our agency, we've come a long way in 67 years. We now have offices in Rye, Scarsdale and Greenwich. The company that began with 2 sales persons now has 85 agents and 17 support staff, with voice mail, Websites, E-mail, computerized desktop printing, car phones, beepers, "with full property disclosure" and "agency relationship disclosure" stipulations and licensing requirements -- and so it goes.
Yet our firm and our agents' entrepreneurial spirit and energy remains unchanged in our goal to satisfy both owner and purchaser in all our transactions.
Down the road I think that the fallout from consolidation mergers and independent residential realtors will cease. We are at the top of the peak of that activity. I believe there will be stronger independent real estate concerns, those with a local presence. I think the cycle will repeat itself and local firms with local information on local markets will flourish."
 
Richard N. Pitassey, partner, Bleakley Platt & Schmidt, White Plains:
Our firm was founded in 1937 by William F. Bleakley of Yonkers and Livingston Platt of Rye as a general law practice. Over the decades, we grew steadily along with the county. But during the past 15 years our growth has been dramatic, going from 15 attorneys to more than the 50 we now have on staff, which makes us the largest law firm in the region.
Our use of the latest computer technology has been a major factor. Today all our attorneys and support personnel have immediate access to information at their desks, including computer-assisted research litigation support, document management and production, network faxing, Internet access for search and communications and direct-line transfers to and from clients. The personal computer is becoming the primary research tool. On line is more up to date, more accessible and less expensive than many of the books traditionally maintained in our law library."
The legal profession traditionally lags well behind the business world in applying technology to its own internal management requirements and the wants and needs of its corporate clients. This is particularly true when it comes to communications, both voice and electronic, the information exchange and the all important tasks of cost control, billing and collections. The hardware and software tools necessary for law firms to deal with their clients in the electronic environment with which those clients themselves operate is available: High-speed Internet connections and data transfer, clients/server base billing and accounting systems, some of which provide for electronic building, Intranets, imaging and video. The trick is to get law firm policy makers to focus on the technology issue, understand it sufficiently and be willing to devote the necessary funds. Those that can pull it off stand to reap tremendous advantages over their lower-tech competitors in the form of speed, efficiency, cost saving, and perhaps most important, clients and prospective clients who can see that their attorneys are on the technology ball.

HEADLINE: The Formula for Sun City Moves East and North

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: BLUFFTON, S.C.

 BODY:
THE first commercial developments are rising outside the gates of the sprawling Sun City retirement community here, three years after Del Webb Corporation started building its only East Coast venture.
Company executives say the new commercial properties -- a medical center, bank, supermarket and fast-food restaurant -- demonstrate that local investors now consider the venture economically viable. 
 Many had seemed skeptical about whether a large-scale retirement community -- it will eventually have 17,000 residents -- could be carved from the isolated pine barrens 13 miles east of Hilton Head Island, according to Glen McCaskey, a spokesman for Del Webb.
But three years of sales have produced 1,000 buyers -- the 1,000th on Dec. 20 -- and a functioning community where 800 houses are already occupied, tightly packed on lots mostly 77 feet wide by 110 feet deep. Two hundred more houses are in construction. "We are selling about 500 houses a year," Mr. McCaskey said.
Sun City Hilton Head, as the development here is called in an effort to capitalize on the fame of the Hilton Head vacation resort 13 miles away, represents Del Webb's first venture in the East after 40 years of development in Arizona, Nevada and California.
Last month the company announced still another venture in a new region, 45 miles northwest of Chicago in suburban Huntley, Ill., the company's only project in the snowbelt. It will have 4,800 homes, an 18-hole golf course and a recreation complex on 1,800 acres of rural land a mile north of Interstate 90, the company said.
In a survey conducted by Del Webb several years ago, 85 percent of those polled expressed the desire to spend their retirement near their long-time homes. And an American Association of Retired Persons poll of the soon-to-be-retired found that 95 percent had that preference.
"Our research shows there is a growing population who want an active quality life but have consistently demonstrated the desire to retire close to family and friends," said David G. Schreiner, the general manager of the Chicago development, which will be ready for its first occupants in mid-1999. Actual construction will begin with the spring thaw. Company officials say they have heard from several thousand people interested in the Chicago development.
Here in South Carolina, Sun City Hilton Head serves a heretofore untapped market by offering retirement homes in the $130,000 to $170,000 range. At Hilton Head and other South Carolina coastal communities, homes sell for upwards of $200,000.
When the project is completed in 2012, some 17,000 people will live here on 5,600 acres, about a third of which has been set aside for golf courses, nature paths and walking trails. A full-scale recreation complex with indoor and outdoor pools, a fitness center, tennis courts, a social hall and craft center covers some 45 acres in the heart of the complex. Yet to be built are two golf courses and clubhouses, a bowling alley, a 325-seat theater, a 1,000-seat outdoor pavilion and a sports building. Residents tend to stay on the site, which is 13 miles from restaurants and major commercial development, at Hilton Head.
THE University of South Carolina, which will soon begin construction of a branch campus near the development's rear entrance, will conduct its first two courses in the Sun City social hall beginning this month.
When it began operations in 1960, the Del Webb Corporation represented a new concept in retirement living. By offering a full-scale recreation program and limiting ownership to those 55 and older, Del Webb launched what has come to be known as the active-retirement complex.
The company's founder, Del E. Webb, a former co-owner of the New York Yankees, sold 1,300 units in the Phoenix Sun City in the first year, convincing bankers and investors of the viability of the concept.
At about the same time, Mr. Webb's company was also developing corporate facilities and residential subdivisions in Oak Brook, Ill., in partnership with Paul Butler. McDonald's Corporation, Xerox and RCA all have corporate headquarters there now. Oak Brook is 35 miles southeast of the Sun City site.
The company is playing up its ties to the Chicago area as it begins marketing the new development. In addition, the company reports that some 11,000 Illinois residents have bought Sun City homes in other areas, the company's second highest market. California is first.
"Chicago residents love Chicago and don't want to leave," Mr. Schneider said, referring to company research. But, new retirees say they will move to a more rural area to escape crime and traffic. They preferred the area northwest of Chicago over Wisconsin and Michigan, the survey showed.
Here at Sun City Hilton Head, an overwhelming number of buyers are from South Carolina. New York, Pennsylvania, Florida and Georgia also lead the list.
Mr. McCaskey said one of the challenges the company has faced in marketing the property has been the long distances prospects must travel to see the resort. In other areas, prospects generally travel an hour or two and spend about three days getting the feel of the property. Here, prospective buyers usually spend almost a week. Though most arrivals drive from home, the development is also seeking buyers from afar. The two nearest airports are 13 miles away, the municipal field at Hilton Head and Savannah International Airport.
The development's look has been tailored to suit the area, with clapboard homes -- ranging in size from 1,000 to 2,900 square feet -- sporting muted colors, porches and steep roofs. In the West, most of the homes are stucco with tiled roofs.
WHERE 90 percent of Southern Californians recognize the name Del Webb, here it was virtually unknown. Its method of operation was new as well. The company does not sell individual lots as most developers do. It sells the entire package, allowing the owner to select carpet, wallpaper and the like from a sales center. When Del Webb has sold between 91 and 93 percent of a certain neighborhood, construction begins, one house at a time, with the workmen making their way down the street.
Ronald and Marcia Garner moved from Cornwall, N.Y., about 50 miles north of New York City, 10 months ago. They clinched their deal over a long weekend after touring several models and making selections from the sales center.
Mr. Garner, who retired as a sales engineer from EE Controls in Hawthorne, N.Y., before moving here, said he liked Sun City because of amenities like the $40 million Town Square, where the fitness and social centers are situated. He and his wife spent about two years looking at retirement areas on the East Coast.
"We were afraid we might move into a community that just has local people and we wouldn't be accepted," said Mr. Garner, who is 63 and lived 35 years in the New York metropolitan area. "Here there are no locals."
Because of that, friends -- and an active social life -- are easier to come by, he said. The South is also a much different place today than he remembers from his time as a young soldier taking basic training at Fort Jackson, about 120 miles west of here near Columbia, S.C.
"We're not living on the edge of civilization or in the Old South," he said.
"The thing we're really selling is lifestyle and theoretically you ought to be able to put it anywhere," said Mr. McCaskey.
That will be the test for the company as it expands its operation into the Chicago area. Taking note of the surge of retirees to come as the so-called baby boomers reach retirement age over the next decade, Del Webb has moved into an aggressive growth program.
It recently announced plans to buy Spruce Creek Golf and Country Club near Ocala, Fla. The purchase represents the company's first foray into the nation's pre-eminent retirement state since it sold Sun City Center near Tampa in 1971 after nine years of disappointing sales.
Only about 300 of the 2,860 homes have been built so far in Spruce Creek. The company said it was buying the company to take advantage of an approved development plan and a knowledgable work force. Del Webb officials said that the company planned additional projects in Florida.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

Giant Creatures, Up Close
"Alaska: Spirit of the Wild" has opened at the Imax Theater inside the Maritime Aquarium in South Norwalk. Hungry grizzly bears, swooping eagles, 30-foot blocks of ice catapulting into the sea, caribous stampeding and salmon struggling upstream are some of the scenes that will seem to be within inches of your face. 
The 40-minute film, narrated by Charlton Heston, begins with the creation of what is now Alaska some 18,000 years ago, and the people who migrated from Siberia to settle there. Sea lions and beavers, polar bears and musk ox, wolves and bison fill out the cast.
Screening times are 11 A.M., noon, 1, 2, and 3 P.M. daily, with an extra show at 4 P.M. on Saturday and Sunday, through June 18. Admission is $6.50, with discounts for older people and children. The aquarium is at 10 North Water Street, off Exit 14 or 15 of Interstate 95. The number is (203) 852-0700 for more information.
 
Country Club Satire
Douglas Carter Beane is the author of "The Country Club," now in its first major production at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.
The play, which is part autobiography of the Wyomissing, Pa., author, runs through Feb. 1 and is a satire on the lives of Pooker, Froggy, Hutch and other of the too-too rich, approaching age 30. They are members of the country club, from which privileged atmosphere they must emerge into the real world.
Mr. Beane's screenplay for "To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar" was produced by Steven Spielberg and featured a cast including Wesley Snipes, Patrick Swayze, John Leguizamo and Stockard Channing. His "As Bees in Honey Drown" is currently running Off Broadway.
Performances at the Long Wharf are scheduled on Tuesday at 7; Wednesday through Friday at 8; Saturday at 4 and 8:30; Sunday at 2 and 7. Tickets priced from $15 to $39 may be reserved by calling (203) 787-4282.
 
Classes in Signing
Each year the National Theater of the Deaf in Chester holds classes in sign language, taught by Betty Beekman with a touch of humor and theatricality. Students are not necessarily hearing-impaired. In fact, according to Laine Dyer, director of publicity for the theater, "most of the students are not deaf at all. They find signing useful in their jobs."
Scuba divers, for example, sign under water to each other, teachers want the skill for use with hearing-impaired students, maitre d's and waitstaff in restaurants, shopkeepers and church personnel find it a great advantage in dealing with deaf or partially deaf customers or parishioners.
There are four levels from beginner to conversational, advanced and total immersion or silent. Each class lasts for six weeks, once a week for two hours, and costs $60 plus a $15 text. Beginning sessions start on Saturday from 9 to 11 A.M. The remaining levels, all held on weekday evenings from 7 to 9, begin on Jan. 13, April 14 and April 30.
The number for more information or to register is (860) 526-4971.
 
Assessing the Economy
Rae D. Rosen, senior economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will be the speaker at a breakfast on Thursday from 7:45 to 9:45 at the Holiday Inn in Stamford.
Ms. Rosen will talk about the international financial situation and its implications, the national economy and, in line with her work in financial research and analysis for the tristate region, she will discuss the area's economy.
Reservations (at $45) may be obtained by calling (203) 359-3220.
 
Dolls, Old and New
Children's toys, dolls and doll houses from the mid-19th century to the 1970's have been gathered by the Wilton Historical Society for an exhibition through January at its newly restored Betts-Sturges-Blackmar House at 224 Danbury Road (Route 7) in Wilton.
America's first commercially made doll, patented by its maker circa 1858, dolls of the 1940's and 50's, china- and bisque-headed dolls from England, France and Germany, an Italian felt doll, a rag doll and high-fashion doll are among those on display.
Large imported English so-called Baby Houses, American commercially made and homemade doll houses and their furnishings, plus the toy-sized laundry machines, old-fashioned stoves and household appliances are also exhibited.
Boys were expected to be the breadwinners, assuming responsibilities outside the home -- learning to be builders with Lincoln Logs and Erector sets, railroad engineers or perhaps owners, with elaborate electric train layouts, truck drivers, soldiers and astronauts.
In addition to its nostalgia factor, the exhibition illustrates the changes that have taken place in the way we regard sex roles. The exhibit may be seen on Tuesday through Thursday from 10 to 4, and Sunday from 1 to 4. Admission is by $2 donation. The number for more information is (203) 762-7257.
 
Ready for Camping
Whether the substantial increase to 25 million recreational vehicles on the road indicates a concurrent increase in camping is hard to determine, but the 16th Annual Northeast Recreational Vehicle and Camping Show will have all the latest equipment for a stay in the wild, the nearest trailer park, or Aunt Nellie's driveway. It will spread over 70,000 square feet of the Hartford Civic Center on Friday from noon to 9, Saturday from 10 to 9 and next Sunday from 10 to 5.
A complete line of conveyances ranging from luxurious motor homes to pop-up campers will be on display, along with camping supplies, accessories and tips on vehicle maintenance. Free seminars, scheduled throughout the weekend, will include the dispensing of advice by travel experts on some of the 16,000 camp sites across the United States, the best routes to take, and which ones are for short or long vacations.
Admission is $7, $3.50 for children from 7 through 12 years old. The number for more information is (860) 529-2123.
 
Ready for Fishing
People ready for spring and the fishing season may get an early start at the seventh Annual Fly-Fishing Show of the Hammonasset Chapter of Trout Unlimited. It will take place on Saturday from 10 to 5 at the Elks Club, 142 Seaside Avenue, in Westbrook.
The accouterments of freshwater and saltwater fishing found along Connecticut's shoreline will be featured in dealer displays, demonstrations of fly-tying, raffle items and informal talks.
Among the speakers will be Ed Mitchell, an authority on saltwater technique and tackle, and Gary Evans, a Montana guide who will give an appraisal of trout fishing in the West. A slide presentation prepared by George Terpenning, titled "Fishing Through My Memories," will be narrated live by his daughter Lisa Terpenning.
Admission is $5, free to children under 16 accompanied by an adult. The number for more information is (203) 245-2654. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
New Tax Laws for the New Year

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey smokers can add another incentive to their list of reasons for resolving to quit this year: money.
The tobacco tax doubled on New Year's Day, to 80 cents a pack of cigarettes, raising the price to about $2.50 a pack at most outlets. Cigar and pipe smokers, tobacco chewers and snuff users will also pay more. 
 The new tax is expected to bring in $200 million for the state, but Governor Whitman said she was not concerned about economists' forecasts that the higher tax would hurt sales.
"If a higher tax on cigarettes keeps people, particularly children, from smoking, that in itself is very good news for the state of New Jersey," Mrs. Whitman said.
The tax increase is the main new component of a five-year, $2.7 billion program to provide state money to hospitals and to provide subsidized health insurance for the poor. Hospitals need the money to treat people who have no insurance and to offset high-cost Medicaid cases.
Two other new laws also took on effect New Year's Day: an auto insurance package that is far weaker than Governor Whitman's original proposal, and a new energy tax structure that is eventually expected to lower consumers' electric and gas bills.
The auto insurance bill promises, but does not guarantee, small savings for New Jersey drivers, who pay the nation's highest average auto insurance rates.
The law eliminates a system that allows insurers automatic, inflation-driven rate increases each July 1. Only insurers that prove they need the higher rates will now be able to have them approved by the insurance commissioner.
It also eliminates surcharges that had been assessed for even minor traffic infractions. Those will be replaced by a tiered rating system. The bill also includes tougher anti-fraud components, makes it harder for insurers to drop good drivers and forces insurers to do more business in cities.
The new energy tax law repeals the 13 percent gross receipts utilities tax that monopolies like Public Service Electric & Gas have been paying and passing on to consumers on their electric bills.
That is replaced with a 6 percent sales tax, a 1 percent corporate tax that can be passed through to consumers and a new 6 percent transitional tax that is to be phased out by 2003. Consumers end up paying the same 13 percent at first, but that is to drop to 7 percent when the transitional tax phases out.
The new tax structure is linked to a deregulation plan that will give consumers the freedom to choose suppliers of electricity and gas, beginning in phases later this year. National power generators like Enron Corporation and Southern will begin advertising for customers, just as competing telephone companies now pitch their long-distance and regional calling services.
The law puts utilities like PSE&G on the same tax footing as other private businesses, paying a 6 percent sales tax on sales plus an income tax on corporate profits.
As the transitional tax is phased out, utility tax revenue is expected to decline from $1.2 billion to as little as $800 million by 2002. Municipal governments shared in the old utilities tax revenue, so lawmakers dedicated $740 million of the new sales tax to towns, and that figure rises to $755 million by 2002.
As a result, the state government, which in 1997 took about $430 million from utilities tax revenues, could see that dwindle to around $50 million for the first year of the next governor's term.

LENGTH: 1219 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West 57th Street;
From Women's Clubhouse to WNET to $75 a Night

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
LAST year the hotelier Ian Schrager announced plans to fix up the old Henry Hudson Hotel, at 353 West 57th Street -- but not too much. He says he wants to charge only $75 a night.
The big, boxy 24-story building is a peculiar presence on West 57th Street, within hailing distance of tenements and old industrial buildings. But things were meant to be so different, for the 1929 building was intended to complement a new Metropolitan Opera House across the street, and to serve as a club where professional women could network their way to success in the business world. 
 To Anne Morgan goes most of the credit for what was built as the American Woman's Association. The daughter of the financier J. Pierpont Morgan, she used her huge inheritance to advance causes of social justice among her crowd of socially advantaged women. In 1903 she was among the founders of the Colony Club, the pre-eminent women's club in New York, and in 1909 she brought striking women's garment workers to be heard by the membership.
Her interest in the position of the working woman took various forms and by 1921 evolved into the American Woman's Association. She brought in moneyed members of both sexes, people like Felix Warburg, Marshall Field, Ruth Baker Pratt and Anne Vanderbilt -- with whom Miss Morgan had been among the pioneer settlers of the colony of luxurious town houses on Sutton Place at East 57th Street.
In 1924 the American Woman's Association announced plans for a $4 million clubhouse on West 23d Street to serve as a residence for working women. At that time the group estimated that 700,000 women held salaried jobs in New York City, with 50,000 of those in managerial or executive positions. Their architect was Benjamin Wistar Morris, who had close ties to the Morgan family. The group took several years to raise the money.
In 1925 the financier Otto Kahn bought a large site east of Ninth Avenue from 56th to 57th Streets to serve as a new location for the Metropolitan Opera House, then struggling with its 1883 building at 39th and Broadway. The next year the American Woman's Association, which by that time had 5,000 members, decided to sell its 23d Street site and build across from the projected opera house on a plot running from 57th to 58th Street.
In a 1927 interview in The Saturday Evening Post, Miss Morgan, who never married, outlined her ideas about the prospects for urban women. Women were at a temporary disadvantage in the business world, she said, because they had been insulated from the rough and tumble that characterized men's upbringing. At the moment there were no women who could head a great corporation, but "in time there will be plenty of such women -- it requires only evolution," she said.
She called the American Woman's Association "a training school for leadership, a mental exchange" where women "can hear what other women are doing." The organization had 61 doctors, 16 lawyers, 939 teachers, a bacteriologist, a tug dispatcher and workers in many other fields. But Miss Morgan said that not everyone was eligible, only the woman "with ambition, pluck and energy, which will push her up and up in her profession."
Kahn had been working with the flamboyant architect Joseph Urban, but soon also retained Morris -- the new opera and hotel would have established an architectural dialogue across the street. But in October 1927, as the American Woman's Association broke ground for its new building, the opera boxholders decided to seek a more central site. (They did not find one until Lincoln Center opened in the 1960's.)
In early 1928, with the clubhouse project under way, a split developed in the women's group -- Gertrude Robinson Smith, president for 17 years, resigned in a dispute with Miss Morgan, her longtime friend. Miss Smith later said that a Morgan-Vanderbilt clique was trying to remake the association along elitist lines. Miss Morgan assumed direct control over the organization, which she held until 1943. She died in 1952.
In May 1928 the cornerstone was laid, with a box containing plans of buildings, newspapers, coins and other memorabilia, and predictions of the future of the feminist movement. The box was intended to be opened in 1978 -- but was not.
Completed in 1929, the new clubhouse had 1,250 rooms, along with a swimming pool, gym, meeting rooms, a restaurant, music rooms and wide terraces on the upper setbacks. Although the sleeping rooms had 128 color combinations, the exterior was bare and boxy, rising up among the aging brownstones of West 57th Street like a grain elevator in the Nebraska prairie grasses. The building was "admirably simple," The New Yorker wrote, "almost factory-like."
THE magazine Survey called the new building "a symbol of the new day that the business woman sees breaking along her horizon," and others also thought the sun was rising on West 57th Street --developers filed plans for two hotels of 30 and 45 stories just east of the association's building. Their plans did not go ahead, although the huge Parc Vendome apartment complex went up on the old opera site in 1930.
By the opening, 500 rooms in the American Woman's Association Clubhouse had been taken, and the clubhouse almost made it through the Great Depression. But in 1941, with bankruptcy proceedings under way, the association gave up and the clubhouse was converted to the Henry Hudson Hotel, for both men and women. At the hotel's opening, Hannie Davidson, an 11-year-old Dutch girl, smashed a bottle of Dutch milk against the doorway.
In 1946 the United Nations Security Council met at the hotel, but otherwise it continued as a rather lonely high-rise outpost on far West 57th Street that was better known as the headquarters of WNET, the local public television station, which owned the second through ninth floors and uses the 58th Street side as its entrance. The television station had shared ownership with St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, which owned the 11th through 24th floors, and Irving Schatz, who owns the stores, the 10th floor and the penthouse, which he uses for his office.
Last year Mr. Schrager bought out both St. Luke's and WNET, and he has leased the 10th floor from Mr. Schatz. Mr. Schrager, who redid the old Royalton Hotel on West 44th Street and the Paramount on West 46th, said he was "in the business of buying dumpy old fleabags and improving them." In the Henry Hudson he sees a location "right in the middle of everything," surrounded by new buildings on Eighth and Ninth Avenues and close to midtown.
He said that he wanted "a modern Y.M.C.A., provocative and original -- like an urban spa" -- and that he would work with his regular architect, Philippe Starck, known for his striking modern designs. Because WNET will not leave until later this year for new space on West 33d Street, Mr. Schrager expects to open the hotel in the year 2000, combining many of the original small rooms to make about 700 suites.
Two suites, redone as samples, have been economically but neatly repainted and refurnished and offer sweeping views north to Lincoln Center and southwest across the Hudson and New Jersey.
As for the American Woman's Association, it withered and was defunct by 1980, and its cornerstone -- with its predictions for the future -- sits undisturbed.
