SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2336 words

HEADLINE: Us vs. Them;
Is There a Deer Problem of a People Problem?

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
IT was dusk. The maroon station wagon slammed to a halt just as a deer came sailing across the road in a leap that took it from the woods on the left toward the field and barn across Wyckoff Road in Monmouth County. The leap was just short. The deer's hooves shattered the passenger window.
After a moment of stunned silence, the driver, Roseann Trezza, grabbed her cellular telephone and called for help -- for the deer. 
 "He was just trying to survive," said Ms. Trezza, who happens to be the assistant director of the New Jersey Humane Society. She had just picked up a colleague at the society's Tinton Falls shelter when the collision occurred a few weeks ago. "We've taken over their habitat; we've moved in on them everywhere. Their living space is smaller and smaller each year. They come out at night because they can't come out at any other time. They're just looking for food and shelter."
By the turn of the century, aggressive hunting had almost eradicated the white-tailed deer in New Jersey. Alarmed state officials began a nine-year restocking program that now seems to have worked all too well: from Passaic and Sussex Counties down to Salem, deer are everywhere.
Exactly how many is a matter of debate. Bob Lund, who manages the deer project for the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, says there are about 150,000, based on information gathered during hunting season.
John Rigolizzo Jr., the president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, practically snorts at that. "Some days, it seems like I see that many myself," he said, adding that New Jersey farms lost "upwards of $30 million" to deer annually in corn, hay, soybeans, apple trees, string beans, strawberries, pumpkins and other crops from a total harvest worth about $860 million. The estimate of 150,000, he said, "is no longer a believable number to me."
John Grande, director of the Snyder Research Farm at Rutgers University, is mailing out 16-page questionnaires to 4,000 farmers this week, hoping to end up with firm numbers for both deer and damage.
Other indicators: Hunting, which accounted for the deaths of 11,021 deer in 1972, brought down 56,704 in 1996 and is expected to exceed that for 1997. Collisions with automobiles are up, particularly during the fall rut, or mating season, and during these winter months of the hunting season. About a month ago, an amorous deer ran across the Garden State Parkway in Ocean Township and ended up causing a 12-car pileup. Miraculously, the deer was the only fatality.
John Dourgarian, a spokesman at the state Department of Transportation, says it had 11,000 deer carcasses picked up from roadsides in 1996 at a cost of $220,000. Steve Firello, who manages two of a small chain of auto body shops in Somerset and Hunterdon Counties, said he saw up to 10 cars a week with deer damage, which he figures to be 30 or 40 percent more than last year. Bruce Klein, a manager at Karl Mey's Collision and Paint Center in Mercer County, said the shop averaged 6 to 10 cars a week that had tangled with deer. And there are at least 5 a week requiring repairs costing $300 to $4,000, at Baker Pontiac's body shop, in Montgomery Township, on the border of Princeton Township, said Tom Mullane, an assistant to the manager.
Last week, one of those cars was his. He was at the intersection of Camp Meeting Road and Skillman when a deer ran in front of him. "Poor little thing," he said facetiously. "I felt like bringing it back to life so I could kill him again."
As the nation's most densely populated state (7.7 million human inhabitants over its 7,500 square miles, according to the 1990 census), New Jersey is simply ahead of, not different from, other states, said Barbara Lawrence, the head of New Jersey Future, a nonprofit organization that monitors growth. "When Kenneth Gibson was Mayor of Newark," Ms. Lawrence noted, "he said, 'Wherever the nation's cities are going, Newark is getting there first.' Well, with suburban development patterns, you can say that about New Jersey."
 
Once Upon a Time, Every Deer Was Bambi
Here, the denial is over. The deer problem has moved to the next phase: bitter debate.
Increase hunting? To groups like the Humane Society, deer shouldn't be hunted in the first place. Lee Bernstein, the society's director in Newark, said: "I have no objection to hunting if the deer is armed and can shoot back. That's hunting. The way we have it is slaughter."
The activity has no lack of defenders. They include, of course, hunters, as well as homeowners sick of having their tulips eaten, environmentalists who object to excessive deer foraging that ruins habitats for other species like songbirds, and epidemiologists who worry about deer ticks carrying Lyme disease or the possibility that deer might spread tuberculosis to cattle. In the face of such concerns, the storybook fondness for Bambi appears to be diminishing, at least in some quarters.
"Once, deer used to be considered a beautiful sight," said Mr. Grande, the Rutgers researcher. "But not anymore, not by the people hitting them with their cars." And Mr. Lund says that in his 30 years on the job, he's seen people go from the attitude "I wouldn't harm a hair on a deer's head" to "get that blankety-blank out of my yard!"
The Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife says that hunting is, so far, more effective and economical than any other deer-control method, and that it is far more humane than letting nature do the job, through starvation and disease. "If you're morally opposed to deer hunting, then don't hunt," said Ms. Predl, senior wildlife biologist at the division. But people who love wildlife should remember, she and others said, that it is hunters, by paying fees and buying licenses to the tune of $5 million a year, who are financing the state's wildlife management.
There are other moral comebacks, too. Anyone who eats meat, Mr. Lund said, should realize that a cow spends its whole life "waiting, unknowingly, for the day it'll get slaughtered." And, he said, "at least the deer hunter is doing his own dirty work."
The Humane Society and other deer advocates prefer a two-pronged plan: administering contraceptives to does, and altering land-use patterns to limit development in rural areas. Both are much more easily said than done. Dan Ferrigno, who directs the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife's deer project in southern New Jersey, said that birth control delivered by dart was completely unsuited to free-roaming populations, because the does need repeat doses. It's a little like trying to give women birth-control pills by tossing them into the crowds at the Short Hills Mall.
Even relatively small, stable populations are difficult to treat. At Frelinghuysen Arboretum in Morris Township, the Humane Society is sponsoring a pilot contraceptive project on a herd of about 20 animals. Park personnel have abandoned the darts in favor of wrestling individual deer to the ground to inoculate them, The Record of Bergen County reported last week.
Ms. Lawrence, executive director of New Jersey Future, said the group, which includes business people and environmentalists, was established 10 years ago to encourage municipalities to adhere to guidelines offered in the state regional plan adopted in 1986. That plan, which is strictly advisory, suggests a balance of preservation of natural systems and resources and compact residential and commercial development.
"It puts us in the awkward position of being in the middle," Ms. Lawrence said. "We believe in economic development, but it matters where those jobs are. And the place for deer is shrinking."
If there is a single point of agreement in the deer debates, it is that humans and their doings are at the bottom of it. Open space is disappearing in New Jersey at the rate of about 10,000 acres, or 16 square miles, a year, Ms. Lawrence said. "One of the things we're concerned with," she said, "is that the very reason people move to the places they move is they love the countryside. But just by moving there, they thereby degrade the very reason they moved there."
The Department of Environmental Protection is now compiling a comprehensive map of land use in the state. Until it is finished, Ms. Lawrence said, the best sense of the problem is "what people get when they look out their window."
What they see is obvious. Mr. Mullane, reflecting on the deer he hit, said: "Twenty years ago, you could shoot a cannon down 206 without hitting anybody. Now you can't even make a left turn."
Asked about the deer problem, Mr. Lund responded, "You mean the people problem?" Then he laughed, but only a little.
"We created this," he said. "More and more people are developing land in what used to be natural habitat, and then you wonder why the deer are eating your shrubs. Some species have disappeared. Some have prospered on what we've left them." Those include Canada geese, groundhogs, rabbits, skunks, and raccoons. But none have flourished more than deer.
In a sense, what they are adapting to is a geographical expression of the modern economy. Shopping malls and condominiums encroached on open spaces in the 70's and 80's. Now office parks and warehouse stores are rising all over the state, as are single-family houses on municipally zoned four- or five-acre tracts.
Spacious estates and woodsy office parks may be lovely places for humans to work and live. But they are also popular resorts for deer: hunter-free zones in which landscaping and horticulture provide privacy and a smorgasbord of high-quality food.
In the history of the world, deer may never have had it so good. Ms. Predl, the Fish, Game and Wildlife biologist, said they evolved over the last 36 million years from artiodactyls, an order of even-toed mammals with compartmentalized stomachs, making them distant cousins of the unlamented cow. When the European settlers arrived in the New World, deer were probably not plentiful in the forested Northeast, Ms. Predl said.
Heavy forest is not the ideal environment for deer; they prefer forest interspersed with plains. Or farms. Once agriculture turned the Northeast's virgin forest into exactly that, the deer boomed, prompting excessive hunting. When the 20th century began, there were almost no deer left in the state. New Jersey responded by banning deer hunting in 1902. Deer were brought in to rural areas from local preserves and from Michigan, Virginia and Pennsylvania starting in 1904 and ending in 1913.
By 1912, farmers were already reporting crop damage. In 1917, the state began issuing special permits to farmers, allowing them to kill deer on their property. The program continues: last year, 509 one-month permits were issued to farmers.
Mr. Rigolizzo said deer did more damage than other wildlife. "A raccoon will take an ear of corn and eat it, and maybe eat four or five," he said. "But deer are famous for walking along at night, picking something out, taking a bite, and walking on, taking another bite. They can really ruin you."
 
Hunt Them Down? It's Not That Simple
Unpalatable as it may be to many people, is hunting the answer? Surprisingly, even those who defend it can no longer simply say yes.
Hunting returned to the state in 1909, with an act of the General Assembly. That first hunting season was every Wednesday in November, and it was firmly restricted. Hunters could be fined $100 -- about three months' income at the time -- if they killed a deer out of season, or killed an antlerless deer, meaning a doe or a fawn. Today's hunting regulations are far more complex. New Jersey has 67 deer management zones in its 21 counties, and the state Fish and Game Council designs a hunting season for each one, authorizing specific time frames for shotguns, crossbows, muzzle-loaders and other weapons. To reduce the herd most effectively, killing of antlerless deer is encouraged; for every one brought in, a hunter receives a bonus tag permitting another deer to be bagged. The only problem is that many hunters have been trained since birth to never shoot does.
While there are no official national comparisons to draw on, hunters and game experts say that New Jersey's season is one of the most liberal in the Northeast; Mr. Lund of Fish, Game and Wildlife says it is the most liberal in all of the Eastern United States.
So why is there still a problem? Because, said Ms. Predl, the hunters can't get at the deer in those four-acre backyards and in those corporate parks. "You could have deer hunting 365 days a year," she said, "and if you can't get in there, you're still going to have a deer problem."
And deer, which don't seem to understand automobiles at all, do seem to grasp the hunting season. "The first day, you see them," Mr. Rigolizzo said. "After that, it's like they all went to Florida."
Some hunting opponents believe that killing deer only results in a biological response in the herd to produce more deer. Ms. Trezza, at the Humane Society, said she believes the hunting season is deliberately planned to increase the total number of deer, so hunters will have more game. Officials of the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife say that is absolutely untrue.
However, it is true that the division is trying new ways to bring hunters in contact with deer populations. This year, for the first time, High Point Park was opened to hunters. Monmouth Battlefield was opened to hunters a few years ago.
There is a controlled hunting program at Lewis Morris Park, in Morristown, and another at the Watchung Reservation, in Union County, which has resulted in the donation of more than 5,000 pounds of venison to the Community Food Bank of New Jersey.
Daniel Bernier, the chief of park operations in Union, said, "The general public has been very accepting."
They may have to be. And that may be the precedent New Jersey sets for a nation likely to become inundated with deer.
As Ms. Lawrence said, "You think its bad now? Wait, just wait."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2500 words

HEADLINE: With Space Tight, Outdated Factories Find New Roles

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
AFTER languishing on the sidelines as the wallflowers of the real estate industry, outmoded industrial buildings, vacant for years, are being pursued by investors and developers who are profiting by dressing them up and dancing them around again.
A shortage of office space in the New York suburban region and a scarcity of the sort of inexpensive research and manufacturing space needed by start-up companies have made developers take a second look at scores of dowdy manufacturing buildings and the relatively small sums it takes to buy, rehabilitate and rent them, real-estate specialists say. 
 Among the old factories being recycled in the New York area are the 1.2-million-square-foot former General Motors ball bearing plant in Connecticut, where Firestone Building Products and other manufacturers are renting space. A former silver-plating plant in New Jersey has been sold for conversion to first class office space, and an old boiler factory in Irvington, N.Y., has been redeveloped with sufficient chic to lure a Manhattan dress designer out of the garment district.
"We went through five years of distressed times when nobody was interested in industrial buildings," said Jeffrey Dunne, senior vice president in the Stamford office of CB Commercial, a national real estate company with offices in Connecticut, Westchester and New Jersey. "In an area with a strong office market, they get converted," he said, adding the caveat that "if they are out in the middle of nowhere, zoning may prohibit conversion, and sometimes it's better to knock them down."
Developers say the re-use of sturdy skeletons and foundations in these buildings keeps costs below those of new construction, even with extensive renovations, and takes about half the time required to erect a new building. The high ceilings, clerestory windows and skylights are desirable for small manufacturers, and they offer esthetic value to office tenants.
Profit is the dominant incentive for rehabilitation, but there may also be a desire to preserve historic architecture. Sales are sometimes hampered by an obligation to clean up contamination that resulted from industrial pollution.
Size, location and proximity to cities help to determine the type of re-use. Big companies like General Motors, Litton Industries, Fafnir Bearing Company and Grumman Aircraft required enormous buildings, and generated the kind of noise and pollution that were best relegated to sparsely populated areas. Many of the buildings erected by these companies during and after World War II are still standing. Older factory buildings, many of them nearer to New York City, have been propelled into obsolescence by residential, retail and office development pushing deeper and deeper into their territory.
William E. Greiner, president of Greiner-Maltz Company, commercial and industrial realtors in Woodbury, N.Y., said, "When the value of an existing property plus alteration costs equals a good return on the investment, it pays to upgrade to a higher economic use."
"Republic Aviation on Route 110 is a classic example," he said. "Since World War II, their frontage has been updated to retail outlets. There may have been several turnovers of the property, but eventually it became a highway outlet operation, salvaging as much of the floor, columns, roof, walls as possible, but adding a new facade, landscaping, and instead of industrial rent that would have been $3.50, it's $15 a foot."
Another Long Island example is a former Grumman property, a 25-year-old, 270,000-square-foot former warehouse on Route 110 in Melville now occupied by Olympus America. It contains the company's sleek headquarters, office and data center, scientific products group, 750-seat cafeteria and a retail store for Olympus cameras.
"We gutted it and reconfigured the interior to accommodate a consolidation of 3 or 4 Olympus locations and 11 of its departments," said Scott Spector, principal of the Spector Group, an architectural firm in North Hills, N.Y., hired to design the renovation. "Recycling old industrial buildings is 20 percent of our work now," he said. "It was a very minor part just a few years ago."
One kind of conversion being replicated in suburban complexes throughout the region involves the preservation of factories for use as studios for designers and artists. Overlooking the water in Irvington, N.Y., is a project nicknamed SoHo on the Hudson. Some 45 small companies consisting of architects, graphic artists, toy designers, advertising companies and others have taken space in what was once the 220,000-square-foot Lord & Burnham Greenhouse, Heating and Boiler Systems Company on Bridge Street.
"We changed the zoning from industrial to commercial and live-work loft studios," said Michael Lyons, a co-developer with William Thompson, owners since 1995. "We have a love for these turn-of-the-century buildings and we believe there is a market for preserving and converting them into creative environments." About 30,000 square feet are still available.
Eileen Fisher, a women's sportswear designer, moved her design and administrative divisions from 5,000 square feet in the Manhattan garment district to 12,000 square feet at SoHo on the Hudson for quality of life reasons, said Gerri Maslanka, chief operating officer of the Eileen Fisher company. "We expanded to 17,000 feet," she said, "and now we are negotiating for another 10,000 feet."
Convenient to rail transportation for commuting employees, the new offices have 31-foot ceilings, a mezzanine, skylights and"stunning views of the river," Ms. Maslanka said, "and we love the ambience."
At the other end of the size-location spectrum, two New York developers, Harold Fetner and David Swersky, bought the 1.25-million-square-foot former General Motors Delco Moraine ball bearings plant on 182 acres in Bristol, Conn., last August. The building had been vacant since 1994, and is, according to the developers, the largest one-story manufacturing plant in New England. Its price was $5.5 million, down from $10 million in 1994.
The new owners, calling themselves the S. F. Bristol Company, are raising 200,000 square feet of the roof, in part to accommodate their first tenant: Firestone Building Products Company, which is consolidating its Springfield, Mass., insulation plant and its North Branford, Conn., plant into 400,000 square feet of the Bristol building at a rent of $3.75 a foot. The division of the remaining footage allows for spaces as small as 5,000 square feet.
The behemoths of Connecticut's smokestack past, scattered through its central corridor, will never again be the economic engine of the state, but they are benefiting from the surge of interest in industrial plants.
"Activity has finally come to Connecticut," said Nicholas Morizio, president of Colliers, Dow & Condon, commercial realtors in Hartford. "We're the tail of the dog, because our economy is just starting to get out of the doldrums. These buildings, abandoned by manufacturers moving to the Far East, Mexico, wherever, are available, and people are buying them."
Far from urban centers and containing enormous amounts of space, they cannot hope to participate in upscale office and retail conversions, but they are attracting investors and developers who refit them for light industrial and research tenants.
More than half a dozen companies involved in fiber optics, aquaculture research, computer services, microbrewery and other pursuits are in various buildings of the 1.2-million-square-foot complex of the former American Thread Company in Windham, Conn. Now owned by the Windham Mills Development Company, a private, nonprofit agency financed by state grants and loans, the property is being redeveloped as a technology, telecommunications and business training center with ties to the University of Connecticut.
Stuart Lichter, a Bronx-born, Los Angeles-based real estate operator, recently bought two major Connecticut buildings. His firm, S. L. Equities, has redeveloped 20 million square feet of large old industrial buildings across the country. In September, he bought the 582,000-square-foot former Litton Industries complex in New Britain for $1.5 million. In October, he purchased the 660,000-square-foot former Fafnir Company plant in Newington for $4 million, and has contracted to buy the 535,000-square-foot former First Brands Building in East Hartford for an undisclosed sum.
"Not a lot of people make a career out of recycling old industrial buildings," Mr. Lichter said. "My principal competition is local preservation groups or local people on a deal-by-deal basis. We only take the largest buildings, spend several million on renovating them, and in Connecticut, rent them for $2 a foot and up."
"There are always companies closing down," Mr. Lichter said, "in good times less than other times. We're in good times now and still finding them. Big companies are downsizing and a lot of small ones are growing and taking their place."
Keith Dee, president of Estec Corporation, moved into 43,000 square feet at Mr. Lichter's New Britain complex from a 9,000-square-foot location in Chester, Conn. "We are planning to expand into another 20,000 feet," said Mr. Dee, whose company remanufactures 10- to 50-year-old machines for the aerospace industry. "We needed more space and could find very little in manufacturing space anywhere in the state. Our rent here is 70 percent less than Chester; below market." Because the factory is in an area designated by the state as an enterprise zone, he said, his company also receives benefits. Such benefits, for areas designated as needing economic stimulus, include savings on state taxes and grants for hiring employees who live within the enterprise zone.
In designated towns, Connecticut gives property tax abatements of up to 80 percent for up to 10 years, depending on how much is spent on renovating or constructing industrial and commercial buildings. Towns regard the zones as "a short-term reduction in revenues," said Keith Chapman, Newington's tax assessor, "against the real potential for growth."
AS office rents go up and concessions such as periods of free rent disappear, "People are looking for opportunities with an economic upside," said David Simpson, senior vice president in CB Commercial's office in Teaneck, N.J.
"Since 1992 we've done about 3 million square feet of turnaround renovations," said Gene Diaz, senior vice president at Gale & Wentworth, developers in Florham Park, N.J. One current project, in New Providence, N.J., is the conversion into luxury offices of a 33-year-old former Prudential distribution center of 220,000 square feet on 14 acres. "We are converting the loading docks into an atrium entranceway, resurfacing the brick exterior, demolishing 50,000 square feet to meet parking requirements, installing a marble floor and wood-paneled walls," Mr. Diaz said. "We have office leases pending at $22 a foot. That's about $3 below market."
Even at the low rent, after paying $7 million for the building and an estimated $4 million on renovations, there is still enough profit built in, he said. The neighborhood, at Spring Street at Central Avenue, had been industrial but shifted to mixed use, and now, Mr. Diaz says, "office conversions will keep going."
A former 1960's Insilco silver-plating plant on 11 acres in Clifton, N.J., bought by BASF in the 80's, is one of three New Jersey industrial buildings to be acquired in recent months by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation. Its size will be reduced from 205,000 to 180,000 square feet to accommodate 4 parking spaces per 1,000 square feet.
"We bought it in April for around $4 million and renovations will be many times that," said Mark Schaevitz, senior vice president at Reckson's West Orange office. "Two hundred fifty thousand cars a day pass it on the Garden State Parkway at the junction of Route 3, which begins at the Lincoln Tunnel," Mr. Schaevitz said. "Visibility and access for commuters is highly desirable, and we have it in spades." Asking rents will be $23 a foot, compared with industrial rents of $7 or $8 a foot.
The New York Times's 581,000-square-foot former printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J., was sold last year to Security Capital Industrial Trust, a real estate investment trust with buildings containing 100 million square feet in the United States and Europe. "We reduced it to 460,000 square feet and will spend up to $4 million on renovations for warehousing," said Michael Nachamkin, vice president and marketing officer for the trust.
While sales and conversions have been brisk for old factories, a major deterrent has been industrial pollution and the tangle of litigation and possible financial losses that can accompany cleanup efforts. Following a Federal court battle in which the town of Sleepy Hollow in Westchester tried to get G.M. to clean up its 75-year-old automotive plant, the company volunteered to return the site to pristine condition after demolition by 1999, said Sleepy Hollow's Mayor, Sean Tracy.
ANTIQUATED and unadaptable, closed since 1995, the property was rezoned from industrial to residential and commercial in line with G.M.'s proposal for redeveloping the site with housing, retail, public access to the riverfront and linkage with the Hudson Valley Greenway System. Mayor Tracy said a plan for 1,900 costly homes in the community of 8,200 people was solidly opposed at a public hearing. The Mayor added: "They say they will have a new concept to present early in 1998 aimed for construction in 2000. I'll believe it when I see it."
A contaminated 28-acre riverfront tract that Anaconda had occupied for a century in Hastings-on-Hudson has gone through a succession of owners since the 70's, but remains polluted. Theodore Kheel, president of the Earth Pledge Foundation, a nonprofit agency that hopes to develop housing, a theater and restaurant on the site, said that its current owners, Alpers Holding USA and Harbor at Hastings, are mired in litigation against each other over money.
Anxious to rid themselves of the property, they are unable to do so, because the contamination by Anaconda must be cleaned up by Atlantic Richfield, a former owner assigned to the task by the Federal Department of Conservation. Atlantic Richfield has made no move toward a cleanup, Mr. Kheel said.
It took 12 years and $21 million for the 316,000-square-foot, 37-acre Singer Sewing Machine plant in Bridgewater Township, N.J., to rid itself of contamination from pollution. "Only $5 million was recovered in the sale," said Paul D. Cohen, executive vice president for SBWE, a real estate brokerage in Edison. "ATS Wood Products bought it and has it on the market for retail, because it's in an area that is developing with shopping malls."
"It's a scary, high risk business," Mr. Lichter said. "These buildings are huge. Lots of space to rent, lots of money to lose waiting to fill them."

HEADLINE: The New Jobs: What They Are, What They Pay

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A survey released last month by state labor officials begins to answer the question of whether new jobs being created in New Jersey are good ones, or whether they're low-paying jobs that offer few benefits.
The study said jobs with the fastest projected percentage growth from 1994 to 2005 tended to be higher-paying positions, including computer programmers (with wages averaging $26.59 an hour), computer engineers ($24.37) and securities and financial sales representatives ($25.67). 
 But the salary picture is less bright when viewed in terms of the actual number of jobs that analysts expect will be added to the economy, according to the report, released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the state Department of Labor.
Jobs accounting for the greatest projected employment increase included seven occupations that all paid less than $10 an hour: nursing aides, waiters and waitresses, home health aides, janitors, salespeople, cashiers and guards,
The three highest-paying jobs on this list were systems analysts ($26.59), marketing and sales supervisors ($19.81) and nurses ($22.46).
The study on earnings was released the same month the Federal Government reported New Jersey's jobless rate was the lowest in more than seven years. The rate fell from 5.2 percent in October to 4.9 percent in November, when New Jersey employers added 8,500 jobs to the economy.
Most of the new jobs gained in November were in service industries, which posted 6,800 new jobs. Business services rose by 2,200 because of a 2,600-job increase in temporary help and employment agencies. Health care added 1,200 jobs, split about equally between hospitals and other health services. Factories added 1,500 jobs in November.
There were 4,156,700 people working in New Jersey in November. That includes commuters who work in New Jersey but live elsewhere.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Out of Work and Out of Luck? She Will Help

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD

 BODY:
SHE has seen them coming in from Bennett Road looking stunned, knowing that they have lost jobs through downsizing or plant closings, and she has seen them cry at how losing work led to the breakup of a marriage or the loss of a house, and it has touched her.
And because it touched her, Ann F. McNierney -- who comes out of Our Lady of Refuge Parish in the Bronx, a Roman Catholic education and work experience in teaching, school administration and business -- has worked that much harder, colleagues say. With almost a religious zeal, she tries to make sure her clients get back to work, and back to finding that self-respect and self-confidence that has been so shaken. 
 She has only one small cubicle in the employment service office of the State Department of Labor here. But the people who come to her for job counseling find a refuge and the concern a mother might give her children as she helps them get the training they need for a new start.
And they in turn send letters of appreciation to the office, singling her out for thanks, using words like consideration, concern and guidance. "She is really a credit to your Work Force program," one woman wrote. Another wrote, "Ms. McNierney's attitude was such a refreshing and unexpected change."
Such comments help explain why she holds the title of Counselor of the Year from the State Labor Department.
"She produces just about twice what other people working in the program produce," says Ellen Yedwab, her supervisor. "It's amazing. She counsels twice the number of people, gets them into the program and brings them through it successfully."
Ms. McNierney, who joined the Department of Labor as a counselor in early 1993, works in the Work Force Development Partnership, a state-financed vocational training program that allows experienced workers who have been laid off to get the skills they need to return to the workplace.
She assesses their situations, tries to console them, gives them a packet listing training programs in vocational schools and two-year and four-year colleges, and encourages them to research at least three of the programs before deciding which is best. Then the state provides tuition grants directly to the schools.
Work Force was created in 1992, at a time when unemployment in New Jersey was high as many companies were folding, merging or downsizing. The program was recently extended because even today, with unemployment dropping to 4.9 percent in November -- the first time in seven years it has gone below 5 percent -- there is still a sense of anxiety as downsizing continues and technology changes the face of business and industry. Even those who have been getting technological training don't always feel they are as well off as before and fear they could lose their jobs again.
"I saw people not only lose their jobs, but lose their houses, lose their families," Ms. McNierney says in her soft-spoken manner. "We're dealing with a lot more than just training and work. We're working with individuals who react in different ways to their unemployment, people who have worked 23 to 25 years with the same company, single parents, people whose husbands are dead who have to support families or support themselves, O.K.? A tremendous amount of counseling."
One woman, who lived alone and craved company after she lost her job as a receptionist, often went to do a load of wash at the laundromat just to be with someone.
Another woman broke down in tears as Ms. McNierney interviewed her.
"And I said: 'What's the matter? What's the problem?' She said: 'I have to get up in the morning. I have to get dressed. I have to go to work. I can't cope with being home. I just cant.'
"So we put her into a training program, and she came in the first or second day of training and said: 'I love it. Thank you. Thank you so much. I have something to do every day.' And she got another job as soon as she finished training."
She adds: "We saw several people from Pan Am who not only lost their jobs, but the pension plan they had counted on. And you know, they were 50 to 55 years old; they had children in college. So there was a great deal of counseling as well."
PATRICIA A. REED, manager of employment services in Jersey City, who was Ms. McNierney's supervisor, was so impressed with her work that last year she nominated her for Counselor of the Year.
In the letter, Ms. Reed said Ms. McNierney assumed the workload of a counselor who was on a six-month leave of absence and came in early and worked through lunch hour to handle it. Ms. Reed also noted that through Ms. McNierney's years of experience in education and business, she had researched all the services available to clients and built up her own network of people and organizations to refer them to.
Ms. McNierney also served as acting supervisor in Ms. Reed's absence, but when she was encouraged to become a supervisor, she declined.
"She wants to spend all her time helping the clients," Ms. Reed said. "Have you heard about all the thank-you letters she gets? I've never seen anything like that with any other counselor. She goes out of her way for every person. She listens to what they're saying. She's very calming."
Ann Fitzpatrick was born and bred in the Fordham section of the Bronx. Her father, an immigrant from Ireland, was a New York City firefighter. She won a four-year scholarship from the department's Holy Name Society to attend Holy Cross Academy in Manhattan, where she grew attached to the Sisters of Charity, and went on to attend a college operated by the order, Mount Saint Vincent in Riverdale. There she took courses emphasizing commerce and education.
After working full time as a secretary to the technical director of the Borden Company and part time as a teacher in secretarial schools, she received her master's degree in education several years later from Fordham University, where she focused on guidance and counseling.
She married a young man she met on a blind date, Edward McNierney, moved to Maywood in Bergen County and, after staying home to rear their five children, went back to work as dean of the Taylor Business Institute in Paramus, where she developed curriculums, like programs for medical and legal secretaries.
She then spent five years as director of guidance in the Fairview school system. She joined the State Department of Education in 1982 as a supervisor of student services and special education for a vocational education program in Newark called the Center for Occupational Education, Experimentation and Demonstration. At the center in Newark, she set up a career program for students, including many with physical and mental disabilities, in 23 different vocational training areas.
Despite its success in helping so many students find their way in the world, the program was eliminated in June 1992.
"I was terribly disappointed," she said. "It was devastating, and I spent a lot of time with the parents of handicapped children trying to save it."
And, for the first time, she was without a job herself.
ONE of the major changes she has seen in the five years in her present job is the growth of the computer and the constant need to upgrade computer skills.
"I've had had advertising managers come in, six-figure salaries; they lost their jobs because they don't have the graphics skills," she says. "I find once they have graphic design skills, they get a job right away."
She adds, "The same way with draftsmen, engineers. I've had people with master's in engineering, and they don't have the latest computer skill.
"We have a lot of clerks, secretaries laid off because they don't have computer skills, even though they have a solid work history and are people-oriented. They've had good evaluations, some of them huge salaries."
Often people take jobs at lower salaries than they were earning before, and she advises them early on to be realistic in salary expectations. In fields like electronics, however, after training, her clients often will make more money in new jobs.
In the end, she says, her job is about meeting people. "It's not just the paperwork or getting people into training," she says, "but helping solve people's problems, helping to reduce their stress."
Aside from the good she does on her job, she and her husband, who retired as project manager for tenant planning and design at the World Trade Center after the 1993 bombing killed several of his colleagues, volunteer their time to feed and shelter the homeless at Holy Trinity Church in Hackensack and a family shelter in the former St. Cecilia's High School in Englewood. She also served on the Maywood Board of Education from 1976 to 1980, the last year as president.
Of these acts, she explains, "I need to help people."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1439 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Mack-Cali Realty Corporation;
From Two Family Firms, a 'Super-Regional REIT'

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
NOT long ago they were family-run New Jersey real estate companies that competed head to head in the suburban office market in the northern part of the state.
Now, in a move that underscores the growing public ownership of real estate, the Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, which became a real estate investment trust in 1994, has merged with the Mack Company of Rochelle Park. 
 The $1.2 billion transaction, announced in August and closed last month, involved the sale of 9.2 million square feet of offices. It elevates Mack-Cali Realty Corporation to one of the largest office real estate investment trusts in the country, with 22 million square feet in 187 buildings and assets of $3.5 billion. REIT's are entities that invest in real estate, paying most of their earnings as dividends to shareholders.
Mack-Cali's holdings also include the Patriot American Office Group, a building owner in Texas and Arizona. "Spreading its wings could buffer the company from the vagaries of one market and make it more appealing for other private companies to join," said David Csontos, a managing director at the Saddle Brook office of the Insignia/Edward S. Gordon national brokerage company.
Most of the space Mack-Cali owns is in markets from suburban Philadelphia to Fairfield County, Conn. and half is in New Jersey. It controls 8 percent of the space in the state's 11-county northern and central market and 20 percent of Class A offices, which with an 8.3 percent vacancy rate is the tightest segment. The average asking rent for such space was $24.43 a square foot as of the third quarter of 1997, up from $22.74 in 1996, said Cushman & Wakefield, another national brokerage.
Thomas A. Rizk. chief executive officer of Mack-Cali, said the company's goal is to become "the dominant super-regional REIT in the Northeast" and said the merger "gives us beachheads in the Southwest."
Mack-Cali is a force to be reckoned with, but its share of the state's 140 million square feet of offices is too small to influence rents marketwide, said David Bernhaut of the Financial Services Group at Cushman & Wakefield. But, he said, it could affect rents in submarkets where it predominates.
The company faces increased competition. In the last year, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, N.Y., a public REIT, and Wellsford Commercial Properties Trust, a private REIT in Chatham, N.J., entered the scene. National REIT's, including Crescent Real Estate Equities of Dallas, are also trying to gain a foothold in New Jersey, which is fertile ground for building sales because of the availability of capital, a tight market and a lack of construction. In the year just ended, 12.1 million square feet of space, valued at $1.1 billion, was sold or was under contract to be sold. Last year, $900 millionworth of properties was sold, Cushman & Wakefield said.
The rise in so-called equity real estate trusts in New Jersey mirrors that in the rest of the country. In 1996 there were 166 such REIT's, up from 86 in 1991, said the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts, a trade group in Washington.
Their growth has raised concerns. "There is too much money chasing far too few quality properties, which will lead to higher prices and lower returns," said David T. Houston of Colliers Houston & Company, a brokerage in Teaneck. "If the upside for REIT's is based on the continued escalation of rents, how much farther can rents go up?"
Mr. Bernhaut said the bidding competition has forced up prices for Class A properties in the state to $150 to $175 a square foot. Several deals were over $200 a square foot, he said, which is above the $180 a square foot needed to make new construction possible.
What the presence of REIT's will mean when the next economic downturn comes is still unclear. But some industry executives like Douglas H. Haynes, president of Alexander Summer, a brokerage in Paramus, say that the liquidity provided by REIT's will smooth the real estate cycle, and that the discipline of the stock market will prevent the kind of lending that fueled the mid-80's building boom.
Becoming a REIT has benefited Cali, founded as a development company in 1949 by two brothers, John and Angelo Cali, and their friend Edward Leshowitz. When it went public in 1994 it had 13 buildings with 2.2 million feet of space. Since then, Mr. Rizk has led the company's growth, including the acquisition last January of the Robert Martin Company, a leading office developer in Westchester County, and now the merger with the Mack Company.
Mr. Rizk shrugged off the competition. With the Mack company incorporated, "we have over 100 years of development and real estate experience, and between our size, tenant base and network of relationships, we feel we have a big competitive advantage," he said.
ANOTHER advantage, many said, is the bankable name of William Mack, who, with his brothers, Earle, Fred and David, are the third generation to run the family company founded at the turn of the century. William Mack is known on Wall Street as a savvy investor from his involvement as a partner in the Apollo Fund, which buys underperforming properties worldwide.
Joining a REIT benefits private developers, who pay no capital gains taxes when they swap their buildings and land for REIT partnership units. Investors are only taxed when the partnership units are converted to REIT shares.
For Mack, which was attracted to the favorable tax treatments as well as the access to capital a REIT provides, the merger "presents us with enormous opportunities," said William Mack, who is director and chairman of the executive committee at Mack-Cali. His family has an 18 percent equity stake in the new company.
Mitchell Hersh, chief operating officer at Mack and now president and chief operating officer at Mack-Cali, said a REIT "was the logical way to continue to grow our company."
"Since our companies share many things in common," he said, "joining with Cali was a natural fit."
Mack-Cali's merger is fueled by a sense that investors will reward size and diversity. A bigger company, said Louis W. Taylor, senior real estate analyst at Prudential Securities, can command lower borrowing rates, funnel more money into acquisitions and reduce administrative costs.
With the ability to raise $1 billion, Mack-Cali intends to continue to grow in New Jersey, particularly in major submarkets where the company is underrepresented, Mr. Rizk said. One is the Princeton Route 1 corridor, where the company is reported to have purchased a 159,000-square-foot building and is said to be vying for Carnegie Center, a 1.8-million-square-foot office park with land for another 2.2 million feet in West Windsor. Another is Morris County, where Mack-Cali is reported to be a top contender for the Prudential Business Campus, a 875,357-square-foot office center with land for 1.4 million more feet of space, straddling Parsippany and East Hanover. Mr. Rizk declined to comment on either the Princeton Route 1 reports or the status of the Prudential Business campus negotiations.
Mr. Bernhaut of Cushman & Wakefield said that as the supply of so-called trophy properties in New Jersey shrinks, he expects REIT's to go after Class B properties and eventually to start to develop new office buildings.
Mr. Hersh, however, said Mack-Cali would pursue its growth through the acquisition of family real estate companies and properties in other regional markets and the Southwest as well as residential and build-to-suit development in New Jersey. As a result of the merger, the company has enough land in New Jersey alone to do seven million square feet of development, more that half of it along the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City.
"The Northeast is not yet ready for significant speculative development," Mr. Hersh said, adding that the company, because of its expanded tenant base, will seize opportunities to build for specific tenants.
One property for which the company will be seeking development possibilities is the Harborside Financial Center on the waterfront in Jersey City, which Cali purchased last year. It includes 1.9 million square feet of existing office space, land to develop 4.1 million more feet of offices and two piers. The piers are zoned for residential or mixed uses, including a hotel. On the north pier Mack-Cali envisions the development of 200 to 300 low- rise residences; on the south pier a hotel of about 200 to 300 rooms. In terms of a development schedule, Mr. Hersh said: "I would not rule out starting development on one or both of the piers in 1998."

HEADLINE: AT THE SHORE;
A Singular Elephant That May Be in Danger of Extinction

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
For more than a century, Lucy the Elephant, the enormous beachfront pachyderm in Margate City, has withstood storms, neglect, commercial development and the threat of the wrecking ball to become a popular seashore landmark.
Now, it is at risk again. The Save Lucy Committee, once a popular charity among Atlantic City casinos, civic groups and local beachgoers, has seen donations dwindle since it won a $305,190 matching grant from the New Jersey Historic Trust in 1995 to complete renovations. Previous contributions, mostly from casinos, helped the committee match one-third of that amount. It must raise the remaining $200,000 by September or lose the rest of the grant. 
 Such a loss would not threaten Lucy with extinction, said Josephine Harron, the committee's president. Margate City pays the structure's utility bills, and operating expenses are covered by admission fees, profits from the gift shop, an annual crafts show and summer rental fees for a snack bar.
"But it would leave us with an unfinished building, which in itself would be vulnerable to any kind of problem we can imagine," Ms. Harron said. "The problems we've been having in the last 20 years have all been with things we couldn't imagine, from interior rust and corrosion to humidity, insect infestations and the rotting of the wooden structural supports. We'd get the funding to fix one thing and find a dozen other things in worse shape.
"Now, if any other major problem comes up, it will force us to close, and even if nothing major happened, we'd still have nothing to pay for even the simplest repairs. One big storm, and we're out of business."
In the past, Ms. Harron said, the committee could depend on contributions from the casinos, which also promoted Lucy as a tourist attraction for gamblers and convention visitors with families. Those contributions ended last year, she said.
Michael DiLeva, community affairs director for Harrah's Atlantic City, confirmed that Harrah's, which had previously contributed money from its video arcade to the committee, was "not going to do anything to help Lucy out."
"We were able to provide a lot of support for a while," he said. "But there are other organizations, like the United Way, the Community Food Bank and the Atlantic City Rescue Mission, that need help."
Ms. Herron said she was also turned down by the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority, the state agency that channels casino profits into civic improvements.
The authority's director, James Kennedy, said: "We got their application, but there hasn't been a compelling need to deal with it. When you're criticized for not building enough low-income housing, it's real hard to do an elephant."
Margaret Westfield, the architect who has supervised Lucy's restoration since 1992 and helped write the committee's Historic Trust grant application, speculated that the real problem might be "that we've tried to stay as far out of politics as we can."
"It's possible that because Lucy is in Margate, which doesn't have the urban problems that Atlantic City has, the C.R.D.A. can think we're not that important," she said. "But if you look in Lucy's guest book or spend time in the gift shop, you'll see that people from all over world come to New Jersey just to see Lucy."
She admitted that the Save Lucy Committee had not done an economic impact study to establish exactly how much tourist money Lucy brought to the state.
That assumption was one of the factors that won Lucy two matching grants from the Historic Trust, the first in 1992, for $182,390; the second in 1995. The Historic Trust's chairman, Donald Sanderson, said his organization stayed "absolutely removed from politics" in awarding grants.
Yet a key criterion is the grant recipient's ability to match the funds. "The match is absolutely critical," Mr. Sanderson said. "Grants are not awarded if the the funding to match them isn't in place. It's clear that there have been some drastic changes in Lucy's status in the last two years. Whatever the casinos were doing for her back then was certainly taken into account."
If the Save Lucy Committee fails to raise $200,000 by September, "that money disappears for good," Mr. Sanderson said. "They can't reapply for more because the trust has no money left and there isn't a state bond issue awaiting approval that would give us more."
Ms. Harron said she was embarrassed to see her organization put in a competitive relationship with other charities. "There's no question that people who can't get enough to eat, or don't have a roof over their heads, need as much help as they can get," she said. "Saving lives and saving a landmark is not the same thing.
"But to go from being something that the casinos were proud to support, to absolutely nothing in two years, is something I just cannot understand."
At 74, she added, she is "not too proud to beg."
"I've done it before," she said. "I'll do it again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lucy, the Margate elephant, as generations of shoregoers may remember it, photographed during the summer of 1993. The attraction is threatened by structural problems. (George McNish for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Miss Siderias, Mr. Stavropoulos

 BODY:
Calliope Maria Siderias, a daughter of Despina Siderias of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., and Chios, Greece, and the late Constantine Siderias, is to be married today to Peter George Stavropoulos, the son of Nancy Stavropoulos of New York and the late George Stavropoulos, the fashion designer. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the Dean of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, is to perform the ceremony at the cathedral.
Mrs. Stavropoulos is a risk analyst at Moody's Investors Service in New York. She graduated from Fordham University, from which she also received a master's degree in international political economy and development. Her father was a restaurateur. Her maternal grandfather, the late Dimitrios Frangoulis, was the founder and editor of The Proodos Daily in Chios. 
 Mr. Stavropoulos is the chief corporate counsel at Xware, a data-base consulting and software engineering company in New York. He graduated from Boston University and received law and M.B.A. degrees from Fordham. His father was known for his chiffon evening dresses, which first came to wide public notice when Lady Bird Johnson wore an alabaster Stavropoulos design to the opening of the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center in 1966.
The bride wore a beaded white satin dress from the last Stavropoulos collection, in 1990.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS;
Niche Providers Out of the Shadow of Megamanagers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
AT a time when big Wall Street houses are acquiring smaller rivals to build the critical mass they believe is needed to compete, two highly regarded managers have chosen to follow the David model, not the Goliath.
In August 1996, two months after Merrill Lynch acquired Hotchkis & Wiley, Tad Rivelle and Laird Landmann, principals and co-directors of fixed income at Hotchkis, left to form Metropolitan West Asset Management in Los Angeles. 
 Their philosophy is that niche providers of investment management services can better serve clients than megamanagers can. Their clients seem to agree.
They are now managing $1.8 billion for institutional clients including the Mayo Foundation of Rochester, Minn.; the Keyspan Energy Corporation, the holding company for Brooklyn Union Gas, and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer of Collegeville, Pa. This flies in the face of a prediction by Goldman, Sachs last year that 20 or so companies, each with more than $150 billion of assets, would dominate the money-management industry by the end of the century.
What is more, at the end of March 1997, Metropolitan West established two no-load, fixed-income mutual funds: the Low Duration fund, which invests in short-term securities, and the Total Return fund, which holds longer-term securities. They have attracted nearly $100 million in assets even though they are too new to be rated by Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking firm in Chicago. But no wonder. Managing similar funds at Hotchkis, the two men had stellar records, and their new funds are now outperforming both the Hotchkis funds and the indexes. Both funds invest in a variety of debt securities including Treasuries, investment-grade corporates, money-market instruments and asset-backed securities.
As of Tuesday, the Total Return fund, net of fees, was yielding 11.7 percent, compared with 10.1 percent for the similar Hotchkis fund and 10.0 percent for the Lehman Brothers Aggregate Bond Index, while the Low Duration fund was yielding 6.8 percent, compared with 6.3 percent for the similar Hotchkis fund and 5.8 percent for the Merrill Lynch 1- to 3-Year Treasury index.
"Mr. Rivelle's funds are off to a great start because he carried over his philosophy to the new funds," said Alice Lowenstein, fixed-income editor at Morningstar Mutual Funds, the Morningstar newsletter.
She added that she would recommend the funds mainly because the managers concentrated on strategies that add value to a bond fund, like buying undervalued securities or focusing on the less expensive areas of the fixed-income market. They also minimize bets on interest rates, which can avoid the potential for a big misstep. "The past performance records of the managers speak for themselves," she said.
In 1994, when the bond market had one of its worst years ever, no fixed-income mutual fund manager did better than Mr. Rivelle. His Low Duration fund at Hotchkis was the country's No. 1 performer, rising 5.18 percent when competing finds were down an average of 3.3 percent.
This record was one of the factors that made Hotchkis attractive to Merrill. Though the two new Metropolitan funds, of course, are not clones of the Hotchkis portfolios, they have similar investment styles.
"Metropolitan West Asset Management's fixed-income philosophy has been designed with the goal of consistently outperforming a client's benchmark while maintaining low volatility," Mr. Landmann said.
He added that such outperformance was gained through measured application of five "value-added" strategies:
* Maintaining the average maturity of securities within the fund. Mr. Landmann said that because managing interest-rate risk is a cornerstone of their philosophy, Metropolitan does not buy bonds with maturities that raise or lower the portfolio's average duration by more than a year.
* Managing yield curve, which means including a mix of maturities that are appropriate for each portfolio.
* Using all sectors of the bond market and other fixed-income instruments, like corporate and mortgage-backed securities.
* Looking for undervalued securities.
* Using buying and selling strategies that involve more securities firms to get the best possible price.
By applying this discipline, the two have succeeded with funds they started at what many would call a bad time -- six days after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates, pushing bond prices lower. Talk of further Fed action was heard most of last year, but the Fed did not tighten again, and bond prices have rallied, sending the yield on the long bond to less than 6 percent, from 7 percent.
"We don't have any special skills in predicting the direction of interest rates or whether corporate bonds will do better than mortgage bonds," Mr. Rivelle said, "but we recognize the connection between rates and the business cycle."
Each quarter, in discussions with members of their fixed-income team, they review that cycle and economic and market developments. From this review, major themes are identified as the keys to what drives the economy and the Federal Reserve, Mr. Rivelle and Mr. Landmann said.
ALTHOUGH relatively young, the two have been in the investment business long enough to have acquired impressive credentials.
Mr. Rivelle, 36, received a bachelor's degree in physics from Yale University, a master's degree in applied mathematics from the University of Southern California and an M.B.A. from U.C.L.A. He has 11 years of investment experience, especially in mortgage-backed and corporate securities. Before joining Hotchkis & Wiley, he was portfolio manager and a vice president at the Pacific Investment Management Company (Pimco), and before that he was involved in developing asset-allocation investment models at Scudder, Stevens & Clark.
Mr. Landmann, 34, received a bachelor's degree in economics with honors from Dartmouth College and an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago. At Hotchkis & Wiley, he obtained experience in futures, options and corporate securities, and like Mr. Rivelle was a portfolio manager and vice president of Pimco. Before that, he was a derivatives specialist with Morgan Stanley's fixed-income division, where he learned hedging strategies.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2104 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS;
Still High on Low-Flying Technology Stocks

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY is in a slump. Wall Street has been getting nervous about the sector, and it has been hit hard by the Asian crisis. But Michael Murphy, long a fan of the field, is as high on it as ever.
Mr. Murphy, founder and editor of the California Technology Stock Letter and author of "Every Investor's Guide to High-Tech Stocks and Mutual Funds" (Broadway Books, $27.50), to be published this week, contends that technology's recent troubles are due to misconceptions, not fundamentals. 
 From his offices in Half Moon Bay, Calif., Mr. Murphy, 56, argues that most investors are seriously underweighted in technology, which is the main sector in what he calls the "new economy," and seriously overweighted in the venerable corporations of the "old economy." Indeed, rather than allocate assets only according to stocks, bonds and so forth, Mr. Murphy would also do so by "new economy" holdings and "old economy" holdings.
Recently, Mr. Murphy, who manages individual portfolios and three mutual funds that specialize in technology, discussed how to do research in this complex field, how to pick winners and how to limit the industry's high risks.
Q. The technology sector finished 1997 down nearly 14 percent from its yearly high. Do you think that presents an opportunity?
A. Yes. I take very seriously what's going on in the Far East, but I think Wall Street's got it backward. The companies that are hurt the most are those that depend on consumer sales there -- soft-drink companies, tennis shoe companies, airlines. The effect on technology is rather limited. Yet that's been one of the groups that's been devastated by Wall Street.
Q. Why?
A. Wall Street looks and says: "Gee, there are problems in the Far East. Who does business in the Far East? Let's sell their stock." A lot of semiconductor companies, for example, make chips here, ship them to the Far East to be assembled and then they come back into the United States and are put into computer or communication systems.
But why would it hurt these semiconductor companies to have these countries' currencies collapse? After all, production costs are lowered.
Of course, semiconductor equipment companies do sell a lot to Korean and Japanese semiconductor manufacturers. But think for a second about how you would get yourself out of this mess if you were in one of these countries. You would not build ships and automobiles and tennis shoes. That's where the excesses are. Instead, you'd focus on businesses with double-digit growth. That's basically technology; there's nothing else growing that fast.
Q. So there must be other factors at play in the technology slump?
A. I think it's all psychology at this point. For example, there was a fear that personal-computer sales would not grow at all in the December quarter, that they'd be flat versus last year. That fear was expressed in a lot of Wall Street reports.
Well, it's now clear that we're going to be up 15 percent in terms of dollars, 18 percent in terms of units, in the quarter, just like in every other quarter in 1997. And for 1998, the lowest forecast I've seen is 13 1/2 percent. So I think it's a great time to be buying these stocks.
Q. How fast is the technology sector growing?
A. About 20 percent a year, right now. And because it's been doing that for a while, it's up to about 15 percent of the total economy.
Q. You've said that Wall Street is sometimes lazy when it comes to covering technology. Why is that?
A. More than 90 percent of analysts are still covering the old economies, either the old mass-production economy, which is where most of the big, comfortable corporate names are, or the even older industrial economy. The reason -- I'm a little cynical, I guess -- is that Wall Street puts its research where the investment banking fees are going to be. And most technology companies are like Microsoft: They do one public offering, once. They don't do secondary offerings. They don't raise a lot of capital. They may occasionally do an acquisition, but not many; a lot of the growth is internal.
As a result, there are a lot of technology companies out there, even with market capitalizations of $100 million to $200 million, that have very little or no coverage.
Q. Then how should the average investor get technology information?
A. These are the best of times for the average investor on that score. Because they don't get coverage from Wall Street, most of these companies now have Web sites where their public-relations firms have written a corporate overview that gives you a lot of the basic facts. All the press releases and the numbers will also be there. The companies have really helpful investor-relations people, too.
The reason for all this help is that technology companies really want individual stockholders. They feel too exposed when their stock is 70 or 80 percent held by institutions and all those institutions are listening only to two analysts. You know, one of them might wake up in the morning a little grumpy and there goes the stock price, down 30 percent.
Q. How do you define technology enterprises?
A. The key differentiator for technology companies is that they spend a lot of money on research and development. We like to see them spend at least 7 percent of annual revenues on R & D. The reason R & D is important is that by creating new products a company helps create its own demand. Nobody knew they had to be on the Internet five years ago. But now it is available and now people believe they have to be on it.
Q. How can you tell if R & D money is being wasted?
A. There are a couple of ways. The first is the common-sense test. Here's a wonderful example. Some years ago, a company was working on doing electrocardiograms of dogs over the telephone. This thing had a $60 million marketing capitalization when it went public, and they'd only done about seven tests. In this system, you called up and gave them your Visa card and they sent you a couple of little rubber cups and you put one over the phone and one over the dog and dialed a special number. I mean, there was a product and they were spending a lot of money on it, but it was just stupid.
Second, if the company is spending a significant amount of money on R & D, ask the investor-relations person, "What percentage of your revenues come from products you've introduced in the last three years?" That number ought to be about 50 percent. If not, then you've got a legitimate question to ask.
This is I.B.M.'s problem. It spends more on R & D than anybody else -- about $6 billion a year -- and yet far less than half of its revenues come from new products.
Q. Explain growth flow -- your method for picking technology stocks.
A. Growth flow is similar to cash flow, a concept people are used to. Cash flow is earnings plus depreciation, and the reason you care about it is that both earnings and depreciation belong to the shareholders.
In an old-economy company, there is a lot of depreciation. But most technology companies don't have a lot. What they do have that would be an expense, but is really an investment for shareholders, is R & D.
So if you add earnings per share to R & D per share you get growth flow. And the advantage of it is that the ratio of stock price to growth flow will tip you off that a stock is cheap before the price-earnings ratio will. And you'll have enough time to go in there, see if they're doing all that R & D on something of interest to you, if the management is able and so on. Later, when the R & D results in new products and the new products result in an increase in earnings, Wall Street will pile on because, of course, they only look at earnings.
Q. What are some good growth-flow companies?
A. LSI Logic is a semiconductor company that has had earnings of about $1.15 a share for the last 12 months. The R & D per share is $1.30 -- they actually spend more on R & D per share than they're reporting in earnings. The management could slash the R & D and report much better earnings, and Wall Street would undoubtedly run the stock from where it is today, which is about a little over $20, up to $30.
But that would be a very short-term thing to do. Instead, LSI Logic will invest the money, produce new products and drive up earnings. The stock's going not only to $30, but to $40 or $45. We actually have a target of $50 for that stock.
Many other companies that are dominant in their niches are spending more or almost more on R & D than they report in earnings. They include Credence Systems, which makes semiconductor testers; Adobe Systems, the software company, and Diamond Multimedia, which makes add-on boards for graphics and modems for computers.
Q. How can investors avoid the dogs out there?
A. There are a couple of ways. You can just say: "Look, I don't have enough time to do this full time. I'm just going to focus on the very best companies -- the Microsofts and Cisco Systems and Oracles and Intels." But instead of buying them at whatever P-E they are and getting killed on the stock price, buy them only when they're down. Of that list of maybe 100 or 120 companies that qualify as great growth-flow technology companies, it's amazing how many of them will have a time when they get cheap because they maybe missed a quarter's earnings by 2 cents a share or Wall Street gets worried about Korea or whatever.
Q. If you own a technology stock, how low should it go before you bail out?
A. Well, you can say: "I'm a long-term investor. As long as the growth-flow numbers look attractive, I'm staying." Or use a mechanical approach and say, "If this stock goes down 20 percent, I'm going to exit on the theory that somebody knows something I don't know or something was wrong with my analysis." I wouldn't use 15 percent; I think it's too tight in a technology company. Then wait until the stock bottoms and, once it starts to lift, go back in it if you still want to be involved.
Q. Do you have any advice for investors who like technology stocks but find them too volatile?
A. There are a couple of things you can do. Instead of owning tech stocks, you could own tech mutual funds. That would spread the risk somewhat. Or you can buy technology convertible bonds. Convertibles have about half the risk of the underlying common stock and they give you about 85 percent of the return that the stock will give you.
Third, don't buy all the same types of stocks. If the first stock you buy is in semiconductor equipment, maybe the next should be in software. And if those first two are roughly in the electronics area, maybe the third should be biotech. When I started following these stocks in 1970, it was the mainframe computer business and they pretty much all moved together. Now, there's much diversity.
Q. Are you particularly bullish or bearish on any sector?
A. The area we're most bullish on is semiconductor equipment, just because the stocks have been hit so hard. We're bullish on biotechnology, too, because it is finally at the point where a lot of products are being approved. Through 1994, three biotech products a year, on average, were approved. In 1995, it jumped to six. In 1996, there were 13; in 1997, almost 30. In 1998, it will be 50.
We're not terribly bearish on any sectors, but we are most negative on the Internet infrastructure software companies -- even though we're big believers in the Internet in general. Most infrastructure companies, which make the browsers and servers and fire walls, are not making money yet. It's a very competitive area, too, with every graduate student in computer science wanting to be the next Marc Andreessen and start the next Netscape.
Q. How should the average investor get started in technology?
A. Put some money into a biotech fund, a broad-based tech fund and then maybe some into a specialty fund that's done well, say one of the software funds or telecommunications funds. If you only want mutual funds and not individual stocks, that's fine. The big driver for future rates of return is what percentage of your assets you put into this area.
Think of it as asset allocation. People think now in terms of stocks and bonds and cash and maybe real estate or foreign stocks. I think you really have to think of it in terms of old-economy and new-economy stocks, bonds, cash and so forth. And make a decision on what percentage of your assets is going to be in these new-economy stocks. The last change like this was in the early 1900's. The people who earned the really high returns recognized that a new economy was under way and shifted assets into that area.
