HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Managers Wanted: Will Train. Start Immed. Bonu$.

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Clint Prescott lost his job managing a country club in Oregon in July, he was exasperated. Even after 25 years in the private club industry, he was not about to hunt for another job at a member-owned club where, he said, internal politics could again put his job in jeopardy. "I wanted one or two bosses, not 500," he said.
Besides interviewing for management jobs, Mr. Prescott also checked in with Robert William James & Associates, a temporary-placement company in Bend, Ore. "I was looking to be placed with a client," Mr. Prescott, 44, said. Instead, he got a permanent job, hired by Robert William James itself as a headhunter trainee. 
 The firm had been searching long and hard to fill the slot and had rejected 100 applicants. Upon hiring Mr. Prescott, it pledged to give him on-the-job training to convert his country-club hiring talent to recruiting for management-hungry resorts and restaurants.
"We made a conscious decision that we would have to train someone to get the best quality for the price," said Scott Pillar, managing director of Robert William James, a franchise of Express Personnel Services in Oklahoma City. Because the labor market is tight, recruiters are especially precious, and experienced ones are unavailable, said Mr. Pillar, who had been the sole recruiter at the 11-person company.
General managers in professional sports use a familiar strategy in times of weak player drafts: pick the best athlete available, regardless of position. These days, that tactic is spreading -- increasingly, applicants like Mr. Prescott find that they can take advantage of some employers' willingness to train new people rather than recruit for a perfect match.
In fact, the tight labor market is creating many advantageous job-hopping opportunities for workers who want a career change but cannot forgo a paycheck to return to school for more training. Once-choosy employers are using incentives like on-the-job education to lure applicants.
The labor shortage is also rewarding workers with freshly minted technology skills, even if the workers are short on hard-knocks experience. They, too, are being welcomed by employers who once barred the door with the mantra "experienced only need apply."
"It's a great time to be a worker because there is opportunity out there," said Alice E. Snell, an analyst for Kennedy Information in Fitzwilliam, N.H., which publishes an annual directory of temporary-placement companies. "In a robust job market, you can think about which road you want to take." The jobless rate fell to 4.6 percent in November, the lowest since October 1973.
Among the most willing to blaze trails in this regard are middle managers and senior executives, sobered by corporate downsizing but now experts at self-promotion, Ms. Snell said. "One thing downsizing did was teach a whole set of people new skills, and more important, an attitude about being responsible for their careers," she added.
Many workers in such situations have used the temporary placement market, where workers generally receive free training. Temps make up 2.3 million workers, or 1.9 percent of the work force.
"As long as an individual has strong basic skills -- they're able to communicate effectively, think on their feet -- they can transition into a different career path," said Mr. Pillar, who recruited two such switch-hitters last year.
Besides Mr. Prescott, he found Derrick McFarland, a 30-year-old former Navy aircraft technician who was hired as a power-plant engineer in training by the Central Oregon Irrigation District in Bend.
"We couldn't find anyone who fit for a year," said Ron S. Nelson, the district's manager, who expects to invest $50,000 in tuition to train Mr. McFarland in hydraulic, electrical and mechanical skills.
Frank E. Curran, a recruiter for Tech Specialists, a division of Office Specialists Inc. in Waltham, Mass., said the shortage of skilled workers was forcing new flexibility on employers. "Before, they may have wanted 10 out of 10 skills," he said. "Now, people are willing to take you with 7 of 10."
What employers prize is often not in the job description. "I found out I had more to offer than I thought," said Lucia G. O'Reilly, 46, of Warwick, R.I., who began looking for part-time work in September through Office Specialists that would allow her time to paint. In 1996, she left a full-time job as beverage director for a restaurant. "Things I had not given much weight to -- like proofreading and editing -- were really valuable," she said.
The tight labor market also forces employers to consider extras like signing bonuses and flexible schedules. The employers' plight is a gift to workers not looking for permanent jobs, like retirees, students, artists and some professionals.
Both Mr. Curran and Gordon J. Bingham, senior vice president of marketing for Olsten Staffing Services, based in Melville, N.Y., say the stigma once attached to job-hopping has been erased and that some professionals see it as a cure for job obsolescence.
This notion is supported in an Olsten study, which found that 30 percent of temps preferred the flexibility or skill-sharpening challenges of short-term projects to the security of a traditional employer, Mr. Bingham said. The down side of this trend, Ms. O'Reilly said, is that temps typically lack autonomy and authority on the job. And health coverage and other benefits, if available at all, must come on the agency's terms, not from the company employing them.
Kelly Services also encounters the trend with its Kelly Scientific Resources unit. Its scientists-for-hire are often refugees from shrinking industries who find that their talents translate into growing fields like biotechnology and pharmaceuticals. They prize assignments that help them polish and develop skills. "If you're not providing an avenue for these professionals to stay current, they won't stay with you," said Rolf E. Kleiner, senior vice president for Kelly Scientific Resources.
Isabel Cooper of Arlington Heights, Ill., represents another part of the same trend: people who are inexperienced in their new line of work, but not totally without training. Ms. Cooper quit her 10-year hospital job as a genetic laboratory technologist after putting herself through seven months and $5,000 of night school at DePaul University to study computer programming. She is one of 10 graduates of the certificate program hired by Interim Services Inc., a temporary placement company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
Ms. Cooper, 36, was expected to earn $10,000 more in 1997 than in 1996. In a different job market, though, her lack of experience might have put her at the bottom of a list.
"There's a lot of work you can do that's not rocket science," said Ms. Cooper, who is helping to build a data warehouse for First Card, a unit of the First Chicago Corporation.
Cynthia E. Cross, president of Parker Services Inc., which finds temporary workers for high-technology and professional businesses in Seattle, said professionals familiar with the most-used software programs could easily detour into technology. "Even people who are gainfully employed are taking this as an opportunity," she said. "People are willing to move for better pay and stock options."
PARKER SERVICES accelerates the process by providing free software training to its temps.
Michael D. Caprara is a believer. A former bank-lending officer, Mr. Caprara, 38, said his early efforts to get a technology-related job failed because prospective employers would not consider his at-home computer dabbling as usable experience.
He took tutoring at Parker Services in September and received high test scores that brought him his pick of offers. He chose the fast-rising Innova Corporation, which makes wireless microwave networks.
Innova offered Mr. Caprara a permanent spot after he spent two weeks in the company's purchasing and engineering departments.
"If you don't have education or experience, you don't get the job," Mr. Caprara said. "They look at job experience, not hobbies."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Some Inadvertent Tosses Out the Fiscal Window

BYLINE: By JOE QUEENAN; The writer is a freelancer based in Tarrytown, N.Y.

 BODY:
F. Scott Fitzgerald: You know, Hem, the rich are different.
Ernest Hemingway: You're right. The rich don't tie up significant amounts of their capital in season tickets to the New York Jets, thereby giving the team's owner, Leon Hess, what amounts to a gigantic, interest-free loan each year. 
THE cornerstone of any successful investment philosophy is finding a way to minimize the amount of money that is sitting in the bank earning almost nothing, and putting the rest of the cash to work. But a fast review of virtually any household's budget will reveal that significant amounts of money are routinely forked over to other parties in an endless series of interest-free loans.
Some of these loans are unavoidable, some can be justified by convenience and some generate savings of their own down the road. Nevertheless, a substantial number of these interest-free loans are just plain dumb.
One of the most obvious examples of an inadvertent interest-free loan that makes no sense is letting your broker hold your stock in "street name," meaning in the name of the broker, and then lend it out. The more stock you have, the bigger the loan. The brokerage house, already earning significant amounts in commissions on your trades, earns additional commissions by putting your stock to work. You earn nothing from this arrangement.
Ideally, your philosophy vis-a-vis your stock certificates should be the same as your philosophy vis-a-vis your kids: If somebody wants to borrow them, let them pay for the privilege. But that's not the way Wall Street works.
A more proletarian example of an interest-free loan given at the individual's expense is any form of prepaid mass transit pass or token that doesn't offer a discount. If you buy a month's worth of undiscounted fares on the first of every month, for example, you are literally giving the transit authority 12 interest-free loans that may amount to hundreds of dollars over the course of the year.
The problem here is that the alternative to buying a pass is to simply buy a token each time you need one. This, of course, is incredibly annoying. Economists would probably argue that this kind of interest-free loan makes sense because the time not spent waiting in line for tokens can be put to better use. Like waiting on the platform for a smelly, crowded, overdue train while reading about Kathie Lee Gifford.
Subscription tickets to the opera, the concert hall or the theater or season tickets to any major sporting event are an even better example of interest-free loans. Tickets to these events are rarely discounted, and in some cases the payment for individual events is made as much as nine months in advance. It may, however, be a worthy trade-off if tickets included in the series -- perhaps to a Midori concert -- would otherwise be unavailable.
The most infuriating form of interest-free loan occurs when the local hockey team makes you buy tickets for several rounds of playoff games even though everyone knows they're going to get massacred by the first opponent they face.
The second-most infuriating thing is when the management then makes you come to the stadium in person to pick up your refund. The team, meanwhile, has been using your hard-earned money to acquire more fat, washed-up prima donnas from Flin Flon, Manitoba, or Thunder Bay, Ontario, who will insure that the next year your team will make an even earlier exit from the playoffs. Which, in turn, will make you feel even more foolish about the interest-free loan you're going to give the owners next year.
Magazine subscriptions are another mechanism for coughing up interest-free loans. But here, there is an upside. When you subscribe to a magazine years in advance, it is true that you are asked to fork over your money long before you receive the product. On the other hand, you usually end up paying less for the product than you would if you had bought a one-year subscription and a lot less than you would have paid at the newsstand.
But there is also a downside. In the case of a magazine like Forbes, writing a check for a three-year subscription is a way of giving its millionaire publisher, Malcolm Forbes Jr., an interest-free loan for years. Mr. Forbes can then use this money to employ additional journalists who will, in the fullness of time, write caustic articles chastising readers for investing their money unwisely. This will make you feel silly. If you don't want to appear silly, stick with that long-term subscription to Details.
Many common commercial transactions ultimately turn into short-term loans. Advance purchases of airplane tickets fall into this category. And then there are traveler's checks, particularly those that are unused for long periods. Unused traveler's checks can be an even bigger waste of a precious resource -- your money -- than unused cash sitting in your wallet, if you paid a 1 percent commission to get them. (Of course, cash itself can be wasted if you had to pay a service charge for using an automated-teller machine.)
The more carefully you examine your personal finances, the more you come to realize how much of your money is tied up in interest-free loans. If you own real estate, you probably have a nice heap of cash sitting in an escrow account somewhere earning little or no interest, at least for the first few years of the mortgage.
If you use an E-Z Pass to avoid waiting in lines while crossing bridges in the New York metropolitan area, you are, in effect, awarding the Port Authority a monthly interest-free loan.
If you belong to a record club and have allowed the company to automatically debit your credit card as soon as you order that "Riverdance" CD, you are paying for the merchandise even before you receive it.
And if you have a checking account that does not pay interest -- or that stops doing so once your balance falls below a certain level -- you are again losing out.
One of the most prevalent examples of this type of inadvertently idiotic behavior involves Federal withholding taxes. Numerous Americans deliberately have too much withheld during the year because they like the idea of getting a refund in April. Obviously, it would be far wiser to underwithhold one's taxes, put the extra cash in an interest-bearing account or a Treasury bill, and then pay the Internal Revenue Service in April.
What are other examples of this phenomenon? Well, there are those level-pay schedules for utility bills and advance purchases of lottery tickets. Not to mention debit cards of any variety, where the whole concept of "the float" goes up in smoke. (Of course, most people find that their easiest interest-free money comes from a credit card, providing they pay in full at the end of the month. But -- and this is a big but -- some banks now charge a fee or seek to cancel a card if the account fails to carry a balance.)
Perhaps the most overlooked type of interest-free loan is the office football pool. Here, you pick your teams, pay your cash, wait for Sunday's results and then curse yourself for picking the Cincinnati Bengals plus six points when you should have gone with the Dallas Cowboys minus seven. Meanwhile, the guy running the pool can do whatever he wants with your money.
This is an example of an inherently foolish investment that is exacerbated by an idiotic loan. All things considered, you'd be better off standing in line waiting for that subway token than participating in the office football pool. At least you get something for your money.

HEADLINE: In Old England, A Silicon Fen

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, England

 BODY:
THE rooms at Mount Pleasant House are filling up with new faces, furniture and ideas. Month after month, the five-story building, whose smoky green glass blends into the leafy texture of this ancient university town, is kept busy as yet another high-technology venture installs itself to produce new software or a growing company leaves for bigger quarters.
Moving in is the ponytailed Adrian Wrigley, working in jeans and a T-shirt -- and with nearly $2 million in venture capital -- to perfect software that allows faster, cheaper and livelier three-dimensional animation for the entertainment industry. 
 Moving out of the building, a kind of incubator for high-tech companies, are Mike Muller and the other employees of Advanced RISC Machines, which outgrew its space and now is piling into a 17th-century converted barn on the edge of town.
There, the company's ever-growing staff -- which now numbers 257, most of them researchers -- is designing microprocessors that are "small, simple, low-power and fast," as Mr. Muller puts it, to go into everything from computers to mobile phones to televisions. The success of the business, a joint venture of Apple Computer and Britain's Acorn Group, is evident in the score of empty champagne bottles lined up along a corridor, each marking a big party held to introduce a new chip.
Almost every week, meanwhile, staff members arrive for the Microsoft Corporation's new research laboratory in Mount Pleasant House, the $80 million beachhead of William H. Gates's campaign to create a global network of brain factories for his software industry titan.
Welcome to the Silicon Fen, as insiders call the vast flat and marshy lands in and around Cambridge. In the last five years, the area has become home to more than 1,000 high-technology companies that employ at least 30,000 people and produce more than $3 billion a year in revenues. Unemployment here is a low 3.5 percent, compared with 5.7 percent for all of Britain and 9 to 17 percent in Europe.
This is no Silicon Valley. The pace here is neither frantic nor flashy, and people frown on loud manifestations of wealth. While Cambridge, the home of one of the world's most prestigious universities, has produced some 50 Nobel laureates, it is a relatively small city of 100,000 encircled by rural landscape. Executives still ride to work on bicycles, as they did when they were students. The buildings are low, the skies wide open and the pace civilized.
But the energy and enthusiasm are palpable.
"I have founded and helped in the launch of 25 companies in the past 12 years," boasts Herman Hauser, 48, whose progeny include Acorn, Britain's pioneering maker of personal computers. A multimillionaire entrepreneur, he is part-owner of Mount Pleasant House and head of the Amadeus venture capital fund, which adopts scientists with brilliant ideas who know nothing about how to turn them into businesses.
"It's real. It's happening," adds the effusive Mr. Muller, at 38 the director and vice president for business development of Advanced RISC Machines. "It's a big buzz. Not quite Silicon Valley, but you have to be aware of the scale without underestimating the impact."
IT isn't difficult to see why the technology industry has planted itself on the Fen. Unlike its intellectual rival, Oxford University, which is best known for its scholarship in the humanities, Cambridge has both a long history of collaboration with industry and a decidedly scientific bent. It was at Trinity College here that Charles Babbage, inventor of the mechanical calculator, studied mathematics in the early 1800's.
"As a base for high-tech engineering, Cambridge with its university is ideal and wonderful," said Mr. Hauser, who first came here in 1973, earned a Ph.D. in physics from the university and has stayed ever since. The ferment has also drawn Xerox, Olivetti, Stanford Research Institute, Oracle and Hitachi to establish laboratories or offices here.
But the appeal is not solely intellectual. "For one thing, many people don't want to live in Seattle, California or America," said Prof. Roger M. Needham, a Cambridge computer scientist who recently took a leave from the university to become managing director of Microsoft's new lab. "Let's face it," he added, flashing a somewhat mischievous smile. "The quality of life is much better here."
The balding professor, who has taught at Cambridge for nearly a quarter-century, energetically paces his sparsely furnished new office in Mount Pleasant House as he explains how good a time it is to be starting a technology venture in England.
There is capital available on the Continent now, something that was not often the case a decade or so ago. And with most members of the European Union -- if not Britain itself, initially -- moving toward adoption of the euro, Europe will increasingly act as a single market, by some measures much larger than America.
"There are 400 million people on this continent who can work here with no permit," Professor Needham said, as if surprising himself with the revelation.
For now the ambitions of the Microsoft venture are modest. It aims to hire about 40 scientists from all over Europe and as little as possible in the way of support staff. The idea is to replicate, on a smaller scale, the company's research center in the Seattle area, where about 140 top researchers look for new computer applications.
"Microsoft wanted to multiply their researchers by three," Professor Needham explained. "But it is not easy to find brains in one place, one continent, which is why they are casting a net around the world, starting with Britain." If the British lab is a success, the company plans to create similar centers in other places where the high-tech research environment is favorable.
But Cambridge is special. "We looked long and hard before deciding on Britain," Mr. Gates said during an October visit to announce the lab. "The computer science tradition here and the companies in the area made this a great spot for us." The university, he said, "has made it possible for this area to develop as one of the centers of advanced technology in the world."
"We're going to put together a really amazing group of people," he added.
CAMBRIDGE'S distinctive role in the world of modern computers dates back to the period just after World War II when Maurice Wilkes, a mathematical physicist, and his students built the Edsac, a 3,000-vacuum-tube contraption that was the first practical computer to use stored programs.
Even today, while not a major force in the computer business, Britain is "very good at niches," Professor Needham said. "We make software for racing cars, engine controls and security," he noted, in addition to computer games. Being an English-speaking nation has been a key competitive advantage, everyone agrees, as the bulk of the world's software is written in English.
The Fen's biggest fan is Britain's new Prime Minister, Tony Blair, whose Labor Government campaigned on a platform of creating a Britain "that is fully up and running on information technology for the millennium."
Among other things, Mr. Blair has fashioned a $170 million plan with British Telecom and various cable television companies to wire every single school in Britain to the Internet; later this year, government-run schools are supposed to have unlimited access for a flat fee of $1,000 a year. Mr. Blair actively courted Microsoft and was rewarded with the company's decision to open its lab in Cambridge. But Mr. Blair also received a pledge that is expected to turn into millions of dollars in software and computer equipment for his schools initiative from Mr. Gates, whom he welcomed at 10 Downing Street.
Mr. Blair's undertaking is a big commitment, the likes of which are seen in Europe only in the Scandinavian nations, not in Germany, France or the other big economies. But analysts say government prodding is badly needed: while Britons have been very good at inventing computer applications, they have never had the means to parlay that creativity into a major industry.
In general, Europeans have been slow to adopt computer technology, in business and even more so at home; it is broadly estimated that only about 20 percent of European households have personal computers, versus about 40 percent in the United States.
Moreover, British technology companies have not enjoyed the full-throated support of the public sector that helped create demand and build a technology infrastructure in the United States. There is no British equivalent, for instance, of the Pentagon financing that established the Internet.
The financial roots of the Silicon Fen are in Britain's economic changes during the 18 years of Conservative Party rule, largely under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Cambridge was always full of scientists, but what began steering money toward their ventures were the Conservatives' tax cuts and stripping down of the welfare state, which attracted foreign banks and international investors to the City of London and British companies.
Into this increasingly amiable environment stepped people like Mr. Hauser of Amadeus, Mr. Muller of Advanced RISC Machines and the many other researchers and financiers now shaping the Silicon Fen.
Their approach is to circle around Britain's limitations, like its small market, and to play to its strengths: fine universities and the ability to work on ideas with universal appeal in a global industry. That adds up to a strategy -- to the degree that one exists -- emphasizing ideas and engineering over manufacturing brawn.
"If you try to do it all, you fail," Mr. Muller said. "Our approach is we sell ideas for a lot of money and royalties. It is based on leverage. We license the technology. It is an intellectual property business."
WHAT plan has certainly worked for his company. Just seven years old, Advanced RISC Machines had profits of $6 million in 1996 on revenues of $27 million by inventing chips that go into computers, mobile phones, television set-top boxes, TV's, digital cameras, smart cards and modems, increasing their power and speed. Its clients and partners include Digital Equipment, Samsung, Alcatel, Yamaha, Sony, Philips, Sharp, NEC and Rockwell Semiconductor Systems.
The brain power on which the Apple-Acorn joint venture is built flows directly from Cambridge University. Mr. Muller, for example, has an undergraduate degree in computer science and says Professor Needham "taught me everything I know about computers."
He is not troubled at finding himself, in some senses, in competition with his old instructor. "I am very happy to have Microsoft" in Cambridge, Mr. Muller said. "It legitimizes Cambridge's big stab at technology, and it makes the job prospects broader."
Besides the ties that the Fen is forging with Britain's leading universities, its most important relationships are with Britain's growing pool of venture capitalists and the City's financiers.
"In past years, the main problem had been a funding gap due to the limited understanding of technology investment by British banks," Mr. Hauser said. According to Bank of England reports, 16 percent of total investments in Britain went to technology from 1984 to 1995. In the United States, technology soaked up 35 percent of investment dollars over the same period.
Now, venture capital firms like Amadeus are changing the picture. According to Mr. Hauser and others who keep count, there are some 140 venture capital funds in Britain with $30 billion invested in high-tech ventures. In 1996, there was $1.08 billion in new technology investment, a quarter of which went to start-ups like the emerging companies of the Fen.
"By Silicon Valley standards, it is not very impressive," Mr. Hauser said. (In 1996, venture capitalists pumped $2.3 billion into companies in the Valley, according to Price Waterhouse, the American accounting firm.) "But remember: This is the second-largest high-tech venture capital market in the world, after the United States, and it is in a starting stage."
A crucial part of the strategy for closing the gap has been widening the circle. Globalization and the growing role of the European Union as a large economic group have helped. Cambridge-based companies can easily transcend their location by hooking up to the Internet and forming alliances in Asia, the United States and other markets.
IN many ways, 29-year-old Adrian Wrigley is the Silicon Fen character who typifies all these trends.
Both his parents are Cambridge graduates; his mother studied botany, his father chemistry. "Both knew to push science. When I was a little boy and asked a question, 'Why is that gray blue?' they would explain it in scientific terms," he said in his new suite in Mount Pleasant House.
By the time he was 11, he had a solid background in electronics and dabbled with computer equipment on the kitchen table. By 18, he was studying engineering, physics and chemistry at Cambridge. At 25, he received his doctorate in computer science.
Sitting in a meeting room, its floor a web of wires trailing from computers, he said his main research interest was "transcribing the architecture of the brain into a computer architecture." Along the way, Dr. Wrigley focused on ways to manipulate images on computers and, eventually, on how to pump life, color and shading into computer animation at tremendous speed, aiming for strikingly realistic results.
Ultimately, Dr. Wrigley developed a chip that he believed would vastly improve the quality of computer images while saving the fast-growing animation industry millions of dollars. "What I didn't know," he said, "was how to devise a business plan, a patent, a license."
It was at that point, in 1994, that Herman Hauser and his Amadeus fund entered the picture. "I went to a lecture at Cambridge by Herman. He was talking about how to start a high-tech company," Dr. Wrigley recalled.
The two men talked after the lecture -- and Mr. Hauser agreed to stake Dr. Wrigley $500,000 in start-up money.
"Herman committed to the amount, but said we have to produce something that made a great deal of money -- an end product that can sell," Dr. Wrigley said. "He said to go back to the drawing board and keep this in mind."
A year later, Advanced Rendering Technology Ltd. was created, a private company with $1.9 million in Amadeus funds, a professional manager and Dr. Wrigley, who retains a one-third ownership. The company created a site on the World Wide Web to promote its technology, and calls started pouring in from Hollywood to Tokyo.
Dr. Wrigley has not yet made plans to move out of Mount Pleasant House -- his chip hasn't really gotten its commercial footing yet -- but if those phone calls turn into sales, he may be making way for a newcomer someday soon.

PUB-DATE: January 4, 1998

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2909 words

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH: LIZ SMITH;
The Scoop? Gossip Maven Starts Saving

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
THE singer Sophie Tucker once offered this advice: From birth to age 18, a girl needs good parents; from 18 to 35, good looks; from 35 to 55, a good personality, and from 55 on, cash.
Almost a decade ago, at age 65, Liz Smith, the queen of gossip columnists, was hopelessly out of sync with Ms. Tucker's agenda. "I had about $25,000 saved, and that was it," Ms. Smith recalled cheerfully during a recent interview. 
 Certainly, Ms. Smith, the woman who broke the news of Donald Trump's divorce from his first wife, Ivana, and attended Elizabeth Taylor's most recent wedding, had rubbed shoulders with some of the savviest financial minds in America, from Henry Kravis to Alan Greenspan to Ace Greenberg. But she had never been a saver. From the year she graduated from college, she had worked obsessively. But her goal was always to be somebody, not necessarily somebody rich.
Even after she became a celebrity, with her name plastered across her daily column, she refused to worry about the future. She lived high, spent lavishly and figured she could always work and earn more. "Money was such an evil to me in my early life that I didn't pay any attention to it," Ms. Smith said in the drawl of her native Fort Worth. "Even before I had money, I thought it was something to throw off the back of trains." Having watched her father's gambling wreak havoc on her family and her mother's emotions, "I had learned that it didn't do any good to try to hold onto money," she continued during an interview at her simply furnished apartment in a midtown Manhattan high-rise.
Then, about five years ago, Ms. Smith met Peter G. Peterson and his wife, Joan Ganz Cooney. Mr. Peterson, a former Secretary of Commerce, was by then chairman of the hugely successful Blackstone Group, a buyout firm. Ms. Cooney was a founder of the Children's Television Workshop. After Ms. Smith got to know Mr. Peterson and Ms. Cooney, they had a discussion about her finances. "They said, 'What do you mean you don't have $5 million in the bank?' " Ms. Smith recalled. "Pete couldn't believe I was so stupid. He couldn't believe I wasn't worth millions."
Though Ms. Smith declines to disclose her salary, people close to her estimate that she makes $1 million a year -- about $900,000 from her column, which appears six times a week in Newsday and The New York Post and is syndicated to more than 60 newspapers nationwide, and about $100,000 from articles for Good Housekeeping magazine and appearances on WNYW-TV, Channel 5 in New York, and on E! Entertainment, the cable channel. In addition, her agent recently negotiated a $1 million advance from Hyperion Books for her memoirs.
Ms. Smith confesses that spending is her financial strong suit. Not only does she support her brother -- as she supported her mother until her death -- she also has a weakness for gourmet restaurants, where she likes to leave big tips. And, she acknowledges, she counted on her popular column to provide her with a steady income for many years. Twice divorced, with no children, she said she "just didn't pay enough attention."
"I was the world's oldest adolescent, emotionally and practically," she said.
THE gave her first thought to saving money about six years ago, prompted by her increasingly large salary, and got serious about it only with what she fondly called nagging by Mr. Peterson and her assistant, Diane Judge.
Mr. Peterson confirmed that he was shocked by the paucity of her savings. His response was to tell her: "As John Maynard Keynes once said, 'Some people have a propensity to consume,' and you certainly are a gifted consumer.' "
He realized that immediate action was necessary. So he sat down with her and worked out a nuts-and-bolts savings plan. The most important issue was disability insurance, "to cover the downside," as Mr. Peterson put it. And because his friend "essentially runs a small business, we got into the most efficient way of creating a tax-deferred pension arrangement" with a tax-deferred retirement account and other tax shelters, he said. "Once we found the right format, and it was tax deferred, we switched her from tax-free municipal bonds into higher-yield fixed-income instruments," he said.
Because of Ms. Smith's age, Mr. Peterson did not recommend stocks despite the higher returns that they have generated over time. "If you are 72 and you are counting on this for a good standard of living later in life, it is probably prudent to give up some of the upside to get the downside well covered," he said. "The stock market is good over the long term, but remember, between 1967 and 1982 it went nowhere."
Mr. Peterson says people should calculate their retirement needs and begin saving early. Ms. Smith had done neither, so he proposed an aggressive plan: Set aside $200,000 to $300,000 a year. She has managed to do so, she said, by directing Ms. Judge, her assistant, to regularly set money aside -- and to hound her about the size of her American Express bills. By now, that presumably means Ms. Smith has socked away more than $2 million.
Still, Ms. Smith says she will never be super-rich. "Pete has some investments now where you have to have $5 million or you can't get into it," she said. "I asked him the other day, 'When can I get into this thing?' and he said, 'Never. You'll never have enough money.' "
Mr. Peterson's role went beyond simply suggesting a financial strategy. He went along with her when she negotiated with Newsday in 1995 and helped her win a contract that reportedly runs seven years in addition to permission to run her column in The New York Post.
The contract with The Post is worth $100,000 a year to Ms. Smith, but its value transcends money, Mr. Peterson said, because it gives her a journalistic pipeline to the cultural -- and gossip -- capital of the United States. "I wanted her to have the psychic income of having a column in New York," he said.
For all of Ms. Smith's recent efforts to prepare for retirement, she just cannot get all that excited about her finances. From time to time, she glances at the monthly statements of her accounts at the Offit Bank, which specializes in money management for individual clients.
She does have a stock portfolio -- but it came about by chance. Some years ago, she said, she inherited some "really great stocks, like Coca-Cola," worth $20,000, from a friend, and the value of that cache has quintupled. But even if the stocks had not gone up, it is unlikely she would have sold them. "I have kept them for sentimental reasons," she said. She said she thought Offit Bank might have bought her a few mutual funds, but she was not certain.
GIVEN the hard times she knew as a child in Fort Worth, it is perhaps not surprising that she became a free-spender as an adult. Though her father was a successful cotton salesman for a time, he was taken off salary and put on commission during the Depression -- and his income slowed to a trickle. To make things worse, he was addicted to the race track, poker and craps.
As a result, she remembers, her parents had to sell their house and move into a smaller one. They paid the local government extra to keep her in her old school -- but she is not sure whether that was good. "I grew up with all these little rich kids," she said. "I didn't have a dime. They talked about their allowances." She never pretended to have more than she did, she added, primarily because she thought that her classmates would see through her and that she would gain stature by owning up to her reduced circumstances. "I knew it wouldn't do any good," she said. "I couldn't face that. I was always a horrible little social climber in my way."
Every Christmas, her father delivered his children a cryptic message that reflected his own tortured relationship with money. He gave each of them silver dollars -- a fortune for a child in the Depression -- but then asked them to do the almost impossible. "He would say we should save them, and of course, we were dying to spend them," Ms. Smith said. "At the same time, we thought it was not right to spend them."
In effect, her father was asking his offspring to show a restraint toward money that he was unable to muster. "It gave us an emotional economic crisis early on," Ms. Smith said.
Even after her father got a new job, the family fortunes did not improve much because he couldn't hold onto his money. "He never stopped jumping around enough to feel bad about anything," she said. "He was a real iconoclast. He had a mind like a computer. He would get a whole lot of money, and the next thing you knew, he was in a crap game."
Ms. Smith recalled his coming home late one night after playing craps, dropping into a chair and commanding, " 'Help me take my boots off."
She said he "had money stuffed down in his Lucchese boots, and it poured out all over the floor -- it was really dramatic."
Like most gamblers, though, her father lost more than he won -- and his habit created dissension in the family. "It drove my mother crazy," Ms. Smith said. Once, her mother returned crying to the house from a walk to the mailbox. "I just can't stand it," she remembers her mother saying. "The Baptist Standard and The Racing Form in the same mailbox."
Another time, when she was a college student, her father reclaimed a gift to pay off a gambling debt. He had bought her a maroon Plymouth for her to drive around the University of Texas -- then showed up one day and asked for the keys. "He said, 'I'm sorry. I have to get rid of your car,' " she recalled. "He had lost the car in a crap game or something. I was heartbroken."
Her father's compulsive behavior had some benefits. He paid her college tuition by winning $1,500 on a horse named Soap Stix, she said.
After earning a bachelor's degree in journalism and nearly getting a master's degree in English, Ms. Smith came to New York in 1949.
She had spent her teen-age years lying on the floor of her bedroom reading Walter Winchell, the most powerful social and political commentator of the 1940's and 50's, whose column appeared in more than 2,000 newspapers and whose voice was instantly recognizable to anyone who ever turned on a radio. "I was dying to go to New York and see the Stork Club," the world's most famous nightclub in those days and a Winchell hangout, she said.
She was also dying to be a journalist when she arrived with $50 in her pocket. For three months she searched for a magazine job. Finally she called the actor Zachary Scott, whom she had known at college. He sent her to see Chuck Saxon, the editor of Modern Screen. "He said 'You have the most virile writing style,' " Ms. Smith said. "I said, 'Thank you,' and hung up. Then I looked up the word 'virile.' "
After that, she worked her way up from freelance magazine writing, eventually going to work for Igor Cassini, the famous society gossip columnist who wrote under the name Cholly Knickerbocker. For the next two decades, she worked for media celebrities, from Mr. Cassini and Allen Funt, host of the TV show "Candid Camera," to Mike Wallace, the CBS newsman, to Helen Gurley Brown, then Cosmopolitan editor and her only boss who was a woman.
Though Ms. Smith envied friends in more mainstream journalistic enterprises, such jobs were hard to get, particularly for women who had not attended Vassar or Wellesley, she said. "I was probably saved from a life of intense nothingness by the fact that I couldn't get a really respectable job," she said.
Like many women in the male-dominated workplaces of those days, Ms. Smith kept in the background. And she never dreamed of demanding a raise. "This was pre-women's lib," she said. "And I thought I was a second-rate person. I was always a first-rate guy's first-rate girl." Even though she was probably one of the best-paid women freelancers around, she said: "I didn't value myself. I was like Rodney Dangerfield. I didn't get any respect."
But with psychotherapy, her attitude began to change. Her psychologist, Mildred Newman, asked her, " 'Why do you think you don't deserve to be a success?' " Therapy did not necessarily make her a better negotiator, she said, but "it helped me get out of my own way. I began to realize I didn't just want to be a journeyman journalist. I wanted more."
It was not until 1978, when The Daily News gave her a column and it became an immediate hit, that she felt she had truly arrived. A year later, when The Daily News was shut down by a strike, her bosses encouraged her to go on WNBC-TV's "Live at Five" newscast to keep her name before the public.
As her salary rose, "I felt I was rich because I could take cabs and not worry about the prices on the menu," she said. By the late 1980's, she was making about $350,000 a year from her Daily News salary, syndication fees for the column and payments for her WNBC appearances.
Still, it never occurred to her to save a penny of it. "I just thought supporting myself and living in New York was great," she recalled. "I lived like a fool and spent everything I ever made."
As Ms. Smith looks back, she realizes that her blase attitude toward money mirrored her father's so closely that it must have been a form of subconscious imitation. "I was just as much of a gambler" as he was, she said. "I kept blindly forging ahead like a mole, without thinking too much about the future. I guess I always thought I would hit it where I wouldn't have to worry. I felt like one day I would write something. I felt like I had the capacity to make money."
THOUGH her job increasingly took her into contact with the super-rich, she said she never resented them for their wealth. "I have been passionately jealous in emotional ways, but I have never been envious of anybody," she said. Sure, she said, she would like to have enough money to quit her job tomorrow and still have $500,000 a year to live on. But that will never happen, she said, and she does not really mind. "I've had a great life," she said.
Nor has she ever counted on her well-heeled friends to bail her out of tight spots. "It may be nice to have rich friends, but they'll never give you any money," she said. "That is the fallacy." Still, she said: "You might live well from knowing them. And they might give you money for charity." (Ms. Smith is an avid fund-raiser for Literacy Partners.)
Only once, after she lost her job when Mr. Cassini gave up his column in 1963, did she borrow money -- $1,500, from the real-estate heir and man-about-town Jerry Zipkin, who had asked whether he could help. She paid back every penny, she said.
Indeed, she dislikes owing money. Her agent, Joni Evans, remembered how Ms. Smith insisted on returning an advance from Simon & Schuster for a book she never got around to writing.
But if she never asks for money from friends, she listens to their advice -- as was seen when Mr. Peterson help her negotiate with Newsday. Ms. Smith had left The Daily News in 1991 and joined New York Newsday, the Long Island newspaper's New York edition. When it folded in 1995, Long Island Newsday wanted to renegotiate the contract. "They had my life in their thrall," Ms. Smith said. "They could have ruined my life very easily. But Pete sat there and said: 'I don't know if you gentlemen have noticed, but you treat Liz like she is this glamorous young girl, but she is no spring chicken.' And he added, 'She has never saved any money. So I want you to do right by her.' "
As part of the new contract, Newsday agreed to let her column appear in The New York Post, which pays $200,000 a year for it, divided evenly between Ms. Smith and Newsday. Newsday also keeps the $150,000 or more in syndication revenue that the columns earn.
Today, despite her new-found penchant for saving, Ms. Smith still spends considerably. She pays a staff of three out of her own pocket. And she continues to indulge her culinary lust. "I eat out at incredible restaurants, and I pick up checks like crazy."
Moreover, she continues to support her brother, who lives in the home she bought for her late mother. And like her father, who loved to give money away after he won it, Ms. Smith sometimes helps out friends. She gave Ms. Judge the money to make a down payment on a country house, for example.
RECENTLY, moreover, her late-blooming financial maturity has nudged her into a more expensive life style. In keeping with what she calls her adolescent outlook, she used to live a bit as a recent college graduate would, working out of an office in her Manhattan apartment. She now rents a second apartment for herself and uses her old one solely for business. And, not long ago, she bought a Mercedes.
With the exception of an occasional gift from the designer Arnold Scassi, a close friend, she added, she buys all her own clothes. So far, she jokes, she has not accepted any bribes to supplement her income. "I suppose I have my price," she said, "but I don't think I have heard it yet."
Still, saving money has become easier. Ms. Judge said that one benefit of moving to Newsday in 1991 was that Ms. Smith's salary was paid electronically. "That way," Ms. Judge said, "she is not as tempted to spend it. It goes directly into a checking account. When the account gets high, I move some of it to a money-market fund."
Clearly, Ms. Smith has heard her friends' words of warning. And it would seem she has adopted the credo of Sophie Tucker: "I've been rich, and I've been poor, and rich is better."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 4; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 154 words

HEADLINE: Dec. 28-Jan. 3;
The U.N. Says It's Time to Pony Up

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Here's a club to join. Not feeling lucky? Never mind: the dues reflect economic position, on a sliding scale. And don't worry. The bill might be high, but there's always the option of not paying.
The club is called the United Nations. 
 When the 1998-2000 "scale of assessments" -- U.N.-speak for dues -- was finally agreed on by the General Assembly , some of the results seemed somewhat unscientific. How come North Korea, where people are starving, has to pay about 30 times as much as Cambodia, where rich politicians and business executives live tax-free lives?
The United States, which argues it is charged too much and has held back payment, sought to reduce its assessment to 20 percent of the U.N.'s regular budget, but its assessment stayed at 25 percent, or $297.7 million, while the poor countries took their cuts, lowering the base payment for 25 nations to $13,000 each. BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section 4; Page 11; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 770 words

HEADLINE: The Tarnished Darlings of Wall Street

BYLINE: By Joseph Nocera; Joseph Nocera is an editor at large with Fortune magazine.

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
The year 1997 was a rough one for the holders of health care stocks. Columbia/HCA, which had been one of Wall Street's favorite growth companies, saw its once high-flying stock drop from $45 a share in March to $26 in October after the company became the target of a major Federal investigation.
Then there was that other Wall Street darling, Oxford Health Plans. Since going public half a dozen years ago, it had been one of the fastest-growing managed care companies in the country. But in October when Oxford stunned the market by announcing its first-ever quarterly loss, shares of the stock lost 63 percent of their value in a single day. 
 And Aetna, the insurance giant, has seen its stock hammered in recent months, thanks to problems with U.S. Healthcare, its managed care subsidiary.
The problems of these companies point out the flaw of a health care industry subject to the turbulent market: What's good for patients isn't necessarily what's good for stockholders. And vice versa.
Until recently, health care stocks were booming -- owing to the recent dramatic changes in the health care economy, particularly the nationwide move to managed care.
For instance, Oxford's profits rose at a compounded rate of 75 percent a year, and its stock climbed from $4 a share in 1991 to $89 a share in 1997. Indeed, in the fall of 1996, 12 health care companies made Fortune's annual ranking of the 100 fastest-growing companies in the United States, the second-best showing of any sector.
When an investor sees numbers like these, his or her natural inclination is to jump in with both feet. Yet by now the word "investor" has come to mean not just the Wall Street cognoscenti but practically everybody -- more than 40 percent of American households are now invested in the market. But these same investors are also consumers of the new health care companies and may even have been part of the recent backlash against the cost cutting practiced by the typical managed care company.
But so long as the stocks kept going up, it was easy to overlook this weird duality. In fact, people tended to view these companies purely through the prism of the market, rooting for the stock while ignoring the business. They were letting the tail wag the dog.
Consider the root cause of the swoon in health stocks. After years of cutting costs with impunity, managed care companies are facing rising costs. Why? Because they are being forced -- in no small part as a reaction to intense criticism from doctors and patients -- to pay more for treatment. Yet at the same time, these companies have been unable to charge higher premiums, thanks to pressure from large employers who contract with managed care companies.
What's more, it's now clear that in some cases the concern with producing results that would please investors caused some companies to make terrible mistakes. Columbia/ HCA's strong-arm tactics and brutal cost-cutting led to resentment so great that the company is now removing the Columbia/HCA name from many of its hospitals.
Oxford, meanwhile, put such emphasis on growth at any cost that it spun out of control when a new computer system caused the company to lose track of its business.
What's particularly troubling is that even as these stocks have tanked, there is still a tendency to view the companies mainly through the prism of the market. Yes, there has been reporting on what Oxford's troubles mean for its customers, but the vast majority of the coverage has been about Oxford's dismal share price and about whether the company can regain its status as a hot growth stock.
But should health care consumers care if Oxford becomes a hot stock again? Maybe they shouldn't. Nobody's saying Oxford, or any other health care company, should have to lose money. But the imperative that Wall Street demands of hot growth companies -- that profits increase by eye-popping amounts year after year -- doesn't quite jibe with the business of delivering first-rate health care to the public. If there is a larger message in the decline of the health care sector, surely that's it. Besides, the situation that caused the stocks to tank in 1997 -- more and better treatment without higher premiums -- may have been lousy for shareholders, but it was a pretty good for anybody who happened to get sick last year.
I'm not advocating an end to the bull market. My retirement money is there, too, just like everyone else's. But when that wild ride does finally end, perhaps we'll start thinking about what matters again, instead of simply worrying about how the stock price will be affected.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Festivity's Not Hot;
There Went the Holidays. Whoopee.

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
YEAR after year, talk-show hosts and other celebrity soothers and healers warn against expecting too much from the holidays, lest either the immediate disappointment or the Jan. 2 withdrawal cause an emotional crash. Now, they can declare victory.
Despite the hottest economy practically since Columbus's once-celebrated landing, Christmas shoppers remained abstemious, giving retailers the holiday blues for the third year in a row. And instead of at least letting loose on New Year's Eve, more and more Americans got by with New Year's Lite: In 170 cities, zero-proof observances known as First Night sent shivering masses between performances by flannel-shirted folk-singers and grade-school ballerinas. Yawning audiences were sustained by cups of cocoa, if they were lucky. 

Not Much Memorializing
But in modern America, Holiday Rot sets in long before late December. The two Presidents' birthdays have been mashed into one. Retailers who still hope against hope for Christmas largess gave up long ago on trying to sell bonnets or anything else for Easter. Memorial Day, once filled with parades and graveyard ceremony and decoration, now memorializes little besides a chance to peel back pool covers and brush the rust from the barbecue. Labor Day? By 1994, workers had so little interest in trudging down Fifth Avenue that New York City's labor leaders had to cancel their parade. Beginning in 1996, they moved it to the following Saturday.
Columbus Day, like New Year's Eve, has gone through a severe correction. On hearing in recent years that the supposedly heroic discoverer was really the imperialistic oppressor of those who got here first, some cities have halted parades. Berkeley, Calif., instead celebrates "Indigenous People's Day," and some witty New Yorkers repaint Columbus Avenue signs to read "Genocide Avenue."
Holidays that are no holidays have modern causes but a long heritage. Extended Easter and Christmas holidays were standard during the Middle Ages, and any saint worth his miracles was remembered with a feast day. France's royal rulers guaranteed 38 holidays. The Reformation, however, began to give holiday-pooping the status of high principle.
 
No More Pudding
In the 1640's, the British Parliament, dominated by Puritans, banned Christmas festivities altogether, outlawing plum puddings and mince pies in particular. In New England, likewise, Christmas long remained a regular workday. "Can you in your conscience think," the Rev. Cotton Mather asked his Puritan congregation in 1712, "that our Holy Savior is honored by mad mirth, by long eating, by hard drinking, by lewd gaming, by rude reveling, by a mass fit for not but a Saturn or Bacchus?"
If British laborers eventually won back their Christmases, rising industrialists pruned away the rest of their holidays until they could only count on Good Friday. The growth of labor unions here and abroad helped reverse holiday erosion for a while. But Americans, overworked and underinvolved in any other activity besides channel surfing, have over recent decades enshrined Dilbert, not Bacchus, as their holiday role model.
Beginning about 1980, workers of all collars began losing paid vacation and holiday time, says Juliet B. Schor, author of "The Overworked American." Downsizing and client demands for round-the-calendar-and-clock access to professionals require many to work straight through whatever holidays they are nominally granted.
"The requirements for success have intensified," Ms. Schor said. Companies struggling to keep up with demand would rather pile on the hours than hire new workers. Boeing, late on aircraft deliveries, kept thousands at work through this year's usual holiday break.
The waning of unions has caused holidays to wane as well. For example, building janitors represented by the Service Employees International Union enjoy at least the 10 Federal holidays, and some have more. But 80 percent of janitors are not in unions, so unless they work for government, a holiday is usually a day for mourning the loss of pay.
These days, people boast of holiday workloads the way they used to recount their mad mirth. When James Rowland, executive chef at Dallas's Hotel Crescent Court, learned that his mother planned a brief Christmas visit from Tucson, Ariz., his response was, "Hey, you want to come to work with me?" Seating her for dinner at his restaurant at 11 P.M. on Christmas Eve, he noted that he was due back at work at 7 A.M.
Count on the nation's journalists, consumed with self-pity over having to publish or broadcast every day, to discover each year that work elsewhere slows around the holidays. But managers are out to keep employees marching. In 1986, the last time Christmas fell on a Thursday, 46 percent of employers gave workers a paid Friday off, according to the Bureau of National Affairs, a Washington research group. In 1997, it was 36 percent.
Even as workplace demands multiply, the civic, family and religious spirit behind the holidays has faded. Participation in all forms of associations, from churches to political groups to bowling leagues and P.T.A.'s, has stagnated or declined. The increasing numbers who don't even take a few minutes to observe Election Day can't be expected to march or wave a flag on any other day.
In devising other ways to spend holidays, wily bosses are increasingly resourceful. Editors unapologetically pre-empted this reporter's rude reveling with an assignment that kept him at his desk New Year's Day. "It's about how Americans are getting really sick of holidays," an editor said. "If you could put this together in the next day or two, it might be really fun."

HEADLINE: The World;
One Korean Certainty: No More Business as Usual

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
AN age-old Korean practice, common among housewives, draws together a group of acquaintances to pool their cash savings and trust one among them to manage the pool profitably. Often, that means providing the money to a credit-starved business at a high interest rate.
Kim Yon-jung, a 54-year-old mother of two who runs her family's finances, participated in this kind of arrangement for years and earned well above what she could have on her own. Putting her cash in someone else's hands, Mrs. Kim also found, allowed her to avoid reporting her holdings to South Korea's aggressive tax authorities. 
 A few weeks ago, however, Mrs. Kim got the shock of her life. The woman in charge of her 30-member group disappeared with all the money, roughly $2 million.
"In the old days, that would never happen," said Mrs. Kim, still amazed that a reliable pillar of her life had disintegrated so swiftly. "My daughter was suspicious of the old way. Maybe now I should listen to her."
 
New Demands
South Korea's financial crisis, so much worse than anyone had predicted, is forcing business executives, government officials and ordinary people to thoroughly rethink the way they have done things for decades. Financial methods and practices left over from a simpler era are abruptly clashing with the demands of a more modern society, like accountability and openness, and it is as true for big conglomerates as it is for housewives like Mrs. Kim.
The current crisis emerged from a tight collusion between big companies and Government that meant that credit was allocated using political, and not financial, criteria. Only when several of South Korea's enormous conglomerates started going bankrupt did the extent of the problem emerge.
When international bankers gathered in New York, Tokyo and London last week and agreed to defer more than $10 billion in Korea's short-term debt, they were mainly interested in keeping the nation from defaulting in a way that would prevent Korean banks from ever paying back the loans.
But rescue packages and loan holidays, even if they keep South Korea's financial system nominally alive, will not fully preserve the old-fashioned ways of this country. And that is good news for an entire generation of younger men and women who see a bright side to South Korea's financial mess. For them, the weakening of conglomerates means that the traditional emphasis on seniority in the business world may have to yield a few steps in favor of ability. Many well-educated young executives are eager to take over from elders they see as long on loyalty and short on efficiency.
Young South Koreans complain that despite a steady modernization over the past 40 years, the nation's economic and social system in many ways still resembles the strict hierarchy of a small village, built as it is on an ethos of trust in a relatively small number of elders who are only informally accountable to the larger group. That may have been fine in the old village, but now it is badly outdated. Just ask Mrs. Kim.
 
Widespread Collusion
By and large, Koreans did not seem surprised that a system of bribery, politically motivated loans and fiscal irresponsibility was widely practiced by heads of conglomerates. What was so shocking was the scale of corruption and collusion. The old Korean financial system may have worked as long as the players -- and their misdemeanors -- remained small. But as companies grew into multibillion-dollar operations, the lack of adequate accountability was bound to lead to abuses.
After Hanbo Iron and Steel went bankrupt in early 1997, for example, an investigation showed that the chairman, Chung Tae Soo, had borrowed $6 billion for the company, and used several hundred million dollars of that to bribe officials to keep authorizing cheap bank loans, keeping some for himself.
Even more stunning, perhaps, was the revelation that the head of the conglomerate that owned Korean Airlines had made a beeline for the presidential mansion in 1983 when a Soviet fighter plane shot down flight KAL 007, killing all 269 people on board. The first concern of the executive, Cho Choong Hoon, was to hand several million dollars to then-president Chun Doo-hwan, to insure that Mr. Cho could keep his job.
Mr. Chun, whose total take allegedly reached hundreds of millions of dollars in his eight-year rule, was pardoned last week and released from serving a life sentence he was given last year.
The election of the liberal reformer Kim Dae Jung on Dec. 18 seems to have given many young people hope that the political system will veer in a more democratic direction. Yet Mr. Kim, who assumes office in late February, is taking over at a time of such financial crisis that it is uncertain how much he can reform the large conglomerates known as chaebol. Even so, the system built around these conglomerates, many of which resemble personal empires rather than efficient businesses, is unlikely to survive in its current form.
 
Seniority System
One aspect of Korean business life that immediately looks vulnerable, for example, is the kisu system of arranging employees by seniority.
Steadily expanding chaebol have hired a new crop of employees each year, labeling each new group according to number of years the company has been in business -- a tag that is expected to remain throughout an employee's career. Even Korea's main airline had a kisu system for flight attendants.
"When you meet someone new at your own company, you immediately ask what kisu they are," explained a Korean journalist. "Whichever one came earlier -- no matter who is actually older -- treats the other one like an inferior."
This year, few chaebol will be hiring; in fact, those that do not fall into bankruptcy will more likely be laying off people.
"The old kisu will gradually become meaningless," said the journalist.
Yet as Mark Clifford, an American journalist, observed in his prescient book about South Korea, "Troubled Tiger" (M. E. Sharpe, 1995), a system so dominated by the Government was bound to run into serious financial trouble.
"The old order is shriveling," wrote Mr. Clifford. "But the new one has yet to be born."

HEADLINE: The World: New World Audit;
Fail-Safe Strategies In a Market Era

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE setting was the White House Situation Room. It was the second crisis meeting of the day in the famous underground briefing center, where, in Hollywood's imaginings, vast screens illuminate the day's catch from spy satellites and orders are barked through secure links to American outposts around the globe.
The truth, of course, is always more prosaic: the room is cramped, and the screens are more likely to be carrying CNN. But what has really changed in the Situation Room in recent months is the things people talk about there. 
 While the "Sit Room" is still where the nation's leaders go to discuss loose nukes in Russia or Iraq's latest act of defiance, it has repeatedly been used lately to hash out America's next moves to contain the financial crisis in Asia. On that Friday in mid-December, the Secretary of State, Defense Secretary and national security adviser all took part in a debate over whether American taxpayer dollars should be committed to a redoubled effort to keep South Korea's private banks afloat -- and over the consequences if the banks were simply allowed to go under.
"You could tell this was New Age foreign policy," one participant recalled later, "because the assessment didn't come from the C.I.A. It came from J. P. Morgan."
In its myriad dimensions -- financial, political, and national security -- the Asian meltdown has all the earmarks of the ultimate post-cold-war foreign policy crisis.
It is not simply that conversation in the Situation Room these days often parallels the talk in trading pits and boardrooms. Nor that Washington has finally come to regard a currency crisis in Mexico or Southeast Asia as a foreign policy problem that needs to be managed with the vigor devoted to Bosnia or the Middle East -- even if falling currencies lack the televised drama of troops with guns.
 
Three Crises
What's happening today goes a step further. The newfangled financial crises that destabilize huge economies in a single trading day appear increasingly connected to old-line political and security crises. In fact, there is growing fear that 1997's market calamities could beget 1998's security crises -- which explains why Defense Secretary William Cohen and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright joined the Administration debate over saving Korean banks.
Their concern dates back to Indonesia's financial seizure in September. That immediately raised fears that the country's economic problems, which have worsened despite an International Monetary Fund bailout, could be exploited by itchy generals looking for ways to push aside President Suharto -- probably not the best way to handle Asia's most problematic political transition. The last time military control of the country changed hands, half a million people died.
But when the trouble hit South Korea, the Administration went on full alert. That is where 37,000 American troops are lined up against the most xenophobic government on Earth. Some Pentagon strategists warned that hard-line North Korean generals might try to capitalize on the South's moment of weakness. But the more immediate worries were how the economic instability might threaten South Korea's fragile democracy, and how it might raise Seoul's doubts about the security alliance with the United States. "If we were perceived to be abandoning them on this issue," one of Mr. Clinton's top security aides said, "they could easily doubt our commitment to help them in an uglier confrontation."
 
You Never Know
Then there is the question of China, which so far has avoided the contagion afflicting the region. George Soros, the financier blamed by Malaysia's leader for starting this madness (falsely, it turns out), marked the New Year with a dour essay warning that the Chinese economy could be the next to burst. At the Treasury, that worry takes a back seat to fretting over Japan.
Of course, these are not the situations for which the Situation Room was built. If they were, every seat at the table would be equipped with a Bloomberg financial terminal.
Some critics even call the Administration's tilting with markets a prime example of its small-potatoes diplomacy. Others say this is the kind of problem where intervention may simply make things worse. As Jeffrey Sachs and Steven Radelet of the Harvard Institute of International Development argued in Foreign Affairs last month, "the currency upheavals probably reflect short-run financial considerations rather than a long-term crisis of regional growth."
The problem is that you never know whether a financial crisis is just a financial crisis until it turns into something worse. The failure of a major Austrian bank in 1931 led to a cascade of failures and devaluations through Eastern Europe and Germany that sped Europe's prewar descent into chaos. No one is predicting anything like that in Asia. But as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said recently, the same technology that has created 24-hour markets has also "enhanced the ability of the system to rapidly transmit problems in one part of the globe to another."
Washington is probably ahead of other capitals in understanding that dynamic, though it underestimated the depth of the brewing crisis. Often, its early-warning system is still tuned to another frequency.
While the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency have talked for years about making economic analysis a top priority, it is still something of a backwater. At the outbreak of the South Korean crisis, almost no one at the American Embassy in Seoul could offer the Treasury insights about what was going on, or extract the truth from South Korea's Finance Ministry.
The Treasury turned to the embassy because none of its own experts are stationed in South Korea -- the world's 11th-largest economy -- or anyplace else in Asia, except for Tokyo. Then again, maybe a bigger presence wouldn't have helped: The International Monetary Fund employs more than 1,000 Ph.D. economists, many of whom constantly travel the globe looking for trouble in the making. They issued reports praising both Thailand and South Korea for "sound macroeconomic management" only months before those countries were pleading for, and got, I.M.F. bailouts.
One reason the Government devotes so few resources to these problems is that the private sector devotes so many. Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, who has spent his days and nights consumed by Asia's problems, notes that "unlike the military sphere, in the financial sphere there are thousands of market participants processing and analyzing information, assessing risk." He adds that "that assessment is reflected in prices" as nations and companies seek to raise money in global markets.
But in the Asian debacle, like the Mexican crisis before it, finance ministries hid the data that might have sounded alarms. That is why the Clinton Administration has been pressing for worldwide rules requiring greater disclosure of monetary data traditionally kept secret. The theory is that if governments know they cannot conceal evidence of trouble, the markets will force them to solve the problem, or watch billions of investment dollars go elsewhere. The problem is that fuller disclosure could set off plenty of false alarms, turning small problems into huge ones if international lenders panic.
So much for the hope the end of the cold war would make the world easier to manage. "For all the talk about free markets and the spreading of American-style capitalism," said Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management and a former Under Secretary of Commerce, "the fact is that global finance has become the quintessential interweaving of public and private institutions, mechanisms and interests.
"And as we are seeing, governments and private markets cannot be unraveled in the real world."

HEADLINE: Idealism, Past and Present

 BODY:
The end of the cold war aroused fears among some who conduct foreign policy that Americans would tire of shouldering the world's problems. Superficially, those fears appear well founded. Surveys show that Americans are put off by news of distant conflicts and prefer not to become involved. Look again, however, and a different picture emerges. It turns out that Americans crave engagement in the world's crises, but not in the way they are defined by some leaders in Government, academic institutions and the news media. As a new year dawns, it is worth remembering that citizens want the United States to assert its global leadership, but in a more nuanced and coordinated fashion than in the past.
These thoughts are prompted by two new surveys showing Americans to be perhaps more concerned and even idealistic about the world's problems than many in Washington. Polls by the University of Maryland's Program on International Policy Attitudes and the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press found a strong cooperationist streak. For example, the Maryland study found that 74 percent of those surveyed wanted a sharing of power internationally, while only 13 percent wanted the United States to throw its weight around as the sole superpower. In addition, while Congress refuses to approve $1.5 billion in overdue assessments for the United Nations, the Pew survey found that Americans hold the organization in high regard. 
 These practical attitudes pose an interesting challenge to makers of foreign policy, not to mention the news media that report it. When it comes to American intervention, the key to winning support is to gain cooperation of other countries. As for foreign news generally, other polls show that if it focuses on the rise and fall of regimes and far-off diplomatic and military clashes, Americans no longer anchored in the worldwide contest with Moscow have little patience. But the Pew survey has shown surprising concern about those occurrences abroad that affect Americans' economic well-being, health and safety.
This might seem like mere selfishness, but the specific examples tell a different story. The Pew survey found broad support for cooperative action to halt global warming, even if it means applying fuel consumption standards that lead to higher gasoline prices in the United States. Pollsters have also found that in the medical sphere, Americans expect a muscular, multilateral response to the spread of disease, whether from the outbreak of mad cow disease in Britain, AIDS in Africa or avian flu in Hong Kong. Americans are also known to be increasingly aware that the collapse of economies in Latin America or the Caribbean can translate into immigration, and that certain economies are dependent on drug exports to the United States. As for the collapse of currencies and financial institutions in Asia, voters will certainly punish any government that ignores the threat they pose to American banks, individual investors and pension funds.
As President Clinton prepares for the second year of his second term, the foreign policy agenda is surprisingly packed. A newly expanded NATO, and a renewal of American troop involvement in Bosnia, will properly require Congressional approval. Global warming, trade, drugs and disease are at the center of American concerns. The Administration's decision to push for more open trade and to help rescue the economies of Asia will affect the jobs of everyone. The new surveys have thus reinforced an old axiom. Americans care more about the world than they are given credit for. The test of leadership remains to dramatize the connection of the new problems of today to their lives.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
