HEADLINE: Yellowstone Wolves and Diversity

 BODY:
In nature as in culture, diversity can be a difficult concept. Understanding it is one thing, accepting it another, especially when diversity means not only acknowledging a pre-existing cornucopia of difference -- the very ampleness of the world -- but also accommodating an adjustment to the status quo. A case in point is the reintroduction of gray wolves in Yellowstone National Park. Thirty-three wolves were released in 1995, and their number has now reached 97. Population expansion is one measure of the wolf program's success, but a better one is the wolves' impact on the natural diversity of the park.
As John Varley, the park's chief scientist, put it, the Yellowstone wolves "can create an elk carcass whenever they want." Typically, a pack kills an elk every few days. But over the remains the wolves abandon, a wonderful new diversity has emerged. Since their arrival, wolves have killed many of the park's coyotes. This has created -- or rather re-opened -- new niches for other predators, which have begun to gather in greater numbers over wolf-killed elk carcasses. The reduction in coyotes has caused an increase in rodents, which also benefits a wide array of predators. Even the coyotes who live at the margins of wolf country have prospered, thanks to the leftovers the wolves leave behind. So do grizzly bears, who feed on wolf-killed elk before beginning hibernation. The benefit wolves bestow on grizzlies may turn out to be the most exciting news of all. 
 What has interested scientists is the swiftness, the dynamism, of this shift in diversity. There has been, however, no matching dynamism in the opinions of humans who oppose the wolf reintroduction. That was made plain by a Federal district judge's recent order to "remove" the wolves, the result of litigation that is the offspring of intransigence. Several livestock groups, including the Wyoming Farm Bureau, had filed a suit that urged, in slightly cleverer terms, the old proposition, no wolves, nohow. Several environmental groups had filed a separate lawsuit -- unconnected to the Yellowstone wolves -- protesting the dropping of legal protections for wolves that were recolonizing Idaho. The two suits were unfortunately merged.
Though Judge William Downes stayed his own decision, pending appeal, his judgment is a sad encouragement to the mistaken defensiveness of livestock groups who purport to represent the interests of most ranchers. It is also a misapprehension of the purpose of the environmentalists' suit. His decision needs to be swiftly and decisively overturned on appeal. It is no exaggeration to say that since the return of the wolves, Yellowstone has witnessed an economics of diversity from which human culture -- including the culture of ranching -- can directly profit, if only it chooses to do so.

HEADLINE: It's Andrew Cuomo's Turn at Bat, And Some See Makings of Slugger

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Not long ago, as Mario M. Cuomo lunched with friends at the Rainbow Room atop Rockefeller Center, someone asked him why he had no plans to run for office again.
"And Mario said something I had never heard him say before," said Sandy Frucher, a family friend who once worked for Mr. Cuomo, the former Governor of New York. "He flat out said, 'I think I would consider it. But it's Andrew's turn now.' " 
 It has been nearly a year since Andrew Cuomo, 40, Mario's eldest son and heir apparent, became Secretary of Housing and Urban Development -- the youngest ever -- and began aggressively shaking up the troubled agency to help rebuild its battered reputation.
And ever since, political pundits and power brokers have tracked his ascent like weather forecasters follow the path of a hurricane.
Will he go back to New York and run for the Senate in a Democratic primary against George Stephanopoulos? Is he shooting to become Vice President Al Gore's running mate on the ticket for 2000? Why did he make a political appearance in New Hampshire in October?
The questions are clearly a nod to a flourishing career, given his fast start as Housing Secretary, his close relationship with the Vice President and his marriage to Kerry Kennedy, a daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, joining two of America's most famous political families. Almost anybody who talks about Andrew Cuomo wonders where he might land after he leaves this job.
"I'm going to be here for the year 2000, unless I get fired before," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview, trying to put the questions to rest. "And then I want to help the Vice President become President Gore, any way I can help. Then, who knows."
But the focus on his political ambition enrages Mr. Cuomo, who is intent on trading his image as a New York-style backroom wheeler-dealer -- one so well known in Washington that he was the inspiration for the character Jimmy Ozio in the political novel "Primary Colors." Mr. Cuomo prefers a more dignified portrait as a Washington mandarin. The very thought that this transition is incomplete profoundly upsets Mr. Cuomo, whose staff formulated a full-scale public relations offensive to counter the image during preparation for this article.
"This is a political business and a political town," Mr. Cuomo said, incredulously. "If I weren't doing the politics, I wouldn't be doing my job. I'm not here to practice medicine."
Andrew Cuomo wants nothing more than for people to quit rehashing his past and predicting his future. He wants them to focus on the present, on accomplishments he can point to without dispute.
 
A Fast Start But Miles to Go
In his first year at the helm of the department, Mr. Cuomo, who spent four years at the agency as an assistant secretary, has earned high marks from members of Congress, the Clinton Administration and several housing industry insiders. They say he has moved quickly, decisively and innovatively to help resuscitate a still-troubled agency.
"I am very impressed with the intensity and the diligence with which the Secretary is pressing for reform within the department," said Representative Jerry Lewis, Republican of California, who is chairman of the housing panel on the Appropriations Committee. "He takes the job very seriously."
But the department remains at "high risk," according to the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, and Mr. Cuomo faces considerable challenges. The agency has antiquated technology, low morale and must deal with its failure to fully address the needs of poor people in urban centers.
And critics wonder whether Mr. Cuomo, in his zeal to right wrongs, may be moving too quickly to consolidate programs, handling matters too harshly and surrounding himself with inexperienced people who have little knowledge of the department.
The question remains: How can the department redefine itself?
"Part of the problem," said Representative Rick A. Lazio, Republican of New York, "is that HUD needs to establish a more relevant and important mission."
 
As Confidence Rises, So Do Budget Dollars
The way Mr. Cuomo sees it, the bottom line extends no further than the bottom dollar. "That is a real indicia of success," he said. "What does it come down to? Did you get the budget or not?"
The White House is proposing to give the department $1 billion to $2 billion more for the fiscal year 1999, which will begin Oct. 1, its first increase in three years and the healthiest rise in more than a decade. This year, the department's budget was $24 billion. The figures mean nothing without Congress's approval, but Mr. Cuomo and others said they underscored the White House's growing confidence in the department.
"I think people will regard this as the best HUD budget in over a decade," said Gene Sperling, a former aide to Governor Cuomo, who is now an assistant to the President on economic policy. "And I think that's due, in no small part, to the feeling that Andrew has been willing to both take some tough steps to improve the efficiency of HUD and that he has been very good at coming up with new ideas that have caught the attention of the President and the Vice President."
A prosecutor at heart, Mr. Cuomo tackles the job with analytical prowess and pragmatism, friends and critics say. He relishes the long hours, the homework and the debate. "Peeling the onion" is a favorite phrase. And he has experience in the field, which is uncommon for a Housing Secretary. In New York, Mr. Cuomo helped develop housing for the homeless.
"He has the best political instincts of any secretary at HUD, and I've known them all," said Cushing N. Dolbeare, the dean of housing advocates and a freelance housing consultant. "My sense is that whenever I have been in a meeting with him, he listened with two ears; one for substance and the other for how this is going to sound to people he has to convince."
The agency has several large missions. It provides rental assistance to about 4.5 million low-income people, helps revitalize some 4,000 cities through grants, promotes fair housing and is responsible for billions of dollars in mortgage insurance.
Mr. Cuomo's strategy has been threefold: acknowledge the mess the agency is in, get tough on waste, fraud and abuse, and overhaul the department's structure.
"What is HUD?" Mr. Cuomo said, posing a question and then answering it himself, a self-Socratic dialogue perfected by his father. "It is scandal. It is inefficient. It is wasteful. It is the constructor of public housing institutions. It is the destroyer of neighborhoods. It is the place where good taxpayers have their dollars ripped off. I'm going to change everything you believe about HUD. But first of all, I'm going to acknowledge all of this. Acknowledge it, then resolve it."
To get tough, he brought in the Justice Department to help chase bad landlords who defraud taxpayers and operate slums. He is bolstering HUD's enforcement center, placing a full-time agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the helm, and cracking down on housing discrimination.
His proudest accomplishment this year, he said, is helping get through Congress the first major piece of housing legislation in five years, which, among other things, ends excessive rental subsidies to private landlords, saving taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.
To get it passed, Mr. Cuomo spent countless hours on the telephone with members of Congress and their staffs, and, in the end, he compromised where his predecessors did not, said a House Republican aide familiar with the circumstances.
"Cuomo does back up with action," the aide said.
"Cisneros got dribs and drabs from us," he said, referring to the previous Housing Secretary, Henry G. Cisneros. "Cuomo is smart. He sees the writing on the wall and changes strokes midstream."
Mr. Cuomo has also tackled the dull but important issue of management reform, consolidating programs, improving automation and taking action to reduce the size of the staff to 7,500 from 9,500 by 2002, a process Mr. Cisneros started.
This downsizing, which the inspector general recently said appeared to be an arbitrary number that could exacerbate problems at the agency, has in fact contributed to low morale. But Mr. Cuomo, with the backing of unions that represent the department's workers, is trying to allay that by running a merit competition for jobs. Employees are evaluated by a panel of civil servants and will "win" their jobs based on performance, not seniority or connections.
"Morale," one Democratic Senate aide said, "will skyrocket."
 
Blessing and Curse Of a Famous Name
Mr. Cuomo does not rest easy in his chair. He leans forward, he leans back, jabbing the air with his index finger. When he talks, he hits his syllables hard and quick, his voice sliding from a near whisper to a head-snapping hurl.
Results are what matter to him.
Yet, the same political astuteness he uses so deftly to get the job done lends him the air of a "politico" that some people find disconcerting, say some people on Capitol Hill.
"I have a feeling, as do many other people, that Andrew's mission is his own future political career," said Madeleine Hastings, a former official of the department who left it unhappily in September.
It is an image Mr. Cuomo cannot escape. He grew up, after all, under the tutelage of Mario Cuomo in a city known for its tough politics. He sounds just like his father. And like his father, he is sometimes seen as someone who is short-tempered and prickly about his reputation.
But it is also an image that implies a sterling political future. "My assumption has been, whenever Moynihan doesn't run, Cuomo will be at the top of the list," said Charles E. Cook Jr., who publishes a bipartisan political newsletter, "The Cook Report." "He will walk into any Senate race with a huge number of advantages: the name recognition, the fund-raising apparatus, and he's obviously a very talented person."
Mr. Cuomo acknowledges that his political background and family ties are both a blessing and a liability. "I was exposed to one of the best teachers you could have, in Mario Cuomo," he said. His father, Mr. Cuomo said, taught him that public service was "a cause and a mission and a philosophy as opposed to a business and a path to power." But, he added, "The inverse is people think you are highly politicized."
One example people cite of his political acumen took place last summer, when he announced that he would open a new enforcement center in New York City. The department's largest union fiercely opposed the move, which would have required several trial lawyers to move from Washington.
One agency lawyer wrote to Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, calling it incredible that "a Republican would want to fill the coffers of Secretary Cuomo for a run in New York."
Mr. Cuomo eventually dropped the idea and made peace with the union. But the notion that the move had anything to do with his political ambition clearly unnerves him.
"People who assume I want to run for elected office may be dealing from a bad assumption," he said.
Others say his plan to open a center in New York and other major cities was Politics 101; an unsolicited gift to important members of Congress who control the housing committees and whose districts were scheduled to lose jobs in the effort to downsize the department.
"It's not illogical to pay attention to the politics that affect those people who are the key policy people you deal with," Mr. Lewis, the California Congressman, said.
Despite all the talk of ambition, the fact is, Mr. Cisneros said, Mr. Cuomo chose to stay committed to the task of fixing the ailing agency.
"He could have gone back to New York at the end of his term," the former Housing Secretary said. "But he chose one of the least attractive, least promising departments in Washington to head. That speaks much more to his intent to produce results and get things done."
As Mr. Cuomo describes it, being Housing Secretary epitomizes the dignity of public service. It is about helping poor people, he said, adding that he would not trade away the job any time soon.
"We can do real good things here for people," Mr. Cuomo said. "When I got here we served 25,000 homeless people a year. We now serve 280,000 a year. Who gets a chance in their life to make that difference?"

HEADLINE: Russia's Church-Run Campus Has a Secular Goal

BYLINE: By MARINA LAKHMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
In the cozy top floor of the Vysoko Petrovsky monastery, where Russian Orthodox monks once immersed themselves in ancient manuscripts, Natasha Nikolayeva and her classmates were taking their final exams in Russian housing law recently. The icons that adorn the walls of the tiny lecture room comforted Ms. Nikolayeva, who came from Ukraine to study here.
"I knew that here I would find people close to me in spirit, faith and style of life," said the 21-year-old senior. "The jurisprudence was secondary, but I was looking for an education that would be a mix of the spiritual with the practical." 
 In Soviet times, it was common for church buildings to be confiscated by the state and turned into Government offices, schools, museums or even granaries. But now, for the first time, people are studying secular subjects in a Russian religious institution. Ms. Nikolayeva is one of the students at the Russian Orthodox University of St. John the Theologian, the only church-run university in the country that is training young people for the professional world of the new Russia rather than priests.
"We did not create this university to train people to serve the church," said the rector of the university and head of the monastery, Ioann Economtsev. "Our purpose was to bring about a synthesis between scholarship and faith, and religion and morality, because scholarship without morality at its core is dangerous."
Despite the university's religious name and leanings, Mr. Economtsev said most of the applicants are seeking to enter the law and economics department and as a result the competition is steeper than in other departments. In contrast with Soviet times, law and economics have become prestigious careers as the Russian media publicize the growing wealth and political influence of the country's top bankers.
Based on the traditions of the Academy of Slavonic, Greek and Latin Studies, a church university in pre-revolutionary Russia, the Russian Orthodox university is a major departure from the kind of schooling the church was able to involve itself in during the Soviet era.
It also reflects the church's attempt to consolidate its hold on Russian society and turn itself back into the country's official religion.
Although Russia's constitution guarantees freedom of religion, President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a hotly debated bill last year -- at the urging of the Russian Orthodox Church -- that limits the growth of new religions in Russia and gives priority to the Russian Orthodox Church. The bill drew fierce criticism from international human-rights groups and a threat from the United States Congress to cut off aid to Russia.
The financing of the university is indicative of the church's willingness to involve itself in politics. Though the church oversees the university, it is primarily financed by private sponsors, the largest of which is the powerful Oneksimbank.
The bank's president, Vladimir Potanin, one of the most politically influential figures in the country, is a major donor to the church. His annual gift of $100,000 to the Russian Orthodox university makes up 40 percent of the university's budget.
Anna Parshikova, a spokeswoman for Uneximbank, said that the bank hopes to employ future graduates of the university's law and economics departments.
"They have attracted a great number of Moscow's elite scholars to teach there," she said. "There are few institutions that can compare."
With religion experiencing a revival since the fall of Communism and the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, the university's religious leanings are an attraction for many students. So is the prospect for a free education, a mainstay of the Soviet Union, an opportunity which is slowly diminishing as the cash-strapped Government finds itself unable to finance higher education.
With departments in law, economics and ecology as well as philosophy and theology and related fields, and with a new medical department to begin next fall, the university has increased its enrollment 10-fold to 500 students since it opened in 1993.
The university offers a rigorous academic program. Students in the departments of philosophy and theology, and history and philology are required to study ancient Greek, Latin and Russian in addition to a modern language, while Bible students are required to add ancient Hebrew and Aramaic, to their studies.
Yulia Butskikh, 20, who is in her third year of study in the philosophy and theology department, said the university had found an educational niche that is not available at other institutions.
"M.G.U. does not have the religious depth and religious academies do not have the scholarship," she said comparing the university with Moscow State University, one of the country's best-known universities. "This is a good combination of the two."
The faculty includes professors from Moscow State University, two from England -- who give their lectures on literature in English -- and Nikita Tolstoy, who until his death last year headed the Slavonics specialty in the history and philology department. Mr. Tolstoy is the son of the Soviet novelist Aleksei Tolstoy and a distant relative of Leo Tolstoy.
Unlike religious universities elsewhere, the Russian Orthodox university does not require its students to attend services and there are no stringent housing rules since the school does not have dormitories for its students. Nonetheless, all students are required to complete courses in the history of Christianity as well as the Old and New Testaments. In addition, economics students also have the opportunity to take courses like "Economics in the World of the Bible" and "The Economic Views of the Fathers of the Church."
Irina Pankova, who is in her last year of study in the university's law department, said she hoped the education she received at the university would allow her to bring about change in Russia.
"I think this education allows us to look at the future with a human view," she said, "not the way things are now, like in economics, where there is no humanity."
Mr. Economtsev said he too hopes to see his graduates transform Russia. "My goal is to prepare the intellectual and spiritual elite of Russia," he said. "We are not preparing students for the Russia of yesterday, and not the Russia that exists today. We are preparing students for a regenerated Russia, for a highly cultural, highly moral Russia of great intellectual and scientific potential."

HEADLINE: Unlikely Twist: G.I.'s Warm to Bosnia

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: OLOVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dec. 30

 BODY:
Staff Sgt. Paul Correale noticed the elderly woman in black with the toddler when the two turned to watch his patrol from 50 feet or so away. The child waved a tiny, pink-mittened hand in greeting.
The sergeant, 34, is a specialist in armed reconnaissance who describes what his training entailed this way: "They tell us to go out and get information on the enemy so the main force can kill them." And that is what he is expected to do in Bosnia if the NATO-led peacekeeping mission deteriorates into combat. 
 But, with that pink mitten waving back and forth, his patrol stopped while the sergeant, laughing, ran over to grasp the child's hand.
"I'm doing what I'm doing for the kids here," he said afterward. "I think the Bosnians are the hardest working, most decent people I've ever seen."
The United States Army has worried about this sort of thing. Senior American officers in Bosnia spent much of the last two years telling their subordinates not to let soldiers get emotionally involved in what they were doing here. There was too high a risk that Western efforts would fail, the officers said, and if the soldiers cared too much about the country their morale might collapse along with the peace.
But it seems too late for such concerns. To a considerable extent, American forces have gone from dispassionate observers in a confusing land to soldiers who feel their job is to help people they now know and like.
Senior officers now say it may be better for the Army if the soldiers feel an emotional association with Bosnians.
Soldiers get constant reinforcement from Bosnians who tell them it is good that the Americans are here. Psychological screenings of soldiers leaving the danger, discomfort and loneliness of long tours in Bosnia find that the troops feel better about themselves and their jobs than the average American does, according to Army psychologists.
An immediate benefit for the Army is that soldiers who have been assigned to Bosnia are more likely to re-enlist than others, officers say. This year the re-enlistment rates for some Army units in Europe, from which most the soldiers in Bosnia have come, are more than 50 percent higher than their goals, the Army says.
In this town there was another statistic to note: The number of times per minute Bosnians smiled and greeted the American patrol.
As they walked the frozen streets at the bottom of a cup-shaped valley where the mountains, the pine trees and the sky were uniformly white with snow and haze, most of the American soldiers spoke optimistically of their work.
They did not dwell on the factories destroyed by shelling or the large number of refugees here who are barred from returning to their homes because the country remains splintered along ethnic lines. Instead, the men in this patrol noted the rebuilt homes and hospital.
Their view of success comes in part from the limited view of their responsibilities expressed by the Army. Their orders do not include having them hunt down indicted war crimes suspects who still powerfully influence politics, although NATO troops are authorized to arrest suspects if security conditions allow. Nor are they supposed to insure that the victims of so-called ethnic cleansing return to their homes.
While a fractured Bosnia, brim-full with the unemployed, the homeless and the angry and governed by politicians who will not work together, may yet blow apart, the soldiers are told their work is going well.
Many of the 8,500 Americans soldiers in Bosnia believe that since their deployment after the December 1995 Dayton accords, they have enforced a peace that is allowing civilian and international agencies to begin rebuilding a country many of them have come to like.
Walking next to the rebuilt Olovo hospital, fresh plaster on the outside and warm clinics filled with children and their mothers inside, Capt. Dan McIntosh, who commands an armored cavalry company, said: "Think of what that means to a community to lose its only hospital. And then, we help open it up. That is something. Our soldiers set the conditions for that."
The executive officer of Captain McIntosh's company, First Lieut. Daniel Fickel, 25, of Miami, said his father tells him that what he is doing in Bosnia now is similar to what his father did earlier in the Peace Corps.
"We're really helping people," Lieutenant Fickel said. "You can't send soldiers halfway around the world to save a country and then say don't get emotionally involved."
Though the American Army policy has been to insist all three ethnic groups -- Serbs, Muslims and Croats -- be treated exactly the same, many soldiers feel that the Muslims, who have the highest number of displaced in Bosnia now, suffered the most during the 1992-95 war. Nearly everyone in Bosnia is relieved the fighting has stopped, but Muslims are convinced the West stopped a war of annihilation that was directed against them, and probably feel especially appreciative toward the peacekeepers.
But with Western governments pressing Bosnian authorities to carry out terms of the peace agreement, there have been times when the NATO-led forces, including Americans, have met violence.
The worst case for the Americans was in August, when troops tried to install a more cooperative police commander in Brcko in the Bosnian Serb-controlled area and mobs organized by local Serbian authorities blocked the attempt. Civilians attacked American soldiers with stones and gasoline bombs.
Despite such incidents, relations between most Bosnians and American troops have been good.
In Olovo, a town named for the lead mined here since Roman times and now inhabited mostly by Muslims, Sergeant Correale seems to have found a place he likes.
Displaying considerable knowledge of medieval Bosnian history, Sergeant Correale, of Huber Heights, Ohio, pointed out a citadel-like building poking through the snow halfway up a mountain and explained that it was one of two centuries-old Roman Catholic monasteries in the area. He added that, based on his reading in the five months since he came here, he has come to doubt the theory that the recent fighting in Bosnia was an inevitable continuation of longstanding ethnic antagonisms.
It is easier now for soldiers to study history and become acquainted with Bosnians than it was in January 1996, when the American troops fought rain, blizzards and a churning Sava River to enter this country. Then, everything was arduous, everywhere was dangerous and living conditions were terrible.
But as political tensions have eased and the Army has become accustomed to working in Bosnia, the soldier's life here has improved.
Even so, soldiers raised questions that senior officers say trouble them as well.
"I think we are doing good, but it is taking a lot out of everyone," said Sgt. Sabrina Pinkard, a medical technician from Columbus, Ohio, who is based at Camp Gentry, a rather isolated base on the northern edge of the American sector.
Referring to the Army's downsizing and the increase in overseas deployments in recent years, she said, "If our unit keeps getting sent places, here or wherever, with no time to rest and catch up, we are going to wear out."
"She's right," said Pvt. David Quinn, also with the Second Cavalry Regiment. Thinking about the stress on soldiers who are separated from their families, he said, "We got our own trouble back home, too."
Soldiers say what makes them think their mission is worthwhile is the balance between the personal burden and the task at hand. In Bosnia, they are getting extra pay and bonuses. Many feel that are sharpening their military skills. And life on their bases, though still difficult, has become less uncomfortable.
At Camp Demi in north-central Bosnia, where the soldiers patrolling the town of Olovo are based, a dinner last week offered choices of 6 entrees including pretty tasty burritos, 6 vegetables, 12 kinds of salad and 8 desserts.
Talk around the base was about how the Army has settled in in Bosnia. The mission has gone from short and arduous to something of indefinite length that has become part of the Army's life.
Soldiers said they were not at all surprised by President Clinton's recent announcement that there is no longer a deadline to withdraw the troops from Bosnia. It seemed clear, many thought, that Bosnia was going to be an assignment to be rotated among combat units for some time.
"I guess it's going to be somewhere between like what we did in Haiti and what we're doing in Korea," said Specialist Jason Suddeth, 21 from Galesburg, Ill.

LENGTH: 1731 words

HEADLINE: EAGER AND FLUSH, MANY STATES PLAN YET MORE TAX CUTS

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 3

 BODY:
With the economy refusing to cool, with most states sitting on sizable surpluses and with gubernatorial and legislative elections scheduled in a majority of states, tax-cut fever is once again sweeping the land as legislatures prepare to open their 1998 sessions.
Experts on state politics and fiscal affairs predict that at least half of the states will enact tax cuts of some magnitude this year, just as they have in each of the last three years. As tax cutting has become an increasingly bipartisan initiative, the debate in many states is no longer whether taxes should be reduced but which ones should be cut and by how much. 
 Even before lawmakers return to their capitols, dozens of tax-cut proposals have been floated in an effort to outmaneuver the political opposition and to snatch election-year credit for returning money to the voters. Gubernatorial elections will be held this year in 36 states, and legislators face elections in 46 states.
A survey this week found that either governors or legislative leaders in at least 26 states have started calling for tax cuts, well before any governor has proposed an executive budget.
Here in Georgia's capital, for instance, Gov. Zell Miller, a Democrat, and the Democratic leaders of the House and Senate appeared in an unusual show of unity last month to announce their support for a plan to cut personal income taxes by $205 million. They have pledged to enact the plan, which would increase personal income tax deductions, within the first two weeks of the legislative session, which begins on Jan. 12.
In most places, this year's tax reduction proposals have been relatively modest, often because larger tax cuts were enacted in previous years and because lawmakers have lingering memories of slashing budgets and raising taxes in the recession of the early 1990's.
But nationwide, authorities on state fiscal matters predict, the aggregate amount of state tax cuts in 1998 is likely to match or exceed that of 1997. As in Washington, that is a reflection of both the fiscal conservatism that has been embraced by both political parties in the Clinton era and the robust health of the economy.
"I think there will be somewhat larger tax cuts in 1998 than in 1997 because, after all, this revenue growth has sustained itself longer than anyone expected," said Ronald K. Snell, director of the economic and fiscal division of the National Conference of State Legislatures. "My guess is that they would exceed 1997 just based on the number of states in which governors and legislative leadership are talking about them."
Another authority on state finances, Hal Hovey, the editor of State Budget and Tax News, predicted that "there will be some form of countable, calculable tax cuts in at least 25 states."
Mr. Snell said that 27 states cut taxes in 1997 for a net national tax reduction of $2.5 billion. In 1996, 29 states cut taxes worth $4 billion, while in 1995, 25 states cut taxes worth $3.3 billion, he said.
In enacting tax cuts over the last three years, many governors and legislative leaders have underscored the need to compensate taxpayers for the tax increases they endured in the early 1990's. And as tax cutting has become a national priority, states have felt pressure to reduce tax rates to remain competitive with their neighbors.
Virtually every kind of tax is vulnerable to reduction this year, although Mr. Hovey said he sensed declining interest in cutting business taxes. He said that may be because job creation had become less urgent with the national unemployment rate at 4.6 percent, the lowest level in 24 years. Property taxes on motor vehicles have become a new target after the Republican candidate, James S. Gilmore 3d, won last year's gubernatorial race in Virginia by promising to cut that state's onerous car taxes.
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican, has yet to announce whether he will propose new tax cuts this year after presiding over a whopping $11 billion in cuts in the last three years. But the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, also a Republican, has called for an additional $1 billion in cuts, much of it to benefit businesses.
"It's started to work in New York," Mr. Bruno said, "and when something's working in a positive way you ought to keep doing it."
In some states, governors and legislative leaders have started to warn that further tax cutting would place services at risk if the economy deteriorates. And, predictably, advocates for more spending on schools and social services argue that state surpluses should be spent rather than refunded.
Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of the Great City Schools, a coalition of the country's largest public school systems, said, "Now is the time, when the economy is flush, both at the Federal and state levels, to do the difficult things that government can't seem to gather the will for in bad times."
But in most places, the steady growth of the last four years has convinced lawmakers that additional tax cutting can be afforded without endangering essential programs.
As in many states, in Georgia the Democratic proposal this year follows large tax cuts in recent years. In 1996, Mr. Miller and the General Assembly enacted the biggest tax cut in state history by eliminating the sales tax on groceries, a $550 million reduction in a state with a general fund budget of $11.8 billion.
This year's pre-emptive strike by Georgia's Democrats comes at a time when Republicans are mounting an aggressive campaign to win the governorship here for the first time this century and when Republicans hope to continue to chip away at the Democrats' thinning majorities in the House and Senate.
Even before the Democrats offered their plan, Guy Millner, the leading Republican candidate for Governor, proposed a much larger tax reduction. He has called for eliminating the property tax on motor vehicles in the first year of his administration, a cut worth $490 million. In the second year, he would offer an additional $360 million in tax credits to residential property owners. Mr. Millner's plan, which has been criticized as unrealistic by some Democratic leaders, would eventually reduce state revenues by more than 7 percent.
Though he refused to comment on Mr. Millner's proposal, Mr. Miller said in an interview that voters wanted a balance between responsible tax cuts and new spending.
"They want investments in education and jobs and safe streets, the things they talk about around the kitchen table, but they also want responsible fiscal government," he said, pointing out that Georgia has spent heavily on education and prison construction in his two terms. "This bubble some day will burst, and we need to always keep that in mind. So while this $200 million tax cut we're going to be doing this year is responsible, maybe to do more than that would be irresponsible."
Alan Secrest, a pollster who has worked for a number of Georgia Democrats, including Mr. Miller, said that the Democrats' tax plan here was aimed primarily at protecting the party's majorities in the General Assembly.
"Democrats in states like Georgia are doing a good job of thinking and acting like a political minority before they become one, meaning that they are presenting a cogent, unified message and they are agreeing to disagree in private," Mr. Secrest said.
The drive for tax cuts around the country is being fueled by strong revenue collections, particularly in personal income taxes paid by the wealthy, which have left states with end-of-the-year surpluses. Many states also have filled rainy-day reserve funds to their statutory limits.
In the 1997 fiscal year, which ended June 30 in most states, 44 states had surpluses totaling $14.7 billion, said Arturo Perez, an analyst for the National Conference of State Legislatures. Since then, the good news has only continued. A report issued this week by Mr. Perez concludes that 29 states predict that revenue collections for 1998 will exceed expectations, while spending in nearly all states has remained on target.
Such news has been a political godsend for Governors like Thomas R. Carper of Delaware. Under Mr. Carper, a Democrat in his second term, Delaware has cut taxes for five consecutive years. "It doesn't get much better than this," he acknowledged in an interview. This year, Mr. Carper has proposed cutting $53 million in personal income and business taxes. Republicans who control the House in Delaware have proposed tax cuts nearly twice that large.
In Massachusetts, all four announced gubernatorial candidates -- two Republicans and two Democrats -- have already called for tax reductions. The Republicans -- A. Paul Cellucci, the Acting Governor, and Joseph Malone, the State Treasurer -- both support a ballot initiative that would reduce personal income taxes to 5 percent from 5.95 percent over three years. Patricia McGovern, a Democratic candidate and former State Senator, has proposed the same rollback over five years. And Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, also a Democrat, wants tax rates brought down to 5.25 percent over five years.
South Carolina's Governor, David Beasley, a Republican who faces re-election this year, is seriously considering calling for a reduction in motor vehicle taxes when he unveils his budget on Jan. 12, said Gary Karr, his spokesman. The state, which has a $4.7 billion budget, has already devoted $750 million over three years to help roll back property taxes for homeowners, and will spend another $240 million on that effort this year, Mr. Karr said.
But in some states, legislators and governors are beginning to urge caution about reducing tax rates further on the basis of recurring surpluses. A particular danger, they said, is that surpluses of recent years have been produced largely by personal income tax receipts, which may reflect the unprecedented three-year surge in the stock market rather than any permanent growth in the economy.
"The danger is that we will give it away and then find over the next years that we're not doing well and can't sustain the tax cuts," said State Senator Rochelle Pingree, the Democratic majority leader in Maine, where Republicans have proposed reducing the state's 6 percent sales tax by 1 percent. "But 1998 is an election year, and it's appealing to say, 'I gave you something back.' "

HEADLINE: Chiropractors' Problem: What Price Acceptance?

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
For chiropractors in New York, 1998 has been touted as the year of the back, the year when insurance companies and managed-care organizations are finally being forced to confer legitimacy on their oft-maligned profession.
With the start of the new year, New York became only the third state to mandate coverage for most chiropractors' services. But the new regulations do not have chiropractors looking for more office space, hiring new associates or ordering new cars. 
 Chiropractors across the state said that although they were gratified by the new laws -- which were opposed by physicians, the insurance industry and the Giuliani administration -- they doubted that they were in store for a windfall.
"I don't think people are going to rush to go see chiropractors just because there's a new law," said Dr. Martin Kotlar, a chiropractor in North White Plains. "If, suddenly, you were able to get open-heart surgery covered by insurance, would you go out and get it just because it was covered?"
Most chiropractors said that they would likely get more patients because of the new law. But they said that managed-care companies, seeking to hold down the cost of this newly required service, would offer chiropractors far less than the fees they are now charging, which had been covered in full or in part by insurance, or, in other cases, were paid out of pocket by patients.
"Managed care pays a fraction of the usual fee and it's usually less than it costs," said Dr. Andrew Lacerenza, a chiropractor who has a solo practice in Lindenhurst on Long Island. "So, most everyone I know is playing it very close to the vest. I don't see anybody moving from a 1,000-square-foot office to 2,000 square feet."
The health-care climate in New York has changed significantly in the decade since chiropractors began their campaign to gain parity under the state's insurance laws. Nearly half the people in the state now receive their health care through managed-care companies that negotiate discounted rates with providers.
In that time, doctors in virtually every specialty have been forced to cut back expenses and streamline their operations, trying to treat more patients for less money per visit.
The new law requires health insurance companies and managed-care organizations to pay for up to 15 visits to a chiropractor each year. Beyond those visits, the insurers can limit payment for treatments that are not deemed medically necessary, but only if the decision does not discriminate specifically against chiropractors. That is, if the insurer would continue to cover such treatment if it was given by an orthopedist or a physical therapist, it cannot bar the treatment simply because the provider is a chiropractor and the patient has reached the 15-visit limit.
Chiropractors say the nondiscrimination provision gives them a sense of legitimacy and credibility that has long eluded them in New York's conservative medical establishment.
"The main focus of this has never been making more money," said Dr. Robert Crocker, a member of the board of directors of the New York State Chiropractic Association, a professional organization representing about 2,000 of the nearly 5,000 chiropractors licensed in the state. "Chiropractors have been marginalized for so long by the medical establishment we're more intense about getting a legitimate standing for the profession."
"We always felt," he continued, "that if we got a fair shake in terms of insurance coverage, we'd stand or fall based on whether or not we did a good job for the patient. We figured any economic boon would come from that."
Dr. Crocker, who has a solo practice in North Babylon on Long Island, said he had no plans to increase his office space, the size of his staff -- which currently consists of one full-time and one part-time receptionist -- or the size of his car.
"This has always been portrayed by our opponents in the insurance industry as a blank check to chiropractors," Dr. Crocker said. "That's not what it looks like from this end."
Dr. Lacerenza said that welcome as it is, the new law addresses only a small corner of the problems chiropractors have faced in dealing with insurers and managed-care companies. Five years ago, he and two other chiropractors filed a lawsuit against 12 insurance and managed-care companies, charging them with violating the Sherman Antitrust Act.
The suit, which will face its next hurdle on Feb. 11 in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, charges that the companies conspired to exclude chiropractors from the managed-care setting and that individual companies had a range of regulations that served to restrain the practices of chiropractors.
One of the biggest problems Dr. Lacerenza described is one faced by various doctors: in putting together their panels of doctors, managed-care companies often limit how many doctors can join, locking some practitioners out and, at times, forcing patients to travel longer distances to get care from a listed provider.
"I've applied to be on the panels of 12 H.M.O.'s," Dr. Lacerenza said. "And I've been denied every time. They told me they had enough people in my geographic area. They told me the plan was closed. Now it's obviously because I've filed this suit. But there is some secret procedure to getting on these panels. We believe that anyone who meets certain minimum qualifications should be able to get in."
Dr. Dale Cohen is on the panels of about 10 managed-care companies. And, he said, in 90 percent of those arrangements, the rates he is paid are lower than his regular rates. He added that even if it meant limiting the number of potential patients, he would not join certain managed-care plans because the fees they offer are too low.
"Access to a bigger patient base is not worth it to me if the reimbursement is too low," said Dr. Cohen, who has his own practice in Camillus, which is near Syracuse.
Still, he said that he expected the new law to bring more patients his way. "But," he added, "I don't expect there to be such an increase in income that I or other people will be going out and buying yachts."
Dr. Howard S. Asness of Great Neck was a tad more optimistic. He said that the new law would give patients more freedom to choose chiropractors to deal with certain medical problems and that he hoped some of those patients would choose to go to him.
"It will help my practice," Dr. Asness said. "Is it going to make me an overnight millionaire? Unfortunately, only the lottery is going to do that."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mr. Break-It And Mr. Fix-It

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Twenty-five years ago today, New York newspapers reported the purchase of the Yankees by a group of out-of-towners whose leader proclaimed: "I won't be active in the day-to-day operations of the club at all. I can't spread myself so thin. I've got enough headaches with my shipping company."
George Steinbrenner laughed last week when he was reminded of that statement. 
 "That's good," he said. "That is the way I started. Sure, yeah, I meant it. I didn't think I was going to be in New York that much. I didn't hold true to my word because I saw things that needed fixing. I didn't understand how bad things were or how complicated they were."
It was his visit to Yankee Stadium on his first day as managing partner, he said, that gave Steinbrenner, then 42 years old, the first clue that his presence would be required on a regular basis.
"I walked in the office the first day," he related, "and in the middle of the winter, fresh-cut flowers were on every secretary's desk. I said to one secretary: 'These are beautiful. What is it?' She said, 'Mr. Burke has fresh-cut flowers on every secretary's desk every day.' I said, 'What does that cost?' When I found out, it got me involved in a hurry. It escalated and enlarged."
Mike Burke, an urbane Irish-American, had run the Yankees for the previous owner, CBS, and it mattered not that the economics of operating the team had run away from the television network. If Burke felt that flowers provided a touch of class, flowers there would be.
Then along came the man from Cleveland.
Without fanfare, the Yankees yesterday marked the 25th anniversary of Steinbrenner's ownership. The number of years is more significant than simply being a round number. They make Steinbrenner the longest-tenured owner in the grand and glorious history of the Yankees. Jacob Ruppert had owned the team for 24 years when he died in 1939.
If it hadn't been flowers, something else would have prompted Steinbrenner to depart emphatically from his Jan. 3, 1973 pledge. To this day, he remains as involved on a daily basis as the proverbial elephant who sits wherever he wants when he enters a room.
Steinbrenner, in fact, is even more involved now than he was at the start because he is more knowledgeable about baseball. He, and not his general manager, negotiates the major player moves the Yankees make, and he also takes time for less glamorous chores, as he exhibited last summer when he ran the Yankee Stadium parking lot for a day.
Whether he is signing Hideki Irabu to a multimillion-dollar contract or parking a Jeep Cherokee, Steinbrenner is involved.
"I'm a hands-on guy," he acknowledged unashamedly. "No sense trying to lie about that."
Worse, he admitted to no one's surprise: "I'm not a good sportsman. I'm a poor loser. I'm just that way." And while he was being candid, he said, "I'm not totally happy with everything I've done, but on balance, I'll stand on the record."
Except for Bud Selig in Milwaukee and Gene Autry in Anaheim, where the cowboy has ceded ownership control to the Disney people, Steinbrenner is the most senior owner of a Major League Baseball team.
To mark his 25th anniversary, he agreed to a series of interviews, even with a reporter he tried to bar from the clubhouse in his first season as owner because he was unhappy with the reporter's articles.
An out-of-towner from Cleveland, who nevertheless liked to say he hadn't just ridden into town on a load of pumpkins, Steinbrenner initially resented negative newspaper articles about him, then came to understand that the important thing was to get his name in the papers, especially on the back pages of the tabloids.
Not very far into his quarter century in New York, he became one of the best and widely known sports personalities in the country.
"You guys did that," he said, meaning reporters.
But no one could have done it without him and his actions, sometimes outrageous, sometimes engaging, but always worth the price of admission.
 
Signing Catfish Hunter Makes the Difference
 Although he has worn out his welcome with many Yankees fans over the years, they all loved him for restoring the team to its championship level in his first five years. But he readily admitted he had help, his arrival in New York closely coinciding with the arrival of free agency.
"Without free agency coming the way it did," he said, "I couldn't have done much because we didn't have much."
Catfish Hunter, whose contract-created free agency preceded by two years the start of negotiated free agency, showed Steinbrenner what he could do by signing stars who were free to roam.
Asked if there was one move that ignited the restoration, the owner said: "Catfish Hunter was the cornerstone to turning our club around. His demeanor around the other players, the way he carried himself, the way he dealt with problems in the clubhouse. He was a winner. He knew how to win. You have to know how to win. It's not something that just happens."
Reggie Jackson followed soon afterward. "Sure he was a hot dog," Steinbrenner said. "So what? He was a great acquisition."
In the beginning, Steinbrenner played the free-agency game better than anyone. But he lost his touch in the 80's, and the change was reflected in the lack of success on the field. Worse, Steinbrenner spent years trying to undermine one of the last good free agents he signed before the drought, constantly feuding with him and gathering questionable ammunition from any source.
"I don't even want to discuss that," he said when Dave Winfield's name was mentioned.
"All of that never should have happened. Dave Winfield was one of the greatest athletes I've ever known. What part of it is me, I'll take the blame."
Does he mean that, or is that just the prudent position to take now, after the fact? Steinbrenner, in the interview, also praised Gabe Paul, his general manager in the early years and the middleman in his $10 million purchase of the Yankees.
"Gabe Paul was one of the smartest guys I met in baseball," he said. "I learned a lot from him. We had problems, but I had a high regard for him."
Yet when Paul left the Yankees to return to Cleveland and the Indians, after the Yankees won the World Series in 1977, Steinbrenner spoke of him with disdain. "He ran baseball teams for 30 years and what did he ever win before he came here with me?" he remarked huffily at the time.
Billy Martin was the manager who directed Steinbrenner's team back to the top, and the owner has a posthumous place in his heart for the man he fired and hired more than any other.
"Billy was a love," he said. "It was an affection for the man, for each other. He couldn't help himself. I'd tell him, 'You're going to destruct if you don't slow down.' I had great admiration for him.
"He was one of the most genius managers I've ever seen. Sheer genius. He always had the other team wondering what he was going to do."
Just as he had Steinbrenner constantly wondering.
"I remember being in Texas," Steinbrenner related. "The alarm system went off in the hotel, and we're all sitting out on the grass at midnight. I was sitting with Tommy John, and here comes Billy. He's got a towel on the side of his head, there's blood all over the towel and his ear is almost off. I said geez, here we go again."
Martin, who had been bloodied in a bar brawl, didn't always requite Steinbrenner's love, like the time in 1978 when he said of Jackson and the owner: "The two of them deserve each other. One's a born liar, the other's convicted."
Nearly 20 years later, Steinbrenner said, "That wasn't a very tasteful thing to say." But he added candidly, "It was accurate."
Steinbrenner's relationship with another of his 14 different managers did not turn out so well. Because he fired Yogi Berra 16 games into the 1985 season after saying the job would be his all season no matter what happened, Berra said he would never go back to Yankee Stadium as long as Steinbrenner owned the team. He has kept his word.
"I've tried everything I know to get him to come back," Steinbrenner said. "I've tried to apologize to him. I would love to have him come back. Every Old-Timers game I call or write a letter. I think it's important that he comes back. But I can't run a man's life for him."
Berra ironically is a close friend and neighbor of John McMullen, former owner of the Houston Astros and before that a limited partner in the Yankees. McMullen is the man who in 1979 uttered the memorable line about Steinbrenner, "There's nothing more limited than a limited partner in the Yankees."
"Oh yeah, there's a lot of truth to that," Steinbrenner said, again speaking candidly.
"I imagine it would have been limited if you were Jacob Ruppert's partner. I've been a tough managing partner, but I think I've been a good managing partner. My partners have done well. I've done well for them."
 
The Perfect Player? 'Tough Warriors'
 Steinbrenner readily acknowledged that he has been tough on players, too.
"I haven't changed a lot like that," he said. "I'm very demanding. I want the very best from each guy, and if he won't give me his best, then God bless him, I hope he's happy somewhere else."
And then he invoked a term that is new for him but one he is certain to use in the future because he obviously liked the sound of it.
"I want warriors, mentally tough warriors," he said. "I'm looking for the Paul O'Neills of the world, the warriors. I have a passion for winning. I want my players to be warriors and have a passion for winning."
The style he seeks, Steinbrenner said, is right for the city his team plays in. "New Yorkers have to be tough," he said. "When you're taking a cab, you're fighting for that cab. You go to a lunch place, you've got to battle for a table. It goes on every day. There's a mental toughness about New Yorkers."
When he came to the city as principal owner of the Yankees, Steinbrenner said: "I was in awe of New York, the bigness of the city. It was four or five years before I saw and really understood that mental toughness that New Yorkers have. I want my team mentally tough. Maybe I didn't always go about it the right way, but I'm a tough boss."
His ownership, or managerial, style, has always followed the practice of creative tension. His best teams, those in the latter half of the 70's, played in an ocean of turmoil and turbulence. "I used to say a calm sea never took a ship anywhere," Steinbrenner said.
"You need some agitation, some volatility, on teams to win."
In the past 25 years, the Yankees have played in and won as many World Series as anyone. They have also won more games than anyone. Then again, Steinbrenner leads the league in suspensions and fines, too. But he holds no grudges, he said, against the commissioners who kept him out of active operation of the team for a total of 45 months, nearly 4 of the 25 years.
"I have no ill will toward Bowie," he said, speaking of the former commissioner Bowie Kuhn, "nothing against Fay Vincent."
Although he has not lost any of his fight, Steinbrenner said he doesn't think he'll remain in charge of the Yankees for too much longer.
He has been grooming his son, Hal, and his son-in-law, Steve Swindal, to take over eventually.
"I don't know how much longer," he said. "I want to see my horses run. I have no trouble talking to them, telling them I want them to win. I have 10 grandchildren. I want to spend time with them. It's hard to back away all of a sudden. But I think I am to the point where it's not too far off where I see myself in another role. I won't say I'm going to get out and let them take over. No one will believe that. But it won't be in the too distant future."
This, remember, is from the guy who 25 years ago yesterday said he wasn't going to be active in the day-to-day operations.

HEADLINE: BOATING REPORT;
Indoor Boat Show Takes Float Out of the Flotilla

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
It might be an anachronism of sorts to stage a boat show when the snow flies. But the New York National Boat Show, in its 88th edition this year, opened its doors yesterday to a thousand reminders of summer days.
Most of those reminders take the form of powerboats lined up in the cavernous environs of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. A dozen sailboats are in the mix too, as well as hundreds of marine accessories from satellite navigation instruments to foul-weather jackets. Spread them out across four football fields worth of display space, and consumers are confronted with the largest indoor boat show in the Northeast. It was only in the 1980's that the show took up more space, said Michael Duffy, the event manager. 
 "That was in the false prosperity of the 80's," Duffy added. "Now we have the repeal of the luxury tax on boats, consumer confidence is up, and the economy is good."
Still, boat show organizers are faced with a hard sell. While big, expensive yachts are having a manufacturers' heyday, the market is relatively flat for smaller boats of 10-30 feet, according to the National Marine Manufacturers Association. The trade group represents about 1,600 marine companies.
As always, organizers are looking for a way to entice buyers. But this year, the boat show is as diverse as it gets. On hand to speak about his experiences in ocean racing will be Brian Hancock, a world-class ocean racer from Marblehead, Mass.
Hancock has sailed in three former Whitbread Round the World Races, and now he plans a solo voyage in the 1998-99 Around Alone, a single-handed race around the world. Hancock already has a 50-foot sailboat ready to compete, and will be at the boat show with slides and videos of the yacht. "When I was 21, it was a real boost for my early years to do a Whitbread," Hancock said. "Now that I'm nearing 40, doing it alone will be another challenge."
Other highlights at the boat show include a Kids Korner, which has a 30-by-50-foot pond set up for radio-operated model boats. In the middle of the pond is a cardboard replica of New York City.
For fishermen, show organizers are offering two computer-controlled, fighting chair simulators. A hydraulic unit is set up by J & B Tackle of Niantic, Conn. The other, which includes a 7-foot video screen, is on display in part through sponsorship of the International Sport Fishing Association.
Seminars are being offered throughout the show, which ends next Sunday. They include instruction on everything from securing a captain's license to fishing for stripers off Montauk, N.Y. A schedule can be obtained by calling (212) 922-1212.
The boats on display range in size from 10 to 58 feet. The largest boat, the Sea Ray 580, comes equipped with a luxury cockpit that includes a digital stereo with four speakers and remote control, and electric foldaway seating.
Below deck, the interior is outfitted with leather seating and wood trim. The yacht has twin 640-horsepower Caterpillar engines. Its retail price, which varies according to options, starts at $908,900.
On a more modest scale, Boston Whaler is coming out this year with a 26-foot center-console outboard. The boat, the Outrage 26, retails for about $35,000 without power. Twin 200-horsepower outboard engines are recommended for another $25,000. As with other Boston Whaler models, the boat is made with a foam core to keep it from sinking if holed.
Amid a wide array of gear, a new compass for kayaks is on display from Ritchie Navigation. The compass fits on the deck of a kayak with two small nonmagnetic fasteners so as not to penetrate the craft's watertight capability. It also twists on and off for easy removal from its mount. The compass is $69.50.
Adult single-day tickets to the show cost $8; children, ages 6-12, are $3; for those 5 and younger, admission is free. The number for general information is (212) 984-7070.
 
MAKING WAVES
Nine sailboats are expected to leave Sydney today for the fourth stage of the Whitbread Round the World Race. The 1,270-mile voyage to Auckland, New Zealand, is one of the shortest in the nine-leg, 32,000-mile race. Leading over all is EF Language, the Swedish yacht with Paul Cayard of San Francisco as skipper.

HEADLINE: American Weaver Revives Old Laotian Art

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Among the more exotic casualties of the Indochina war, the long-nosed lion-elephant, the eternal Naga serpent and the magical Mom bird appeared to be on the verge of extinction in Laos.
These mythical creatures, once common throughout this tiny rural nation, were part of the symbolic vocabulary of traditional Laotian silk weavers, whose work fell victim to the chaos of the war and the social disruptions that followed it. 
 Now an American weaver named Carol Cassidy is working to revive an art that, like that of the dancers of neighboring Cambodia and the temple muralists of Thailand, has embodied the nation's cultural inheritance.
In a refurbished French colonial mansion surrounded incongruously by a white picket fence, she employs 40 weavers, dyers and bobbin winders to produce glowing fabrics adorned with the stars and ships and scrolls of Lao tradition, as well as the dragons, peacocks and butterflies of Buddhist symbolism.
But Ms. Cassidy is not a preservationist; her scarves and slipcovers and wall hangings bear her own contemporary stamp. For her, the ancient symbols are artistic forms rather than bearers of legend.
"I start with traditional patterns and techniques and I modify, interpret, translate, adapt into a product that becomes international," she said. "The elements are traditional but the complete design is my own creation."
A recent example is a wall hanging woven for Denise Tomecko, an American masseuse who lives here, who wanted an ornament that would complement a treasured deep blue Tibetan carpet.
Ms. Cassidy found Laotian symbols that echo the dragons and knots pattern of the carpet and arranged them in a severe symmetry that seems more Tibetan than Laotian.
"She made me something that was very Lao but was reconstructed and modified to blend with a Tibetan prayer rug," Ms. Tomecko said.
Ms. Cassidy's enterprise, Lao Textiles, was founded in 1990 -- the first American company licensed here after the end of the war in 1975, and still one of relatively few Western businesses in this country of 4.6 million people.
Laos was heavily bombed during the war when the United States tried to cut Communist supply lines in neighboring Vietnam. As in Vietnam, the Laotian war ended in victory for the Communists, who continue in power today.
Ms. Cassidy said her experience with Laotian officials had been excellent as they begin to open their country to foreign investment.
"They have honored everything they ever said," she said. "Everything we agreed to in 1990 has been maintained, which is an incredible feat. I believe in the Lao's integrity and their deep commitment to their principles."
Pitched to a small, high-priced and mostly overseas market, her business is thriving at a time when the Laotian textile industry has been badly wounded by recently imposed foreign tariffs.
She markets her products as one-of-a-kind "original art" rather than as mass-produced textiles, placing them beyond the scope of the tariffs levied on assembly-line manufacturers.
"Threads are our palette," Ms. Cassidy said. "We weave art."
Her work sells in American boutiques or is shipped on special order for cushions or upholstery. A scarf might cost from $85 to $125; a brocade wall hanging sells for $1,800.
"In local terms our prices are high, but they aren't high by international standards," she said. "And I pay my workers professional wages."
These wages can reach to nearly three times the average national income of $350 a year. Many of the weavers -- like Simone Bankeo, 28, whose husband is a university professor -- earn more than their husbands.
Ms. Cassidy, 41, is a native of Woodbury, Conn., and studied weaving at the University of Michigan and at the University of Helsinki, in Finland. She spent seven years in Africa, where she taught village women the art of mohair weaving.
She arrived in Laos in 1989 and spent a year training weavers for the United Nations Development Program before starting her business. It did not take long for her art to be recognized: it was displayed for three months in 1995 at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York.
There is an air of intense concentration at the 20 looms in her workshop. The hands of the weavers perform a rapid, repetitive ballet as Laotian pop music plays quietly.
The brightly colored patterns emerge slowly. The workshop produces no more than 30 to 50 pieces a month.
On the concrete floor by a water cooler, a woman turns a spinning wheel. In a small room behind her, ropes of silk are dipped in imported chemical dyes mixed by Ms. Cassidy to match the colors of the less hardy local herbal dyes.
"This is my world, my cocoon," Ms. Cassidy said. "It's bamboo, wood, silk. But it ends up -- if you look at Vogue -- in Valentino's Paris apartment."
Along with the techniques of her workshop, Ms. Cassidy said, she also teaches her workers the concept of weaving as art. One of the first English phrases she taught her chief weaver and collaborator, Chansouk Phomalin, was, "I am a designer."
In this achingly poor and isolated country, Ms. Cassidy is fostering not only the revival of an art form but a rare standard of personal achievement.
"I've been rough with the workers," she said. "I've introduced the idea of the critique. They need to understand this, because their work has never been integrated into the monetary economy. Everything matters. Every color matters. Every thread matters."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Simone Bankeo, above, earns more money than her husband, a university professor, by working for Carol Cassidy, an American entrepreneur who is trying to revive the Laotian art of silk weaving. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times)
 
Map of Laos showing the location of Vientiane: Silk weaving is being revived in Vientiane, the Laotian capital.

HEADLINE: Flaws Known Decades Ago at Madison Ave. Tower Where Bricks Fell

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
After a ton of bricks rained onto Madison Avenue from the wall of an office tower last month, it took just a day for engineers to determine that the 39-story facade was missing thousands of masonry anchors that tie it to the building.
While city officials and the tower's new owner were shocked to learn of the shoddy and dangerous workmanship at 540 Madison, another unsettling surprise awaited them: the precise flaw had been revealed in a lawsuit that sat unnoticed for more than 20 years in a public file at the State Supreme Court in Manhattan. 
 In fact, the tower's troubled but largely unexamined 27-year history is rife with red flags that went unnoticed by city building officials, the tower's original investors and its current owner, Harry Macklowe. Warning signs showed up in city inspection reports filed in 1982 and 1987. And cracks in the brickwork appear to have been covered over with cosmetic work, according to city officials and executives involved in stabilizing the building. Yet, none of this came to light earlier this year when Mr. Macklowe's contractors punched 94 windows into the wall, which Gaston Silva, the city's Buildings Commissioner, said probably aggravated problems with the brickwork.
The trouble with the building was reckoned with only when it became unavoidable. The shower of bricks on the afternoon of Dec. 7 has disrupted life ever since along Madison Avenue from 52d to 55th Streets, with vehicle traffic fully restored only last week.
The cause of the collapse is unrelated to the hunk of ornamental masonry that fell from the Belleclaire Hotel on the Upper West Side Dec. 29, or the chunk of concrete that tumbled from a building on 46th Street the next day followed quickly by the partial collapse of a six-story building on West 42d Street, near Eighth Avenue. But all the concrete and masonry suddenly raining down on New York does highlight the weaknesses or loopholes in the city's building inspection process.
Landlords have no obligation to notify the Buildings Department of serious structural problems that might lead to a collapse, Commissioner Silva said. And the facade inspection reports that the city does require landlords to submit every five years often leave many problems undetected.
In the case of 540 Madison, the lack of a rigorous inspection and reporting program had devastating effects -- a major thoroughfare partly closed for weeks, business derailed, lives exposed to risk. The wall is being dismantled and replaced at the cost of several million dollars.
The trail of unheeded problems began with a 1973 lawsuit in which Francis J. Kleban, who built and originally owned the tower, said it was serious flawed. He claimed that the brick mason -- the J. Harry McNally Corporation -- had failed to install the dovetail anchors, brick ties and expansion joints that are intended to bind the brick facade on the south and west walls to the building's frame.
"It provides some background to what's happening today," Commissioner Silva said recently. "It's very troubling that this guy had known about these problems for 20-odd years."
One engineer involved in dismantling the south facade of 540 Madison said that two-thirds of the 14,000 brick ties -- corrugated metal strips -- that should have been laid into the mortar during construction were missing. And, he said, there were no anchors in the dovetail joints that hook the brick facade to the interior concrete walls of the building. Further, he said, only two expansion joints were found to be "operable."
Mr. Macklowe, who bought the building for $35 million from the Kleban estate in September 1996, said he had been unaware of Mr. Kleban's allegations in the 1970's and of a 1991 report on the building's facade.
"If we had been given any information, we would have immediately investigated it with the seller and the proper authorities," Mr. Macklowe said.
But unwinding the history of the tower is difficult. The firm that designed the building is defunct, as is the McNally Corporation, and Diesel Construction, the general contractor, has gone through various corporate permutations. Irwin Miller, a former top executive at Diesel Construction whose name is on the original building permit for 540 Madison, was not the only person to say, "I can't remember back that far."
In 1968, Mr. Kleban, who had already developed office towers and apartment houses on Park Avenue, set out to put up his tallest building, on a Madison Avenue parcel owned by the Government of Finland.
His friends say Mr. Kleban, a descendant of a real estate family that had built apartment houses along the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, took special pride in 540 Madison, designing a luxurious apartment for himself atop the tower. A meticulous person who gained construction experience with the Navy's Civil Engineer Corps during World War II, Mr. Kleban oversaw many details of the project.
"I'm surprised to see what happened because he really knew construction," said Arthur Rosenbloom, vice chairman of Newmark & Company and a longtime friend of Mr. Kleban.
According to court records, Diesel sued Mr. Kleban in 1973, three years after the building opened, alleging that he owed it $66,851.39. Mr. Kleban fired back, stating that Diesel had not properly supervised subcontractors on the job, resulting in "severe leaks" in the glass walls and the "collapse, cracking, spalling and other deterioration" of the bricks walls on the south and west sides of the building shortly after it opened in 1970. He also sued the architect and the engineer.
As the lawsuit dragged on, Diesel sued the subcontractors and extensive repairs were made to the glass walls in the 1970's, though it appears that the brick walls were left largely untouched. It is unclear how the litigation ended because no record of a settlement can be found.
"My best recollection is that the overall litigation was settled," said Douglas R. Hoyt, a lawyer who then represented the bricklayer, J. Harry McNally. Diesel, he said, "would continue to make repairs."
Asked about the litigation, Nathan Goldman, one of Mr. Kleban's partners at 540 Madison, said: "It's news to me." Mr. Goldman, a founding partner at Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, a real estate investment bank, said the tower had always been a "well-paying" investment.
Profitable or not, the tower continued to have problems. I. Leonard Messer, a consulting engineer, inspected its facade in 1982 and 1991, in accordance with a city law passed after a student was killed by falling masonry. According to his 1991 report, repairs were made in 1982 that involved "vertical cracks in the brickwork at the southeast and northwest corners at various floors." Vertical cracks and flaking brickwork were found in 1987 by another engineer, his 1991 report said. He found no unsafe conditions in 1991, but did suggest annual inspections by a licensed engineer, a nonbinding recommendation that the owner did not adopt, Commissioner Silva said.
The city requires landlords to file building facade inspection reports every five years, but there is no guarantee those inspections will detect serious problems, since they cover only the front of a building and usually involve only a visual inspection from the street.
About one year after Mr. Kleban died in 1995, Mr. Macklowe bought the tower. He quickly raised rents, renovated the lobby, enlarged the retail space and cut windows into the south wall.
The tower was a step in a comeback attempt for Mr. Macklowe, who had developed more than $1 billion worth of properties in the 1980's but lost several of them in the recession that followed. Mr. Macklowe revived his real estate career last year and was moving on to his next deal -- a tower on Madison between 41st and 42d Streets -- when things went awry at 540 Madison.
According to a top executive at the Macklowe organization, it was around Halloween when the company first noticed a serious problem: bulging brickwork near the new windows on the 34th floor, the same section that gave way on Dec. 7.
The discovery was a surprise, said another Macklowe executive who spoke on condition of anonymity, adding that the company had found no problems with the brick walls during a physical inspection at the time of the purchase, nor did the title company come across the Kleban lawsuit.
But Mr. Messer, the engineer, said that workers and engineers who installed the windows in the south wall should have noticed the cracks and the lack of brick ties securing the facade to the interior wall. "Punching those windows out really caused the thing to let go," he said.
Jacob Grossman, a partner at Rosenwasser/Grossman Consulting Engineers, said the contractor called him on Nov. 7, asking him to come to the building " 'because there are some problems in the wall.' "
"Our inspector immediately identified the problem: the wall was bulging out," Mr. Grossman said. "He told them to raise the safety net. We also told them masonry walls are not our expertise."
The next day workers hoisted safety nets along the south wall. On Nov. 12, Mr. Macklowe's company notified the owners of the low-slung buildings to the south of the tower that it had "discovered some shifting of the brick on the south side of the building" and wanted to install protective measures during repairs. Mr. Macklowe is still being fined $150 a month, as he has been since February for failing to file the required facade inspection report.
Two weeks later on Nov. 25, the contractor obtained a permit for a sidewalk shed along Madison Avenue.
But once again, the Buildings Department remained in the dark until the bulging bricks gave way on Dec. 7.
"If the engineer and the owner were aware of the seriousness of the bulge they should have notified us," Commissioner Silva said, though he added that they were not legally required to do so. "They did the right thing in setting up the nets and the shed, but it would have been better if we had known."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The facade of a Madison Avenue tower where bricks fell on Dec. 7. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)
