LENGTH: 609 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '98;
1997 HIGHLIGHTS

 BODY:
STOCKS
The stock market roared once again in 1997 - the third consecutive year of blockbuster gains - despite fears that the rapidly spreading turmoil in Asia would kill the great bull market of the 1990's.
 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose nearly 23 percent, ending the year at 7,908.25 points. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose even more. The Nasdaq composite index, with a concentration of technology stocks and smaller issues, rose nearly 22 percent, to 1,570.35 points.
 Analyst said that despite jitters about higher inflation, shrinking profit margins and a looming economic and currency crisis in Southeast Asia, investors continued to funnel money into the stock market in the belief that the American economy was nicely balanced, with little inflation. It wasn't just the United States that saw big gains. Except for Asia, many parts of the world register stellar increases, particularly in Europe.
BONDS
Bonds got off to a shaky start in 1997 but made a comeback as a healthy demand arose for United States Treasuries.
 In a brief stumble, the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond rose as high as 7.17 percent after the Federal Reserve Board raised short-term interest rates in late March to try to stave off inflationary threats. But even thought the economy revved and labor shortages crept up, the inflation threat never materialized, and that helped drop the yield on the 30-year bond below 6 percent in December for the first time since early 1996.
 The rally was aided by a "flight to quality" as investors, concerned that the crisis in Asia would spread to other parts of the globe, parked their money in Treasuries. If an investor had bought a 30-year Treasury at the beginning of the year, by Dec. 31 the return, including price appreciation and interest, would have been more than 14 percent.
 THE DOLLAR
The dollar rose sharply against mot currencies last year, though the ascent was not without interruptions. The United States and its allies tried to put the brakes on the dollar early in February, as Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin switched from supporting a strong dollar to saying the dollar was strong enough.
 At the time, however, Mr. Rubin and his counterparts from Europe, Canada and Japan also acknowledged that exchange rates are determined by economic fundamentals. Those factors continued to favor the dollar through the end of the year as foreign investors were attracted to the United States stock and bond markets as Asian economies tumbled.
 So while the dollar dipped agains the Japanese yen in May, it rallied smartly afterward, touching five-and-a-half-year highs last month amid the financial turmoil in Asia. Agains the German mark, the dollar rose nearly 17 percent for the year.
GOLD
United States Treasuries and dollars seemed to replace gold as the world's safest haven for nervous investors in 1997, partly because the world's central banks have been threatening to dump their gold reserves.
 Gold has also lost osme of its luster as a hedge against price increases, particularly with inflation - at least in the United States - apparently dead, or at least in deep hibernation.
 The price of gold, which had soared as high as $850 an ounce in the 1980's, fell below $300 an ounce last autumn for the first time since 1985.
 The loss of gold's appeal as an inflation hedge reflects a greater faith in the ability of central banks to keep prices under control. That makes paper assets like bonds more attractive.
 And gold, once considered the safest investment, continues to sink; some analysts think it could go as low as $250 an ounce in 1998.

HEADLINE: Disneyland for Deadheads: Ultimate Nostalgia Trip;
Rock Group Lives in Memory and Master Plan

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: NOVATO, Calif.

 BODY:
If the red-brick warehouse in this Marin County town were open to the public, it would be a haven for one-stop shoppers. Its endless shelves are lined with everything from toothbrushes to golf balls, dog collars to stamps, skis to motorcycle parts, baby rompers to electric lanterns. But this is not a supermarket. It is the headquarters of Grateful Dead Merchandising, where the golf balls are tie-dyed and the dog collars are emblazoned with the head of Jerry Garcia. A thousand packages of Grateful Dead items are shipped from this warehouse each day, bringing in an annual gross of $50 million to $60 million.
But much more than the sale of memorabilia is involved here. There is a Grateful Dead master plan. Most of the revenue coming in is being earmarked for an enormous project, perhaps the biggest undertaking ever attempted by a single band. It is called Terrapin Station, to be built in San Francisco, a $60 million museum, amusement park, gathering place, concert hall, research center and possibly even a hotel for Grateful Dead fans who have lost their way since the band broke up after Garcia, its leader, died two and a half years ago. 
 "There's a way to keep this band going, even without Jerry, God bless him," said Dennis McNally, the band's press agent for 14 years. "Instead of dying, the Grateful Dead is morphing."
Rock-and-roll is a 50-year-old beast, and its founders and early innovators are just beginning to die off. With its pioneering musicians and bands gone, rock-and-roll is becoming a museum piece. Two years ago, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame opened in Cleveland. And Paul Allen, a Microsoft entrepreneur, is in the process of developing a $60 million Experience Music Project rock museum in Seattle. But Terrapin Station, named after a 1977 Grateful Dead album, promises to be a different type of tourist attraction altogether.
"This is probably the first rock-and-roll museum dedicated to one artist," said Bob Grossweiner, the senior editor of the concert industry magazine Performance. "If kids traveled all over the country following the band when they toured, I'm sure they'll all go to San Francisco to see the museum. It will bring a lot of money into the economy, and it's very possible that Terrapin Station will outdraw the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame, because it's in a bigger city, and some people are going to be spending weeks there instead of just a day. Hopefully, they'll have smoke alarms in the bathrooms and the staircases."
In its 30-year existence, the Grateful Dead was transformed from a band into a cult, attracting and retaining a more loyal, obsessive and dedicated following -- the Deadheads -- than any other rock group. Its tours were among the highest grossing, regularly earning some $50 million in a good year. But when the band broke up in 1995, it left tens of thousands of fans with nowhere to go, no band worthy of following so slavishly around the country. One of the roles of Terrapin Station will be as a kind of shrine and meeting place for Deadheads. Its builders expect, in their most conservative estimates, that Terrapin Station will attract 1.2 million people in its first year.
Though a site has not yet been chosen, the band is considering two San Francisco locations and expects to close a deal by the end of the month. Meetings have already begun with city officials. Spokesmen for the band said that the city had pledged its support.
Phil Lesh, the Grateful Dead's bassist, said the idea first germinated in the late 60's when the band dreamed about becoming what he called "a rock-and-roll satellite" that would stay in one place and broadcast concerts around the world.
"The relationship between the band and the Deadheads needs to be nurtured because they are us, and we are them," Mr. Lesh said in a recent interview. "We'd been talking about Terrapin Station more seriously for the last five years, but the touring overhead and the number of employees we had were so great that we couldn't think of a way to generate enough time and energy, let alone money.
"With Jerry's death, everything changed. We are no longer a viable touring operation. We couldn't even support our entire staff. To make a smooth transition, we had to fall back on merchandising our music archives, and that became the cash cow for the whole organization."
"But we didn't want to just put out old live concerts until the material and interest dwindled away," he continued. "As big a draw as the music at our shows was the fellowship and community people had there with one another. We wanted to create a place that would be a presentation of what we did musically and culturally, and a place where people could gather, and new music could be showcased, and a nonprofit organization for music groups in the Bay Area could be developed."
The entrance to the 65,000-square-foot Terrapin Station, which Mr. Lesh said he hoped would be open by New Year's Eve 1999 for reunion of surviving Grateful Dead members, will be a parking lot, a re-creation of the place outside concert halls where Deadheads used to meet and sell food and crafts. Inside, there will be a 1,000-seat auditorium for concerts by Bay Area bands and by members of the Dead, most of whom have formed their own groups; rotating museum exhibits focusing on the Bay Area music scene since the 60's, world music and chapters in Grateful Dead history, and a store full of band merchandise.
 
Grilled Cheese Sandwiches
Plans also call for a roomful of percussion instruments for spontaneous drum circles and jam sessions; a multimedia theater that will recreate the experience of Grateful Dead concerts, and a restaurant tentatively called the Dancing Bear Cafe. (Expect the vegetarian burritos and grilled cheese sandwiches typically served up in a Dead concert parking lot.) Depending on the size of the site that the Grateful Dead buys, there may also be a theme hotel or apartment complex, named Mars Hotel after another Dead album.
Terrapin Station will not be a giant Hard Rock Cafe, those involved say.
"I want to put my entire legal and business files on display," said Hal Kant, the band's lawyer for 30 years. "The music industry is kind of new, and I was one of the first lawyers, so maybe my files can help teach people about the development of contracts and business practices from the beginning. A substantial part of the museum is intended to be a research center."
Deadheads seem to be behind the project and have already contributed $1.5 million. Unlike most rock corporate ventures, the Grateful Dead has a very elaborate business partnership in which the musicians are heavily involved. Each original member owns an equal share in Grateful Dead Productions and has an equal vote in approving merchandise and business decisions.
When Garcia died, in keeping with an agreement made 25 years ago, the remaining members of the band bought back his interest in the corporation while his estate continued to receive his royalties from music and merchandise.
Although it isn't involved in band decisions, the estate is behind Terrapin Station, said Garcia's widow, Deborah Koons Garcia. "It sounds like a really fun and imaginative project," she said. "I think it's a few years off, but my understanding is that people are most excited about it being a high-tech playground and looking toward the future, which is something Jerry was really interested in." (The estate still owes $4.6 million to Garcia's second wife, Carolyn Adams Garcia, known as Mountain Girl.)
The shock of his death, and the realization that with Terrapin Station the Grateful Dead would survive as a business entity long after its members were gone, has forced the rest of the band to set up a trust and start appointing trustees to take over their stock after their deaths.
 
Decisions Made By the Band
"Band members are the board of directors," Mr. Kant said. "They're not figureheads. They make all the decisions, and we don't do anything until everyone agrees, so we're not dragging along a reluctant party. We're among the first rock groups to have health coverage, pension plans and other employee benefits."
Grateful Dead Productions itself is a complex, rapidly growing machine fueled by the band's insistence on direct control over its products, enabling it to control its image and keep a greater share of the profits than most musicians who work through separate record labels and merchandising companies Besides the new company being established to run Terrapin Station, Grateful Dead Productions includes a retail arm, which develops products and runs a mail-order catalog for direct sales. A division licenses the Grateful Dead name and trademark to manufacturers (from multinational companies to entrepreneurs working out of the trunks of their cars) to develop and sell products.
There is a also a merchandising service, which works on product development, inventory control and concession sales not just for Dead-related concerts but also for other music acts like the Gipsy Kings and Maxwell, and sports teams like the Oakland Raiders. And there is Grateful Dead Records, which recently expanded, to compensate for some of the loss of touring revenue and merchandise, releasing albums by Crosby and Nash and the Allman Brothers as well as the Dead, whose rigorous and extensive archives of some 2,300 concerts and numerous studio sessions are kept in a vault in the Novato warehouse. In case of a fire, the vault has a security system that will pump the air out from the room, killing anyone inside but saving the music.
"Thanks to the archive that the band had the foresight to compile over 30 years, the music can be presented in different ways in the band's absence," said Peter McQuaid, the chief executive of Grateful Dead Productions. "With Terrapin Station, the Grateful Dead could theoretically go on and on performing without even having to show up and get on stage and play their instruments."

HEADLINE: Taxes and Chicken Little

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The collapse of the empty 42d Street building and similar self-demolitions (Editorial Observer, Jan. 5) are not so much the fault of failed inspection as they are the fault of assessment laws. With city land underassessed and taxes on property and improvement high, an aging structure may be the best investment in a growing city, since the increase in its land value exceeds the relatively small tax on an old building. 
 Henry George, in his 1879 book, "Progress and Poverty," advocated taxing land more and buildings less to make urban renewal economically feasible. Only Pennsylvania has followed this initiative, permitting its cities a two-tier tax structure so the tax burden could be gradually shifted from property and improvement onto land. The result: less urban sprawl, easier city planning, increasing new construction and lower taxes. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani could learn from this.
 
EDWARD W. MILLER
San Rafael, Calif., Jan. 2, 1998

HEADLINE: The Bad News About Bailouts

BYLINE: By Lawrence B. Lindsay; Lawrence B. Lindsay, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, is a former governor of the Federal Reserve.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Suppose your brother-in-law announced to the whole family at Christmas that he had lost a bundle on Wall Street, couldn't meet his margin calls and didn't have the money to meet either his credit card bills or his mortgage. Would you bail him out?
Your answer would probably be, "It depends." While the issues involved in the international bailout of South Korea (and other countries) are complex, some of the questions you would ask yourself about your brother-in-law aren't much different from the ones we should be asking ourselves about South Korea. 
 First, how did the debt burden get so large? In South Korea's case it was a web of sham accounting standards. The reported size of South Korea's exposure has mushroomed over the last several months. Last month the Korean Government gave a "final" estimate of $160 billion, and that is just international debt; it doesn't include what Korean companies owe domestically. It is as if your brother-in-law lied to his broker about his assets, cheated on his mortgage application by misrepresenting his income and then used one credit card to pay off the other.
Second, was the money used for a good purpose? In South Korea's case the loans were used to finance economic development and build an industrial infrastructure. There is no question that this is worthy. Unlike other countries we have bailed out, South Korea did not go on a consumption binge. In 1995, only about 10 percent of its total imports were consumer goods. The rest were capital goods to build productive capacity and raw materials and energy to drive those factories. Furthermore, Koreans work very hard. The great majority work six-day weeks, and it is easy to be impressed with their dedication and sacrifice.
On the other hand, those investments were made without much thought about the risks involved. The job of the Korean banking system was to say "yes" if one of the giant chaebol that run the economy asked for money. Under a web of protectionism and cozy relations with the bureaucracy, none of these companies ever got into trouble, even though their profit performance was poor. The national purpose was rapid industrialization and growth; gaining market share was the objective.
Assume your brother-in-law did not buy fancy consumer goods with his money. He used the proceeds from his home refinancing and his credit cards to build a position on Wall Street, which he leveraged further by using his margin account. Like South Korea, he was trying to get rich quickly, but he ran into trouble.
Third, what signals are sent if you finance the bailout? The Korean bailout is all being done very publicly. The United States Treasury and the International Monetary Fund are telling the other nations of the world and their creditors that they will be the lenders of last resort. Consider Mexico, which is being touted as a success. The money that flooded into the countries now in trouble really started flowing after our bailout of Mexico. The interest rate markups were unusually low for the supposed risk on these loans, and the greatest financing binge in world history quickly followed.
Remember, it is not South Korea that pockets the bailout money, but the large multinational financial institutions that get paid back. They presumably lent this money in the expectation of making a profit. Their job was to make sure of the creditworthiness of the people they lent to. They could have insisted that the accounting standards of their customers be cleaned up. They didn't, and lost.
Interestingly, American banks that were forced by the Federal Reserve and other regulators to accept more careful risk assessment standards and build their capital base were much less exposed to South Korea than European or Japanese banks. When lenders are burned on bad loans, they become much more cautious the next time around.
Back to your brother-in-law. Since everyone will know that you bailed him out, what will be the effect on your siblings, aunts, uncles and cousins? Will they borrow more and assume that they can count on you? For that matter, will your brother-in-law have learned his lesson? And, if all of the lenders in the country know that there is someone in every family just like you, will they supervise the loans they make as closely?
Finally, what happens if there is no bailout? Unable to get their money, the creditors take possession of the companies, factories and machinery that their loans financed and look for a new owner. The new buyers aren't necessarily part of the same bankrupt crony system; they are the ones who will pay the highest price. They may be American entrepreneurs or Koreans who have been on the outside in the past.
If the creditors can't get all their money back, they will take the loss and be forced to be much more cautious the next time. In some cases these losses may be quite large, and the regulators of these banks may be forced to take some remedial action (though these same regulators let their wards get overextended in the first place).
However, this route is far preferable to a bailout; both the South Korean and the world economies will be much better off. In South Korea, there will be much more competition and a greater focus on the bottom line. New credit will flow to the new owners much more easily than it would ever flow to the old deadbeats. All the "conditions" supposedly negotiated by the I.M.F. will be forced on South Korea by the market.
The parallel to our home-front analogy is this: Not wanting to see your relations on the street, you might consider your brother-in-law's house a good asset, assume the mortgage from the bank and allow him to pay you back. Let the other creditors get burned.
Rest assured, though, that you will have a lot more control over your in-law's behavior when you hold the mortgage on his house than if you simply bail him out. Not to mention, the chances that Aunt Sally will need a bailout next Christmas will be substantially reduced.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Scott Menchin)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Foreign Minister of Mexico Is Named Finance Minister

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
In a surprise appointment that gives Mexico's booming economy an energetic spokesman well known to international investors, President Ernesto Zedillo today named Jose Angel Gurria his Finance Minister.
By choosing Mr. Gurria, 47, an economist and experienced financial negotiator who served as Foreign Minister for the last three years, the President opted to continue the conservative fiscal policies he applied to pull Mexico out of a depression. 
 The appointment ended an uncomfortable stretch that began on Dec. 15 when Mr. Zedillo designated the former Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, to head the central bank, known as Banco de Mexico. Mr. Ortiz is highly regarded by foreign business leaders for helping rescue Mexico after the peso collapse of 1994. The delay in naming a successor to Mr. Ortiz at the Finance Ministry generated fears that Mr. Zedillo might appoint someone deemed to possess lesser skills.
But Mr. Gurria enjoys a reputation as strong as that of Mr. Ortiz among United States bankers and investors as a result of his role as lead negotiator in talks to resolve Mexico's debt crisis in the 1980's.
"This is a guy who really knows his stuff," said Ernest W. Brown, chief economist for Latin America at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, who said he first met Mr. Gurria during the debt negotiations. "He was a hard bargainer who always used every tool at his disposal, but he was always unfailingly politically gracious."
In a slightly stilted ceremony including both Mr. Gurria and Mr. Ortiz, broadcast on nationwide television from the President's offices, Mr. Zedillo said he had instructed Mr. Gurria to observe "unshakable discipline" in fiscal policy and to promote domestic savings.
Mr. Gurria, a gregarious man who appears to thrive in the fray of politics, was also chosen to help Mr. Zedillo move federal budgets through a Congress dominated by opposition parties. That opposition is likely to grow more contentious with the approach of highly competitive presidential elections in 2000.
Mr. Ortiz is an academic economist, not known for talents as a political bargainer, but he nevertheless succeeded in persuading Congress to approve a lean 1998 budget that was almost exactly as Mr. Zedillo had proposed it.
However, Mr. Zedillo decided to shift Mr. Ortiz to a six-year term in charge of the central bank as part of a larger plan to enhance the bank's independence and give it responsibility for virtually all monetary policy, while leaving only spending management with the Finance Minister.
The President's goal is to lock in mechanisms to keep the peso stable past the end of his term, officials said. For the last two decades the end of each six-year presidential term has brought devaluations and economic upheaval.
Under current rules of the Government party, Mr. Gurria cannot be a candidate for president in the 2000 race because he has never held elected national office. As a result, analysts noted, Mr. Gurria will probably not leave his post before the end of Mr. Zedillo's presidency.
The new Finance Minister "will be navigating on a considerably calmer sea" than Mr. Ortiz, said Sergio Martin, chief economist for ING Barings in Mexico. According to estimates released today, overall growth for 1997 is expected to be about 7 percent, and inflation is expected to come in on target at just under 13 percent. Consumer spending, which remained depressed long after the larger economy showed signs of recovery, was up 4.5 percent in the first half of 1997 over 1996.
Just as Mr. Zedillo was announcing Mr. Gurria's appointment this morning, protesters allied with the Zapatista rebels in the southern state of Chiapas surrounded the Mexican stock exchange and delayed the start of trading by 45 minutes.
They doused windows of the dome-shaped exchange building, on a central downtown boulevard, with red paint and cluttered the entrance with miniature coffins, symbolizing the 45 people who died last month in a massacre that has been linked to a pro-Government paramilitary gang in Chiapas.
"The power of money is stained with the blood of the Indians of Chiapas," read a banner the protesters waved.

HEADLINE: THE BALANCED BUDGET;
Excerpts From Remarks By Gingrich on the Budget

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks and questions and answers by Speaker Newt Gingrich to the Cobb County Chamber of Commerce yesterday in Marietta, Ga., as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:
So in summary let me just say I believe if we have the courage to take where we are -- we passed welfare reform, we've passed a balanced budget plan, we passed tax cuts, we passed a program to save Medicare for a decade without raising taxes. Now we are at a magic moment where if we are willing to take on the dialogue and say, all right, let's have an honest conversation: Should America be formed around "We the people," or should America be formed around "We the government"? 
 Can we in fact take the ideas that are transforming productivity in the private sector and transform productivity in government? Can we set priorities? Can we rethink programs? And could we set these four goals: A drug-free safe America for our children, the best system of learning in the world at all ages, a retirement program that is better and safer for everyone, and not having the government take more than 25 percent of our income from any American?
If we could set those four -- it will take us 10 or 12 years to work them all out -- but if we focused and got those four done, we'd leave our children and grandchildren a safer, healthier and more prosperous America. And I think that's a conversation worth having. I think we're adult enough as a country to have it, and I hope the political system and the news media structure care. . . .
Q Mr. Speaker, I was curious about the budget surplus that you mentioned. There was a lot of talk over the weekend about what to do with it. What do you foresee occurring? . . .
A I want to make two points on this. First of all, I believe unequivocally our first goal should be to get to surplus and in peacetime, to stay in surplus, and I don't think we should do anything that threatens getting to surplus. . . .
A number of my friends believe we may be able to be in balance this coming year, and therefore let's go ahead and not have a tax cut and not do anything -- let's figure out how we get to balance this year. And I'm willing to be talked into that. But I just wanted to point out the original radical notion that was laughed at in Washington was balanced by 2002, which is almost guaranteed now, barring a war or a very deep, deep recession. But I think we ought to start with a surplus.
Second point: The surplus's first goal should be to pay down the debt; in particular to pay down the debt to take care of the trust funds. We can pay off the transportation trust fund, and we could gradually begin to monetize the Social Security trust funds so we could have a safe Social Security system as we develop a more modern personal system for our children and grandchildren. That can be taken care of.
But the third point I'd make -- I would like to see us as a goal to try to get to at least a small tax cut every year. And my reason is twofold. First I believe if you cut taxes a little bit every year over a generation, you'll get down to the 25 percent level, and I think that's the right level. I would argue that should be the goal of the state and local level, too. So we have got to find some model that says the Fed is going to shrink X amount, the state and local are going to have their burden shrink Y amount, but we are all going to get to a total combined burden of the three of us of no more than 25 percent.
The second -- and I just want to say I don't understand the reasoning of some people in Washington. My second reason is real simple: You have a $1,600,000,000,000 Government. You can't tell me that we ought to waste -- basically what those who are opposed to tax cuts are saying is: "Let's waste another $5 billion on the earned income credit next year, because we don't have the nerve to solve it." "Let's waste another couple billion dollars in food stamps, because we don't have the nerve to solve it." "Let's not look at every single department and make them downsize their bureaucracy, because we don't have the energy and discipline to do it." So rather than give you a tax cut we are going to throw the money away in Washington.
So I would argue, as we did in our original contract, we were for a balanced budget with lower taxes with a less expensive Government.

HEADLINE: THE BALANCED BUDGET: THE MARKETS;
Rosy Budget Forecast Is No News to Investors

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Wall Street greeted President Clinton's plan to propose a balanced Federal budget next year with a resounding yawn yesterday -- but that does not mean the financial markets are not interested in the size of the Federal deficit.
Rather, the lack of excitement on Wall Street reflects the fact that traders and investors have already decided that the Federal budget is likely to be balanced, and that the deficit is shrinking. The President merely confirmed what financial analysts and economists already believe -- and meeting investors' expectations does not move markets. 
 "Some of the stock market's strength recently is because of the attitude that the budget is no longer a beast out of control and the deficit is decreasing rather than growing," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm based in Greenwich, Conn. Concern about the Federal budget and deficit, he said, "is in the market's past."
The President's announcement that the deficit for the current fiscal year will be less than $22 billion came as no surprise to investors, either. "I think the market expects a lot better than $22 billion," said Joseph Liro, chief economist for the securities firm CIBC Oppenheimer in New York. "The market very much expects a balanced budget, if not a surplus."
Stocks did rise modestly yesterday -- the Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up 13.95, to 7,978.99, a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent. The gains were not attributed to Mr. Clinton's announcement, analysts said, but by a rally in the bond market, where investors had become more optimistic that the Federal Reserve might take steps to lower interest rates.
"It's no secret to the bond market that the budget is essentially balanced," said Scott F. Grannis, chief economist for Western Asset, which invests billions of dollars for pension funds.
Calling the President's announcement yesterday "irrelevant" to the market, Mr. Grannis said that investors were focusing on a speech given over the weekend by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, in which he discussed deflation. Many analysts said the speech suggested that the Fed would lower interest rates.
It was not so long ago that Federal deficits loomed large among investors' fears, and Wall Street clamored for a balanced budget. Big deficits lead to high interest rates, many economists contended, because when the Government spent more money than it took in, it had to borrow from investors, at home and abroad, to make up the difference. Competition from the Government made it more expensive for other borrowers, be they companies or homeowners, to get loans.
But interest rates have been falling since 1995, and have dropped sharply in the last six months. Meanwhile, fears about the deficit have died down, in part because the size of the annual budget deficit has been shrinking since 1993, and because last year the White House and Congress agreed to legislation that would lead to a balance budget in 2002.
Because Wall Street is so sanguine about the prospects for a balanced budget and lower deficits, there is some danger that markets could fall sharply if Washington disappoints investors, analysts said. Some are already expressing concern that the Government will be tempted to spend any surplus, rather than paying down the national debt.
But in general, investors are not expecting that the Government will do much to give a lift to the financial markets, Mr. Birinyi said. "I don't think the market's looking for Washington to do much," he said. "There's not another shoe waiting to drop."

HEADLINE: THE BALANCED BUDGET: THE REPUBLICANS;
Gingrich Calls for Tax Cuts Tied to Any Budget Surplus

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that any budget surplus produced this year should be used to reduce the national debt and to pay for the first of a series of annual across-the-board tax cuts.
Mr. Gingrich spoke before President Clinton's declaration today that the budget he will send to Congress later this month will indeed be balanced -- a situation that has not occurred since 1969. 
 The Speaker said it was important symbolically to return any surplus produced by the strong economy to taxpayers.
Mr. Gingrich told a breakfast meeting of the Cobb County Chamber of Commerce that the anticipated budget surpluses should also be used to lower the national debt. And he said his long-range goals for future surpluses were to eliminate the so-called death penalty -- high inheritance taxes -- and to reduce the capital gains tax.
"The surplus's first goal should be to pay down the debt," he said, especially on the trust funds for transportation and Social Security.
But he added that it was an important goal to "try to get to at least a small tax cut every year."
Even in the first year a surplus occurs, there should be an across-the-board cut achieved either by increasing personal deductions or reducing tax rates, he told reporters after the speech.
"We should take a step in the right direction, even if it's a small step," Mr. Gingrich said. Such an approach to cutting taxes, he said, was preferable to tax cuts for specific groups like those in last year's budget agreement, which were for families, especially those with children in college.
Mr. Gingrich said that the drastically changed Federal fiscal landscape, widely anticipated in the coming years, should be used to gradually reduce all taxes, including local taxes, to no more than a fourth of an individual's income.
"I would suggest that in peacetime, our goal should be that all three levels -- state, local and Federal governments -- should not take more than 25 percent," he said, adding that the average is now about 38 percent.
Although the gathering was not a prayer breakfast, many of the bankers, accountants, power company officials and others offered spontaneous and hearty "amens" to the Speaker's calls for reducing taxes.
Mr. Gingrich cautioned that he was as yet unsure about whether there would be a surplus in the current fiscal year and said that he would know better in coming weeks when both the Congressional Budget Office and the Office of Management and Budget issue their projections for the deficit.
Mr. Gingrich also agreed with President Clinton's call to have Congress address changes in the Social Security system before the end of the century. But he questioned the view of most analysts, who believe that doing so would involve considerable sacrifice. He proposed that Congress establish a commission, made up of members who represented three generations, to consider ways to buttress the Social Security system.
While not offering any specific proposals, he rejected the view that painful choices are inevitable. "Anyone who thinks you're going to have to make painful choices doesn't understand the marketplace," he said.
Mr. Gingrich said that he believed that the best, if not the only, opportunity to change the Social Security system would be in the "the 12 to 15 months after the elections this fall." After that, he said, the crosscurrents of Presidential politics would be too strong to deal with the matter.
The first weeks of a new year have become the period in which the President and Congressional leaders compete in presenting new ideas and laying out plans for the legislative session. But Mr. Gingrich spoke largely in generalities today.
"Everywhere in America lie people who make long-term decisions and have long-term discussions, except in politics and government," he said. "I would like to propose that we have an adult discussion, as a country, about where we are going and how we are going to get there," using a 20- to 30-year time frame.
Still, Mr. Gingrich showed flashes of his penchant for tossing out ideas, declaring, for example, that bilingual education should be phased out and all pupils should be required to read in English by the fourth grade. He also said that equipping teachers with cellular telephones, as is being done in a pilot project in suburban Atlanta, would increase security and efficiency in schools.
He declined to comment on reports that Mr. Clinton would propose allowing people ages 62 through 64 to buy their way into the Medicare system, to provide coverage between their early retirement and the time they become eligible.

HEADLINE: Miami Hopes New Manager Is a Sign of Recovery

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 5

 BODY:
In the six weeks since he took over as Mayor of Miami, Xavier Suarez has moved, in his words, like "a meteor the size of Texas."
Mr. Suarez dismissed one city manager, tried to remove the police chief, sought the resignations or transfers of 70 employees and went to war with the board appointed by Gov. Lawton Chiles to oversee the city's recovery from a fiscal crisis. 
 But today, stability may have begun to take hold as Jose Garcia-Pedrosa was installed as city manager and pledged to stay for the long haul. He is Miami's fourth city manager since November.
Mayor Suarez also announced that his new financial consultants had discovered an error in the city's five-year financial projections, and that the city was less in debt than had been thought.
The prospects for stability got another lift last month from the prosecutor's office in Miami-Dade County. Prosecutors said Mayor Suarez's personnel changes had violated the city charter, which allows the mayor only to hire or to dismiss the city manager.
To avoid prosecution, the Mayor agreed in December to six months of judicial oversight. He also agreed to rescind the personnel moves, except those involving the city manager's position. If there are no further violations, the state attorney will dismiss the complaint after the six months.
Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa, a 51-year-old former city attorney with law and economics degrees from Harvard University, said he saw less need than Mr. Suarez had for challenging the state's oversight board, which Governor Chiles appointed about a year ago to oversee Miami's recovery from a $68 million budget deficit.
"I intend to work closely with the oversight board," Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa said. "My position is we need to earn our way out of the oversight process."
The board is expected to vote on the city's amended five-year financial recovery plan on Jan. 14.
Widely considered to be a professional and tough city administrator, Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa served as city attorney from 1982 to 1984. He quit to wage an unsuccessful campaign to unseat the Dade County prosecutor, Janet Reno, the current United States Attorney General.
After the election, Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa went into private practice. He left his law partnership in 1995 to become the city manager of Miami Beach. In moving to Miami, he willtake a pay cut, to $96,000 from $148,000, but he said he expected the benefits package to compensate for the difference. The benefits are still being negotiated.
Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa said he was ready to participate in the "rebirth" of Miami after 18 months of financial problems and corruption scandals, and added, "This city is going up, up, up, and 1998 is the year to do it."
Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa said his priorities included putting finances in order and streamlining city agencies. He estimated that one-third of the city government's 3,300 positions could be eliminated in the next two years, largely through attrition.
"The first thing I hope to bring and have begun to bring to the city of Miami is a lowering of our voices and a tranquility," he said. "Miami needs to get off the front pages of the newspapers and stop being the lead story on TV and radio."
The appointment of Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa follows a monthlong shuffling of city managers, as Mr. Suarez, the city's first mayor to have extended powers, sought to put his stamp on the government.
The Mayor said the reports of turmoil in his administration had been greatly exaggerated, and he described Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa as only his second city manager. City Manager Alberto Ruder resigned after 23 days rather than dismiss the police chief; Frank Rollason, who stepped down last week as city manager, was an interim appointee, and Ed Marquez, whom Mr. Suarez dismissed, was appointed by Mayor's Suarez's predecessor.
Though acknowledging that perhaps he should have moved more cautiously, Mr. Suarez said the taxpayers wanted change.
"This is a government that can really use reform," Mr. Suarez said.
As city manager of Miami Beach, Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa helped to improve the city's investment bond rating, something he also hopes to be able to do for Miami, whose bond rating has been lowered to junk grade.
Miami's government has been in turmoil for more than a year. In addition to the financial emergency and bribery charges that resulted in the removal of three officials in 1996, the city has had seven elections in 17 months, including a referendum on whether Miami, one of 30 municipalities in Miami-Dade County, should continue to exist at all.
The city survived that referendum, but voters decided to change its form of government, giving the mayor executive powers for the first time and having City Council members elected from districts rather than at large.
But the legal problems are not over. The commission chairman, Humberto Hernandez, remained under Federal indictment on charges of fraud and money laundering in a case unrelated to city business. Law-enforcement agencies have also been investigating reports of election fraud, and former Mayor Joe Carollo has filed a lawsuit challenging Mr. Suarez's victory.
Commissioner Willy Gort expressed confidence today that Mr. Garcia-Pedrosa would stay on the job. The commissioners have warned Mr. Suarez that they do not want to see any more new city managers.

HEADLINE: THE BALANCED BUDGET: THE POLITICS;
Free-for-All, Driven by Ideology and Special Interests

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
As unpalatable as they may have been to big-spending Democrats and tax-cutting Republicans alike, the rules of the game in Washington have been clear since the Federal budget deficit began spiraling out of control in the early 1980's: consideration of nearly every issue would be limited by the politics of austerity.
President Clinton's announcement today that he could balance the budget next year, three years ahead of schedule -- and his implicit acknowledgment that the budget could show a surplus this year -- left the rule book shredded. The result is sure to be a free-for-all, a grab driven by ideology, special interests and old-fashioned pork barrel politics for any windfall that comes the way of the Government and taxpayers. 
 In economic terms, moving from the $22.7 billion deficit the Government recorded for the year ended Sept. 30 into balance or surplus over the next year or two is not terribly significant. The deficit has already come down from a peak of $290 billion in 1992, and at its current level is only a tiny portion of the nation's economic output.
But in political terms, closing the last of the gap not only allows Mr. Clinton and both parties in Congress to say that they completed the job as they maneuver for advantage in this year's mid-term elections, but it also gives them freedom to move into a less constrained new era.
"I welcome other people to the debate," Mr. Clinton said, effectively pronouncing a start to the politics of plenty.
Both Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders cautioned against a rush to abandon fiscal discipline, although the evidence suggests that it has been a stronger-than-expected economy more than any belt-tightening or political fortitude in Washington that led to today's good news.
Moreover, the nation will undoubtedly face fiscal challenges again, perhaps sooner than anyone in Washington has been counting on if the economy turns unexpectedly down. Asia's current woes stand as a reminder of how sharply high-flying economies can fall.
But judging by the almost unfettered rush among members of Congress over the last several months to stake claims to any budget surpluses, no one is much listening to the warning signals.
Hours before Mr. Clinton's announcement, Speaker Newt Gingrich said any surplus should first be used to help pay down the $5 trillion debt the nation has accumulated over the years. But he quickly added that some part of any surplus this year should go to an annual broad-based tax cut of the sort that Republicans have been pushing unsuccessfully for years.
Indeed, after coming to a wary truce with Mr. Clinton last year in order to put in place a plan to eliminate the deficit, Republicans now seem eager not just to battle for big tax cuts, but to reintroduce their ideological argument that cutting taxes not only puts money back in the pockets of citizens but helps starve, and therefore shrink, the Federal bureaucracy and Washington's influence.
"There's a difference between a big government with a balanced budget and a small government with a balanced budget," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee. "That's why it's important to reduce the excessive tax burden on the American people, which in turn reduces the size and power of the government."
For their part, Democrats, while pledging fiscal responsibility, have been asserting that there is pent-up demand for additional spending -- they prefer the term "investment" -- on health, education and social programs.
"We face a set of delayed or deferred choices for the country, particularly with respect to children, with respect to our schools and our infrastructure," Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat, said on Sunday on the ABC program "This Week."
And both parties show signs of succumbing to old political habits. Representative Bud Shuster, a Republican from Pennsylvania who is chairman of the House Transportation Committee, has won support from both sides for plans to increase spending on road-building, the kind of tangible project that members of Congress can point to with pride when they go home to campaign.
Mr. Clinton has yet to specify how he would allocate any surpluses but White House officials have been particularly wary of efforts by Republicans to pass big tax cuts. They said their fear was that Republicans might push through big tax cuts during a period of prosperity -- and then demand big spending cuts in programs that Mr. Clinton has battled to protect at the first hint that the deficit might reappear.
The jostling for a piece of the surplus is likely to be somewhat tempered by an emerging consensus within both parties that the good fiscal news provides an opportunity to confront the problem of how to keep the Social Security and Medicare programs from going bankrupt in the first decades of the next century.
The Administration said this weekend that it wants to help forge a bipartisan solution to the problems of Social Security in the next two years. Mr. Gingrich endorsed that timetable today. And although there is still no agreement about how to go about shoring up the retirement program, White House officials and Republican leaders said the elimination of the budget deficit gives them added political and economic flexibility.
"The job of dealing with Medicare and Social Security is now teed up for the political process," said Franklin D. Raines, the White House budget director.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CREDIT;
Bond Yields At the Lowest In Decades

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level in almost 30 years yesterday as weekend comments by the chairman of the Federal Reserve convinced investors that the prospect of falling prices could force the Fed to cut interest rates soon.
While the remarks by the chairman, Alan Greenspan, left room for a wide range of interpretations, his mere mention of deflation, or widespread price declines, caused the bond market to rally. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 5.74 percent, the lowest level since the Government began issuing the bond regularly in 1977. And yields on other long-term debt, like corporate bonds, hovered at about 6.6 percent, levels not seen since the end of 1968. 
 Market analysts attributed the decline in long-term rates, which were above 7 percent in April, to the continuing good news on inflation -- now below 2 percent -- and the hope that the relatively rapid pace of economic growth last year will slow by just the right amount in 1998.
The drag on United States growth from the economic collapse in Asia, a flight of foreign capital into what are considered safe American securities, and the prospect of less Federal borrowing also helped the credit markets.
"These low rates were earned the hard way," said Robert V. DiClemente, the chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "They were done without extremely low short-term rates and in the midst of good economic growth," he said, adding that the low rates may last a while.
But even with long-term rates at new lows, shorter-term rates have not fallen so far. In fact, they are well above their levels of October 1993, when the yield on the 30-year bond hit its previous low of 5.78 percent. The yield on the 10-year note, for example, dropped to 5.51 percent yesterday, but is still well above its 5.17 percent low in 1993.
This means that the kick for the economy from falling rates might not be as big as the drop in long-term rates would suggest. Many rates that consumers pay for borrowed money and the rates that they receive on their savings are tied to shorter-term rates.
Rates for many consumers and small businesses are pegged to the prime rate, which has not fallen in almost a year. Mortgage rates, which are most closely tied to the 10-year note, are coming down, but they have further to go to reach new lows.
According to Bank Rate Monitor, the national average rate on a 30-year mortgage dropped to 7.09 percent in the week ended last Wednesday. That was the lowest since February 1996, when the average was 6.88 percent. Given that the yield on the 10-year Treasury has dropped almost a quarter of a percentage point since Wednesday, this week's survey number should be lower.
What caught investors' notice yesterday was a speech by Mr. Greenspan to a meeting of the American Economic Association and the American Finance Association in Chicago on Saturday.
He spoke of deflation, a prospect that has arisen as inflation has fallen below 2 percent a year and a rush of goods from troubled economies in Asia appears likely.
Just the mention of deflation by a Fed chairman who has made his reputation by fighting inflation led to speculation about his intentions.
Some interpreted his remarks as an indication that the Fed would soon be cutting short-term rates, rather than holding them steady or raising them. In this view, the Fed will try to stimulate the economy to keep prices from falling precipitously.
Those who believe that the Fed will be cutting rates, though, are still a minority of Wall Street strategists.
Market participants, however, showed a different bias yesterday, pressing yields on the Treasury's two-year, three-year and five-year notes below the 5.5 percent target that the Fed has set for its shortest-term rate, the Federal funds rate for overnight borrowing between banks.
Some analysts said the market had overreacted to the Greenspan comments. "Just because he mentions deflation doesn't mean that he thinks it's a big risk," said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "That is a big leap of faith."
Joseph Liro, the chief economist at CIBC Oppenheimer, said he expected Mr. Greenspan "to stay very resistant to raising rates." But, he added, in reading the speech "I didn't get an easing out of it."
Mr. Greenspan's speech was mostly about the problems of measuring inflation, but deflation did come up. "For most purposes, biases of a few tenths in annual inflation rates do not matter when inflation is high," he said. "They do matter when, as now, inflation has become so low that policy makers need to consider at what point effective price stability has been reached. Indeed, some observers have begun to question whether deflation is now a possibility, and to assess the potential difficulties such a development might pose for the economy."
Yesterday's rally sent the price of the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction of the yield, up 1 1/4, to 105 1/2. The enthusiasm carried over into the Government's regular weekly bill auction. Following are the auction results:

HEADLINE: With a Delightful January Like This, Who Needs Spring?

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
It would be difficult to underestimate the general giddiness that has greeted the great heat wave of January.
"This weather is giving my clients spring fever," said Bonnie Kogos, a travel agent who took a flurry of phone calls for tours to the British Virgin Islands at McCord Travel Management in Manhattan yesterday. "They're as restless as a willow in a windstorm. They're saying it might as well be spring." 
 Right now, she said, the warm spell has brought balmy climes to the forefront of her clients' minds, and so plane tickets to the Caribbean are hard to come by. And indeed, the mild weather, which began last Friday and is expected to last until this Friday, has created its share of instant economic winners and losers in a metropolitan region momentarily freed from the prison of winter.
This unpremeditated outbreak of mild weather in the darkest days of winter, caused by an unexpected air mass that drew in warm, dry weather from the Great Plains, is a good time for golf driving ranges, ice cream stores and vendors on the suddenly crowded streets. But ski shops, heating-oil companies and outdoor stores are hardly sharing in the general euphoria.
"It is never a good time for warm weather in the ski business," said Richard Carp, general manager of the Princeton Ski Shops on East 22d Street in Manhattan. "But if it had to happen, this is a good week for it. We just finished our New Year's sale on Sunday, and we were absolutely mobbed. So we see this as a chance to catch our breath."
Since Saturday, the 150 member companies of the New York Oil Heating Association "haven't been busy at all," said John Maniscalco, the trade group's executive vice president. "The longer this goes on, the more the impact will be. But that's just Mother Nature, and we're certainly used to it."
For the region's department stores, "it's white knuckle time, because retailers have a very narrow window in which to sell outerwear, sweaters and boots," said Isaac Lagnado, president of Tactical Retail Solutions, a Manhattan-based marketing consultant. "They have to move it now."
Sales of topcoats, parkas, loden coats, hats, gloves and scarves were sluggish during the holiday season, Mr. Lagnado said, and the early weeks of January "would usually be a chance for a second wind for such items on markdown," he said.
Ironically, though, the weather is helping sell more pricey items at other department store counters. "It's putting people into the early spring state of mind, and increasing interest in full-price spring merchandise," said Jason Weisenfeld, a spokesman for Barneys.
Yesterday many workers, grimly returning to the January blues and the realities of employment after an extended holiday, found the balmy winter interlude an unexpected gift. "Hard to believe it's January," said Robert Alvarez, a management consultant, who headed into the Eddie Bauer outdoor store on Third Avenue in Manhattan.
In his pocket was a $60 gift certificate he had received from his grandmother. He strolled past the microfiber down coats, the thermal gloves and the fleece-lined skiers' goggle cases.
"It's hardly the day to buy ski poles," said Mr. Alvarez with a laugh. After looking over some wallets and keychains, he left the store, gift certificate unused.
Yesterday was the kind of day when "everybody said they wanted ice cream when I said I was going out to the bank," said Rebecca Simon, an administrative assistant at Feinberg & Associates, a Manhattan law firm.
So there she was in Tasti-D-Lite on East 45th Street, placing four orders for soft-serve frozen dessert with Jay Brenner, the owner.
"Today business is up 100 percent over a normal Jan. 5," Mr. Brenner said. "Winter is not our friend. Business drops off by half."
Instead of huddling in company cafeterias, Manhattan office workers strolled outside for lunch and stopped at street stands. "It's been so cold lately, I'd usually be home by now," said Said Azizi, proprietor of a street fruit stand at the Avenue of the Americas and 43d Street. But yesterday, business was up 35 percent.
Across the region the warm weather will likely cause an increase in construction that is usually stalled by the cold weather, said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York City.
January is the cruelest month for the Broadway theater, "when business can be off as much as 20 percent," said Jed Bernstein, executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers. "This weather will only bring more people into our theaters."
Indeed, it has already. During the palmy afternoons of Saturday and Sunday, 13,205 theatergoers lined up at the reduced-price TKTS booth in Duffy Square in Manhattan, "up 31 percent over the same days last year," said Jack Goldstein, executive director of the Theater Development Fund, which operates the booth.
And for restaurant owners, the pause in winter "represents found money," said Tim Zagat, publisher of the Zagat Restaurant and Hotel surveys. "There is no question that this weather will fill restaurant seats that would otherwise be empty in a very slow week."
Maple Moor Golf Course in Westchester County had an unusually busy weekend -- 421 players on sunny Saturday and Sunday -- and drew 212 players yesterday. But yesterday morning, a group of 4-year-olds taking their first lesson were the only skiers on the slopes of the Thunder Ridge Ski Area in Putnam County.
"If we can just get down in the low 20's it will be all right," said Bob Conklin, the resort's owner.
Yesterday's sullen, overcast January morning yielded to blue skies and a high of 50 degrees in Central Park at 2 P.M., on a day when normally the high is 38 degrees.
Such January weather "is uncommon," said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. The cause, he said, is an abnormally warm, humid air mass that has developed between Bermuda and the Southeastern United States. It has "strengthened southwesterly winds that are bringing warmer air to us from the Plains states," he said.
Mr. Gadomski predicted high temperatures in the 50's until Friday, when the mercury will slide to the freezing mark.
Until then, in Rye, N.Y., the Feinsod Hardware Store has available "500 winter-weather related items," said Carmen Braiotta, the manager. "The problem is, none of them are selling."

HEADLINE: German Churches, Ever Giving, Ask to Receive

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: MORFELDEN, Germany

 BODY:
When Gert Holle began to prepare to become a Lutheran minister more than eight years ago, he braced himself for arduous studies followed by hard work and modest pay.
But now, five months before he is supposed to take his vows, the 33-year-old seminarian faces the one prospect he did not anticipate: unemployment. For the first time in memory, the bishop here announced recently that the church has jobs for only a fraction of the 48 seminarians who will graduate in May. 
 So after spending years studying theology, Greek and Latin, Mr. Holle is now cramming for a backup career in public relations. "At least in public relations you are working with people," he said glumly, as he stirred a cup of tea in his sparsely furnished apartment.
Mr. Holle's problem stems not from a crisis of faith, but rather a crisis in tax revenues. Under an unusual century-old system, religious institutions in Germany get almost all their revenue from a 9 percent church surtax imposed on the income tax of every registered Catholic, Protestant and Jew.
Taxpayers are asked to declare their religion on their income tax returns, and churchgoers are pressed to register their religion with the Government. Those who are not members of the religions covered by the tax do not pay it, nor do those who have taken the bureaucratic step of revoking their registration.
Church taxes totaled about $11 billion in 1996, almost as much as the sin tax on cigarettes. In striking contrast to the United States, with its separation of church and state, Germany uses its religion taxes for the salaries of priests and rabbis, the construction of churches and a sprawling array of church-run social programs, from Christian day-care centers and kindergartens to drug-counseling clinics and hospitals.
But now the church-state partnership is cracking. With 4.3 million Germans, or more than 11 percent of the work force, unemployed, and thus paying no taxes, church revenue fell about 4 percent in 1996. It could have plunged as much as 10 percent in 1997. That would represent a combined drop in revenues for all religions of more than $1 billion.
Here in the state of Hesse, the Protestant hierarchy slashed $40 million out of its $500 million budget in 1997 and for each of the next five years. In Stuttgart, home of Daimler-Benz, struggling officials have cut money for social programs and international aid. In Saxony, in eastern Germany, the Protestant churches are gearing up to sell or rent as many as 200 empty church buildings.
"The problems will not end quickly," said Bishop Peter Steinacker, who oversees the Protestant churches in the west German region of Hesse-Nassau. "All the economic predictions call for more than four million unemployed over the next two, three or four years. As long as unemployment stays high, the financial situation will not get any better."
Germany's church tax supports three main religious groups: the Evangelical Churches, an umbrella organization of Protestants that oversees the Lutheran, Reform and United Protestant branches; Roman Catholicism, and Judaism. Protestants, most of them Lutherans, account for 45 percent of the German population, with Roman Catholics at 37 percent. Jews represent only a small percentage. Muslims and others are not part of the tax structure.
Much like German industry, German religion is now preaching the need to cut costs, become more efficient and refocus priorities. In Munich, Protestant leaders even got a free strategic analysis from the management consultants McKinsey & Company. And they are talking about trying to wean themselves, at least partly, from the tax system.
In early November, Protestant leaders in Hesse announced plans to cut 25 percent of spending on 19 programs, like psychological counseling and adult education. Pastors will also be sent into retirement as soon as they turn 60, while new seminarians will be kept out. In addition, the church will sharply reduce its extensive support for kindergartens and cut the number of religion teachers it sends to public schools.
Over the next five years, church leaders in Hesse seek substantial cuts in the ranks of pastors. Their numbers have kept pace through the years with the growing wealth of both Germany and its churches, swelling to about 1,800, from about 1,200 in 1970. Church officials say they want to reduce that number, probably by several hundred.
"We became, really, a little fat," said Joachim Schmidt, a spokesman for the Protestant church in Hesse.
Though revenues have been stagnant for several years now, church officials say they were blindsided by the decline in 1997. For the first time ever here, seminarians will have to choose between unemployment and a change in career.
"We have tried to avoid unemployment among ministers," Bishop Steinacker said, "but there were simply too many. We couldn't anticipate the development of the economy."
Mr. Holle and many of his classmates were shocked as well as infuriated by the news. Most of them have spent at least eight years preparing for the ministry -- at a cost to the church of more than $100,000 per person. After graduating from college, they often spent years in church-sponsored social work or serving as deacons in small parishes. Then there is a two-year program of theology and pastoral work, and students are normally not admitted to this last step unless the church is certain that there will be positions for them when they finish.
Now they are stuck. "They say that our training should make us good for many kinds of work," said Frank Albrecht, one of Mr. Holle's classmates. "But we are competing with all kinds of graduates in the arts and humanities, and we have a disadvantage -- we're older than most of them." Indeed, many of the seminarians are married, and some have children.
Many are hunting for jobs in other parts of the country. Horst Frank, another classmate, is looking in Austria. "The problem," Mr. Holle said, "is that the kinds of work we are most suited for, such as teaching or social work, are just as difficult to find as being a minister."
The financial crunch is causing religious people at all levels to rethink their partnership with the Government.
It began when the state took it upon itself to tax people who went to church and to funnel that money back to the denominations. In exchange, the churches assumed a range of nonreligious responsibilities in areas like adult education and social work as well as providing religious instruction in public schools.
Today, seminarians like Mr. Holle argue that churches have become as complacent as government institutions and have fallen woefully out of touch with the concerns of their members.
As Mr. Holle and fellow seminarians wrote in a dissident newspaper they recently started, "The greatest danger for the churches is not primarily financial, but rather the anonymity and unapproachability of its functionaries." Mr. Holle argues that if churches relied on direct contributions from parishioners, as they do in the United States, people would identify more closely with their churches and dig more deeply into their pockets. But many Germans view the idea of passing a collection plate as tasteless.
High-ranking Protestant officials have begun talking openly about the need to reduce their dependence on the tax system. They are also trying to improve the image of the church, and have even created a new logo.
"I prefer to describe this as a time of fundamental change, rather than a crisis," Bishop Steinacker said. "There are real opportunities here to renew ourselves."
But the churches cannot wean themselves so easily from the system. Officials of the Roman Catholic Bishops' Conference in Bonn noted, for instance, that while the church now pays the state more than $100 million a year for its tax collection service, that cost could triple if the job was privately undertaken.
Meanwhile, churches have begun to pull away from responsibilities not directly related to church life. In the case of kindergartens, Protestant officials want to force either the state or parents to pay more. Under the budget plan here in Hesse, the church's contribution to kindergarten costs would drop to 15 percent, from 40 percent in some schools.
And children who do not belong to the church will have to pay extra.
"Parishes are explicitly instructed to obtain higher contributions from parents who do not belong to a church," the church in Darmstadt recently alerted members.
Mr. Holle and his classmates, in an unusually scathing and public criticism, have accused the church leadership of succumbing to the "dictatorship of finance."
"Our church leadership is built on sand," the group of seminarians wrote in their newspaper. "No ideas, no heart, its eye on commerce."
Those are harsh words for people still trying to get a permanent job from the church they are attacking. But Mr. Holle is not worried.
"What can they do?" he asked. "Fire us?"

HEADLINE: THE BALANCED BUDGET;
Clinton's Remarks on Prospects for the First Balanced Federal Budget in 30 Years

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Following is an excerpt of President Clinton's remarks on the budget and answers to reporters' questions today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.
 
Statement
We can begin the year with some good news. I can now say that we believe that the deficit this year will be less than $22 billion. That means that it will decline for the sixth year in a row, a truly historic event. Twenty-two billion dollars is a far cry from the $357 billion the deficit was projected to be this year when I took office, or the $90 billion it was projected to be when the balanced budget agreement was enacted. So we have come a very long way. I can also say that the budget that I present to the Congress in February will be a balanced budget for 1999. Again, this will be the first time in 30 years we've had a balanced budget. And that's good news for the American people and for the American economy. 
 It continues the successful economic policy that we adopted. Beginning with the budget in 1993, which was the first major step, we have followed a policy of investing in our people, expanding the sales of American goods and services overseas and practicing fiscal discipline. We reversed 12 years of trickle-down economics in which the deficit of this country exploded year after year and our national debt was quadrupled.
So we have taken a different course. And thanks to the hard work and productivity of the American people, it is working. And I'm very, very pleased about it.
Now what we have to do now is to build on it, first, with the balanced budget, to keep interest rates down and keep the economy growing; secondly, with other policies, which I will be outlining in the State of the Union. I welcome other people to the debate.
But let me say I want to caution everyone that I will do everything I can to prevent anyone from using a projected future surplus as a pretext for returning to the failed policies of the past. We do not want to go back to the terrible conditions that paralyzed our Government and paralyzed our own people's potential in 1992 when I took office. We have to go forward.
This is great news today. I'm very pleased by it. The American people should be pleased by it. But we should be determined to stay on the course and do what works. And that's my determination.
 
Questions and Answers
Q. Are you ruling out a tax cut, Mr. President, with this surplus?
A. I do not -- let me just say -- I want to say just exactly what I said. We don't have a surplus. We can project a surplus, but we don't have one. And we've waited 30 years for a balanced budget. Between 1981 and 1992, we projected all kinds of things and went out and spent the money, on tax cuts and spending, both. We spent the money. And we quadrupled the debt, drove up interest rates, put our country in a terrible hole. Now, we have dug ourselves out of that hole with a lot of effort and a lot of pain. In 1993 it was a very difficult dig, and a lot of people paid a very high price for it. Then we had the overwhelming bipartisan support for the balanced budget.
All I'm saying is that any policy we adopt must not, it cannot, run any risk of returning to the failed policies of the past. We got away from trickle-down economics. We're into investing and growing our future. We're doing it the old-fashioned way. I have been exhorting the American people for five years now to be responsible, to remember that we cannot have opportunity without responsibility. Well, that same rule applies to the Government. We have to set a good example. We have to create opportunity, and we can't do it unless we're also responsible. So, whatever policies we adopt has to be within the framework of the budget to the best of our knowledge. We cannot take risks with the future that we have worked so hard to build.
Q. Mr. President, are you going to call for cigarette tax increases to help pay for new initiatives?
A. I will -- first of all, on the tobacco issue generally, and I'll have more to say about this later, but keep in mind what my first priority is. My first priority is to protect our children from the dangers of tobacco, from the illegal dangers of tobacco. And I will propose a plan that I believe is best designed to do that; that will build on the settlement agreement that was reached earlier. And I will work with members of Congress, in both parties, in good faith to try to pass comprehensive tobacco legislation that I think will achieve that goal. And I'll say more about the details later.
Q. Mr. President, there has been some controversy today about whether the press invaded your privacy in St. Thomas. Do you feel your privacy was invaded? And where should the press draw the line, sir?
A. The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is that's why we have a First Amendment. You get to decide the answer to the second question. But --
Q. You didn't like your dancing picture? Everybody liked it.
A. Actually, I liked it quite a lot. But I didn't think I was being photographed.
Q. Was it off limits, sir?
A. That's a question that you have to ask and answer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
