HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
One Word From a Corporate Ex-Wife: Half

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
A LOW point in the previously decorous life of Lorna J. Wendt came two Decembers ago, when she found some jottings from her husband and learned that he planned to divorce her after Christmas. Within days she was simultaneously interviewing her own divorce lawyers and meeting with caterers for the annual corporate Christmas party that her husband, a General Electric executive, had asked her to give one last time.
The question, of course, is not why the Wendts were divorcing, but why on earth Mrs. Wendt agreed to play hostess. 
 "My personality is, unfortunately, that I don't like to disappoint," Mrs. Wendt said yesterday, sheepishly, in an interview in her lawyers' office in Westport, Conn. She did think about canceling the event, she said, but her two daughters insisted, "Mom, that's not you."
Mrs. Wendt, 54, paused for a moment. "On the other hand," she said, "maybe it was dumb."
No one these days is likely to accuse Mrs. Wendt of stupidity. As the very recent Stamford, Conn., ex-wife of Gary C. Wendt, 55, the chief executive of GE Capital Corporation, General Electric's most profitable subsidiary, she has set off a debate about the economic worth of the corporate spouse. Last month, in a divorce settlement closely watched by nervous C.E.O.'s across America, a Superior Court judge in Connecticut awarded Mrs. Wendt $20 million -- half the Wendts' hard assets -- but a smaller part of Mr. Wendt's stock options and future pension benefits.
For Mrs. Wendt, who argues that as a full-time corporate spouse she contributed to her husband's success and half the economic value of the marriage, that wasn't enough. Late last month, her lawyers went back to court. The ultimate goal: half of an estate valued by her side at as much as $130 million. Although 50-50 divorce settlements are typical, and are the law in 11 states, American courts have been reluctant to give the wife half when an estate is worth more than $10 million to $15 million.
It's not the money, Mrs. Wendt says; it's the principle.
So don't ask her why she can't get by on $20 million. "Of course that's enough," she said.
"But I can turn it around and say, 'Well, what does he need all that money for?' He's out there working, and I've been fired."
Mr. Wendt was in meetings yesterday with Jack Welch, the General Electric chairman, and then heading out of the country on business, and was unavailable for comment, said his spokeswoman, Cathy Callegari. "Unlike Mrs. Wendt, he has a job to do," Ms. Callegari said.
In court, Mr. Wendt said that he was almost entirely responsible for the creation of the Wendts' assets. He has also said that he felt lonely in the marriage, and has given as an example Mrs. Wendt's refusal to take golf lessons. He is now seeing a retired, 65-year-old businesswoman.
UP close, Mrs. Wendt does not seem so much an angry woman as a potent one -- a formerly dutiful, pre-feminist-era spouse who has been empowered by both the public spectacle and private humiliation of her divorce. She grew up in Rio, Wis. (population 700), in the late 1950's and early 60's, a time when women were told that marriage and motherhood were the ultimate careers. Friends say that what has been most stunning to Mrs. Wendt is her realization that society does not necessarily view marriage as an equal partnership. "When I first met with one of my lawyers," Mrs. Wendt recalled, "he said, 'You're not going to get half.' And I said, 'What!' "
Mrs. Wendt says she began to see things differently about eight years ago, when she started going on wilderness survival trips run by Outward Bound -- first climbing Mount Kilimanjaro with her husband, but then heading out on her own for backpacking in Patagonia, living with native tribes in the Irian Jaya province of Indonesia and pitching a tent at 1:30 A.M. amid Costa Rican mudslides.
"I found within me a lot of strength I didn't know I had," she said. "I must have given up who I was as a person to my marriage."
Nonetheless, she still displays all the markings of a perfect hostess -- friends describe her as sociable, chatty, open. "May I take your coat?" she said yesterday in her lawyers' office. Then she inquired about coffee. "How do you take it?" she asked. One of Mrs. Wendt's lawyers, Sally Oldham, hung in the background, amused. "Lorna has made herself at home here," she said.
Mrs. Wendt trained as a corporate wife from birth. Her father was a Lutheran minister, and her mother a full-time wife devoted to the flock. "My mother was really a corporate spouse," Mrs. Wendt said.
She and Mr. Wendt were sweethearts at Rio High -- he the sports star, she the popular baton-twirler -- and went to the University of Wisconsin. After they married in 1965, Mrs. Wendt taught music and helped put Mr. Wendt through Harvard Business School (although Mr. Wendt's spokeswoman says Mr. Wendt's father paid the tuition). Then she quit to raise the children and support Mr. Wendt's corporate climb.
Mrs. Wendt said she bought and sold five homes, entertained heroically and found the schools and dry cleaners. Only once in 32 years, she said, did she tell her husband she was too tired to attend a business dinner.
"And he had a hissy fit," she said of an event in Warsaw in 1995. "He needed me for the social ability. He was not a schmoozer, and he didn't remember people's names."
This year Mrs. Wendt will be speaking for her new organization, the Foundation for Equality in Marriage. A piece of her advice: Get a pre-nup.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nagging Worries on Asia Deflate a Rally on Wall St.

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The first signs were bullish. The Dow Jones industrial average crept above 8,000 points early yesterday after European markets rallied overnight. Financial and technology stocks soared.
But before the day was over, investors were treated to another variation on what could become the theme of the year: Will or won't the Asian economic crisis take a bite out of one of the greatest bull markets in history? 
 The struggle between stock optimists and pessimists is not about whether a slowdown looms for corporate earnings; it is about about how much earnings growth will slow. Yesterday, victory went to the optimists, albeit just barely.
After an early rally carried the Dow average 70 points higher, heavy selling around midday pulled the blue-chip index 50 points lower, before it finally edged up to 7,978.99, a gain of 13.95 points in heavy trading.
Broader stock indexes were equally volatile. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, strong early in the day, finished up just 2.03 points, to 977.07. The Nasdaq composite index, up as much as 21 points in early trading, closed up 12.59 points, to 1,594.12.
Yet the earnings debate, as evidenced by yesterday's seesaw trading session, goes on. Some stock analysts say the slowdown will be muted by a healthy American economy, while others insist that weakening profits will eventually dismantle a record-setting three-year sprint.
The evidence would seem to be stacked against bullish investors. Largely because of the crisis in Asia, Wall Street strategists have tempered their forecasts, and analysts have trimmed earnings estimates.
History also suggests a slowdown is coming. For a record three consecutive years, the Dow average has risen 20 percent or more annually. The end of 1997 also marked the best 10-year period on record for the Dow. In the 1990's alone, the Dow is up 191 percent.
Even more, the economy is well into its seventh year of expansion, and although wage pressures have begun to rise, inflation has not.
This kind of economy, some stock analysts say, is inevitably followed by a slowdown and weaker share prices. But while many analysts are expecting a year of modest stock returns of, say, 5 percent to 8 percent, at least one stock researcher sees gains of up to 15 percent.
Richard Bernstein, director of quantitative research at Merrill Lynch, said the bull market had been powered by a period of incredibly stable inflation, creating an economy and stock market quite different from those in earlier periods.
Much of the credit, he said, goes to Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who has been a vigilant inflation fighter.
"You have to remember, the last 18 years are probably the first 18 years in history where the Federal Reserve was intent on killing inflation," Mr. Bernstein said yesterday. "And nothing kills the value of financial assets more vehemently than inflation."
Although the gains of recent decades are unusual, he said, they are exactly what should be expected in a noninflationary economy. One reason is that to bolster profits, corporations have had to overhaul themselves or increase productivity since they cannot easily raise prices.
For those reasons, the current economy and stock market do not easily yield to historical statistics. "The economy is fundamentally different than it was 25 years ago," Mr. Bernstein said. "Yet you don't have the universal acceptance that this is a different period."
At the other end of the spectrum is Barton Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and one of the most bearish of Wall Street bears.
Mr. Biggs says the stock market could fall as much as 25 percent this year, largely because the Asian contagion may spread.
"The U.S. economy is beginning to slow, the European economies are beginning to slow, and we're going to see less growth than is now expected," he said yesterday. "A loss of pricing power is going to continue and earnings are going to be disappointing."
A big decline in the market is likely, he said, because the stock market in the United States has been "priced for perfection."

HEADLINE: Panel Seeks H.M.O. Overseer For California, a Bellwether

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Grappling with the future of managed health care in the nation's most populous state, a special advisory commission recommended today that California establish a new agency to oversee the administration of health maintenance organizations and enact a wide range of measures intended to protect consumers and improve care.
The managed-care revolution has gone further in California than in any other state, with more than 70 percent of insured Californians now in some kind of managed-care plan. The public backlash against its shortcomings has been equally pronounced. The commission, the Managed Health Care Improvement Task Force, was appointed by Gov. Pete Wilson and the California Legislature last spring after a raft of piecemeal legislative proposals for change. 
 At a time when states and the Federal Government are wrestling with how to assure that the financial savings achieved by managed care do not undermine patient care, the panel's recommendations are considered likely to carry weight nationally. In California, the immediate practical effect will be to give renewed impetus to some 70 pending bills -- some of which Mr. Wilson vetoed in the past -- that would guarantee patients easier access to care, including wider access to specialists and prescription drugs without administrative hurdles.
The commission's executive director, Philip J. Romero, who is also Mr. Wilson's chief economist, said its members, who are representatives of the health care industry and of consumer groups, had been "very aware of the national implications" of their work.
"More than 70-plus percent of Californians are in managed care, and nationally it's more like 40 to 45 percent," Mr. Romero said. "Eventually the nation will catch up, but we're probably four to five years ahead of the rest of the country right now."
The recommendations of the 30-member panel, headed by Alain Enthoven, a Stanford University economist regarded as a father of the managed-care movement, are nonbinding, and the commission itself did not attempt to list priorities among its more than 100 recommendations, or estimate the costs of the proposed changes.
But the debate here is likely to play out nationally as Congress struggles with the same issues this year. In a preview of that debate, those speaking for the industry today complained that the commission's recommendations amounted to costly micromanagement while those speaking for consumers said they did not go far enough.
As part of its work, the task force commissioned a poll, which found that while three-quarters of insured Californians were generally satisfied with their health care coverage, just over 40 percent had experienced a variety of problems in the last year, from being forced to change medications to being denied care or treatment they thought they needed, with the sickest residents reporting the most problems.
At the center of the panel's recommendations is the creation of a state entity to oversee managed-care plans, replacing the California Department of Corporations, a securities regulatory body that has been widely criticized as an inadequate overseer of H.M.O.'s over the past 20 years. But the task force disagreed over whether such an agency should be headed by a single gubernatorial appointee (as the health care industry wanted) or by a board with legislative and gubernatorial appointees (favored by consumer groups) and made no recommendation on that issue.
The panel also recommended a study of consolidating all health care regulation under the new agency, and establishing an "unbiased, independent, third-party" state review process for resolving patients' complaints over denial of treatments. This would include establishing uniform procedures for resolving complaints; for example, guaranteeing patients the right to appear in person at grievance hearings. It also recommended requiring health plans to collect and publish more detailed information on consumer complaints and to standardize their plan descriptions to make it easier for patients to comparison shop.
Representatives of both the health care industry and consumer interests today criticized the panel's final recommendations for falling short of the task at hand, albeit from opposite perspectives.
Myra Snyder, the president of the 40-member California Association of Health Plans, the state's largest organization of H.M.O.'s, insuring some 18 million people, said it was "disappointed that the task force really didn't take a systemic approach to the health plans and review what works and what doesn't," but had instead endorsed a grab-bag of proposals attempting to satisfy various interest groups.
"There are no priorities, by their own admission, and there are no cost estimates, so you're getting into extreme micromanagement of the health plans," Ms. Snyder said. "By the sheer volume of the recommendations, we anticipate that this legislative session will see another flood of bills."
Assemblyman Martin Gallegos, a chiropractor from the San Gabriel Valley who is co-chairman of the Legislature's conference committee on managed care and was also a member of the task force, agreed with that prediction. He has already vowed to reintroduce his own bill to allow a patient to continue to receive drugs for a chronic condition, even if the patient's health plan removes that prescription from its list of approved drugs. The task force endorsed a similar idea.
"In many very important instances, the recommendations of the task force fall very short of the types of reforms we really need to have for H.M.O.'s in California," added Mr. Gallegos, who has also proposed a ballot referendum for November that would make it easier for patients to sue health maintenance organizations for malpractice. "Nevertheless, I think you're going to see a push on the part of the Legislature for stronger reforms."
Mr. Wilson's spokesman, Sean Walsh, said that the Governor intended to use the task force report as a "resource" in evaluating possible legislative changes in the future, rather than embracing or rejecting any of its recommendations now.
"It's a repository that we'll go to as we deal with probably over 100 bills that'll be headed toward the Governor's desk this year," Mr. Walsh said.
Mr. Romero, the commission's executive director, said he believed its recommendation for adopting more sophisticated payment techniques intended to discourage health plans or hospitals from seeking to enroll only the healthiest patients could be especially significant. Under this proposed system, known as "risk adjustment," health plans would all pay a percentage of their revenues into a pooled fund, which would then be redistributed to plans whose patients are older and sicker than the insured population as a whole, to avoid punishing such plans for taking on that burden.
Such a process is highly technical, and there is debate about whether it is feasible, but the task force recommended that it be adopted by the giant California Public Employees Retirement System and then phased in for the University of California system and other large insurance purchasing groups.
Mr. Romero said managed care was now so widespread, and some problems with it so evident, that some changes were now inevitable.
"Even the most blue-blood, conservative Republican politicians, if they're not in managed care themselves, have friends and relatives who are," he said. "And they all have horror stories, whether they're true or not."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Samsung to Slash Its Overseas Production

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Samsung Group, South Korea's second-largest conglomerate, said today that it would cut electronics production in China and Southeast Asia by 40 percent as part of a worldwide retrenchment.
The cuts reflect Samsung's anticipation of the slowest economic growth in South Korea for at least 18 years as the country seeks a way out of a crisis that has halved the value of the won, South Korea's currency, in the last three months. 
 The won's decline has made it far more expensive for South Korean businesses to repay foreign loans and buy imported materials. But South Koreans could benefit from the Samsung cutback because the retrenchment means the company will export more from domestic factories and create up to 5,000 jobs at home.
Samsung Group employs 260,000 people worldwide in businesses ranging from electronics to shipbuilding to finance. The 60-year-old company has about $45 billion in assets and about $5.2 billion in annual overseas sales.
Samsung's announcement coincided with a visit to the United States by South Korean officials seeking help in repackaging billions of dollars in short-term debts.
Optimism that Seoul will overcome the debt crisis helped South Korean stocks rise 1.17 percent by midday today after a 2.9 percent gain Monday.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in New York on Monday that a debt-restructuring agreement must be found to "enable Korea to return to a situation of stability."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan to Try to Save Banks By Buying Stakes in Them
The Japanese Government is drafting a law to bail out banks by purchasing a stake in them, akin to the way the United States Government rescued banks during the Depression years.
The legislation, which could be presented to Parliament next week, appears to be the core of an increasingly ambitious effort to strengthen Japan's frail banking system. The size of that effort, originally estimated at 10 trillion yen a month ago, has tripled to 30 million yen in the last few weeks, roughly $225 billion at current exchange rates. Page D4. 

Thailand Seeks Different Terms
The weakening of Thailand's currency, the baht, and its worsening economic crisis have led its Prime Minister to ask the International Monetary Fund to ease the terms of its $17.2 billion bailout package. D4.
 
Samsung Group, South Korea's second-largest conglomerate, said it would cut electronics production in China and Southeast Asia by 40 percent as part of a global retrenchment. C4.
 
New Finance Minister in Mexico
President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico named as his Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria, left, a 47-year-old economist who served as Foreign Minister for the last three years and is well regarded by foreign investors. The appointment ended a stretch that began Dec. 15 when the former Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, was appointed to head the central bank. D2.
 
A Settlement Is Reached at TCI
John C. Malone, the chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc., won more control over the company in a settlement reached with the estate of its founder, Bob Magness. D7.
 
Ford Planning to Diminish Pollution
Ford said that it planned to reduce the air pollution produced by its sport utility vehicles and Windstar mini-vans by installing bigger and more effective catalytic converters and by adjusting their engines. The costs will not mean higher prices for the vehicles, the company said. A1.
 
Stocks Edge Up in Heavy Trading
The volatile stock market continued, as the Dow Jones average climbed early yesterday, then fell, and ended the day up 13.95 points in heavy trading. Other indexes rose, too. D6.
 
Companies Shrink Dividend Payouts
The number of companies that raised their dividends last year fell 1.5 percent, and the payouts climbed just 4.1 percent, compared with an 8 percent jump in 1996. In fact, the growth of dividends has not been anywhere as great as the rise in either reported corporate profits or the increase in stock prices.
Floyd Norris: Market Place D7.
 
Investments Roll Into Funds
Even though money flowed out of overseas funds in the fourth quarter, investments in stock and bond mutual funds in the first 11 months of 1997 surpassed the previous record for a full year. Moreover, bond funds returned to popularity as a safe haven for the turbulence in equity markets. D7.
 
Microsoft Accuses Official of Bias
Microsoft accused a court-appointed official of "exhibiting clear bias" against the company and demanded that he disquality himself from the Government's antitrust case. D22.
 
Volkswagen Rolls the Bug Back
The new Beetle was introduced at the auto show in Detroit. The Volkswagen car, which is meant to remind buyers of the popular Bugs of the past, is scheduled to go on sale in March in the United States at prices starting at $15,200. Jens Neumann, a member of Volkswagen's board, called it "a very modern car that we all seem to have known for quite some time."

HEADLINE: THE BALANCED BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON WILL SEEK BALANCED BUDGET IN '99 INSTEAD OF '02

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he would propose a balanced Federal budget for 1999, three years ahead of schedule, signaling a halt and perhaps an end to the deficit politics that have confined the dreams of a generation of Presidents and lawmakers.
Predicting that the deficit in 1998 would fall to less than $22 billion -- a virtual rounding error in a budget of more than $1.7 trillion -- President Clinton in effect marked the fiscal equivalent of the fall of the Berlin Wall. The deficit has governed domestic politics much as the Soviet threat defined foreign policy, curbing Democratic hopes for spending, and limiting Republican hopes for tax cuts. "We have come a very long way," Mr. Clinton said in brief public remarks in the Cabinet Room of the White House, where he met with his economic advisers today. 
 The budget was last balanced in 1969. The last time a President even proposed a budget he said would balance was in 1971, when President Richard Nixon did, but Congressional and economic facts of life thwarted him.
Crediting the "hard work and productivity of the American people" as well as his own policies with reducing the deficit, the President cautioned against "using a projected future surplus as a pretext for returning to the failed policies of the past." Excerpts, page A12.
But in acknowledging today what private-sector economists and Congressmen have believed for months -- that robust economic growth was cutting the deficit far faster than expected -- Mr. Clinton was sure to encourage what has already become politicians' favorite new parlor game here: how to spend the surplus.
Even some of the President's own aides, in predicting balanced budgets beyond 1999, indulged in a bit of the euphoria today. "You'll see surpluses as far as the eye can see," said Gene Sperling, the director of the President's National Economic Council.
Even so, Administration officials acknowledged that the nation faced serious long-term fiscal challenges, especially the looming insolvencies of the Social Security and Medicare trust funds.
In an appearance in Marietta, Ga., before the President's announcement today, Speaker Newt Gingrich, who had urged Mr. Clinton only two weeks ago to propose a balanced budget for 1999, also cautioned policy makers to keep the budget in surplus once it gets there. He said that the "surplus's first goal should be to pay down" the Federal debt, which is about $5.4 trillion. But he said that he also favored setting as a goal "at least a small tax cut every year." Page A13.
Asked today whether he ruled out a tax cut this year, Mr. Clinton repeated his exhortations about not spending money the Government does not yet have. "We cannot take risks with the future that we have worked so hard to build," he said.
Under the balanced budget agreement reached by the White House and Congress last year, the deficit was supposed to rise in 1998 and remain flat in 1999 before declining and then vanishing in 2002. As recently as Sunday, top Clinton Administration officials were refusing to discuss the idea that a surplus could come sooner.
The deficit in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 of this year was supposed to be $90 billion, although in August the Administration cut that estimate to $58 billion.
The Administration declined to disclose its assumptions about future economic performance, which are critical to any predictions about tax revenues and hence, deficits.
Even the finest economic model could prove disastrously wrong, if economic turmoil in Asia or an unexpected shock to the economy, like an oil shortage, surprised policy makers.
But Mr. Sperling said that forecasts of "both good and bad times" were "built into the budget assumptions." For five years, the Administration's forecasting has proved pessimistic, with revenues regularly exceeding expectations.
As a result, the robust economy has permitted Mr. Clinton to cut the deficit without causing undue pain to his most cherished programs. Tax revenues have been so healthy that both he and the Republicans have been able to finance new proposals.
But stricter fiscal discipline has played a role in shrinking the deficit. President Clinton arrived at that approach reluctantly, after taking office in 1993 with plans for substantial new spending on highways, health care and other programs.
Mr. Clinton never mentions it, but a tax increase signed at great political cost by President George Bush began the work of deficit reduction. While Mr. Clinton campaigned on pledges to cut the deficit and increase spending, he concluded after a battle among his economic advisers that he would have to put greater emphasis on deficit reduction before interest rates would fall. Then, further reining in his spending plans, Congress torpedoed his proposal to stimulate the economy by increasing financing for the nation's infrastructure.
Mr. Clinton's economic plan in 1993, which included a tax increase on wealthy Americans, passed without a single Republican vote in favor, as he frequently notes now at Democratic fund-raisers. Mr. Clinton's aides argue that that tax increase has substantially cut the deficit.
Since then, the President has been forced, according to rules governing budget negotiations, to find sources of revenue for each new program he proposed.
His aides say that as a result, he has been able to increase spending for his priorities, like medical research and education, while counteracting years of Republican criticism of big government.
Rahm Emanuel, Mr. Clinton's senior adviser, said that showing that "Washington can in fact be fiscally responsible does bring back a different vision of Government as an affirmative force, a force for good."
Mr. Clinton is expected to seek a raft of new spending initiatives in his budget, including money to expand child care and to encourage businesses to cut pollution. But Franklin D. Raines, the budget director, said the Administration was not using part of "any projected surplus to pay for initiatives."
"We are doing it the old-fashioned way," he said.
The Administration is also likely to try to close tax loopholes and take other measures to raise revenues, but the Republican-controlled Congress will probably reject such steps as tax increases.
Mr. Clinton is planning to seek substantial increases in tobacco taxes, as part of a broad effort to put into law the settlement negotiated last year between the tobacco industry and states attorneys general. Mr. Raines said that the tobacco revenue would not be used to help pay for Mr. Clinton's 1999 budget. "The tobacco legislation that we will be supporting will be self-contained and will have a net-zero impact on the rest of the budget," he said.
Mr. Clinton is expected to announce on Tuesday a proposal to permit younger retirees, age 62 through 64, to buy into the Medicare program by paying premiums. That proposal, which has been sharply criticized by Republican leaders, would be financed through further changes in Medicare, so it should have no impact on the President's budget plan.
For weeks, Mr. Clinton's aides have been leaking the President's forthcoming budget priorities, part of a time-honored political ritual in advance of the President's formal announcement of his budget next month. Mr. Clinton, who returned to Washington on Sunday after a vacation, appeared eager today to set the terms dramatically for the coming budget negotiations.
Mr. Raines said that it was only this morning that the Administration's budget planning became detailed enough that he could generate reliable deficit estimates for 1998 and 1999.
"People had been working all weekend on coming up with a number for what did 1998 look like, and what did 1999 look like," Mr. Raines said. "As soon as that number had firmed up so that I was sufficiently convinced of it, I communicated that to the President."

As Kurdish refugees continued to arrive at Italy's borders, fleeing the 13-year-old civil war in Turkey, officials in Italy and several other European countries have made renewed calls on Turkey to change its approach to the conflict, but Turkey has rejected them. Alarmed at the exodus, officials from several countries will meet on Wednesday in Rome to map out a strategy. A9

An American adventurer, Steve Fossett, was forced to abandoned his fourth attempt to be the first person to travel around the world by balloon because of malfunctions and unfavorable winds. Mr. Fossett landed in Russia, where he was whisked by a Russian air force helicopter to the district capital of Krasnodar. "I don't even want to think about continuing my journey," he said. "I just want to go home and get warm." A4

President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya was sworn in for his final five-year term. The elections have left the country splintered. A6

Monthlong protests in France have forced Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's Government to pass legislation to make more funds available to aid the country's 3.1 million unemployed. HEADLINE: Medical Research Funding

 BODY:
Only a year or two ago, the nation's research community was in despair over a potentially bleak future. Congress and the Administration had agreed to balance the budget by the year 2002, threatening huge cuts in science and other "discretionary" programs. But now champions of research in both political parties are vying to pump large sums into the politically popular biomedical sciences. It is a startling turnabout that could save American research from mindless cutting -- or dangerously distort its priorities.
The push for more medical research comes from two directions, as described by the Times reporter Robert Pear last Saturday. President Clinton's new budget will propose a $1 billion boost for the National Institutes of Health, the Government's chief medical research agency -- a 7 percent increase over the current $13.6 billion level. He will undoubtedly be outbid by Congress, where lawmakers from both parties have talked of doubling the agency's budget in five years, which would mean annual increases averaging 15 percent. 
 Biomedical research has always been a political favorite, given that every lawmaker has constituents who are ill and many have had medical tragedies in their own families. The fiercely aggressive medical lobbies have no trouble gaining attention for their favorite causes. But this year the drive for more funding is also fueled by a belief among the conservative Republicans who control Congress that research in general, and biomedical research in particular, help generate economic growth. There is also concern that the expansion of managed care has sharply reduced hospital revenues that were previously used to support research, suggesting that more Federal research money will be needed just to stay even.
If the bipartisan drive saves research from devastating cuts or actually increases overall spending, the nation is bound to benefit. But it would make little sense to force-feed biomedical research at 15 percent growth rates at the expense of other vital scientific areas, such as physics, chemistry, energy and environmental sciences, that may be just as worthy as medical research even though they lack its political appeal.

HEADLINE: Family and Police Seek Missing Times Square Reveler

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
For the last few years, Lawrence R. Andrews and a half-dozen or so of his friends have journeyed from Brewster, N.Y., to Times Square to ring in the new year. They followed a routine familiar to suburban revelers: Hop on an evening train. Go to some bars. Celebrate with the masses as the ball drops. Go home feeling merry.
But this year, Mr. Andrews -- who the police said was drunk -- somehow became separated from his friends just after midnight on the inhospitably cold night. And yesterday, five days into 1998, Mr. Andrews was still missing. 
 On Sunday and again yesterday, Mr. Andrews's family visited midtown Manhattan and plastered the area with 3,000 fliers that show a picture of Mr. Andrews and phone numbers for the city's Midtown South police station house. Family members said they would continue to hand out the fliers until they know what happened to Mr. Andrews, 22, an unemployed landscaper who is 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 190 pounds.
"It's been up and down," said Mr. Andrews's sister, Jennifer Andrews, 25, describing the family's emotions. "But we have to do what we have to do."
The case is reminiscent of that of Patrick McNeill, a 21-year-old Fordham University student who was last seen by friends leaving a bar on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The disappearance prompted a citywide search by Mr. McNeill's family and more than 1,000 volunteers. His body was found floating near a pier in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in April, two months after he had disappeared.
But for Brewster, a working-class community of about 1,500 people in Putnam County on the Connecticut border, the story may seem like a continuation of what was already a very bad 1997.
In the last six months, the village lost its first firefighter in the line of duty, suffered through an explosion at a hotel that claimed two lives and mourned the death from a heart attack of a town councilman, Michael McEnery.
"It's just been one right after another," said Ruth Argo Mazzei, the clerk of the nearby town of Southeast, which handles some of Brewster's municipal business. "My kids watch TV and they say, 'We're on again, and it's not good news.' "
In Mr. Andrews's case, the police in New York City and Putnam County said it was too early to speculate on what had become of Mr. Andrews. But his friends and relatives said that Mr. Andrews was gearing up for a series of important family events -- including his sister's wedding next month -- and that it was unlikely that Larry, as he is known, would have just disappeared without calling anyone.
"I have my own phone line, and he calls me if he's in trouble, even if it's at 6 in the morning," said Ms. Andrews, who like her brother still lives at home. "So it's not like him not to call."
That evening, the family was not overly concerned about Mr. Andrews's itinerary: he was, after all, going to be with friends in a city he knew well, on a night he had celebrated before. They said the only thing that concerned them was the weather -- the low that night was a bone-chilling 16 degrees. So they asked Mr. Andrews to wear layers: a T-shirt, a black turtleneck, a black sweatshirt and a deep-blue ski jacket.
First, Mr. Andrews went to a friend's house to begin partying and drinking. The group then boarded a train, arriving at Grand Central Terminal around 10:30 P.M., said Daniel Stephens, senior investigator with the Putnam County Sheriff's Office.
Mr. Stephens said the young men went to two or three bars, all near Grand Central, before stepping outside and celebrating with the 500,000 or so other shivering souls crammed into Times Square.
But then, just after the ball dropped, Mr. Andrews apparently became separated from his group. "They turned around, and my brother was gone," Ms. Andrews said.
About 1 A.M., he was spotted at a bar inside Grand Central Terminal, where he bumped into some other Brewster residents and chatted about football and other subjects dear to him, his sister said. Then, somewhere between 2 and 2:30 A.M., he ran into two other Brewster residents -- but under more inexplicable circumstances, Mr. Stephens and Ms. Andrews said.
They said Mr. Andrews was last seen running in his T-shirt on 42d Street, heading west, away from the train station. He gave the other Brewster residents a Yankees cap -- which he did not have when he left Brewster. And he was no longer wearing the black turtleneck, sweatshirt or jacket.
Mr. Stephens said witnesses described Mr. Andrews as drunk, but not incoherent. "He was in control of his speech, he recognized people, so it wasn't like he was falling down or anything," Mr. Stephens said.
Mr. Andrews was not carrying much money, according to his sister. Nor did he have a bank card or any credit cards. And he may not have even had his driver's license because was arrested last year for driving under the influence and his license was being revoked, his sister said.
The family has checked with homeless shelters, hospitals and the city morgue. The only known medical problem that Mr. Andrews has is a slight asthmatic condition, which prevented him from joining the military. He is, however, a regular smoker.
On Friday, Mr. Andrews was supposed to go skiing with a friend. He had plans to watch the N.F.L. playoffs over the weekend to root for his beloved Pittsburgh Steelers. And yesterday, he was supposed to accompany his sister to the doctor. He even planned to start his own landscaping business.
But for now, all of these things must wait.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The family of Lawrence R. Andrews has distributed fliers. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Video Center Is Set For West Harlem Site

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Broadway Video, a production company owned by Lorne Michaels, the producer of "Saturday Night Live," announced yesterday that it would open an 8,600-square-foot, $1.1 million video duplication center in West Harlem at 3280 Broadway at 132d Street.
The business, which is expected to open in March, will employ 20 people and will handle mass videotape duplication, packaging and distribution of broadcast videotape, fiber optic video transmission and videotape storage. It will expand Broadway Video's current video duplication complex in midtown Manhattan at 1390 Broadway, between 49th and 50th Streets. 
 Employees will come from the Strive/A.S.A.P. program, which teaches disadvantaged city residents job skills. Financing for the project is being provided by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone and Citibank.
"What we are doing here is the right thing to do for our business and the right thing to do for New York," said Stephen Shippee, the chief executive officer of Broadway Video. "Not only are we providing area residents with employment and valuable training, but this opportunity allowed us an economically feasible expansion within the city." NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: SOCCER: NOTEBOOK -- METROSTARS;
Mondelo To Replace Parreira

BYLINE: By ALEX YANNIS 

 BODY:
The search for a head coach has ended for the MetroStars. They will announce in a day or two that ALFONSO MONDELO will be their fourth coach as they start preparations for their third season in Major League Soccer, which will release its 1998 schedule at noon today.
 Mondelo was hired last fall to be an an assistant to CARLOS ALBERTO PARREIRA, who left the MetroStars this past fall in order to coach Saudi Arabia in the World Cup finals in France next summer. Mondelo led the Long Island Rough Riders to the A-League championship two years ago. 
 RALPH PEREZ, who has worked as an assistant to all three MetroStars coaches -- EDDIE FIRMANI, CARLOS QUEIROZ and Parreira -- will stay on under the new coach. Perez, who coached at Old Dominion University for six seasons before joining the MetroStars, was an assistant to BOB GANSLER on the United States World Cup team that played in Italy in 1990.
 TIM MULGUEN will remain as the goalkeepers coach, a job he has had from the team's first day.
 The MetroStars' goalkeeper TONY MEOLA started working with the World Cup team in Orlando, Fla., yesterday. The goalkeeper for the Americans in the 1990 World Cup in Italy and the 1994 in the United States, Meola was recalled by Coach STEVE SAMPSON to replace BRAD FRIEDEL, who signed with Liverpool of England's Premier League two weeks ago and will most likely make his debut with Liverpool tomorrow in a game at Newcastle in the League Cup.
 Meola fell out of favor after the 1994 World Cup with BORA MILUTINOVIC, the United States coach at the time. Meola wanted to pursue other other career options, including acting and a tryout with the Jets of the National Football League as a place-kicker. He has been one of the top goalkeepers in M.L.S. the last two years.
 
WORLD CUP
 Iran is apparently desperate to do well in the first round of the tournament in France in its games against the United States, Germany and Yugoslavia. After they dismissed VALDEIR VIEIRA of Brazil as coach, the Iranians met with UDO LATTEK of Germany last week and offered him the job.
 Lattek, who is one of Germany's most successful club managers, with tenures at Bayern Munich and Borussia Moenchengladbach as well as Barcelona in Spain, said he was hesitant to accept the job because of the language barrier and having to leave his family behind for six months.
 "My main strength as a trainer is that I can motivate the players by talking directly to them," Lattek said. "If somebody has to translate what I say, then that's lost."
 
FIFA
 Soccer must be protected from exploitation by commercial and political forces, the FIFA general secretary, SEPP BLATTER, said yesterday in Singapore, where he opened the sport's first industry trade show. Blatter warned that the $200 million-a-year industry that soccer had spawned was in danger of consuming it.
 "There is a danger that our marketing partners are trying to take over the rights of football associations or clubs," Blatter told the 400 or so sponsors of soccer from some 50 countries that gathered for the show.
 Blatter also warned about political intervention and the dictating by sponsors of the times games are played in order to attract larger television audiences. He said that soccer's social, economic and political influence made it one of the most important parts of modern life -- and that it had to be defended against exploitation.
 
ENGLAND
 It took Chelsea 27 years to win the F.A. Cup, the most coveted prize in British soccer, for a second time, but it took only about 28 minutes to lose it again on Sunday. Six of the Chelsea players who beat Middlesbrough in the Cup final last May were in the lineup for the 5-3 drubbing by Manchester United at Stamford Bridge on Sunday in Chelsea's first match to defend the trophy.
 Two goals from DAVID BECKHAM, after 23 and 28 minutes, two more from ANDY COLE, after 45 and 66, and a TEDDY SHERINGHAM header 15 minutes from the end of regulation time gave United a 5-0 lead. Two goals from the substitute GIANLUCA VIALLI and one from GRAEME LE SAUX in the last 12 minutes made it respectable for Chelsea.
 
BRAZIL
 The former Brazil captain CARLOS ALBERTO TORRES, who played for the Cosmos two decades ago, lashed out last week after he was dismissed as coach at Botafogo, accusing club directors of being dishonest and his replacement of being unethical.
 Torres, captain of Brazil's team in the 1970 World Cup triumph and the sweeper of the Cosmos in their glory days, was livid after GILSON NUNES gave a news conference confirming that he had been appointed coach before Torres knew he was dismissed.
 The country's so-called dance of the coaches has continued in full swing since the championship ended late last month and Botafogo did not make the playoffs. Along with Torres, EDUARDO AMORIM, who coached both Corinthian and Sport Recife in the Brazilian championship, became Portuguesa's third coach in two months -- and Portuguesa is generally considered one of the more stable clubs.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
A Japanese Plan to Save Banks by Buying a Piece of Them

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Borrowing a chapter from America's rescue of its banks during the Depression, the Japanese Government is drafting a law to bail out banks in this country by taking a stake in them.
The legislation, described by officials in interviews today, appears to be the centerpiece of a Government effort to strengthen the banking system and lessen the risk of global financial crisis. 
 That effort, first announced last month, has grown in size and scope. The Government said on Christmas Day that it would set aside as much as 30 trillion yen to stabilize the banking system -- about $225 billion at current exchange rates -- and triple the original package of 10 trillion yen announced on Dec. 10.
Officials hope that the initiative will be welcomed by financial communities here and abroad, which have expressed growing anxiety over cracks in the financial system of Japan, the world's second-largest economy. They and financial-industry professionals share a nightmare that a Japanese banking collapse could ripple around the world with devastating effects.
To be sure, Japan in the 1990's is hardly a mirror image of the United States in the 30's. But many of Japan's banks have been badly strained by huge debts, and their frailty has helped stunt national economic growth here for years. The problems have only worsened as other Asian nations have suffered under debt burdens in recent months, most notably South Korea, one of the biggest foreign debtors of Japanese banks.
The bank-rescue legislation, as described today by officials in the Government and the dominant Liberal Democratic Party, would inject capital into banks in exchange for preferred stock, a plan modeled on the successful effort to salvage the American banking system in the Depression years. Officials said the legislation would be presented to Parliament as early as next week and could take effect in the next couple of months.
"The point is not the injection of capital itself," said Koji Yasuoka, head of the Liberal Democratic Party committee that is leading the effort. "The point is for the Japanese Government to show clearly the will to stabilize the financial system."
In the 1930's, the United States helped private banks increase their capital by buying preferred shares from both strong and weak institutions, which reinvigorated the banking system and helped pull the economy out of the Depression.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was created in the early 1930's to carry out the responsibility. But banks initially declined to take part out of fear that this would stigmatize them as weak and scare customers into withdrawing deposits.
Finally, Washington prevailed upon the J. P. Morgan Bank and Trust Company, the strongest institution at the time, to take the lead and issue preferred shares to the Government. After that, weaker banks thought that they could do likewise, and the plan succeeded.
The Japanese proposal has raised sensitive questions on the use of public money to help weak and strong banks alike. Some argue that bad banks should close rather than get a new life-support system. But anxiety about the banks and the fragility of the economy is so great that critics seem willing to accept the plan.
"Principally, I don't agree with the Government plan," said Satoru Yoshida, a professor of money and banking at Musashi University here. "As an emergency rescue plan, I must admit that it is necessary."
The financial markets have remained skeptical of the Government's efforts to help banks and invigorate the economy, as reflected in the languishing Japanese stock market and the diminished value of the yen. Today, Japan's currency touched the weakest level against the dollar since April 1992, and stocks dropped nearly 2 percent on pessimism about an economic recovery. On Tuesday morning, the yen was stable, selling at 133.73 to the dollar. Stocks declined by a further 127.17 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 14,829.67 at midday.
The bank-rescue legislation, which Finance Ministry officials have worked on through the New Year holiday, would empower a special Government-sponsored bank to buy preferred shares in ailing institutions. These shares would carry no voting rights so Tokyo would not, in theory, have a say in running the bank in which it took a stake.
While the plan would be used primarily to aid weak institutions, officials also hope to encourage strong ones, like the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, to issue preferred shares ahead of the others so that the plan would gain respectability -- just as J. P. Morgan lent respectability to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Katsumi Tsuiji, a spokesman for the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, said that while his company had been considering changes in its articles of incorporation to allow it to issue preferred shares, it had no specific intention to issue such shares yet.
According to the plan, a seven-member committee would decide which banks would be allowed to sell their preferred shares to the Government. Banks with a sound financial background that ran into sudden shortages of money would most likely be allowed to take part, as would banks that purchase hobbled institutions and would be weakened by such purchases.
But Tokyo does not want to be seen rescuing poorly run banks, so some would presumably be judged ineligible and would be shut down.
Those accepted under the plan would sell shares to the special bank, which would be managed under the Deposit Insurance Corporation, a Government entity somewhat similar to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the United States.
The Deposit Insurance Corporation would be given a total of 30 trillion yen to help support the banks, with 13 trillion yen of that going toward the preferred-share plan. The remaining 17 trillion yen would be used in part to buy assets of weak banks, though details about exactly how that money would be allocated remained unclear.
Talk about the legislation over the last few weeks has stirred intense debate. Will such a bailout encourage more unsound risk taking and sloppy management? Or will it impose strict conditions, in the way the International Monetary Fund attaches conditions to money used to bail out countries?
Critics have long argued that the Finance Ministry, and banking and other Government officials, have tried to save financial institutions that were insolvent or nearly so, rather than let them collapse.
A Finance Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that strict conditions would be imposed on banks accepted into the plan. "We know that people very much worry that the Government is going to extend its helping hands to ailing financial institutions who do not deserve public support," the official said.
At the same time, he acknowledged that it would be difficult to penalize managers of ailing institutions or to force them out, because few executives would take their banks to the Government knowing that they would lose their jobs.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 7, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a plan to strengthen Japanese banks misidentified the country's biggest foreign debtor in some editions. It is Hong Kong; South Korea is the fourth-biggest.
Also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly in some editions to the Presidential administration that created the United States Reconstruction Finance Corporation, a 1930's effort similar to the Japanese Government's proposal. It was Herbert Hoover's, not Franklin D. Roosevelt's.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Boom, but Mostly for Planes

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Orders to American factories in November posted the largest increase in 14 months, but aircraft accounted for most of the gain and other industries showed signs of slowing.
The 2.5 percent advance to a seasonally adjusted $345.1 billion was the sixth in a row, after a revised increase of one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the Commerce Department said today. 
 Transportation orders surged 21 percent, the most since July 1991. For aircraft alone, orders doubled. Economists said airlines around the world need to replace their aging planes.
Excluding transportation, orders fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the second consecutive decline. And capital goods, like factory machinery used to make other goods, fell 1.5 percent excluding transportation and military orders.
"That may be one of the first signs that the Asian crisis is beginning to affect the U.S. markets, given that about half the capital goods produced in the United States are exported," said Cheryl Katz, an economist at Merrill Lynch.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Some newly issued stocks that flopped may deserve a second look.

BYLINE: By Reed Abelson 

 BODY:
NEW stocks seem more forlorn than neglected initial public offerings. Aimed at the moon, they fall with a thud, struck down by disappointing news or the sudden unpopularity of their business. They are left to languish in anonymity with few on Wall Street willing to give them a second look.
But some new issues may be prove to be worthwhile buys, according to Christian K. Stadlinger, a portfolio manager with Provident Capital Management in Philadelphia. Among the fallen offerings Mr. Stadlinger is considering is Ispat International N.V., a steel producer based in the Netherlands with nearly $2 billion in annual sales. Ispat is one of the fastest-growing steel companies. 
 Last August, the stock went public at $27. But the shares, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, dropped as low as $17.75 in mid-December after the company failed to win the bidding for a state-owned steelmaker in Venezuela. Falling steel prices have also scared many investors away from the stock, which traded yesterday at $19.125 a share, down $1.875.
Although further declines in the price of steel could make Ispat no bargain, Mr. Stadlinger wonders if investors are overreacting. At the stock's current price, Ispat has a price-earnings ratio of roughly nine times this year's estimated earnings, consistent with the other steel companies. But Mr. Stadlinger believes the company will be able to grow without going on a buying spree. "Fundamentally, it is a very, very nice company," he said.
The IRI International Corporation, a Houston-based maker of oil rigs and related equipment, is another example of a new offering that fell out of favor, Mr. Stadlinger said. Amid the enthusiasm early last year for oil-service companies, IRI went public in mid-November at $18 and quickly traded as high as $21.125.
Like other oil-service stocks, IRI was dragged down when oil prices fell. The stock, also listed on the New York Stock Exchange, traded yesterday at $13.1875, off 37.5 cents. Over the long term, IRI, which had sales of $242 million over the year ended last Sept. 30, should do pretty well, said Mr. Stadlinger, who is considering buying some shares.
Another new stock battered by sudden bad news -- its own -- is the National Research Corporation, a tiny company in Lincoln, Neb., that provides surveys of doctors and patients for health care organizations. Having sold 2.1 million shares in October at $15 each, the company announced less than two months later that it had lost its largest customer. That client, Kaiser Permanente-Northern California Region, accounted for 40 percent of its 1996 revenues of $12.6 million. The stock plummeted by nearly two-thirds, closing yesterday at $6.125, down 37.5 cents.
Linda Killian, an analyst and portfolio manager at the Renaissance Capital Corporation, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that specializes in the new-issue market, thinks National Research could a be a "very interesting" stock if "you still believe the company is viable, which it should be." The company's reliance on Kaiser had been declining and Kaiser had not been unhappy with National Research's work, Ms. Killian said.
The danger for investors in buying some of these stocks, she said, is that they may remain forever obscure. Wall Street analysts tend to focus only on those stocks that have already taken off.
National Research, for example, is largely covered by only two analysts at the two regional investment firms, William Blair and Robert W. Baird, which were responsible for taking the company public. Even IRI International is now followed by only one Wall Street firm, Lehman Brothers, also the company's underwriter.
Investors buying these stocks are also betting partly against the current market mood, which remains largely hostile to many small-company stocks.
For many investors, the strongest hint that new offerings had reached a peak came less than a month ago, when an investment banking company that specializes in taking other companies public went public itself -- and got a tepid response. The Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group, a company in Arlington, Va., that was one of the year's busiest underwriters, sold $220 million of its own shares in late December at $20 apiece. After a short spurt to $21.75 the stock has fallen, selling yesterday for $17.25, down 43.75 cents.
The doldrums in the new-issue market have quelled much enthusiasm for Friedman Billings and the stocks of other underwriters. Only investors willing to put all their money on the belief that the new-issue market will come roaring back should wager on Friedman Billings -- and investors are still refusing to pay much attention.

HEADLINE: Latin American Loans

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In contrasting the new hands-on government role in the Asian financial crisis with policy in the 1980's, a Jan. 1 Business Day article states that in the earlier period "the borrowers were Latin American governments, not the private sector." This is not entirely accurate.
In the earlier period, about 60 percent of Latin American loans were strictly private, but with the assistance of the United States Treasury Department and the International Monetary Fund, the banks forced Latin governments to guarantee private loans as a condition of further lending. 
 The result was that Government-guaranteed loans rose from 40 percent in 1982 to 85 percent in 1987, adding $44 billion, or 25 percent, to the public foreign debt obligations of the region. This, of course, violated the spirit of free enterprise and the theory of the disciplinary role of private risk-taking as seriously as any later bailouts.
 
EDWARD S. HERMAN
Narberth, Pa., Jan. 4, 1998
 
The writer is professor emeritus of finance at the Wharton School.

HEADLINE: Federal Express to Raise Shipping Rates

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The Federal Express Corporation said today that it would increase rates for shipments within the United States an average of 3 percent to 4 percent on Feb. 15 and would expand its international service to include cheaper freight delivery.
The Memphis-based company said it would begin international economy shipping Feb. 2. 
 "For the first time we will offer a time-definite, cost-effective shipping option for international freight," said Greg Rossiter, a spokesman for the company, the country's second-largest delivery concern.
The new service will provide delivery within five business days to important markets in other continents and will offer tracking of shipments, Mr. Rossiter said. Federal Express has offered only international priority service, with delivery in one to three days.
Last week the United Parcel Service of America Inc., the nation's largest package-delivery company, raised its domestic rates 3 percent to 4 percent, depending on the method of shipment. The Atlanta-based United Parcel also said it would add to its international services, though those rates will remain unchanged.
The rate increases come as the companies race to expand internationally and at home.
Federal Express plans to open a new sorting hub in Paris, and it recently added 100 workers to its hub in Frankfurt. In addition, the company said in October that it would spend $50 million on a new hub in Miami to bolster its Latin American business.
Shares of Federal Express rose $2.75, to $63.875, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Seizing the Initiative

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In his proposals to open Medicare to hundreds of thousands of people 55 to 64 years old, President Clinton has again found a way to appeal to voters while showing concern for middle-income families and putting Republicans on the defensive in an election year.
Republicans control both houses of Congress, but Mr. Clinton and his Capitol Hill allies still seem to set much of the agenda, especially on domestic policy issues like the minimum wage, health insurance and child care. 
 The basic Republican attack, renewed today, is that even if a program starts out with beneficiaries paying the full cost, subsidies will follow sooner or later, leading to a new, expensive entitlement.
Comments today by Administration officials showed why Republicans are concerned. While insisting that new Medicare beneficiaries would initially pay the full cost of their insurance coverage, the officials said Mr. Clinton might in the future propose Federal subsidies to help those unable to afford the cost, which would range from $3,600 to $5,000 a year.
The outlook for the President's proposals in Congress is more complex and uncertain than the simple partisan differences would suggest.
Labor unions and lobbyists for the elderly and near-elderly can put formidable pressure on Congress if they choose to do so. Business groups, especially the insurance industry, were generally cool to the President's proposals, but some employers may be glad to have their early retirees protected by Medicare. And the proposals for people 62 to 64 may be easier to enact than other parts of the package.
The costs of the new coverage may well exceed White House estimates, especially if -- as experts predict -- sick people are the ones most likely to buy Medicare coverage.
Republicans may ultimately be proved right on such points. But their warnings will probably not sway many voters this year unless the Republicans come up with alternatives to help older people who cannot obtain or afford health insurance because they have pre-existing medical problems or have lost their health insurance along with their jobs.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, asked today, "If the era of big government is over," as Mr. Clinton contends, "why is the President proposing all these Government expansions?"
Kevin P. Phillips, the political strategist and publisher of the American Political Report, said: "Clinton has a winning issue here for a number of different reasons. People feel there's so much money going to the affluent part of this society that they will support a program that helps those who need medical coverage just prior to reaching the Medicare eligibility age."
More generally, Mr. Phillips, who in recent years has strayed from his Republican roots, said: "Republicans are uniquely vulnerable on Medicare. Whatever they say, they really want to get rid of it. When Clinton forces them to deal with this issue, Republicans can't keep their eyes from blinking. Many of them look shifty."
Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, described the political potential of the issue today when he said the President's proposals would define the basic differences between the two parties. Republicans will eventually have to support major elements of the President's plan, Mr. Stark asserted, and if they continue to resist it, they do so "at their peril."
Mr. Thomas spoke for many Republicans when he described Mr. Clinton's proposals as "a crazy quilt patchwork system designed for political purposes."
The budget-balancing law signed by Mr. Clinton in August creates a bipartisan commission to study the future of Medicare and recommend ways of preserving it for baby boomers. The 17-member commission is supposed to issue its report by March 1, 1999, but has not begun work because Mr. Clinton and Congressional Republicans have been unable to agree on a chairman.
The commission is required to study the health insurance needs of people 62 to 64, but Mr. Thomas said Democrats wanted to use Medicare as a political issue in the next 10 months. "It's pure politics," he said.
Mr. Clinton's goals have not changed significantly since 1993, when he proposed an ambitious, unwieldy scheme to guarantee health insurance for all Americans. But his tactics have changed, as he pursues the same objective step by step.
"What I tried to do before won't work," Mr. Clinton conceded four months ago in a speech to the Service Employees International Union. "Maybe we can do it in another way. That's what we've tried to do, a step at a time until eventually we finish this."
E. Neil Trautwein, manager of health policy at the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said, "We are acutely uncomfortable with piecemeal expansion of health coverage, especially when it's done through a huge Government entitlement program like Medicare."
And Richard P. Coorsh, a spokesman for the Health Insurance Association of America, expressed concern about the precedent.
"This is the camel's nose under the tent," Mr. Coorsh said. "Why stop at people 62 to 64, or 55 to 64? Some people will argue that Medicare should be even more inclusive."
Mr. Clinton promised that taxpayers would not bear any of the cost of expanding Medicare, but it is easy to imagine demands for Federal subsidies in a few years.
Deborah Briceland-Betts, executive director of the Older Women's League, which lobbies for women over 40, said today: "It's important that any new program have subsidies for low-income people, who tend to be women. The vast majority of older women who need health insurance protection cannot take advantage of the President's proposal because they are too poor to pay the premiums. Administration officials told us today that they were eager to work with us to provide some kind of a remedy to make the coverage affordable."
Gene B. Sperling, assistant to the President for economic policy, did not rule out such proposals in the future.
"If there are programs that help people, that don't have overriding negative incentives in the market, and are fiscally responsible and being paid for," Mr. Sperling asked, "who would be against that?"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Small-Stock Fans Hoping For a January Effect Rally

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Fans of small-company stocks are beating the drum once again.
For months, they said small stocks were poised for a rally. When the rally failed to materialize, they began to look expectantly to January. 
 The subject of their attention: the oft-discussed January effect, which refers to the habit of small stocks outperforming big stocks early in the year. Partly because once such patterns are identified investors respond to wipe them out, there has not been a real January effect in three years.
A few days into 1998, there is not much evidence of one yet this year either.
Still, small-company stock followers say the fundamentals remain in place for a comeback -- if not in the first days of the year, in the coming months -- and point to relatively attractive prices to buttress their case.
Last year investors saw less risk in big stocks than in small stocks, said Mary Lisanti, who manages portfolios of small and midsize stocks for the Strong Funds in Minneapolis. "When does the psychology change?" she asked. "I don't know, but at some point it will. I'm not sure about a January effect, but maybe there will be a February effect or a March effect."
In the first few days of many years past, investors have bought back shares of smaller-company stocks that they had sold in previous months to realize losses for tax purposes. During the selling, some stocks got beaten down so much that they became bargains. In recent years, the selling and buying spree began earlier and earlier, so that by late November or early December, investors had already sold and repurchased small-cap securities.
For that reason, small-company stocks have not outperformed larger- company issues during the first quarters of the last few years, explained Melissa Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities.
But this year, many stock analysts predicted the January effect could return with a vengeance. As the Dow Jones industrial average posted gains of more than 20 percent in 1997 for the third year in a row, the prices of many small stocks slumped. Furthermore, earnings growth is now expected to slow for many big, multinational companies because of the Asian financial crisis. Small companies, by comparison, typically have a domestic orientation.
And small caps are cheap. The price-to-earnings ratio on small-company stocks, usually higher than that on big-cap stocks, has fallen, creating a gap between small and big stocks' P.E.'s roughly near the 1990 and 1987 lows, said James Stoeffel, a vice president and emerging growth stock analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "I think you have some good names that are ripe for a bounce," Mr. Stoeffel said recently. "My sense is that you will have a January effect."
More than 50 percent of the 420 small-cap stocks tracked by Nationsbank Montgomery Securities finished 1997 off more than 30 percent from their 52-week highs. Michael Moe, director of growth stock analysis at the firm, predicts a comeback and favors companies that do business on the Internet, including E-Trade, Onsale and Preview Travel.
"You have a lot of beaten-down small stocks, valuations are compelling from a historical perspective and interest rates are low," Mr. Moe said yesterday, adding that he was not willing to give up on the prospect of a January effect just because of three poor trading days.
Broad market indexes suffered yesterday, amid concerns about the impact of Asia's slowdown on banks and on oil companies. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 72.74 points, to 7,906.25, erasing its gains for the first days of this year. The Standard & Poor's 500-company stock index fell 10.49 points, or 1.1 percent, to 966.58. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 13.98 points, to 1,580.14, while the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks edged down 3.96 points, to 433.10.
Since its big decline on Oct. 27, the Dow has rebounded by 2.5 percent and the S.& P. 500 has gained 2.6 percent. Still, the Russell 2000 is down 3.2 percent.
"When stocks are this cheap, it tells me the bulk of the damage has been done," said John Laporte, portfolio manager of the $5 billion T. Rowe Price New Horizons fund. But "it doesn't tell me a turn is imminent. Small caps can remain cheap for a relatively extended period of time."
"My net outlook for 1998 is that small-cap growth will do fairly well," said Aasch Shah, who manages the $350 million Small-Cap Strategies fund of Federated Investors. But he does not expect a rally in the sector until the second quarter.

HEADLINE: News in U.S. Can Be 'Rumor' in Seoul, and Lead to Jail

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 6

 BODY:
What is most striking about Richard Choi is not so much that he is in a jail, wearing his prison uniform and wondering whether he will get the full five-year sentence for "spreading rumors."
Rather, it is that most people here seem to think it perfectly natural that a rumormonger should be behind bars. 
 The case of Mr. Choi, 49, an American journalist accused of broadcasting damaging rumors about Hankook Ilbo, a major Korean newspaper, marks the collision of two world views. He champions the notion of freedom of expression and aggressive reporting, while many South Koreans focus on the need for order, accuracy and responsibility.
"According to the mindset of the Korean people, anyone who fabricates rumors should be punished," said Park Jung Sam, an executive of Hankook Ilbo. "It is quite natural to punish someone like that."
Officials of Hankook Ilbo pressed to have him prosecuted for reporting, on a Korean-language radio station in Los Angeles, that it was in financial difficulty and would be acquired by a large conglomerate. Mr. Choi is expected to go on trial later this month.
In most countries an aggrieved party might file a civil suit for defamation and seek damages, but Hankook Ilbo filed a criminal complaint with the prosecutors, and so now Mr. Choi is in jail and has been indicted for the crime of spreading rumors.
Under South Korean law, there will be no jury trial. Instead, a judge will hear the case and will decide whether he is guilty and what prison term would be appropriate, up to a maximum of five years.
To critics, mostly abroad, the law underscores the problems that got South Korea into its present economic mess: a legal structure that protects crony capitalism and makes it risky to call attention to financial weaknesses. The imprisonment of Mr. Choi has enraged some people in Los Angeles and led to some calls for the United States to halt its bailout of the South Korean economy until he is released.
But in South Korea, no one seems to understand what the fuss is about.
"The American press is talking about freedom of the press and human rights, but ordinary people here are wondering what the issue is," said Mr. Park, the newspaper executive. He may be tough on rumors, but he is not just a caricature of an autocrat: in the 1970's he himself was imprisoned for his reporting about the dictatorship of the time.
The case comes as many Asian countries are still searching for the best place to put the fulcrum that balances free expression and social order. South Korea is growing more democratic, but it is fearful of North Korea and partly as a result has always put the priority on order and stability.
The law that Mr. Choi fell afoul of never attracted much notice until he, as an American citizen, was arrested for violating it. And even many South Korean liberals and former dissidents accept harsh national security laws that lead to the imprisonment of people who praise North Korea or even read North Korean propaganda.
In Mr. Choi's case, each side seems mystified by the attitude of the other.
"This is just like a bad dream," Mr. Choi's wife, Choi Young Yun, said today as she picked at a sandwich for her lunch at a Seoul hotel, her mascara smudged with tears. "If you steal, you go to jail. Or if you're a Communist, you go to jail. But nothing else. Even though I grew up here, I can't believe it."
Mrs. Choi said that since her husband's arrest, she had been able to see him, through a glass panel, for a visiting session of only seven minutes a day. So they touch their fingertips to the glass, to get as close as they can, and say, "I love you" -- in English, because it sounds strange to voice such intimacy in Korean.
The case arose when Mr. Choi, an American citizen who was born and grew up in South Korea, returned in December to cover the presidential election here. He is vice president of Radio Korea USA, the leading Korean-language radio station in Los Angeles, and thus a well-known figure in the Korean community in Los Angeles.
On Dec. 15, Mr. Choi made his report about Hankook Ilbo to his Los Angeles radio audience. Truth is a defense that under South Korean law can be used against charges of rumor-spreading, but Hankook Ilbo was not acquired, as Mr. Choi had suggested it would be, and the company said that although it was having financial difficulties, they were not as severe as Mr. Choi had reported.
When Radio Korea did not immediately retract the statement, Hankook Ilbo went to the prosecutors and filed a complaint. As it happened, the prosecutor's office was just cracking down on "rumormongering" under a statue that declares, "Anybody who makes false statements and thereby damages the credit or reputation of another person shall be subject to imprisonment of up to five years."
So the police burst into Mr. Choi's hotel room and arrested him on Dec. 19. He has been in jail since then, and his radio station and human rights groups have been organizing protests.
"I don't understand how an American reporter can be in jail for reporting the news," said Lee Jang Hee, the president of Radio Korea USA in Los Angeles. "This is a violation of his human rights."
"If this were a Caucasian journalist, this could not happen," Mr. Lee added.
The law apparently has never been applied to a foreign citizen before, although it has been used to imprison Korean reporters. Indeed, at the same time that Mr. Choi was arrested, the police seized two Koreans who work in the securities industry and charged them with the same crime of spreading rumors. Their plight has attracted no interest.
One complication in Mr. Choi's case is that his radio station's competitor is another Korean-language radio station in Los Angeles that is run by Hankook Ilbo. So Hankook Ilbo suggests that he was trying to destroy a competitor, while Mr. Choi's supporters say Hankook Ilbo is trying to manipulate the criminal law to punish its rival.
Many Koreans seem wary of coming across as authoritarians but still insist that the criminal libel law is needed to punish rumormongers.
"Korean businesses have no methods to defend themselves from the arrows of media attacks," said Oh Dong Su, a director of the Federation of Korean Industries. He said financial issues should be discussed in public with great delicacy.
"It is true that the Hankook Ilbo was experiencing financial difficulties," he said. "But this is not something that we can blurt out."
