HEADLINE: Whitman Lures Builders to Tainted Sites

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: EDGEWATER, N.J., Jan. 6

 BODY:
As crews demolished the contaminated remains of an 83-year-old factory behind her, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill today that is intended to entice developers to build on thousands of pollution-tainted industrial sites around the state.
The law, some developers and urban planners said, could spur urban renewal by shifting the construction of new commercial buildings and housing from suburbs to places like downtown Newark, Trenton or long-abandoned spots along the Hudson River waterfront. 
 The bill was opposed by some New Jersey environmental groups for giving too much control over the extent of a cleanup to the companies responsible for polluting a site and for limiting public access to cleanup plans.
But Mrs. Whitman rejected the criticisms and a call for a conditional veto, saying the bill would both protect the environment and help bring new economic activity to long-dormant so-called brownfields around the state. "Today hundreds of these sites lie fallow, a blight and burden to the state of New Jersey," Mrs. Whitman said. "We must make reusing brownfields truly worth the effort. Today we begin to do just that."
The bill creates tax incentives equal to up to three-fourths of the cost of cleaning a site and offers a cash credit to small developers who test new technologies for sealing off or eliminating pollution. But the most important provision of the new law, according to several developers and urban planners, exempts anyone who buys and restores one of the 8,800 tainted sites in New Jersey from any new cleanup costs once state environmental officials approve the job.
A buyer of a tainted tract can also be protected from private lawsuits related to past pollution problems if a cleanup is approved by the State Department of Environmental Protection and completed promptly.
The prospect of lawsuits and the lack of clearly defined costs in fixing a site -- whether heavily or lightly polluted -- have until now discouraged potential buyers, said Ronald Bruder, chairman of the Dames & Moore/Brookhill Corporation, a Manhattan real estate and engineering company that has bought tainted sites in dozens of states but until now not in New Jersey or New York.
"The issue has always been certainty -- to be able to say for certain to your lender that this cleanup is going to cost $5 million," Mr. Bruder said. Until the signing of the bill in New Jersey, there was always the prospect of new cleanup orders and more costs, he said, adding that New York and Connecticut still lacked similar laws.
"Now in New Jersey at least you have a rational way of going forward," Mr. Bruder said. "Our appetite there is much stronger than it was a week ago. Probably in a year we'll have some things going there."
Some representatives of private environmental groups said they planned to push for revisions to the law in the new legislative session, saying that too many controls and standards for cleanups of polluted tracts were weakened.
Under the new law, developers, without involvement by the community, can choose a level of cleanliness for a site depending on the planned new use. A site intended for an industrial or commercial building would not have to be as thoroughly cleaned as a site intended for housing.
"The bill ends existing legal requirements for community involvement and ends making cleanups consistent with local master plans," said Timothy Dillingham, the director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, a private group. For example, he said, a community might be trying to encourage the construction of housing, but a developer might decide to clean a site to a standard that is only sufficient for a commercial enterprise like a mall.
"Whenever the public is excluded from decisions affecting public health and the future of their neighborhood, we think that's bad policy," Mr. Dillingham said.
Robert C. Shinn, the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, said that under the new law his agency could still require public hearings in the cleanup process. "There are lots of safeguards," he said. He added that if a company failed to meet standards set in a cleanup plan, it lost the advantages offered under the new law.
Mrs. Whitman pointed to the crews working to tear down the abandoned Alcoa factory behind her, which made toothpaste tubes and other aluminum products from 1914 until 1965, as an example of what could soon happen around the state.
Oil that contained PCB's, a toxic chemical, had permeated the concrete floors of the building over the decades, and the site lay fenced and forgotten for 30 years.
After months of talks with local residents and officials from Edgewater, Bergen County and the State Department of Environmental Protection, Daibes Brothers, a local developer, began the demolition and decontamination and planned to build a 460-unit complex of apartment buildings.
Fred Daibes, the company's chief executive, said that this kind of project would now be far easier.
"In the past, you'd get into the bureaucracy of the D.E.P. and it scared the hell out of the developers because they knew there was no end in sight," Mr. Daibes said. "Now you're going to have to abide by all of the laws, but at least you know there's an end."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Journal;
Ban on Leaf Blowers Is Voted, and Noise Ensues

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6

 BODY:
To the mostly Hispanic gardeners who use it, it is a labor-saving tool of their trade as vital as the truck or the telephone. To the mostly affluent Angelenos who have led a 12-year campaign to ban it, it is a noisy, filthy contraption that fouls the air and shatters the calm of their well-kept streets.
Whichever the case, the Los Angeles City Council today voted its final approval of an ordinance that would ban the humble gasoline-powered leaf blower from use in residential neighborhoods. The vote followed a bitter debate that ranged across issues of cultural imperialism, environmental correctness and economic elitism. It also left 11 people -- gardeners and their supporters -- continuing a hunger strike in protest on the steps of City Hall. 
 "We're all victims of these machines," the actor Peter Graves, whose wife, Joan, has crusaded for the ban, told the Council in solemn "Mission: Impossible" tones before the vote this morning.
But in protest, Adrian Alvarez, a spokesman for the Association of Latin American Gardeners of Los Angeles, formed last year to fight the ban, has been drinking only water and Gatorade in a three-tent encampment on the South Lawn of City Hall since last Friday. He said the ban was a severe blow to the livelihood of gardeners, many of them recent immigrants, who use the blowers to groom upward of a dozen yards a day and routinely receive as little as $70 a month for weekly visits to a house.
"We're all aware that leaf blowers make noise," said Mr. Alvarez, an artist who joined the gardeners' cause in sympathy. "We've never denied that. But do you deny us a vital tool, or do you pressure industry to come up with a better, quieter tool? This ordinance was exclusively designed to address the concerns of an elite minority of residents."
In fact, the leaf blower has long been a fixture in a place where residents pay almost as much attention to their perennially verdant lawns as they do to their perpetually spotless cars, though several neighboring communities, including Beverly Hills, have already banned it.
The Los Angeles Council first passed a ban in December 1996, then delayed enforcement until this Jan. 1 to give the city time to figure out how to go about issuing citations for misdemeanors that could draw a $1,000 fine and six months in jail.
Then, last month, just weeks before the ban was to take effect, the Council passed an amendment that reduced the offense to the level of a violation, with fines of $100, plus $170 in court costs, for gardeners or the property owners who hire them. Because that vote was not unanimous, however, the Council was required to vote on the amendment again today, and it passed by 9 to 6.
The bill now goes to Mayor Richard J. Riordan, who is expected to allow it to become law. But blower manufacturers have filed a lawsuit seeking to overturn the ban, and Mr. Alvarez and his colleagues vowed to continue their fast in hopes of inspiring a mayoral veto.
Jack Allen, former City Attorney of Beverly Hills, who drafted its anti-blower ordinance in 1985, testified today that efforts to regulate the blowers by limiting their noise levels -- as the gardeners want -- had proved impractical, because an expert technician with a sensitively calibrated measuring machine has to catch an offender in the act. That is all but impossible.
"We tried to regulate it, but there was just no way," said Mr. Allen, who himself lives in the quiet Los Angles enclave of Pacific Palisades and gave his own gardener a raise for agreeing not to use a blower.
Joan Graves, who has lived with her actor husband in Pacific Palisades for 47 years, helped organize other celebrities to fight for the ban, among them Julie Newmar, the original Catwoman on the old "Batman" television show, and Meredith Baxter, who played the mother on "Family Ties."
Mrs. Graves said her gardeners had never used a blower.
"We have never allowed our gardener to use a blower," her husband corrected her.
But City Councilman Mike Hernandez passionately defended the blowers as "a vital tool" of the working class, and told the packed Council chamber, "You need to understand that it is an emotional issue to gardeners."
Indeed it was, as several hundred gardeners in baseball caps and work jackets filed quietly into the ornate Council chambers this morning, with scores more waiting outside. As the gardeners lined up to get in, one of their leaders addressed them in Spanish, explaining the procedures.
At that, an older gardener with a pronounced Irish brogue piped up: "This is America, you know! You're supposed to speak English!"
Whereupon a Hispanic gardener retorted: "This is a democracy! You can vote to speak whatever language you want!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Adrian Alvarez addressed other protesters yesterday after the Los Angeles City Council voted to ban gasoline-powered leaf blowers, like the one on the back of the demonstrator at right, from residential areas. (Jill Connelly for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Long Bond's Yield 5.72%, a New Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices ended higher for the fourth straight session yesterday, pushing yields further into record-low territory and inducing more corporate borrowers to sell debt.
Although the appetite for bonds was not as hearty as on Monday, investors were still motivated to buy on resilient speculation that the Federal Reserve's next adjustment of interest-rate policy might be down. Lower rates tend to enhance the value of bonds already in circulation. 
 The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond closed up 9/32, to a price of 105 25/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.72 percent, beating the record low of 5.74 percent set on Monday.
Long-term prices initially fell but rallied in the late afternoon after corporate debt sales were met with good demand, a sign that the broader pressures pushing up bond prices have not peaked. Securities dealers who had sold long-term Treasuries ahead of the uncertainty over those corporate sales bought them back.
"The initial selling came from large hedge funds," said Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. He also attributed some of the early selling to dealers who were taking profits from the recent rally on "perhaps a feeling that the bond market had overshot reality."
Among the $2 billion of corporate debt priced was International Business Machines' $700 million of 30-year debentures through Merrill Lynch, yielding 6.5 percent, about 79 basis points above the Government's long bond. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Following are results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new 52-week bills:

HEADLINE: Message by Pataki to Outline Proposals to Improve Schools

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's annual address to the Legislature will offer an array of proposals intended to improve the academic performance of students, including intensive English courses for immigrants and remedial summer classes for low-achieving fourth-grade students, according to his aides.
He will also use his fourth State of the State Message on Wednesday to emphasize many of the major educational initiatives adopted during last year's legislative session, including some proposed by his Democratic rivals in the Legislature. They range from increasing financing for textbooks and computers to expanding the number of prekindergarten slots. 
 By focusing on education in his election-year address, the Republican Governor appears intent on deflecting some of the criticism he has endured over his efforts to cut funds for schools during the early days of his administration. It also may help him moderate an image that he has built with an agenda that has largely stressed cutting taxes, toughening penalties on criminals and putting welfare recipients to work.
He will also use his address to the Legislature's 211 members to propose initiatives covering a variety of other topics, from crime and taxes to economic development, his aides said. Mr. Pataki has spent the last week writing the speech, which lays out his legislative agenda for 1998.
Among his more ambitious educational proposals is a plan to offer a financial incentive for school districts to provide fourth-grade students remedial instruction in English during the summer. Though aides gave few details, they said the plan would generally compensate school districts for 80 percent of the cost of running a six-week summer program for students who do poorly on standardized English tests.
Mr. Pataki is also expected to make a pitch for a proposal to require the state to give school districts more money for remedial instruction for students who show limited proficiency in English between kindergarten and the second grade. His aides did not provide an estimate of the program's cost. Nor did they say how many students they expect to qualify for the program.
In his message, the Governor will also promote a plan that would establish after-school programs at schools for students in kindergarten through 12th grade. The program, which would run between 3 P.M. and 7 P.M., would be paid for through a combination of state, local and private financing. Pataki aides did not say how much the plan would cost.
Mr. Pataki's aides said he would also push for two pieces of legislation that he has proposed in the past. The first would allow parents, teachers and community groups to create so-called charter schools that are financed by taxpayers but operate independently of local school boards.
The second would give teachers more control over their schools by allowing them for the first time to suspend disruptive children from their classrooms for up to 10 days. The suspension initiative did not survive the 1996 legislative session; the charter proposal failed last year.
Mr. Pataki's package of proposals drew qualified support from Sheldon Silver, the Democratic-led Assembly's Speaker. Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said he would take a serious look at the proposals once they were drafted in bill form. "But we will have to see more details," she said.
The Governor's aides said he would again call for overhauling the special-education program by eliminating financial incentives that have encouraged schools to place mildly disabled students in expensive segregated classrooms. That program has been widely criticized for years as an inefficient bureaucracy that shunts too many children, a disproportionate number of whom are black and Hispanic boys, into separate classrooms with virtually no prospect of returning to regular classes.
The Governor's aides said he intended to hammer out a plan with Richard P. Mills, the Education Commissioner, who has proposed his own plan for improving the program.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Faltering I.M.F. Bailouts Raise New Fears About Asia
With the International Monetary Fund's bailout plans for Thailand and Indonesia starting to fray, Clinton Administration officials are privately worrying about whether the tough I.M.F. prescriptions for rescuing the entire Asian region -- including South Korea -- will work.
In the last two days, the Thai and Indonesian currencies have plummeted to new depths on Thailand's effort to renegotiate easier terms for its I.M.F. bailout and Indonesia's continued resistance to austerity pledges it made to the lending agency months ago. One of the most significant challenges came yesterday from President Suharto of Indonesia, above, who announced big increases in Government spending in defiance of a key condition for the I.M.F.'s $40 billion rescue. Page A1. 

Indonesia proposed an optimistic budget with few cutbacks, avoiding the tough austerity measures analysts say are needed to restore confidence. D2.
 
Florida Utility to Buy Maine Power
A Florida utility is buying the nonnuclear generating plants of Central Maine Power for $846 million and plans to jointly build two natural gas power plants. The moves are part of the effort to deregulate energy and reduce the high electric rates in New England. D5.
 
Unisys to Take a $1.1 Billion Charge
The new chief executive of Unisys announced that the company planned to leave the personal computer business and write off its acquisition of Sperry, resulting in a $1.1 billion charge to fourth-quarter earnings. D3.
 
Small Stocks Are Poised to Jump
Shares of small-company stocks are believed by some to rally in the early part of each year, which is known as the January effect. Although this has not happened in the last three years and so far in 1998, many analysts believe the time is now for the beaten-down sector. Yesterday, the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks slipped 3.96 points, to 433.10. D8.
 
Some initial public offerings have fallen steeply, but are looking attractive to some portfolio managers. Market Place. D9.
 
Bond Yields Tumble Again
Bond prices rose, pushing yields down to 5.72 percent, lower than the record of 5.74 percent set on Monday. D8.

A Surge in Factory Orders
Factory orders rose 2.5 percent in November, the largest increase in 14 months, but aircraft accounted for most of the gain. D9.
 
Seeking to End Good Life of Debtors
Florida, Texas and several other states are debtors' paradises, because residents can file for bankruptcy protection but still keep their luxurious homes, wages and other assets. But a Government commission and others are urging lawmakers to end the disparity. A1.
 
Wells BDDP Dismissed by Liberty
Liberty Mutual Insurance has dismissed Wells BDDP, becoming the latest longtime client to end its relationship with that agency. The others were Bristol-Myers Squibb and the Swiss watch account of TAG Heuer.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D4.
 
A Tobacco Ad Plan in 1993
An internal company document shows that Philip Morris Companies considered a plan in 1993 to "unilaterally begin work on legislation to modify, restrict or reform advertising of cigarettes to young people." A12.
 
Iraq to Resume Oil Sales Soon
Iraq said it would resume selling oil as soon as possible, after the United Nations approved a plan for distributing humanitarian supplies bought with the oil revenues. A5.

HEADLINE: Despite Carnage, Algeria Shuns Aid Offers

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 6

 BODY:
As reports mounted that Islamic militants were committing atrocities against Algerian civilians, France and its European Union partners struggled today with Algerian Government resistance to any attempt to bring international pressure to bear to stop the killings.
The Algerian newspaper La Tribune reported today that "several hundred people" were burned alive on Sunday night in a village in Relizane province in western Algeria, where 412 men, women and children were reportedly slaughtered last week by Islamic rebels opposed to the country's military-backed Government. 
 La Tribune also said that 117 civilians were killed in a separate attack on Saturday night in the same area.
Germany's Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, called over the weekend for the dispatch of a European Union mission to Algeria to offer help to the Algerian Government in dealing with the crisis. France, Denmark and Portugal expressed support, and European officials will discuss the crisis in Brussels next week. But today, as it has in the past, Algeria rejected all outside interference in its internal affairs.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, welcomed the show of concern by European countries and the United States, which expressed support today for international inquiries into the massacres. But Algerian officials rejected the soundings about the possibility of sending a United Nations mission to Algeria, diplomats said.
France strongly condemned the massacres in a statement on Monday that called on the Algerian Government to do its duty to insure the security of the civilian population. The Algerian Foreign Ministry and much of the Algerian press responded by accusing the French Government of unacceptable interference in Algerian internal affairs.
"I don't say that there isn't anything that can be done," Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France said at a gathering at the Quai d'Orsay today, but he reminded interlocutors that by the end of the colonial war in Algeria not even 600,000 French and Algerian colonial soldiers were able to defeat the movement for independence in the 1950's.
Between 60,000 and 75,000 people are believed to have been killed in violence that began six years ago after the Government canceled an election that Islamic parties in the Islamic Salvation Front, since outlawed, were poised to win.
As the European colonial power that ruled Algeria for more than a century until it wrested independence from Paris in 1962, France is expected by its European allies to take the lead in diplomatic efforts to try to stop the new carnage.
But French officials say they are not sure that all the violence is the work of Islamic militants, and some suspect that the Algerian Government may have incited atrocities against villages sympathetic to the rebels or left them open to attack.
But there are other considerations for France as well. Today about five million Muslims, most from North Africa, live largely relegated to ugly urban development projects surrounding French cities, where members of the fundamentalist Armed Islamic Group, thought to be responsible for some of the worst violence in Algeria, recruited disillusioned youths in 1995 and 1996.
The group terrorized France with bombings of subway stations that killed a dozen people and wounded hundreds, with the aim of pressuring France to cut off relations with the Algerian Government. French police are still patrolling the Paris subways today because of those bombings, but the killings in Algeria never stopped.
With European aid and trade credits totaling only $300 million in 1996, European countries including France have little leverage over Algeria. Though American and European oil companies invest heavily in oil operations there, the idea of sending troops to stop terrorism strikes officials in both the United States and Europe as unacceptable.
"I'd like to see the first country that will send its military there," Belgium's Foreign Minister, Eric Derycke, said today.
The French Government statement condemned the massacres of more than 400 people at the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan as "acts of barbaric savagery," but carefully avoided pinning them on Islamic militants.
"The French authorities, in the most absolute manner, condemn these terrorist crimes, which can have no justification, especially a religious one," the statement said. "They recall the legitimate right of the Algerian population to be protected. The duty of any Government is to allow its citizens to live in peace and security."
Calling on President Liamine Zeroual to continue changes that produced multiparty elections last year, even though the outlawed Islamic parties remained banned, France said, "It is essential that this process should lead rapidly to authentic democratization that would allow the integration into political life of all forces desiring to put an end to the violence and participating in the reconstruction of a peaceful Algeria."
The Algerian authorities, who have rebuffed past outside attempts to negotiate a reconciliation with the Islamic movement, reacted with indignation. "The French authorities have no right to remind the Algerian Government of its duties, and it is out of place that they suggest solutions while Algeria is carrying out its own approach to end the crisis," the Foreign Ministry in Algiers said today.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Envoy on Trouble Spots
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (By The New York Times) -- The State Department said today that it had dispatched an envoy to Paris for talks on Wednesday with French officials that will focus on Iran, Iraq and Algeria.
A State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said that the envoy, Thomas Pickering, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, will deal primarily with policy on Iraq and Iran but that the intensifying violence in Algeria may also come up.
On Monday, the State Department called for an international inquiry into the Algerian massacres, asking nongovernmental organizations and the United Nations to take charge of the investigations.
American officials said Mr. Pickering would also give French officials a detailed briefing on the results of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's trip to Africa in December. Before she left, she had discussed Africa with Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine, but she wanted them to have a better understanding of her views after the trip, the officials said.
Human rights groups welcomed the United States' support for an international inquiry into the massacres.

HEADLINE: Vallone Urges Lower Tuition for CUNY's Best

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, is proposing that the City University offer half-price tuition for two years to students who maintain at least a B average in high school and college, saying that such a policy would encourage academic excellence and hard work.
Mr. Vallone's plan, which he is to announce today in his annual address to the Council, represents his latest attempt to position himself for a gubernatorial run by concentrating on issues that he can use to criticize Gov. George E. Pataki. 
 Tuition at the CUNY system, whose governing board is controlled by the Governor, has risen since Mr. Pataki took office in 1995. Tuition is now $3,200 a year for the senior colleges at CUNY, up from $2,450 in 1994, and $2,500 for the community colleges, up from $2,100, CUNY officials said.
"The cost of higher education is one of the biggest burdens confronting the working class," Michael S. Clendenin, director of communications for Mr. Vallone, said yesterday. "Instead of support from Albany, the city and state universities find themselves under attack."
The cost of the plan would be about $38 million annually, which Mr. Vallone proposes to finance from the city's budget, his aides said. The current CUNY budget is more than $1.2 billion -- $110 million from the city, $620 million from the state, and $525 million from tuition payments, officials said.
Mr. Vallone, a Queens Democrat, is also expected to detail in the speech an ambitious proposal to keep all public elementary schools in the city open from 3 P.M. to 7 P.M. on school days for after-school programs. The proposal would eventually cost the city about $150 million annually, and Mr. Vallone wants the state and Federal governments, as well as private institutions, to pay most of the bill, his aides said.
Although student leaders applauded Mr. Vallone's CUNY plan, it comes just as a debate over grade inflation is roiling the system, with many of the trustees calling for stricter standards. About half the course grades given at CUNY are A's and B's, officials have said.
Some critics of CUNY, including aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, pointed out that if it was so easy to attain high grades, then qualifying for the tuition reduction would not be much of an achievement.
Mr. Giuliani, who has repeatedly assailed CUNY for what he says are lax standards, has the authority to block the proposal by refusing to approve the allocation of city money to pay for it.
"There is no way to know what a particular grade even means in that system," Randy M. Mastro, the deputy mayor for operations, said in a statement. "So rather than focus on givebacks, the focus should be on developing higher standards."
Aides to Mr. Pataki, who could also defeat the proposal, expressed little enthusiasm for it. "We don't hear a lot that makes sense that comes out of that office," said Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's press secretary, referring to the Council leadership. "But we are certainly willing to take a look at it."
Herman Badillo, who was appointed vice chairman of the CUNY board of trustees by Mr. Pataki, reacted more positively, saying that while he was concerned about grade inflation, the board should nonetheless consider the plan.
"I support the idea, provided that the grades earned are not given away through grade inflation," Mr. Badillo said.
Mizanoor Biswas, a student representative on the CUNY board, said a tuition cut could have a marked impact on the lives of some poor students. "I couldn't get better news for 1998 than this," Mr. Biswas said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSES OPENING MEDICARE TO THOSE 55 TO 65

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton proposed a significant expansion of Medicare today, to allow hundreds of thousands of early retirees, laid-off workers and uninsured Americans between the ages of 55 and 65 to enroll in the Federal health care program for the elderly.
The proposal addresses the problem of a growing group of Americans who are at high risk of losing their health insurance through layoffs or reductions in corporate benefits. The three million uninsured people in this group, known by insurance statisticians as the "near elderly," are too young for Medicare and not poor enough for Medicaid, the insurance program for the poor and disabled. 
 Although the proposal was immediately criticized by many Republicans, the President said it would pay for itself and, for the first time, make health care coverage available for hundreds of thousands of people who could not otherwise find or afford it.
"This is an entirely new way of adapting a program that has worked in the past to the needs of the future," Mr. Clinton said at a morning ceremony at the White House. "For many Americans, access to quality health care can mean the difference between a secure, healthy and productive life and the enormous burden of illness and worry and enormous financial strain."
Individuals who choose to buy into the expanded Medicare program would pay $3,600 to $5,000 a year, depending on their ages.
The proposal represents another incremental step toward providing health insurance for the 41 million Americans who currently lack it. Since the Administration's universal health care initiative was rejected by Congress in 1994, Mr. Clinton has tried in less ambitious ways to extend health benefits to the uninsured, most recently in the 1997 budget agreement that extends Government-financed medical care to an estimated 5 million low-income children. News Analysis, page A14.
But enactment of the Administration's new Medicare proposal is by no means certain and the plan is likely to become a political issue in Congressional elections this year. Even before it was announced today, Republican leaders in Congress complained that the proposal would create a new Medicare entitlement at a time when the program already faces long-term financial strains.
"Before Congress considers expansion of a program that is already going bankrupt, several important concerns must be addressed," said Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who heads the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. "I'm cautious because every time Washington promises something for free, the taxpayers end up footing a bigger and bigger bill. In this case, the cost of the proposed expansion puts taxpayers at risk of seeing their taxes hiked and Medicare beneficiaries are at risk of having their benefits reduced."
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who heads the House Budget Committee, predicted flatly that the Republican-led Congress would reject the Clinton plan.
On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton plans to offer a major initiative to help working families obtain child care, with a variety of new Federal subsidies and tax breaks. Administration officials and Congressional aides said the package would cost $20 billion over five years.
Congressional aides said they had been told that the package would include more than $7 billion to bolster the Child Care and Development Block Grant, which provides money to states, mainly to subsidize child care for low-income families. The President will also seek an increase in the Federal income tax credit that parents can take for child care expenses, at an estimated cost of $5 billion over five years.
The President's plan will also include a new tax credit for businesses that establish or run child care centers for workers, or reserve places in existing centers. Mr. Clinton will also ask Congress for money to improve the training of child care workers, to finance care for older children after school and to expand the Head Start program for preschool children. The proposals are all subject to approval by Congress.
Administration officials said today that the Medicare proposal was designed to aid those who had lost jobs and health benefits in the corporate downsizing of the past decade. Private insurance for the healthiest people ages 55 through 64 costs $5,000 a year or more, while those with chronic illnesses like diabetes, high blood pressure, ulcers and kidney ailments often find they cannot buy private insurance at any price.
There are 22 million Americans ages 55 through 64; roughly 3 million of them now have no health insurance. Administration officials estimate that 300,000 people in this age group will take advantage of the Medicare proposal, if it is enacted.
But the plan is designed to deal with the baby boom bulge of people in that age group coming after the turn of the century. By 2010, there are expected to be 35 million such Americans, and if the current reductions in employee benefits continue, there will be many millions more without health care coverage.
The Administration plan would allow those ages 62 through 64, who want Medicare coverage, to buy into the program for about $300 a month. When they become eligible for full Medicare benefits at 65, they would then have to pay $10 to $20 a month above the premium for physician services, which is now $43.80 a month. Hospitalization for Medicare recipients is paid for by payroll taxes on current workers.
The plan would benefit those who lose health coverage sponsored by their spouse's employer, when their spouse qualifies for Medicare. It would also provide a reasonably priced option for those with existing medical conditions that make private health insurance unavailable or prohibitively expensive.
In addition, laid-off workers, beginning at age 55, could participate in a similar Medicare coverage plan, although they would have to pay the full cost of insurance from the time they enroll. Older workers who become unemployed often cannot find new jobs; half never work full-time again and few get company-paid health insurance. Officials estimated that individuals in this group could join Medicare for about $400 a month.
The President also proposed expanding the "Cobra" program that lets retirees buy into their former employers' health plans, to guarantee their coverage through age 64. Cobra health care continuation benefits now expire after a maximum of three years.
In recent years, the number of companies offering retiree health benefits has been shrinking. In 1993, only about half of retirees from medium-sized or large companies were covered by company plans; in 1985, the figure was 75 percent.
The proposal would allow companies to charge a somewhat higher premium for continued Cobra coverage. Workers now pay an average of 102 percent of their former employers' cost of health insurance to obtain Cobra coverage; the extra amount is used to cover administrative expenses. The Administration's extended plan would allow employers to charge premiums of as much as 125 percent of their cost.
The White House said that the $2 billion to $3 billion in start-up costs for the program would be financed by unspecified savings from reducing fraud and waste in the Medicare program. The proposal is designed to be fully self-supporting after five years, officials said.
"Americans aged 55 and above tend to need more health care services, and have higher health care costs than most younger people in our society," said Horace B. Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons. "For people who are younger spouses of Medicare enrollees; for those who retire and their former employer terminates their health insurance, and for people who are downsized out of their jobs -- this proposal could make a real difference."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Budget Opportunities;
Mr. Clinton's Deficit Coup

 BODY:
President Clinton's surprise decision to propose the first balanced budget in a generation may not by itself have much impact on taxes, spending or the economy. But it was a shrewdly symbolic move to transform the way these issues are debated politically. By moving three years ahead of schedule to eliminate the Federal deficit, the Administration will be on firmer ground to oppose reflexive Republican demands for tax cuts. The prospect of a balanced budget has also cleared room for Mr. Clinton to promote disciplined plans for meeting neglected needs.
Since the first term of President Reagan, gaping Federal deficits have made it all but impossible for mainstream politicians to advocate new Federal spending, even for important programs. The budget is now close to being in balance because of recent spending restraint, a series of tax increases -- especially those under Presidents Bush and Clinton -- and, most important, a prosperous economy. The balance is temporary, however. In the next several years the growing cost of health and retirement programs is projected to throw the budget back into the red, and reckless tax cuts will only make the problem worse. 
 President Clinton has already signaled his willingness to spend some additional money in sensible areas, such as education, food safety and the environment. The Administration is also talking about limited tax breaks to reduce automobile emissions and pay for child care for working families. But the Administration is commendably avoiding the big new tax cuts that some Republicans have started advocating.
The end of Federal deficits, even if temporary, could remind Republicans to be careful what they wish for. The party faces infighting over whether to advocate tax cuts for the wage-earning voters it needs to attract or the affluent Americans who expect the Republican Party to deliver more Reagan-style windfalls. Some G.O.P. deficit hawks warn against any revenue decreases right now. Others welcome any tax cut that could force the Government to shrink in size.
As it burgeoned during the Reagan and Bush years, the deficit came to have a greater political than fiscal significance. Understanding his own and his party's vulnerability on that issue was one of Mr. Clinton's signal accomplishments. His bigger challenge, especially with a Republican Congress, will be converting this tactical coup into policies that will be remembered beyond his final term.

HEADLINE: Weaker Yen Pushes Stocks Higher in Tokyo

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Japanese stocks rose today, led by exporters like the Bridgestone Corporation that stand to benefit from the yen's weakness against the dollar.
Stocks also rose in South Korea, reflecting some modestly improved confidence that the nation will overcome its financial crisis and avert default on billions of dollars in overseas loans. 
 But plummeting currency values elsewhere in Asia, particularly in Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia, hurt several stock markets and reinforced pessimism about the region's economic outlook. Hong Kong's key Hang Seng Index lost 472.02 points to close the morning session at 9,663.49, down 4.6 percent. Singapore's main index fell 3.83 percent, Malaysia fell 3.67 percent and the Philippines fell 4.02 percent.
The Japanese stock market's benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 62.04 points, or 0.42 percent, finishing the morning session at 14,958.44. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index slipped 1.02 points, or 0.09 percent, to 1,159.63.
Traders said the primary force strengthening Japanese stocks was the weak yen, which enables Japanese exporters to lower prices in overseas markets and expands dollar-denominated revenue.
The dollar cost 134.21 yen by midday in Tokyo, stronger than its 133.65-yen level in New York on Tuesday and the highest level in nearly six years.
Bridgestone rose 110 yen, to 2,930. Sony climbed 100 yen, to 12,000. NEC gained 30 yen, to 1,460. About 110 million shares traded as of late morning, roughly the same level as on Tuesday morning.
In Seoul, the main stock index rose 1.57 percent as investors bought shares of big companies that have been hurt in recent weeks. Analysts said foreign investors appeared to be turning somewhat positive on the market because of efforts by the International Monetary Fund and other creditors to accelerate disbursement of emergency loans.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
With the Focus on South Korea, Thai and Indonesian Aid Falters

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
As the United States has focused on rescuing South Korea, the emergency programs to stabilize Thailand and Indonesia have begun to unravel, raising new fears about the effectiveness of the International Monetary Fund's prescriptions for stabilizing large regions of Asia.
With investors still stampeding out of Asian markets, the currencies of Thailand and Indonesia have plummeted to new lows, defying months of efforts to restore confidence and making it far more costly for companies to repay crushing debts denominated in dollars and Japanese yen. 
 On Monday, Thailand announced that it would ask the I.M.F. to ease the terms of a $17.2 billion bailout package. Indonesia has so far refused to honor several key conditions of its nearly $40 billion rescue package. And today, President Suharto said his Government would increase spending by 24 percent next year despite pledges of austerity.
Clinton Administration officials insist it is premature to call the bailout efforts a failure, noting that Mexico fell into months of economic pain after a restructuring of its economy began early in 1995. But while the officials seem optimistic that Thailand has belatedly begun to honor its loan terms, they make no secret of rising tension with Indonesia.
At the end of December, the I.M.F. sent President Suharto, Asia's longest-serving leader, a strongly worded letter urging his officials to carry out economic changes. Members of the Suharto family and close friends of the President, who hold financial stakes in the country's most lucrative businesses, have sought to dilute or evade such reforms. Twice in the last week, the Indonesian military, projecting unemployment soon of two million workers, said it stood ready to suppress protests that "disturb national stability."
"There's no question that we're in deep trouble again in Southeast Asia," a senior adviser to President Clinton said today. "The political problems are getting a lot more complicated. And the markets are having trouble sorting out which countries are tackling their problems, and which are not."
Yet the economic magnitude of Thailand and Indonesia pale by comparison with that of South Korea, and all three pale in size compared with Japan. Washington's real fear is that renewed economic instability among the relatively small Asian countries could spread beyond control.
Early in July, Thailand's decision to abandon the longtime link between its currency and the dollar set in motion a domino effect that brought down the currencies of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and eventually South Korea. That cycle can accelerate because each devaluation makes a country's exports less expensive overseas, forcing other nations to devalue to stay competitive.
But it is less clear that a similar pattern is about to be repeated. Each country in the Asian crisis has distinct problems, and eventually, Administration officials and economists say, investors will recognize the differences.
"We are dealing with a self-reinforcing process," George Soros, the billionaire hedge-fund manager and a central figure in the three-dimensional chess game under way between investors, governments and the I.M.F., wrote last week. "Once it is reversed, it could become self-reinforcing in the opposite direction. The trouble is that the process is still moving away from equilibrium."
Mr. Soros's announcement on Monday that he would again start investing in South Korea temporarily reversed sentiments, and the currency and stock markets in Seoul rose. But many investors are still fleeing the major Southeast Asian currencies. Now, the Thai baht and the Indonesian rupiah have fallen lower than before the I.M.F. intervened.
The I.M.F.'s five-month-old economic plan for Thailand assumed that the baht would stabilize to a rate of about 32 to the dollar. Tonight, it traded at 53.65 to the dollar, a huge difference that makes it far more costly for Thais to pay their foreign debts. A company that owed $1 million at the I.M.F.'s projected rate would have to raise 32 million baht to pay it back. But if that $1 million loan was due now, it would require more than 53 million baht to repay it.
Unsurprisingly, such wildly off-the-mark forecasts have fueled criticism of the I.M.F.'s approach -- and by extension the Clinton Administration's approach -- to solving the Asian crisis. Equally unsurprisingly, the critics disagree among themselves about what Washington and the I.M.F. may be doing wrong.
The Clinton Administration and its backers say the mixture of high interest rates, economic austerity, more financial disclosure and closing weak banks will work, given enough time and the commitment of political leaders. "These programs work best when governments adopt them as their own," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said a few weeks ago. "That is the beginning of restoring market confidence."
Administration officials say that while Thailand agreed to the I.M.F. package last summer, it did not begin to honor the terms until November, after a weak and divided Cabinet was replaced. "We've really only seen a month or so of real action in Thailand," a senior Administration official said. "And you cannot blame the I.M.F. for worsening the problems in Indonesia," he said, where the Government has complied with only a few key conditions for its loan package. I.M.F. experts are planning to travel to Indonesia in two weeks, and its findings may result in a threat to cut off the next stage of aid.
The dominant group of I.M.F. critics is led by Jeffrey Sachs of the Harvard Institute for International Development. In opinion pieces widely reprinted and often endorsed in Asia, Professor Sachs has argued that the I.M.F. strategy of raising interest rates only worsens a nation's economic troubles, turning minor disturbances into panic.
He noted that in February 1995, the I.M.F. predicted the Mexican economy would grow 1.5 percent for the year; it shrank 6.1 percent. "The same is happening now," he said. "We're lowering the estimates of how much Thailand and South Korea will grow. And that turns into a self-fulfilling panic."
In contrast, Mr. Soros argues that high interest rates "are essential to prevent the currency from going into a free fall" and have forestalled disaster in recent months in Hong Kong and Russia.
He argues that the I.M.F. is failing to address a more fundamental problem: that banks and other international lenders "move in a herd-like fashion in both directions," lavishing cheap money on nations deemed promising, then fleeing at bad news.
In a long essay last week in The Financial Times, Mr. Soros advocated creation of an international organization to help allocate loans to countries. It would guarantee a certain number of loans in return for an insurance premium. The country borrowing the cash would be required to provide a range of data about its economy, and the authority would use that information to "set a ceiling on the amounts it is willing to insure." Beyond that, lenders would be taking their own risks. Neither the I.M.F. nor the United States would bail them out.
Such a system would outrage free-market advocates, who argue that if the market is working well, nations that handle their economies badly must pay more to borrow. But the Asian crisis has shown that countries are increasingly adept at hiding bad news -- both the Thais and the South Koreans misled investors about the size of their currency reserves.
A last school of critics argues that the United States should not signal that it will bail out countries and their creditors -- in this case some of the largest banks in New York, Tokyo and the capitals of Europe. The right course, they argue, is to allow some big defaults so that banks learn what it feels like to take a huge loss.

HEADLINE: Solving and Preventing 'Sick Building' Illnesses

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
THE bedroom is often the scene of the crime. Dr. Adrienne Buffaloe, a specialist in environmental medicine, reels off a list of innocent-sounding potential irritants: "There are the perfumes, the cosmetics, the hair-care sprays on the vanity; the synthetic carpet sprayed with a stain resistant." Then there are cedar closets, mothballs, leathers treated with tanning agents and dyes and even stuffed animals sprayed with flame retardants.
"People's bedrooms should be their oasis, but anything with a scent could be harmful to people breathing it in all night long," she said. 
 Dr. Buffaloe is part of an expanding range of specialists and consultants in Manhattan who are trying to cope with an increasingly borderless territory, the consequences of daily life in largely synthetic interiors. Dr. Buffaloe is the medical director of Healthcare for the 21st Century (212-355-2315), a two-year-old clinic in the Architects and Designers Building, Third Avenue at 58th Street. The clinic is one of only six in the country that is chemical-free, the doctor said.
There, in a high-tech detoxification chamber, if needed, patients can be treated for physical and mental ailments caused by allergies and hypersensitivities related to environmental conditions. (Even visitors are asked not to wear perfume when coming to the clinic, which has marble floors, metal chairs and wall coverings of 100 percent wool.)
Although the clinic's location in the Architects and Designers Building is coincidental, Dr. Buffaloe noted that designers often attend her public lectures on "sick house syndrome," among other subjects, and they drop in for advice regarding health-conscious products they might use.
For 25 years, Wayne Tusa, the president of Environmental Risk and Loss Control (212-369-5400), has helped companies with environmental risks, including "sick building syndrome." But in the last year, he said, more and more individuals have started hiring him to vet the homes and apartments they are thinking of buying or the plans for homes they want to build.
A house inspection with some elementary testing of air quality and recommendations for short- and long-term alterations might cost a few hundred dollars. More extensive testing for problems like asbestos, radon, lead paints, electronmagnetic fields and molds could easily run into several thousand dollars.
"I've noticed that more upscale residents these days just add the cost of extensive testing to their budgets as a matter of course," Mr. Tusa said. (Harold Evans and Tina Brown have been clients.) But rich or poor, Mr. Tusa says, everyone may be at risk, either at home or at work. A huge number of chemical-based products fill the home -- from chemicals used in construction materials, including the formaldehyde found in common plywoods, to the glues that join furniture, to the cleaners and pesticides found under the sink.
Paradoxically, the same energy efficiency that makes well-insulated buildings operate economically also seals in pollutants that can then build up to toxic levels. "Each person has to decide for themselves how much they can tolerate," Mr. Tusa said.
Environmental Construction Outfitters of New York (718-292-0626) is a kind of environmental Home Depot, said its owner, Paul Novack. He provides organic and nontoxic materials to architects and designers -- even homeowners who come to him saying, "I want a safe house." At a warehouse in the Bronx, Mr. Novack stocks paints, sealants, glues, strippers, carpeting, wall coverings, full-spectrum light bulbs and special insulation, everything but the bulkiest materials like plywood and wallboard. The products available at the five-year-old company are recycled, natural, hypoallergenic or are made from renewable resources.
"We supply everyone from the student who needs one can of hypoallergenic paint to the developer who wants 10,000 quarts," Mr. Novack said. "We went into business to supply the 10,000 quarts, but how can you say no to someone who comes to you saying they want to be healthy?"
The Human Ecology Action League is a national support group for people suffering from environmental illnesses. The 17-year-old New York chapter offers monthly lectures by experts in the field. The next lecture, on Saturday, is "Back to Basics in Environmental Illness." For information: (212) 517-5937.

HEADLINE: In America;
Schumer's Big Challenge

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Twenty-four hours after Geraldine Ferraro's glitzy campaign debut at the Sheraton New York Hotel, Representative Charles Schumer sat in a quiet restaurant, not far from Madison Square, and talked over lunch about the legislative record he has compiled.
Mr. Schumer is running against Ms. Ferraro (and Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate) for the Democratic Senate nomination. The winner gets to engage in unrestrained warfare with the three-term Republican incumbent, Alfonse D'Amato. 
 When Ms. Ferraro walked into the hotel's Riverside Ballroom to announce her candidacy on Monday, news photographers surged forward and surrounded her as if she were a movie star. The cornerstone of her candidacy is her fame. It may have been years since Ms. Ferraro held elective office, but she is a celebrity and her supporters are betting that will be enough. Her announcement generated page-one headlines and live television coverage by her most recent employer, CNN. She begins the race well ahead in the polls.
If Mr. Schumer was bothered by the early excitement surrounding Ms. Ferraro, he didn't let on. "I am not the most glamorous person in the world, but I know how to legislate," he said. "I work hard and I have a record of getting things passed that have an effect. My challenge is to get that record out."
Politicians are programmed to blow their own horns. Somewhere Dan Quayle is bragging about all he has done for America. But even taking that into account, Mr. Schumer's legislative record is impressive:
* He is the principal author of the 1994 Crime Bill, which, among other things, provided funds for up to 100,000 additional police officers nationwide. The bill included the Violence Against Women Act, which was the first Federal law designed to protect women from domestic violence.
* He is the leading gun control advocate in Congress, author of the Brady bill and the ban on assault weapons.
* He introduced the bill that eventually forced credit card companies to disclose their interest rates on all solicitations.
* He was the principal author of a bill that guaranteed women the right to enter family planning and abortion clinics without being attacked or harassed. The number of violent incidents outside such clinics plummeted after President Clinton signed the bill into law in May 1994.
"I love legislating," said the unabashed Mr. Schumer. He spoke of the exhilaration and the satisfaction he experienced rounding up votes for the crime bill from liberals, moderates and conservatives. He described the difficulty of passing gun control legislation at any time, but especially in a Congress controlled by Republicans. He seemed almost to relive the tension that surrounded the final tally on the assault-weapons ban. It passed by one vote.
Mr. Schumer, a Harvard Law School graduate whose Congressional district encompasses parts of Brooklyn and Queens, believes in the old-fashioned notion that "government can and should be a force for good."
"That's why I'm running for the Senate," he said.
Pretty sentiments aside, the Congressman is hardly naive about how to get to the Senate. He already has more than $8 million in campaign funds that he can use to trumpet his record and increase his name recognition. That is a lot more than either of his Democratic opponents. Mr. Green has about $1 million and Ms. Ferraro has just begun her mad scramble after cash.
"We will spend the next several months showing my record to the voters," Mr. Schumer said. "By the time of the primary I will be as well known as Gerry."
Mr. Schumer would not criticize Ms. Ferraro during the luncheon interview. But his emphasis on his record (Mr. Green has adopted a similar strategy) inevitably draws attention to Ms. Ferraro's lack of same. In 1992 when she was beaten in a bloodbath of a Senate primary, she said that she would never again run for public office.
"I can't do that anymore," she said. "You know, I'm not a kid."
She has not actually held office since 1984. She has been a pitchwoman for Pepsi-Cola and a sparring partner for Pat Buchanan. For awhile she was the U.S. representative to the United Nations Human Rights Commission.
But now she's back. And she's not just running for the Senate, she's the front-runner. Her claim to fame is that she's famous.

HEADLINE: Low Mortgage Rates Spur A Rise in New-Home Sales

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
New-home sales surged 5.1 percent in November, propelled by falling mortgage rates and the most buoyant consumer confidence in nearly three decades.
Economists said sales for all of 1997 probably hit a 19-year high and predicted the strength will carry over into early this year. 
 "We're working on all cylinders," said David Lereah, the economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. "You have cyclically low mortgage rates. You have a robust economy. The bottom line is that has given the consumer the financial wherewithal to go out there and buy homes."
New single-family homes sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 830,000 in November, the most since April 1986, the Commerce Department said today.
Analysts predicted sales for all of 1997 will top 800,000, roughly a 6 percent increase over 1996 and the best since 817,000 new homes were sold in 1978. Sales should slacken to around 760,000 this year, still among the handful of best years during the last two decades.
In November, sales of new homes rose strongly everywhere but the West. They surged 23.4 percent, to a rate of 79,000 in the East, highest in six months. They jumped 14.9 percent in the Midwest, to a rate of 162,000, the most since December 1993, and 4.9 percent in the South, to a rate of 382,000, the most since February.
In the West, sales fell 6.3 percent, to a rate of 207,000. They were hurt by bad weather.
"We think the economy as a whole, home building included, will slow down a bit," said the economist Michael Carliner of the National Association of Home Builders. "But it still looks very positive. The slowdown in 1998 will be a fairly modest one."
Economists had expected home sales to slow late in 1997. Instead, they took off as interest rates fell.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.2 percent in November and most recently have fallen to just under 7 percent, nearly the best in four years. That reduced the monthly payment on a $100,000 loan by about $17.
And new-home prices have remained affordable for many. The median price -- meaning half sold for more and half for less -- was $140,000 in November, down 2.4 percent from a year earlier.
The Commerce Department also said today that the supply of new homes for sale nationwide fell 1 percent in November to an annual rate of 285,000, the lowest since July 1993. When compared with demand measured by November's sales rate, the inventory of vacant new homes fell to a 4.2-month supply, matching the level in August 1971.
Economists are looking for home sales and related purchases of furniture and appliances to help the economy this year as export sales to Asia drop.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Korea will suffer, but the banks that lent the money won't.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
FIRST Mexico. Then Thailand and Indonesia. Now, South Korea.
If every emerging economy that reaches beyond its grasp is automatically eligible for a multibillion-dollar bailout from the International Monetary Fund, what incentive do borrowers have to play by the rules of the free market? 
 Second-guessing the South Korean rescue effort is certain to become a popular sport. But specialists in international finance argue that most criticism of the $57 billion package amounts to blaming the victim. For while South Koreans will pay long and dearly for their financial transgressions, the Japanese, European and American banks that provided much of their capital seem destined to leave the field of battle unscathed. "The only winners in Korea are the foreign banks, who will get their money back and then some," argued Richard Medley, the head of Medley Global Advisors, a New York-based consultant on risk management.
With hindsight, it is clear that growth-obsessed South Korean conglomerates borrowed rashly, secure in their belief that the Government would shield them from any debt difficulties. South Korean banks made little effort to assess the creditworthiness of large borrowers, since Seoul would always prop them up.
This led the banks to borrow tens of billions of dollars abroad and to economize on interest expenses by agreeing to repay the principal on just a few months' notice.
When currency instability hit Southeast Asia last summer, South Korea was vulnerable. Weakening markets for South Korean exports made it difficult for the financially leveraged conglomerates to service debts.
More important, the banks had all too often lent in South Korean won with funds borrowed in dollars. So the collapse of the won left many banks with dollar liabilities they could not repay.
It is difficult to argue, though, that what is casually termed a bailout will tempt any other country to act profligately. South Korea is obliged to close insolvent banks, open jealously protected markets to foreign competition, shut down the easy credit pipeline for financially pressed conglomerates and, of course, pay back the $57 billion package rescue loan with interest.
The I.M.F. is also demanding fiscal austerity that will drive the economy into recession, bankrupting many well-managed businesses in need of credit. "It's indiscriminate punishment that if anything will deter other countries from turning to the I.M.F. before their problems become intractable," argued Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Institute for International Development at Harvard.
Foreigners can expect an easier ride. To be sure, those who bought shares in South Korean companies or lent them money directly will take a bath. But the bulk of the foreign investment in South Korea is in the form of loans to South Korean banks. And as Jeff Uscher, editor of Grant's Asia Observer, says, "These lenders will get back 100 cents on the dollar."
Cash from the I.M.F. goes directly to the Seoul Government, which is relending the money to South Korean banks to pay maturing dollar-denominated debts. Foreigners will thus not be punished for ignoring risks in lending to overextended banks. Those who refuse to roll over funds can expect to be paid off with I.M.F. funds. Meanwhile, those now negotiating to extend their loans will be able to extract stiff fees or above-market interest rates in return for forbearance.
"Foreign banks are in the position of monopolists since nobody is rushing to replace them as lenders," said Guillermo Calvo, an economist at the University of Maryland.
And while the South Korean Government is now trying to raise as much as $35 billion by floating bond issues of its own, thereby giving the banks an alternative means of staying afloat, the expected cost will be a big five percentage points above interest rates paid by risk-free borrowers.
The inequity of this outcome has not been lost on the officials at the I.M.F. and the Treasury, who had wanted the lenders to feel some pain but feared causing panic in the currency market.
Mr. Sachs is not impressed by this reasoning. "Looking back," he allowed, "it's hard to imagine that the Korean won would have fallen any further if the I.M.F. had punished the lenders rather than the borrowers."
But most specialists are looking forward, wondering whether the I.M.F. can continue to play the role of global lender of last resort without doing more harm than good. "Foreign banks will be there with cheap money as long as the I.M.F. is waiting on the sidelines to bail them out," Mr. Calvo worries.
The answer, he suggests, is less reliance on bailouts and more on domestic regulation limiting flows of hot money. Mr. Calvo cites the example of Chile, which has avoided currency gyrations by discouraging short-term borrowing abroad.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Only in Albany Is a Surplus Reason to Fret

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
IT'S an election year. There's a budget surplus. What could be more dangerous?
In his annual address to the Legislature yesterday afternoon, Gov. George E. Pataki offered lots of lofty if vaporous pronouncements about the state of the state. 
"Yesterday's job losses have dissipated behind us like a dark cloud passing," the Governor declared at one point.
"We have emerged from the mist to the endless, enduring dream," he said at another.
Such vague pronouncements are a staple of State of the State addresses, and most of Mr. Pataki's 63-minute speech was given over to them. Still, the Governor did manage to include calls for speeding up tax cuts for the elderly, accelerating tax cuts for farmers and adding new tax cuts for what he referred to as "job production."
In so doing, the Governor joined a long list of politicians, both in the state and out, intent on giving away the largesse that prosperity has provided. At this point, experts say, tax cutting plans are under discussion in roughly half the states.
Here in Albany, even before the legislative session began, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, had proposed new tax cuts for large corporations, small businesses and financial service firms, as well as reductions in motor vehicle registration fees. Meanwhile, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, had already weighed in on the side of huge increases in the state's education budget.
All of which goes to show that excessive fiscal prudence has surely ceased to be considered good electoral policy, if it ever was.
For all of the state's recent prosperity and all of Mr. Pataki's talk of "our destiny, which lies before us like a land of limitless opportunity," it is important -- though not exactly in the spirit of yesterday's festivities -- to point out that New York is still tied with Louisiana for lowest bond rating in the country.
This does not mean that fiscal analysts doubt New York's ability to pay its creditors. It means they are horrified by the state's budget-making process.
And who can blame them?
Over the years, the state's fiscal monitors have watched in horror as Albany has flouted just about every conceivable tenet of sound budgeting, selling its prisons to itself and then leasing them back, for example, or, more recently, deciding to issue bonds for unspecified pork barrel projects. Despite a near-record stretch of economic growth and a Wall Street boom that has produced a flood of unanticipated revenues, New York continues to have the largest debt of any state and some of the smallest reserve funds.
What fiscal watchdogs fear this year is that the happy event of a budget surplus, estimated by the Governor yesterday at more than $1.4 billion, will, in the months ahead, be transformed by that old Albany magic into a liability. They worry not only that the surplus will be spent -- a sad but pardonable act of prodigality -- but that it will be spent many times over.
"It's the surplus that keeps on giving," said one such watchdog, Andrew Rein, who is a research associate at the Citizens Budget Commission.
ONE problem is that Albany has a habit of treating any bit of good fortune, no matter how fleeting, as if it will be permanent. Last month, for example, when Mr. Bruno offered his plans for spending the surplus, he didn't just propose tax cuts for the coming fiscal year, but for every year after that, too.
Another problem is that a surplus triggers all the ancient, vexatious Albany rivalries.
To be fair, the plans that Mr. Pataki outlined yesterday for spending the surplus appear, at least by Albany standards, to be relatively conservative. But already it seems that the Republican Governor's plans overlap with the Republican Senate majority leader's plans only in part, and with the Democratic Assembly Speaker's hardly at all. And it is easy to anticipate where this conflict will lead.
Eventually, there will be three separate plans for spending the same surplus. All parties will acknowledge that the plans can't all be enacted, yet none will want to give in. And so after endless bickering and grandstanding and secret meetings that pass for budget negotiations -- who knows what they are really doing in that room? -- the Governor and the legislative leaders will agree that actually the surplus was all along larger than they thought.
Then, not long after that, the state will be scrounging around, looking for another stretch of highway to mortgage to itself.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Robust Sales News Snaps 4-Day Bond Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds snapped a four-day rally yesterday, falling under the weight of robust housing and auto sales data, a weaker dollar, a growing corporate-debt supply and talk that the market's ebullience may be overdone.
The 30-year bond fell 29/32, to a price of 104 23/32. Its yield, which moves inversely to price and had fallen to record lows over the prior two days, rose to 5.78 percent, from 5.72 percent Tuesday. 
 While a pullback had been expected, it nonetheless erased nearly a third of the price gains over the last week made in the bond market, which had been surging on signs that the economy is slowing and interest rates may decline. The weekend comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, about possible price deflation also contributed to the market's euphoric mood.
"The favorable market climate produced by this outlook hit a stone wall today," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
While market participants still believe the economy is slowing and inflation remains tame, he said, the rally was snapped by the Commerce Department's strong November new-home sales report, healthy December sales by auto makers and "a growing perception that Chairman Greenspan's recent comments may have been misconstrued to some extent."
Mr. Fine said the home-sales report was significant because housing leads the overall economy and there is no sign the growth trend is ending -- in fact new-home sales are at the highest level in more than a decade.
While statistics on housing activity do not negate the prospect of a slackening economy in 1998, he said, the bond market nevertheless is likely to await more concrete data on the future direction of business activity before prices rally further.
"But bond market psychology is most certainly not bearish," he said. "With the Fed on hold and inflation acquiescent, the market's performance today appears to be much more a matter of curbing bullish enthusiasm."
Aside from the home and auto sales data released yesterday, the dollar's pullback against the yen also weighed on the bond market. The United States currency fell nearly 2.5 yen on fears that the United States and Japan may jointly sell dollars in the foreign-exchange market to curb its strength. A lower dollar would tend to diminish demand for securities denominated in dollars.
At the same time, the prospect of a supply glut from more corporate bond sales hangs over the market. Many companies view the decline in the yield of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond as an opportunity to raise money by selling debt themselves at relatively low financing costs.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Asia Turmoil Seen Leading To Stormy Times for Stocks

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Investors, after having thrived for three years on a great bull market, may be in for a little more turbulence.
There is a growing consensus among Wall Street experts, and perhaps even Main Street investors, that the crisis in Asia and its potentially deflationary effects on the rest of the world are not going away anytime soon. And with each passing day comes a little more confirmation. 
 Yesterday, it came with another batch of warnings about disappointing corporate profits in the United States. That was quickly followed by several downgrades on Wall Street -- warnings that investors ought to be cautious about certain stocks.
Then there was evidence that several large banks, technology companies and, yes, even Wall Street brokerage firms may find it much harder in 1998 to keep pace with last year's growth.
So it was no surprise that banking, technology and brokerage firm stocks plunged early in the day. The Dow Jones industrial average soon followed, tumbling 111 points by mid-day, before mounting a late afternoon rally.
Even though the Dow survived with just a few nicks, closing down 3.98 points, at 7,902.27, a hair below where it began the year, the broad market remains under siege.
"There's a growing recognition that Asia is a long-term problem that can't be easily solved by the I.M.F. or private lenders," Charles Pradilla, a market strategist with Cowen & Company, said, referring to the International Monetary Fund. "And so the odds are very high that for the next two quarters the earnings surprises are going to be disappointments."
To get a sense of the turmoil, investors need only look to Asia, where stock markets in Hong Kong, Japan and Singapore continue to slide. Overnight, the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong plummeted nearly 6 percent. Japan's Nikkei 225-stock index is down 2.6 percent this year.
European markets are better off, but they also weakened yesterday. And stock prices in Mexico and Brazil are down 3 and 5 percent this year, as the world braces for the possibility of a global slowdown.
In the United States, the latest earnings warnings came from Atmel, a computer-chip maker, and Rainforest Cafe, a restaurant chain. Both are rather small companies, but analyst fears seem to build with each profit warning.
Two large Wall Street houses -- Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover -- reported huge fourth-quarter profits. But brokerage stocks fell yesterday, perhaps on the fear that the new year would be stingier.
While the Dow's fall yesterday seemed minor, the broader market offered a clearer reflection of the day. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index lost 1.2 percent, and smaller stocks, as catalogued in the Russell 2000 index, dropped eight-tenths of a percent; both suffered heavier losses early. Bank and brokerage issues fell more than 2 percent.
For the Dow, which climbed 115 percent between the end of 1994 and August 1997, the last five months have been unnerving. Ignoring the day-to-day and week-to-week moves, the Dow has gone basically nowhere. It rests about 350 points below its Aug. 6 high of 8,259.31, and suffered its first quarterly loss in three years in the fourth quarter, when it dipped five-tenths of 1 percent.
The weakness is centered on fears the Asian crisis will spark deflationary pressure and depress corporate profits in America.
Edward Yardeni, the Deutsche Morgan Grenfell economist who not too long ago was parading the notion of a Dow at 10,000 by the year 2000, now frets about a market whose "days are numbered."
"The Asian crisis threatens to slow the global economy," he said. "The world economy desperately needs yuppies, and we thought we'd have yuppies in Asia to sell to, but now the outlook is grim."
As a result, Mr. Yardeni has slashed his United States profit forecast from 10 percent gains in 1998 to 5 percent, and he even talks about the possibility of profits being flat to down this year.
Charles Hill, director of research at First Call Inc., which tracks earnings estimates, said he had received lots of disappointing news on fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, and that analysts continued to trim their fourth-quarter forecasts, already down to 8 percent from expectations of 13 percent.
There are some bright spots. Interest rates are near a 30-year low, making stocks appear less expensive, and yesterday, when things looked dour, investors rushed in at the close and bought about $200 million worth of stock, according to Birinyi & Associates, a research firm.
