HEADLINE: Billionaire Selling 60 Broad St. Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Only a few years ago, lower Manhattan was devastated by layoffs, bankruptcies and a recession that left empty one out of every four floors of the district's office towers.
But in yet another indication that the city's financial district is on the rebound, Li Ka-shing, the Hong Kong billionaire, is selling the 1 million square foot tower at 60 Broad Street for $62 million to investors. The new owners, who plan to spend $60 million more on renovations, are spending $122 a square foot in an area where buildings were going for as low as $30 a square foot just three years ago. 
 The 39-story tower, once home to the Drexel Burnham Lambert investment bank, is being bought by a joint venture of Kennedy-Wilson International, a publicly traded real estate company based in Los Angeles, and Pioneer Holdings, a Hong Kong investment company. The deal is scheduled to close next week.
"We are extremely bullish not only about the future of New York's financial district but on the role that 60 Broad Street will play in its continuing revitalization," said Richard Mandel, president of the commercial division of Kennedy-Wilson. "We've already started work on upgrading the building to modern standards."
The deal also illustrates just how fast conditions have changed and how rival developers are battling to buy potentially lucrative properties while the market is hot.
Francis Greenburger, chairman of Time Equities Inc., has sued the owner of 60 Broad Street, claiming that it reneged on a year-old agreement to sell him the top half of the tower, which he planned to convert to 400 condominium apartments; Mr. Li would have retained the lower portion of the tower as office space. Mr. Greenburger said he had worked for a year negotiating the terms of the deal. Suddenly, last September, the owners told him that the deal was off because the entire building was to be sold to a different buyer, Mr. Greenburger said.
"We feel they were obligated to deal with us exclusively and in good faith until the deal was completed, Mr. Greenburger said in an interview yesterday.
A spokesman for the owner declined comment.
"I think it's a reflection of how hot the market is," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, a civic organization. "There is a competition for buildings and a competition for uses that's affecting the market now."
Much had changed downtown while Mr. Greenburger planned his conversion. Developers had transformed about 16 vacant office buildings downtown into apartment houses. Then, the long dormant office market revived, with the downtown vacancy rate falling to 17.6 percent in December, from 25.1 percent in 1995, according to the Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company. Tenants were looking downtown because of the lack of large blocks of space in midtown.
Property values escalated so rapidly that the investor, Steven C. Witkoff, was able to sell the 29-story tower at 100 Wall Street last October for $58.5 million, or $128 a square foot, only five months after buying it for $37 million, or $81 a square foot.
With office space in demand, some developers switched plans. Mr. Witkoff was framing out apartments at 10 Hanover Square last spring when Goldman Sachs & Company agreed to lease the entire building for a unit of the investment bank.
"The office market has gotten to the point now where it rivals the residential market downtown," said Peter Hauspurg, president of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a real estate investment banking firm in Manhattan.
"Office rents have moved quickly to close the huge gap that existed with residential rents."
Some real estate brokers question how long the boomlet will last, given the wave of consolidation in the financial services industry and the fact that the industry has yet to reach employment levels of 1987. But Mr. Mandel is betting that he will have little trouble in leasing out 60 Broad Street.
"The market is moving upward in a very straight manner," he said.
Built for RCA during a real estate boom in 1961 by the developers Percy and Harold Uris, 60 Broad Street has served as a barometer for the downtown real estate market. The Reichmann family's Olympia & York company bought the Uris properties during a recession in 1977, the first step in establishing itself as the largest commercial landlord in New York. The Reichmanns had a $160 million mortgage on the building in 1990, when the principal tenant, Drexel Burnham Lambert, went bankrupt.
Mr. Li bought the mortgage and a 50 percent stake in the building for $57.5 million in 1991, when Olympia & York was unable to cover the monthly mortgage payments. Olympia & York, which eventually went bankrupt, defaulted on the mortgage. Mr. Li ultimately took control of the building.
In the last year, Mr. Li spent $25 million renovating the lower half of the building and leasing the space to three state agencies.
After considering a sale of the top half, Mr. Li, who lost millions on the building, decided to sell the entire property to Kennedy-Wilson and Pioneer, which had invested with Mr. Li in the mortgage.
"In the current market, they have a chance to do well with the building," said Jonathan Coven, vice president of Concord Properties, Mr. Li's company.
"Li is getting out because it doesn't fit his global strategy."

HEADLINE: Federal Deficit Will Fade Away in '98, Budget Office Predicts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office projected today that the Federal budget deficit would be all but eliminated this year, continuing a deluge of good fiscal news that has both political parties eager to begin dividing the spoils.
The budget office said the deficit for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 would be just $5 billion, down from $22.7 billion last year and so small in a $1.7 trillion budget as to be almost meaningless. 
 Its analysis showed even smaller deficits for the next two years, and then steadily larger surpluses running out at least to 2008.
The $5 billion figure for this year was far more specific than President Clinton's announcement on Monday that White House budget analysts expect the 1998 deficit to decline to below $22 billion, and it is the latest evidence of how the strong economy is propelling Washington into an era of fiscal plenty far faster than almost anyone anticipated. As recently as last September, the budget office was predicting a $57 billion deficit for this year.
Mr. Clinton and the Republican leadership agreed on a plan last summer to balance the budget by 2002. The President said on Monday that he now expected to balance the budget next year, three years ahead of schedule.
But the budget office's projections, which in recent years have proven considerably too pessimistic, confirmed the predictions of many private analysts that the deficit could be wiped out this year, well before most of the spending cuts called for by the budget deal take effect.
"From where we're sitting now, it does look like it's possible there could be a surplus, although at $5 billion the deficit is so small it's indistinguishable from balance already," said June E. O'Neill, the budget office director.
With the specter of huge deficits now eliminated, both parties have begun maneuvering to use any surpluses to address their priorities. Republicans have been agitating for big tax cuts, while Democrats have been calling for new spending on programs like education and health care.
"I hope our friends on the other side won't plunge into the debate with a broad-based tax cut program," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the Budget Committee, who said the big Republican tax cuts of the early 1980's were what led to the sharply rising deficits in the first place.
Mr. Lautenberg's Republican counterpart, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Budget Committee chairman, warned against abandoning the spending restraint that had been imposed by efforts to curb the deficit.
"Now is not the time to open the Federal spending floodgates," Mr. Domenici said.
The improved outlook seen by the budget office encompassed both higher-than-expected tax revenue and lower-than-planned spending.
The budget office said Federal revenue this year should be $1.665 trillion, or $30 billion higher than it was expecting in its last forecast in September. Spending for entitlement programs like Medicare, Social Security and welfare is now forecast by the budget office to total $950 billion this year, $18 billion less than it expected in September.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Warning To Indonesia: Comply on Aid

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it was "crucial" for the Indonesian Government to begin complying with terms of its $40 billion financial bailout. Several officials said emergency aid to help the country escape its crisis could be cut off if President Suharto ignored the warnings.
The statement came a day after President Suharto, Asia's longest-serving leader, announced a budget for the next year that failed to comply with several requirements set by the International Monetary Fund when it agreed to huge loans to the country in October. The United States committed $3 billion to aid Indonesia in a "second line of defense" if the I.M.F.'s own funds proved insufficient; none of the American money has been disbursed. 
 "It will be crucial for Indonesia to carry through on policy commitments it has made in the context of the I.M.F. program," Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary and a central figure in the American efforts to contain the Asian financial crisis, told reporters late today. Mr. Summers specifically pointed to "measures to reform and clean up the financial system, to adjust monetary policy, and to control public infrastructure spending."
Mr. Summers's statement came as the Clinton Administration appeared headed for an unusual collision with Mr. Suharto, with whom President Clinton has gone to some lengths to build a relationship. Mr. Suharto has ruled the world's fourth-most- populous country for 32 years, and his power was unquestioned until recent months. But the combination of the financial crisis, increasing social unrest, signs of dissension in the Indonesian military, and evidence the 76-year-old leader is ailing have led to concerns about how a transition of power may unfold.
The American commitment to join the Indonesian bailout -- after it had pointedly declined to join an earlier rescue effort of Thailand -- was intended to show confidence in Indonesia's ability to right itself. Since then its currency, the rupiah, has plummeted, as it has become clear that Mr. Suharto and his relatives, who are deeply involved in the country's most profitable businesses, were resisting I.M.F. strictures.
Now the Administration is joining the I.M.F. in sending Mr. Suharto a blunt message: If Indonesia does not fulfill its reform commitments, the money will be cut off.
"We've tried the quiet approach," one official said last week. "Now the message is being sent through the markets."
In fact, before Mr. Summers spoke today, the markets began imposing their discipline on the Indonesian Government. In the first week of 1998, the Indonesian currency has fallen by more than a third, touching 8,400 rupiah to the dollar today. In trading on Thursday, the rupiah weakened to as low as 10,000 to the dollar.
At such levels,, many Indonesian companies cannot afford to repay huge loans from Japanese, American and European banks that are denominated in dollars or yen.
Indonesian officials insist they are committed to reform. "The loss of confidence and loss of trust is becoming irrational," the country's Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, told a news conference today. But that loss of trust was intensified by Mr. Suharto's budget, which was based on economic projections considered wildly unrealistic. For example, the budget assumes an exchange rate of 4,000 rupiah to the dollar, or twice as strong as the currency's current levels. Mr. Suharto also projected that the Indonesian economy would continue to grow; most economists believe it is headed for a major recession and double-digit inflation.
Within the Clinton Administration, a debate has already begun over how to handle Indonesia in coming months. Treasury officials have made clear that unless Indonesia complies with terms of the I.M.F. accord, continuing financial support would undercut the credibility of the I.M.F. bailouts around the world. Other nations might circumvent politically difficult reforms, especially those that result in bankruptcies and layoffs. Indonesian military authorities have said publicly in recent days that they expect two million people may soon be unemployed in their once-booming country, and they have vowed to suppress protests.
At the State Department there is growing concern that the financial crisis not turn into a series of street confrontations, or that it inflame the touchy issue of who will succeed President Suharto.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, was a bit softer than Mr. Summers today, telling reporters: "President Suharto and other Government officials have expressed their willingness to undertake reforms outlined in the I.M.F. program. Some steps have been taken, including the closing of 16 banks. But far more remains to be done, especially if markets are to have confidence that Indonesia is fully committed to implementing the letter and the spirit of the program."
Military officials are also concerned, and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen will be stopping in Indonesia during an 11-day tour of Southeast Asia. He will likely be delivering a version of the warning Administration officials offered today.
Mr. Summers also said today that the United States would not provide $1.7 billion in speed-up aid to South Korea -- part of an $8 billion package of accelerated aid from many nations -- until commercial banks agree on extending payments for about $25 billion in short-term loans to South Korean banks.
European, Japanese and American banks are meeting Thursday morning at Citicorp headquarters in New York to negotiate such an agreement, which may include an accord to extend the loans for 90 days while new agreements are worked out. Such agreements are necessary before any of the short-term loans can be converted into more manageable long-term debt.
Mr. Summers also met this evening with Japan's Vice Finance Minister, Eisuke Sakakibara. That meeting, which followed a session between Mr. Sakakibara and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, prompted market speculation that the United States and Japan would intervene to prop up the yen by selling dollars.
The dollar plummeted 2.4 yen today and settled at 131.25 yen in New York on fear of such intervention. Mr. Summers would say little about the meeting, but American officials are clearly concerned that Japan has done too little, to reform its own ailing banking system, an underlying cause of yen weakness.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Fall Worldwide As Asia Tremors Linger
Stock markets around the world continued to be weakened by concerns over Asia's financial crisis and its potential deflationary effects. The Dow Jones industrial average recovered from an 111-point deficit to end down 3.98 points, at 7,902.27, but broader market barometers fell sharply. The Nasdaq composite index fell 18.44 points, or 1.17 percent, to 1,561.70. 
 Financial and technology companies were especially hurt, reflecting investor fear that their earnings will suffer as a result of decreased demand from Asia. Page D8.
 
Citing the rapid buildup in short-term foreign loans as the major cause of the Asian crisis, American, South Korean and Japanese economists have called for new ways to curb such lending and borrowing. D4.
 
The currencies of Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines again touched record lows against the dollar on investor skepticism that Asian nations were committed to economic change. D4.
 
Bonds Fall After Four-Day Rally
Long-term Treasury prices fell yesterday under the weight of robust housing and auto sales data, a weaker dollar, a growing corporate debt supply and talk that the market's strength may be overdone. The decline came after four days of gains that had pushed yields on the 30-year bond to record lows. D8.
 
Morgan and Lehman Earnings Rise
Two of Wall Street's biggest firms reported surprisingly strong fourth-quarter earnings. The results from Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. suggested that big brokerage firms have not been hurt by turmoil in Asia markets, at least not yet. D2.
 
Criminal Case in Tobacco Inquiry
The Justice Department accused the DNA Plant Technology Corporation of engaging in a scheme with a major cigarette maker to produce tobacco that had twice the nicotine level of the regular leaf. It is the first criminal action brought by the agency in its long investigation of the tobacco industry. A16.
 
Camry Is Top Seller in 1997
The Toyota Camry, left, was the best-selling car in 1997, beating the Honda Accord by 12,547 autos. It is the first time a Japanese nameplate has captured the No. 1 spot in five years. The Ford Taurus, which had held the title, came in third. Auto makers sold 15.2 million cars in the United States last year, up from 15.1 million in 1996. D9.
 
New-Home Sales Rose 5.1%
Falling interest rates and rising consumer confidence sent new-home sales surging 5.1 percent in November, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 830,000, the most since April 1986. Analysts predicted sales for all of 1997 will top 800,000, a 6 percent rise. D23.
 
SBC Is Changing an Industry
SBC Communications is emerging as the iconoclast of the telecommunications industry by persuading a judge to strike down a portion of the Telecommunications Act and by announcing plans to buy the phone company for most of Connecticut. News Analysis. D5.
 
Clinton Seeks to Expand Child Care
President Clinton proposed a $21.7 billion package of grants and tax breaks to help working families find affordable child care. He called it the nation's largest investment in child care, which would essentially double the number of children eligible for child-care assistance to 2 million by the year 2003. A1.
 
It's a Bird, a Plane - Jerry Seinfeld?
References to Superman occasionally pop up in episodes of "Seinfeld." So it may not come as a surprise that American Express has decided to pair Jerry Seinfield with the cartoon superhero in a new commercial. D9.

HEADLINE: Pataki Says He Delivered on Promises; Experts Aren't So Sure

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki used his election-year address to the Legislature today to remind New Yorkers that he had delivered on the major campaign pledges he made four years ago: creating jobs, reducing crime, cutting taxes and shrinking the welfare rolls.
But interviews with experts in each of those areas raise questions about some of the Governor's claims. Here are some of the victories Mr. Pataki touted, and the experts' assessments:
 
Crime 
 Mr. Pataki boasted that the streets of New York State are far safer today than they were three years ago, when, he said, the state led the nation in violent crimes. But according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, New York's rate of violent crime three years ago was really seventh, behind Florida, California, South Carolina, Nevada, Louisiana and the District of Columbia.
Mr. Pataki also claimed that the tough anti-crime measures he pushed through the Legislature, particularly the enactment of the death penalty and the elimination of parole for violent offenders convicted for a second time, had contributed to the state's plummeting crime rates.
But most experts say that a direct link between enacting the death penalty and deterring crime is difficult to prove, and that the parole change, enacted in 1995, is too new to have had any effect. They also say that the state's drop in crime has been driven by trends in New York City, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has employed new and aggressive police strategies.
For instance, there were 1,171 fewer murders in New York City in 1996 than in 1991; statewide, there were 1,214 fewer murders in 1996 than in 1991.
"No one attributes the drop in crime in New York City to policies coming out of Albany," said Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York. "Rather, it's a result of demographic patterns, new police strategies and a truce among rival drug gangs."
 
Job Creation
 Jobs will surely be a major campaign issue this year, and Mr. Pataki today touted New York as a leader in job creation since he took office. "When I was elected, New York State was 49th in the nation in creating jobs," he said. "Now we are sixth."
But economists said the numbers Mr. Pataki cited were a bit misleading. New York did indeed create more jobs in absolute numbers, 236,400, between 1994 and 1997. But in terms of percentages, New York went from 48th to 42d in job growth during those years, according to the Fiscal Policy Institute.
"Counting jobs is inappropriate for state-by-state comparisons," said Jennifer McCormick, an analyst with the Fiscal Policy Institute. "Using this measure, the third most populous state, New York, has to eke out a 1 percent increase to beat out the 38th most populous, Nevada's 6 percent employment increase."
 
Taxes
 One of the Governor's least disputed claims was his assertion that New York State had become a leader in cutting taxes. "We've cut so many taxes -- in so many different ways and so many times -- that it would take me 10 minutes just to read you the list," he said.
According to the National Conference of State Legislatures, New York has led other states in cutting taxes for the three years that Mr. Pataki has been in office: $944 million between 1995 and 1996; $1.9 billion between 1996 and 1997 and $803 million between 1997 and 1998. In all, New York's tax cuts amounted to more than 38 percent of the $10 billion in tax cuts enacted nationwide in the three years.
"Those are very impressive figures," said Ronald K. Snell, the director of the economic and fiscal division for the conference of legislatures.
 
Welfare
 The Governor said his administration had succeeded in freeing many people trapped in a culture of dependency fostered by old welfare programs. He said the number of people on public assistance had been reduced by 456,000, to 1,191,000 from 1,647,000, since he took office.
The numbers have indeed plummeted, but many experts contend that the numbers have been largely driven by experiments in welfare overhaul by local governments, though some of those programs required approval by the state.
In New York City, the rolls have declined by 338,000, to 822,117 from 1,160,593 three years ago. "The city's welfare program has driven the state decline," said Tony Coles, Mayor Giuliani's welfare adviser. "But the Governor has been helpful in advocating legislation that has been helpful to our program."

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Welfare Chief Chosen for New York City

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
The architect of a Wisconsin welfare program that has pushed more people off public assistance than in almost any other state in the country was selected yesterday to run New York City's sprawling social service agency.
Jason A. Turner, 44, who instituted some of the nation's most radical welfare changes, which abolished cash assistance and will soon require almost every able-bodied welfare recipient to work, will take over in February, city officials said. As Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, Mr. Turner will oversee the largest workfare program in the country. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani introduced his new social services chief at a news conference at City Hall yesterday and emphasized Mr. Turner's national reputation and his commitment to making work "part of the centrality of people's lives."
"We're very, very pleased that he's willing to take on this challenge," Mr. Giuliani said. "We're very fortunate to have him."
With the selection of the well-known policy maker, who replaces Commissioner Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, Mr. Giuliani clearly hopes to burnish his own welfare reform efforts.
More than 300,000 people have left the welfare rolls in the last three years, although city officials have not followed them to see if they have found jobs.
Some advocates for the poor fear that Mr. Turner's approach may be too harsh, but others see his appointment as a sign that Mr. Giuliani, who is often criticized for failing to move people into private-sector work, may soon be shifting strategy to offer more support services for welfare recipients struggling to find jobs.
If the Wisconsin program is one of the toughest in the nation, it is also in some ways among the most generous. Last year, for instance, Wisconsin provided day care to all 9,600 children whose families wanted it. In New York City, 12,000 families are on waiting lists for child care.
While the number of families on welfare rolls has fallen 58 percent in the last five years in Wisconsin, the state has increased its spending on those families 62 percent in the last year alone, offering child care, health care and training designed to move mothers into the workforce.
But in New York City, the sheer scale of the task easily dwarfs that of Wisconsin. Mr. Turner, who left his state job to work as a consultant last year, now confronts an infinitely more difficult job.
In Wisconsin, he had to put only 31,000 mothers to work in a state with an unemployment rate of about 3 percent. New York City, on the other hand, has the second-largest welfare caseload in the country, with 314,000 mothers on welfare and only 15,326 currently participating in workfare, and an unemployment rate of 8.5 percent.
It is also a city where human resources commissioners working for Mr. Giuliani typically have little autonomy to make their own decisions or initiate new programs. Welfare policy, according to city officials, is generally run directly from City Hall.
But Mr. Turner, a ruddy, blue-eyed welfare policy expert who said he has been dreaming about reforming the system since his junior high school days in Darien, Conn., says he relishes the opportunity to work in one of the nation's largest social laboratories.
"For somebody in the welfare community, New York City is it," Mr. Turner said. "This is the place where it's possible to make large amounts of difference in many people's lives and I look forward to that."
When asked if he could replicate his reforms in a city with a much larger caseload and a tighter job market, Mr. Turner said, "The kinds of things that you need to do to get somebody a job is the same in Milwaukee as it is in New York City."
Mr. Giuliani declined to outline his plans for welfare reform in his second term, saying only that he would like to place more emphasis on moving people directly from workfare into private-sector work. He said he had lobbied the state government for increased funding for day care and would continue to do so.
But Mr. Giuliani did reject two planks of the Wisconsin program, saying he opposed the privatization of the welfare system and the cutting off all benefits to mothers who failed to comply with work rules. In New York City, those women lose only a portion of their welfare checks.
"I have great resistance to any sanctions that will impact on children," he said.
Reaction to Mr. Turner's appointment was mixed among advocates for welfare recipients. Some were troubled, noting that the number of homeless and hungry people increased during Mr. Turner's three-year tenure as director of the Welfare Replacement Project in Wisconsin. And officials in Wisconsin, like those in New York City, made no effort to track the progress of the people who vanished from the rolls.
"The bottom line is that we're nervous," said Don Friedman, a senior policy analyst at the Community Food Resource Center, a nonprofit advocacy group.
But Allen Kraus, a former deputy commissioner in the city's social service agency, said he thought the appointment might signal a shift in a program that has focused on workfare.
"If you take what happened in Wisconsin and bring it here, you have to do more than we're doing now, you have to do more than just workfare," said Mr. Kraus, who is the co-chairman of a civic group called the Task Force for Sensible Welfare Reform. "It means a workfare program that actually moves people toward work. If that's what the Mayor wants to do, that's good."

HEADLINE: Council Speaker Proposes Cut to City's Income Tax

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, called for a $500 million cut in the city's personal income tax yesterday, seeking to bolster his candidacy for governor by portraying himself as a champion of the middle class who gives "money back to the people."
But in a role reversal, the proposal by the Democratic Speaker immediately ran into opposition from his Republican counterpart across City Hall, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who labeled it an election-year ploy that the city could not afford. 
 The sudden flare-up over the proposed tax cut underscored how the city government is increasingly being pulled into the gubernatorial race, with Mr. Vallone, a candidate for the Democratic nomination, trying to tailor his agenda to insure that he has programs to promote on the stump. Mr. Vallone unveiled the proposal in his annual address to the Council, a speech that included a glimpse of some of the themes that he plans to stress in his statewide campaign. He also took several jabs at Gov. George E. Pataki.
Mr. Vallone said the city should cut taxes by $500 million by letting a 12.5 percent surcharge on its personal income tax expire at the end of the year. He also called for changing some tax rates so that working- and middle-class people receive more of the benefits of the cut.
The moves would lower the annual tax for a family of four with earnings of $25,000 to $199, from $270, a drop of 26 percent. For a family of four with earnings of $60,000, the tax bill would decline to $1,448 from $1,677, a drop of almost 14 percent. For a family of four with earnings of $200,000, it would go to $7,115 from $7,825, a drop of 9 percent.
City and state officials first approved the surcharge in 1990 to help the city close a budget gap caused in part by the recession. It was reauthorized the following year, with the money dedicated to pay for the hiring of police officers as part of the "Safe Streets, Safe City" program, which was adopted after a surge in violent crime in the city.
In his speech yesterday, Mr. Vallone said that with the recession over and the economy rebounding, the surcharge should lapse.
"The people of this city made the sacrifices that we asked of them," he said. "We were their representatives. Now it's up to us to pay them back -- with tax relief and tax reform and tax equity."
At a news conference soon after, Mr. Giuliani emphasized that while he generally favored cutting taxes, the city could not handle the loss of $500 million in revenue at a time when its finances are finally stabilizing after several years of austerity. "You're getting to the point where you are creating some degree of fiscal irresponsibility for the position of the city," he said of the proposal.
Mr. Vallone's aides said that by seeking to end the surcharge, he would help insulate himself during the gubernatorial campaign from accusations that he supported high taxes. If Mr. Vallone wins the primary, his fiscal record is almost certain to come under attack from the Pataki campaign, which would likely publicize a list of instances when he voted for tax increases.
The Speaker did not say in his speech how the city would make up for the lost revenue from the tax cut. The city is already facing a projected budget gap of $1.2 billion for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
In an interview after the speech, Mr. Vallone said city tax revenues continued to exceed expectations because of strong profits on Wall Street, so the city should not have trouble balancing its budget after the surcharge expires. Nor would the city have to reduce the number of police officers, because it would use other sources of revenue to make up for the police financing from the surcharge.
Mr. Vallone also said he was open to compromise with Mr. Giuliani. "I think that it's a very responsible proposal, or otherwise I would not have made it," he said. "That does not mean that we cannot sit down and modify it."
In his speech, Mr. Vallone formally announced two other proposals that his aides first disclosed on Tuesday. One would give half-price tuition for two years at the City University to students who maintain at least a B average. The other would keep all the city's public elementary schools open on school days from 3 P.M. to 7 P.M. for after-school programs.
All three proposals, he said, would revitalize the city's middle class, a theme he repeated in his speech.
Mr. Giuliani, though, derided the three proposals as exorbitant, saying that they would cost more than $1 billion a year. He questioned whether the tax cut would force the city to reduce the size of the Police Department just as he was planning to hire 1,600 police officers, bringing the total to 40,000, the highest ever.
Mr. Giuliani said he would strongly oppose the tax cut, but he is in a difficult position. Approval by the Governor and the State Legislature is required for the surcharge to be extended, yet it would be very unlikely that they would agree to do so without the assent of Mr. Giuliani and the Council. So Mr. Vallone could force the surcharge to lapse simply by blocking approval by the Council.
Mr. Giuliani called for doing away with the surcharge in January 1996. But he abandoned that proposal, and in the last two years, he has focused on eliminating the sales tax on clothing, which he said would provide more benefits to poor people than reducing the personal income tax.
The city and state have agreed to eliminate the sales tax on clothing under $100 next year.
In recent years, the Mayor and the Council have also cut the commercial rent tax and a tax on the earnings of unincorporated businesses.

HEADLINE: Government by Increment: Pataki Speech Takes Few Chances

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign showed that for an incumbent blessed with a healthy economy and strong poll numbers, an election year is the season for government by increment, not bold action. And Gov. George E. Pataki has learned the lesson well.
In his annual State of the State Message today, the Governor hewed to the core conservative ideas that got him elected, attacking high taxes and crime, but with nothing like the striking proposals of his first three years in office: the death penalty, deep cuts in income and property taxes, and smaller budgets. 
 Instead, as he begins the election year, Mr. Pataki, a Republican, cast a broad net of smaller, highly popular ideas, like allowing victims' relatives to testify at the sentencing of murderers and accelerating a tax cut for family farms. Where Mr. Clinton talked during his campaign about school uniforms and "portable" health insurance that an employee could carry from one job to another, Mr. Pataki today offered renovation of a Niagara Falls tourist center and a pilot after-school program.
Early in his 63-minute address, the Governor said that "today is truly a time for reflection," and sure enough, the speech was more a litany of past accomplishments than a blueprint for the future.
It was a signal that in the coming campaign, Mr. Pataki will take no chances because he believes that he does not have to. Mr. Pataki has huge leads in the polls over the Democratic gubernatorial hopefuls and a huge campaign war chest, and his advisers have figured that the heavy work of carrying him to a second term has already been done.
The tax cuts are in place, capital punishment is state law, and the welfare overhaul that the Governor sought in his first two years in office was delivered by Congress and Mr. Clinton. Wall Street's boom has left state government flush, allowing for pet programs, rather than spending cuts, to be the order of the day. And seven years into an economic expansion, New York's economy is finally growing at something approaching the national rate.
Taking another page from Mr. Clinton's re-election book, Mr. Pataki seized on issues that have been more commonly associated with the opposition, areas where he might be politically vulnerable.
In the past, Mr. Pataki repeatedly proposed sharp cuts in education and health care spending, cuts that were largely beaten back by the Legislature. Today, he proposed several new education programs and said he wanted to provide health care to all uninsured children.
The Governor boasted of a law enacted last year that will make prekindergarten classes available to most 4-year-olds, but that was the Democrats' initiative, and Mr. Pataki accepted it only in trade for property tax cuts. The kind of after-school program he proposed was a favorite of his Democratic predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, has been approved in other years by the Assembly and is already in place in several places, including New York City.
"Pataki started out as Newt Gingrich, and now he's Nelson Rockefeller," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester County Democrat. "Next, he'll be Bill Clinton."
Mr. Pataki has always made a virtue of simplicity, choosing a few themes and playing them to the hilt. Yet today, speaking from the comfort of incumbency and lacking any dramatic plans, he proposed no fewer than 28 pieces of legislation.
But they mostly had the distinct ring of familiarity. Some, like ending parole for all violent felons or passing a hate-crimes law, were proposals he has made in previous years that died in the Legislature. Others involved expanding programs or delivering tax cuts that are already set in law a year or two ahead of schedule. And the Governor, who used to chide Mr. Cuomo for his frequent use of pilot programs rather than broad initiatives, even proposed a few of his own pilot programs.
Pataki aides have said for months that the Governor would have no appetite this year for the kind of big, bruising fights with the Legislature that have marked his term so far. His speech today contained just one potential point of confrontation with the Democratic-controlled Assembly -- his renewed call for ending parole for all violent felons. But that idea is so widely popular with the public that many Democrats say they will be unable to resist going along with it this year.
Although Mr. Pataki has often railed against the dysfunction of state government, embracing ideas like term limits and ballot initiatives that put him at odds with the Legislature, today he mentioned none of them. "This speech was good political theater," said the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat who considered a run against Mr. Pataki this year. "It didn't take any chances and it showed George Pataki taking credit for the accomplishments of New York."
State Senator Thomas W. Libous, a Republican from Binghamton, put a kindlier spin on the same conclusion."There's no new direction because we don't need a new direction," Senator Libous said. "This is a great direction he's already put us in."

HEADLINE: Dueling Campaign Speeches

 BODY:
The biggest question raised by Gov. George Pataki's State of the State speech yesterday was what he saved to say when he announces for re-election. This speech was supposed to be about the challenges New York State has yet to meet, but its agenda was both modest and overly focused on campaign headlines.
The Governor failed to make a single mention of campaign finance reform. He did not speak of rebuilding the crumbling and overcrowded schools in many parts of New York. There was no offer of support for the drive by New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, to end tenure for public school principals. The Governor talked about creating jobs, but overlooked infrastructure -- the subway and rail service improvements needed to get workers to those jobs in New York City. 
 One important exception to the trivial tone was the call for making health care coverage available to every uninsured child in the state. Assembly Democrats say the plan should cover more types of treatment. That may be a desirable goal, but the most important priority, as Mr. Pataki seems to understand, should be making basic coverage universal for the state's children.
The Governor is at his best when he takes this statesmanlike stance between the Democratic-led Assembly's desire to spend and the Republican Senate's obsession with tax cuts. But when he begins to pander, he simply makes the normal partisan gridlock in Albany more hopeless. Mr. Pataki's call for expanding the death penalty laws before the state's first capital case has even come to trial was a tipoff that his law enforcement plans have more to do with winning in November than defeating crime.
He restricted his call for tax cuts to proposals that the Legislature speed up previously approved property tax relief for senior citizens and farmers. That restraint is welcome, since even the tax cuts already scheduled could create a fiscal crisis if another recession occurs.
This points up a problem in the State of the City speech yesterday by the New York City Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, who plans to run against Mr. Pataki. Mr. Vallone criticized the Governor's tax cuts as fiscally dangerous, but then proposed a $500 million reduction in the city's personal income tax and expensive new after-school programs without any balancing spending cuts. The Speaker's call for giving A and B students a huge tuition break at public colleges was less a serious idea for education reform than a sure-fire invitation to grade inflation. It was yet another sign of how election-year politics can wreak havoc on rational government.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Indonesia Leads Deeper Dive of Asian Currencies

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Indonesia's battered currency plumbed new depths today and its stock market tumbled after the nation drew blunt criticism from the United States for not doing enough to reform its economy and satisfy conditions for a $40 billion International Monetary Fund aid package.
The decline of the currency, the rupiah, weighed on other Asian currencies and stock markets. 
 Japanese shares were flat, dipping six-hundredths of a percent. Stocks in Hong Kong fell but rose 3.5 percent in South Korea.
Traders said the dominant theme in the markets was growing tension between the United States and Indonesia and the possibility that American displeasure might result in a cutoff of emergency relief.
"The Indonesians have gotten into the wrong side of the book of the U.S.," said Chia Woon Khien, head of Asian research at Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken in Jakarta. "It's not going to do Indonesia any good."
The rupiah tumbled 19 percent today, to as low as 10,000 to the dollar, its lowest since the currency began trading in 1971. It has fallen to record lows on each trading day this year. In 1997, the rupiah was the world's worst-performing currency, falling 56 percent against the dollar.
The Thai baht lost 2 percent this morning, declining to 54.10 to the dollar, its fifth drop in a row.
The Bank of Thailand is considering a return to a managed float of the baht, a daily newspaper reported today. The Nation quoted the bank's senior assistant governor, Siri Ganjarendee, as saying that under a proposal the central bank would form a consortium with commercial banks and big companies to quote the baht-dollar rate, effectively setting the exchange rate. The baht has lost 51.3 percent of its value since it was floated last July.
In Malaysia, the ringgit weakened as much as 2.7 percent, to 4,704 to the dollar, before recovering as the central bank bought the currency.
The Philippine peso and the Singapore dollar were little changed. The peso traded at 44.97 to the dollar compared with yesterday's settlement price of 45.35. The Singapore dollar was little changed at 1.7445 to the American dollar compared with 1.7535. Those declines contributed to a 5.8 percent tumble in Indonesian stocks, a 6.9 percent fall in Philippine shares and a 1 percent drop in Singapore stocks.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell despite an earlier rally by shares of exporters like Sony and the Toyota Motor Corporation, which are expected to benefit from the yen's depreciation against the dollar to the lowest levels in six years.
The Nikkei fell 8.99 points, or six-hundredths of a percent, to 15,019.18.
Hong Kong stocks continued to fall after a deep drop yesterday; the Hang Seng index was down 4.5 percent at midday. The market remained unsettled by news that Peregrine Investment Holdings might revise a deal with Zurich Center Investments Ltd. giving the Swiss group a stake in the company.

HEADLINE: U.S. Leaders Plan to Grapple A Hot Potato: Social Security

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
To one camp, Social Security is an inviolable promise to provide all workers the foundation of a comfortable retirement, and the program's looming financial problems should not be an excuse to dismantle what is in many ways the Federal Government's premier antipoverty program.
From another perspective, Social Security's obligations to future retirees so greatly exceed its projected receipts that the system cannot and should not be maintained as a mammoth Government entitlement. It should instead be remade to push more responsibility -- and risk -- into the hands of individuals. 
 Somewhere within that ideological gulf, the Clinton Administration, the Republican leadership and Congressional Democrats say they have begun looking for a politically and economically feasible way of assuring that the Social Security system does not become insolvent in the decades after the huge baby-boom generation begins retiring around 2010.
The White House and Speaker Newt Gingrich both said this week that they wanted to begin tackling the issue, one of the most politically explosive on Washington's agenda, and wanted to reach a final deal sometime between the mid-term Congressional elections in November and the start of the 2000 Presidential race a year or so later.
Because the problems in Social Security have been apparent for years, there is no shortage of proposed solutions bouncing around Washington. But while many politicians, economists and public policy experts say there is room for a compromise, there is little consensus on which of the competing and often painful proposals should be adopted.
"Substantively, the ground has been plowed," said Senator Judd Gregg, the New Hampshire Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee's task force on Social Security. "The question of whether anything is going to grow is one of political leadership."
Also unresolved is just what process President Clinton, Republican leaders and Democrats in Congress will use to hash out their differences and avoid turning Social Security into a bitterly partisan issue subject to demagoguery by both sides.
And all sides are still trying to gauge public opinion, both among retirees receiving Social Security benefits now and later generations who face the prospect of making bigger contributions to finance their parents' retirements while receiving little when they reach old age.
"We have to try to raise the sense of national urgency," said Gene Sperling, the White House's economic policy adviser.
The revenue raised for Social Security by payroll taxes on workers and employers currently exceeds what the system pays out in benefits, allowing the Government to accumulate a surplus. But after the baby boomers start to retire in droves around 2010, benefit payments will begin to exceed revenue, and under current projections the program will run through the surplus by 2029. After that, revenue each year would be sufficient to pay no more than about 75 percent of promised benefits.
Those who favor maintaining the Social Security system more or less in its present form include many Democrats, unions and the big groups representing the elderly. They advocate relying on financial changes to increase revenue or limiting benefits to avoid big changes in the system's structure or obligation to make guaranteed payments based on lifetime earnings. Most White House officials lean toward keeping a system that guarantees a defined amount of money to retirees.
"We need to also encourage private savings, but that should not come at the expense of the Social Security system that provides a base, a floor of support for millions and millions of Americans," Franklin D. Raines, the White House budget director, said on Sunday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
To keep the current system intact would require choosing among options including a reduction in benefits, an increase in taxes and an acceleration in the already scheduled increase in the retirement age.
There is also support for trying to increase the amount of money the Government makes investing the pool of funds it holds to pay future benefits. That trust fund is now invested entirely in Government bonds, which have generated only a fraction of the returns from stocks in recent years. Many analysts say the Government should invest part of the money in stocks.
The other general approach, favored by many conservative Republicans, calls for reducing the level of payment guaranteed by the Government but putting more of the taxes paid back into the hands of individuals to invest.
The most modest of these proposals would allow individuals to allocate some fraction of the money they contribute to Social Security to particular investment vehicles. The most radical approaches call for largely replacing the system with mandatory retirement savings accounts.
After two years of work, a Federal advisory panel reported last year that it was deeply split about which approach to take. Six of 13 members supported bolstering the current system, in part by allowing the Government to invest part of the Social Security trust fund in the stock market. Five favored creating mandatory savings accounts managed by individuals, reducing the current program to a minimum safety net of assured payments.
Two of the panel's members, however, advocated a middle-ground approach that many analysts think could point the way to a compromise: retain the current system but offset a decline in benefits with a mandatory savings account that would be financed by an increase in the payroll tax.
Many of the proposals circulating on Capitol Hill seek to strike a similar balance between fixing the current system and taking a more market-oriented approach.
But powerful groups representing the elderly are wary of substantial changes. "We feel that retirement should be built on the foundation of a defined benefit plan you can count on," said John Rother of the American Association of Retired Persons.
There are some measures that could prove politically palatable. Nearly four million employees of state and local governments are not covered by Social Security, and bringing them into the system would generate more revenue.
Many analysts think there will be no way to avoid unpopular steps. The retirement age for full benefit eligibility is already set to rise gradually to 67 from 65 between 2003 and 2029, and some Congress members believe it will be necessary to speed that timetable considerably.
The tax levied to finance Social Security might have to be increased. Currently, a 6.2 percent payroll tax, matched by the employer, is paid on wages up to a cap of $68,400. One option sure to be considered is substantially raising or eliminating the cap, placing a higher tax burden on people with higher incomes. Other options include reducing benefits for the wealthy and cutting cost-of-living increases.

HEADLINE: PATAKI PROPOSING HEALTH CARE PLAN FOR YOUNG PEOPLE

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Positioning himself for a re-election campaign this fall, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a major expansion of health insurance for young New Yorkers as well as an acceleration of tax cuts and an expansion of anti-crime measures that he said had already enabled him to lead the state to "the dawn of its greatest day."
In his fourth annual State of the State address, a speech notably devoid of contentious initiatives, the Republican Governor cautiously previewed the economic and social themes that he is likely to use if, as widely expected, he runs for a second term: reducing taxes, cutting welfare and fighting crime. 
 At the same time, while playing up his successes over the past three years in those areas, he strove to shore up potential electoral weaknesses elsewhere by offering a cheery, upbeat review of New York's job picture -- an outlook that his potential challengers insist is particularly dim because of a lack of gubernatorial leadership.
In this same context, by proposing the youth health insurance plan, he may also have been seeking to soften the oft-held perception that he is too rigid on social programs, especially welfare revision. The health proposal, he said, would guarantee access to comprehensive health coverage "for every single child of New York through the age of 18."
The proposal drew some of the loudest applause of the day, even louder than the applause drawn when earlier in the speech he proposed to more than double the size of the scheduled 1998 tax cut, to $1.2 billion.
"No child should be denied medical care," he said, though he offered no further details, particularly as to how much Federal money might be available for such a program.
At the start of his hourlong speech, delivered to both houses of the New York Legislature but aimed more at voters beyond the Capitol's ornate Assembly chamber, Mr. Pataki proudly asserted that "in just three years, we have restored the dream." As delivered, it sounded like a line that could well be heard many times over before November.
"We have reduced the size and cost of government," he said, his voice flat and carrying little emotion. "We have returned power that was for the people back to the people. We have restored sanctity to the idea that every New Yorker has a sacred right to choose and shape their own destiny."
The Governor had good reason in his speech to play up the tax cuts, education programs and anti-crime measures that he strongly supported, for, in the view of many political professionals, his support for them has enabled him to achieve approval ratings of close to 60 percent in the polls. In addition, those ratings have won him some recent mention as a possible Presidential or Vice-Presidential candidate.
In one of the several areas in which the Governor seemed to go out of his way to shore up his political fences in an area where he has been perceived as somewhat weak, job creation, he called for aggressive recruitment of high-technology firms by the state.
"Make no mistake," he declared. "New York will lead America into the high-tech age of the 21st century."
Arrayed around Mr. Pataki on the legislative dais as he spoke were most of the top elected officials in the state, including the leaders of both the State Senate and State Assembly, as well as Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, his running mate three years ago, who has since defected to Democratic ranks and now plans to challenge him in November.
The speech was received with enthusiastic support from Republican legislators, who repeatedly interrupted it with applause.
"In just three years, Governor Pataki has turned around New York State, pointing us towards greater economic prosperity," the Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno of Rensselaer County, said as he and other Republican lawmakers dispersed after the Governor's speech.
Democratic lawmakers mostly were polite but restrained.
"I never reject anything out of hand," said Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly, a Democrat of Manhattan.
Beyond Albany, where most of the Governor's potential re-election challengers live, the rhetoric often took on a sharper, more partisan tone.
"Today's speech shows New Yorkers that George Pataki is letting the ship of state float aimlessly toward the 21st century," said Peter F. Vallone, the Democrat who is Council Speaker in New York City and who has said he plans to run for Governor.
Mr. Pataki saw it otherwise, of course, in his speech.
He asserted that because of his leadership, New York is now "the undisputed tax-cutting capital of America." A "vast majority" of New Yorkers, he contended, now pay taxes at rates at least 25 per cent lower than they did when he first took office. "In the budget I send you in two weeks," he added, "I will propose more than doubling this year's tax cuts, to $1.2 billion."
The new cuts, he went on, would be written in particular to reduce property taxes paid by farmers and retired people. The votes of both played an important role in Mr. Pataki election victory in 1994, especially in upstate New York, a major base for him.
Turning to crime, another major issue in the 1994 Pataki victory -- he favored restoration of the death penalty -- the Governor said that the drop in the state's crime rate had been so drastic in the years since he took office that "the rest of the nation is looking at New York with awe." Then he called for passage of even tougher crime measures, including allowing juries to hear evidence about a defendant's criminal history, as well as allowing them to hear testimony from relatives of murder victims about the impact of the slaying on their lives.
The Governor also proposed giving apartment tenants and community organizations legal power to evict drug dealers from their neighborhoods. He called for an end to parole for all violent felons. And he said that drug offenders who are convicted repeatedly for "minor" offenses should eventually be charged with a felony, though he did not say how many convictions should result in the heavier charge. "Our mission is not to stem violent crime but to eradicate it, " Mr. Pataki declared.
On education, the Governor called for expanding the state's pre-kindergarten programs, urged setting up more charter schools and suggested increased efforts to improve reading and English-speaking skills.
"Nothing in our future holds more promise than the vivid dreams of a child," he said. "And no obligation is more fundamental -- for us, as parents -- than the obligation to give them a clear path to those dreams. Let's tackle the real-life problems that we know are preventing our children from learning."

HEADLINE: Canada's Indigenous Tribes Receive Formal Apology

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Jan. 7

 BODY:
For the first time, the Canadian Government has formally apologized to its 1.3 million indigenous people for 150 years of what Indian groups have charged were paternalistic assistance programs and racist schools that devastated their communities as thoroughly as any war or disease.
Along with the formal apology, the Government promised today to establish a $245 million "healing fund" for the thousands of Indians who were taken from their homes and forced to attend the schools, where they were sometimes physically and sexually abused. 
 Some social and economic development programs were also outlined.
The Government was responding to a report last year that condemned its treatment of indigenous people, but fell far short of fulfilling the report's recommendations. Indian leaders have long demanded an apology but federal officials refused to give one until now because of fears of setting a legal precedent.
Just as soon as the apology was read, it exposed a rift among Indians. Some leaders called it a historic step but others invited to the ceremony in the Parliament Building here today said the apology and the offer of compensation did not go far enough.
"The federal Government is insulting aboriginal people with this response," said Marilyn Buffalo, president of the Native Women's Association of Canada. Leaders representing the Inuit, as Eskimos are called here, were upset that forced relocations of their people were not mentioned. And the Metis, people of mixed Indian and European ancestry, said the Government's actions were insincere.
Indian leaders also pointed out that the compensation package is less than the $350 million that the Government acknowledged it wasted when it canceled a fleet of rescue helicopters. On Monday, it reordered essentially the same helicopters.
Prime Minister Jean Chretien, a former minister of Indian affairs who has not made Indian affairs a priority in his Government, was criticized for not having personally endorsed the apology by signing it.
Still, the formal "Statement of Reconciliation" represents a significant reversal and a difficult acknowledgment for a Government that prides itself on its compassion.
Speaking after an elaborate ceremony punctuated by drumbeats and traditional dances, Phil Fontaine, the national chief of the Assembly of First Nations, referred to the officials present as partners. His conciliatory attitude is thought to have played an essential part in getting the Government to act. He said it took courage for officials to take a "historic step to break with the past and to apologize for the historic wrongs and injustices" committed against Indian people.
Jane Stewart, the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, who also is considered a moderate voice in Indian affairs, said, "History cannot be changed." She said, however, that "it must be understood in a way that reflects that people today are living out the legacy of decisions made in a different time."
Indigenous people are among the poorest and least healthy of Canadians. Rates of infant mortality, youth suicide and unemployment are significantly higher than those for other Canadians, and most live below the official poverty line.
The apology, read by Ms. Stewart, specifically mentions abuses that took place at the residential schools. The system began in 1849 but was most active earlier this century. The Government took thousands of youths from their families and forced them to attend schools where they could not speak their languages or practice their customs or beliefs.
"To those of you who suffered this tragedy at residential schools, we are deeply sorry," the statement said.
Several religious orders that ran the schools have already apologized for abuses, and a number of individuals who were victimized during the 1950's, in the waning years of the schools, have filed lawsuits.
Residential schools were also operated in the United States, and similar abuses took place. The closest the United States Government came to apologizing was a 1969 Senate investigation, initiated by Senator Robert F. Kennedy, that documented abuses.
In addressing the broader pattern of historic injustices and prejudices here, the Canadian Government seems to have managed to avoid inviting new claims for reparation by expressing regret rather than admitting guilt: "The Government of Canada formally expresses to all Aboriginal people in Canada our profound regret for past actions of the federal Government which have contributed to these difficult pages in the history of our relationship together."
The Government also tried to reverse an emotional source of tension involving Louis Riel, the Metis leader of a rebellion who was hanged for treason in 1885. The statement of reconciliation pledges the Government will "look for ways of affirming the contributions of Metis people in Canada and of reflecting Louis Riel's proper place in Canada's history," but it stops short of revoking the treason charge, as indigenous people have demanded.
Gerald Morin, president of the Metis National Council, also criticized the Government's apology because it did not resolve the question of the group's status, which prevents them from pursuing land claims and some support programs.
Ms. Stewart said today's declarations were the Government's formal response to the November 1996 report by the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples, established by the federal Government in 1991 after a violent confrontation between Indians and the police on the Oka reserve in Quebec.
While supporting the commission's conclusion that Canada's Indian policy for the last 150 years has been wrong, the Government's actions do not come close to meeting any of the 440 recommendations the commission made. Among those were establishing a separate aboriginal parliament, abolishing the current Department of Indian Affairs and increasing annual spending on Indian affairs by about $1.4 billion by the end of the century. Current federal spending exceeds $4 billion.

HEADLINE: DINER'S JOURNAL

BYLINE: By Ruth Reichl 

 BODY:
In New York City, 1997 was an extraordinary year for restaurants. It was a time when talented chefs and restaurateurs had the courage to reconsider the notion of what makes a restaurant great.
On the one hand, we got Jean Georges. In his determination to make food the star of his establishment, Jean-Georges Vongerichten created a cool atmosphere and a menu filled with fireworks. He wanted his restaurant on Central Park West to be the antithesis of a celebrity spot, a place where people gathered to eat great food rather than to be surrounded by famous people or flattered by a famous chef. He succeeded, brilliantly. 
 Meanwhile, just across town in the Palace Hotel, Sirio Maccioni was recreating Le Cirque 2000, making it bigger, more opulent and more daring than before. He built what may be the world's most spectacular kitchen for his chef, Sottha Khunn, and surrounded it with a giddy, gaudy room to cater to the rich and famous. This time, however, he went one step further; although this social circus is dedicated to glamour, it is now a place where anyone can feel comfortable.
Downtown another great chef was creating a different sort of experience. At Bouley Bakery, David Bouley designed a small and intimate restaurant where he could experiment with flavor. The result is an ambiance of casual elegance that is utterly rewarding.
But high-stakes players were not the only ones who pleased us by pleasing themselves. Greek food finally got its due when the Livanos family, which owns a string of restaurants, decided to pay tribute to their native country. Molyvos is a midtown Greek restaurant where the food of the islands is cooked with enormous respect. At the same time, Francois Payard, who had been the pastry chef at Daniel, was also returning to his roots. At Payard Patisserie on the Upper East Side, the chef, Philippe Bertineau, is turning out wonderfully focused bistro food. The flip side of the same coin? Balthazar, the big bold SoHo bistro that is so celebrity-packed it is easy to overlook how good the food is.
This was also a year when a handful of talented younger chefs opened new Manhattan restaurants. With Katy Sparks (Quilty), Seen Lippert (Across the Street), Gary Robins (Aja), John Schenk (Clementine), Laurent Manrique (Gertrude) and Rocco DiSpirito (Union Pacific) around, we can be certain that the future of food in our town is very bright. These are all expensive restaurants, but an extremely encouraging trend also emerged in inexpensive eating places. Soup restaurants opened in droves last year, offering affordable, healthy, home-style cooking as an alternative to fast food.
But here's the best news of all: 1998 could turn out to be even better. The economy is good, everyone's eating out, and this year promises a spate of interesting upscale ethnic establishments. There are great French, Indian and Korean restaurants on the horizon. Doesn't that whet your appetite?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the chef at Jean Georges. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)
