HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
 
* BO DIDDLEY, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-6300. The first innovation Bo Diddley devised was to take what he'd learned playing classical violin -- "choking the strings," as the critic Robert Palmer once called it -- and apply it to playing guitar. Thus, some say, funk was born. And Mr. Diddley's innovations just kept propagating. He designed and built his own instruments, experimented with amplified distortion, mixed urban myths and African-inspired legends in his lyrics and made the maracas a major part of rock-and-roll. Most famously, he created an approach to rhythm that is one of rock-and-roll's foundation stones. And he's still the master of the form. Johnny Allen also performs. Tonight at 7:30 and 10:30; tickets are $20 (Ann Powers). 

REGINA CARTER, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Ms. Carter is a magnificently gifted violinist who loves her blues phrases. She's had momentary lapses of sense, venturing into instrumental pop music, which is a bit like having Michael Jackson digging post holes. She'll be backed by Kenny Barron on piano, Peter Washington on bass, Rodney Jones on guitar and Lewis Nash on drums, a jazz rhythm section that takes the back seat to no one. Let's find out what Ms. Carter, in the right context, can really do. Sets through Sunday night at 9 and 11 with a 12:30 show tonight and tomorrow. Admission is $17.50 with a $10 minimum (Peter Watrous).
ELIANE ELIAS, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. The pianist's latest record, "The Three Americas" (Blue Note), unites the Americas: North, Central and South; her quartet reflects that vision, with bass, drums and flute. Tomorrow night at 9 and 11; cover of $25 at the table with a $10 minimum and a cover of $20 at the bar (Ben Ratliff).
JERRY GALANTE, Latin Quarter, 2551 Broadway, at 96th Street, (212) 864-7600. Colombian salsa has its own rhythm, and its own lightness, and Mr. Galante, from Colombia, is a good improvising singer. He's relocated to New York and uses a local band, and he knows how to make a dance hall swing with his orchestra. Tomorrow's show starts at 10:30 P.M.; there is a cover of $20 for men and $15 for women (Watrous).
* GREG GARING, the Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Plaintive, countryish songs about being lost and lovelorn grow even more disoriented in arrangements permeated by eerie electronic sounds; the hybrid may be trendy, but somehow it doesn't sound forced. Tonight at 9:30; admission is $7 (Jon Pareles).
BRENDA KAHN AND JOHN S. HALL, Fez, 380 Lafayette Street at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. It makes sense that singer-songwriters from the Lower East Side would be more likely to focus on their decrepit apartments and the strange folks they end up taking home from the local bar than on other, more rustic versions of Americana. These two performers have been offering cockeyed observations of various urban myths for more than a decade. Mr. Hall made a splash with his band, King Missile. Ms. Kahn has never hit heavy rotation on MTV, but even if she did, she probably wouldn't lose her sarcastic edge. With Fisherman Stew. Tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.; tickets are $8 (Powers)
* B. B. KING, the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. After all his years on the road, B. B. King can still wring pain and grit and desperate love from his familiar songs, as Lucille, his guitar, wails in sympathy. This is a rare club engagement. Tonight through Sunday at 9 and 11:30, but early shows are sold out. There is a $65 cover and a $5 minimum at tables or a $45 cover at the bar (Pareles).
* THE KLEZMATICS, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3055. The Klezmatics love the laughing, moaning melodies of traditional klezmer music. They also love jazz, rock and downtown improvisation, and they bring all of them to bear on their music, which can be raucous, hypnotic, reverent and dizzying, sometimes all in one quick-changing piece. They carry klezmer's itinerant, idea-gathering spirit all the way into 1990's New York City. Sunday at 8 and 10:30 P.M.; admission is $10 (Pareles).
JOE LOVANO, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. The saxophonist is almost surreal in his inventiveness: where does all this knowledge come from? His solos billow with ideas, and giving him another half an hour to finish won't stop the flood. He surrounds himself with all sorts of groups, and this week he's showing some of them off. Tonight he'll be playing with the large band that he used on a Sinatra tribute; it's a bit precious. Tomorrow and Sunday he'll be performing with the Cuban pianist Gonzalo Rubalcaba; they've recently released an album, "Flying Colors." Sets through Sunday night are at 9:30, 11 and midnight; no third set on Sunday. There is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum (Watrous).
MASTERS OF THE NEY, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 545-7536. The World Music Institute is presenting two ensembles led by players of the ney, a reed flute used across the Middle East. Tonight at 8, Hossein Omoumi, from Iran, and two percussionists are to play Persian classical music: thoughtful, spiraling improvisations on ancient modes and melodies. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., Omar Faruk Tekbilek will lead his ensemble, which includes oud, bass, keyboards, guitar and percussion. Mr. Tekbilek is from Turkey, where he worked as a studio musician and studied to be a Sufi priest; his music draws on folk, pop and jazz influences. Tickets to each concert are $15 (Pareles).
CHRISTIAN McBRIDE, NICHOLAS PAYTON AND MARK WHITFIELD, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. The trumpet-bass-guitar trio got together last spring to make a recording of Herbie Hancock tunes, "Fingerpainting" (Verve). That's right, no pianist. And with this pared-down instrumentation, they even tackle funk tunes like "Chameleon." Sets tonight are at 9 and 11; cover is $25 at tables and $10 at the bar (Ratliff).
* FRANKIE NEGRON, Latin Quarter, 2551 Broadway, at 96th Street, (212) 864-7600. Perhaps the hottest of the young salsa singers, Mr. Negron, from New Jersey, is being primed as the next Marc Anthony, the assumption being that Mr. Anthony is leaving salsa for economically richer pastures. Certainly Mr. Negron's hits, produced by Sergio George, have him chasing Mr. Anthony, which means nothing less than a good singer singing good material with great arrangements. The show tonight starts at 10:30; there is a cover of $15 for men and $10 for women (Watrous).
CHICO O'FARRILL, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. Having orchestrated modernist Afro-Cuban jazz fantasias for be-boppers in the 1940's, and 50's, Mr. O'Farrill has a more important place in jazz history than anyone probably yet recognizes. His 18-piece band, starting a regular Sunday night gig at Birdland, provides a good demonstration of how jazz harmony can mesh with guajira and guaganco rhythms. The music represents both a basic recipe for modern jazz as well as a highly developed side road of it. Sunday at 9 and 11 P.M. Cover, $15; minimum, $10 (Ratliff).
* PACHORA, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. The musicologist-improvisers of the Knitting Factory scene have been venturing deeply into Eastern European music for some time now, and this excellent quartet -- the saxophonist and clarinetist Chris Speed, the guitarist Brad Shepik, the bassist Skuli Sverrison and the drummer Jim Black -- are the most flexible among them. Tonight through Sunday in the club's comfortable new basement lair; sets are at 8 and 9:30, and a $10 cover includes a $5 drink minimum (Ratliff).
JEAN-MICHEL PILC TRIO, Internet Cafe, 82 East Third Street, East Village, (212) 614-0747. Mr. Pilc, a French jazz pianist in his mid-30's who arrived in New York two years ago, seems to have dropped from the sky fully formed, with technique and ideas in place. He is a physical and densely harmonic player, a splashy stunner who also has a Rubik's Cube mind for chord substitutions. His own songs, as well as his versions of Monk and Coltrane, make you dizzy with their key changes and sudden, pulled up short rhythmic effects. Tonight and tomorrow at 10 and 11:30; admission is $5 (Ratliff).
POLVO AND TRANS AM, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 544-1666. In bands like Polvo and Trans Am, the instrumental excursions of progressive rock have made an inconspicuous resurgence by using the scruffier, more modest trappings of alternative rock. Polvo's songs barely contain the dissonant clangor of their unconventionally tuned guitars; Trans Am plays instrumental rock with clear-cut song forms and arrangements that trace long arcs from delicacy to grandeur to noise. Tomorrow at 9 P.M., with Spatula opening; tickets are $10 (Pareles).
SHIMMY DISC 10TH ANNIVERSARY EXTRAVAGANZA, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Throughout the 1990's, this Lower East Side-based label, run by the resolutely eccentric artist Kramer, has been home to some of underground pop's wackiest and most charming acts. Less active now than it once was, Shimmy Disc still garners loyalty from enough iconoclasts to make this a promising bill. Performers include Kramer himself, Ikue Mori, Semi-Beings, Blue Whales, Glen or Glenda, King Missile II and Drazy Hoops. Tonight at 7; tickets are $10 (Powers).
SIMENTERA DE CABO VERDE, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Newark has a large Portuguese population, and in its first year, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center is presenting performers from Portuguese-speaking countries. Among the former colonies is Cape Verde, a group of islands off the coast of Senegal, which has produced a kind of song called morna that's both lilting and wistful. Simentera de Cabo Verde blends morna with Brazilian and African pop and touches of Portuguese classical music. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $25 (Pareles).
* STEVE WILSON, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. At Chick Corea's recent show at the Blue Note, Mr. Wilson, a saxophonist, walked away with the awards. He's a musician's musician: young players flock to him. And he's been playing better than ever recently, mixing odd harmonies with a rhythmic sense and poise that's dancelike. He's playing with his great partner, the drummer Leon Parker, along with the pianist Kevin Hays and the bassist Ed Howard. Tonight through Sunday, there are sets at 8, 10 and midnight, with no third set on Sunday. There is a $20 cover and a two-drink minimum (Watrous).
STEVE WYNN, RICHARD LLOYD, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. A hero of the mid-1980's post-punk rock revival, Steve Wynn has made a career of taking the advice of his hero, Bob Dylan, not to look back. For a traditionalist, he is steadfastly experimental, always trying new settings and structures for his basic, rootsy guitar rock. Richard Lloyd is a groundbreaking guitarist with a strong sense of the old-fashioned song. Amanda Thorpe opens the show. Sunday at 8 P.M.; tickets are $7 (Powers).

GRAPHIC: Photos: B. B. King is to perform at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village. (Agence France-Presse); Regina Carter is at Sweet Basil in Greenwich Village this weekend. (Jack Vartoogian)

PUB-DATE: January 9, 1998

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 904 words

HEADLINE: Aston Becomes a Lab For Ford's Technology

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
SOMETHING about Aston Martin seems to foster experimentation. Modified by Q, the gadget guru in Her Majesty's Secret Service, a model DB5 often saved Agent 007's hide with an ejector seat, wheel hubs that shredded villains' tires, machine guns hidden behind the lights and a screen that deflected bullets.
But Q could never have oictured an Aston Martin like the Project Vantage, a concept car shown by the tiny British car maker this week at the North American International Auto Show here. It can reach a top speed of 200 miles an hour but delivers a respectable 20 miles a gallon, making it an ideal getaway car for James Bond (who has defected to BMW in his two latest movies, perhaps because that auto maker has far more money to spend on advertising tie-ins). 
 In unveiling the Project Vantage, the Ford Motor Company, which bought Aston Martin in 1987, said it planned to use the small sports car company as a lab for new technologies that might eventually find their way into other Ford products.
"We take several approaches to test new technologies," Jacques A. Nasser, president of Ford Automotive Operations, said. "Our involvement in Formula One racing is a test bed for some new technologies, for instance. Concept vehicles are another. With Aston Martin, we can test technologies with low investment and low volumes."
In addition, buyers who purchase Aston Martins, which start at $126,000, are able and willing to pay for expensive new technologies. "Our customers want to make a statement about themselves," Bob Dover, chairman and chief executive of Aston Martin, said. "They enjoy driving their cars, so we have to integrate technology to be useful to them."
The technologies used in the Project Vantage's V12 engine hold the most promise for power plants in more mundane Ford products. The prototype six-liter, 48-valve engine was developed by Ford, Aston Martin and another British company, Cosworth Engineering, which builds engines for Formula One cars.
The Project Vantage, a two-seater with the engine up front and the driving wheels in the rear, can deliver blistering, race car performance. Engineers calculate that it will accelerate from 0 to 60 in a scant four seconds and reach more than 140 m.p.h. in a quarter-mile. But unlike most high-performance V12 engines, which are notorious gasoline hogs, fuel consumption is on a par with many of the sport utility vehicles popular with Americans. The Project Vantage's low emissions should meet or exceed the world's strictest standards, its developers say.
"Whether we're developing a V12 or an in-line four-cylinder engine, we should be able to take some of the lessons and technology we are developing with the Project Vantage's engine and feed it back through the Ford system," Mr. Nasser said.
Ford has no plans to put the prototype vehicle into production, he added, but company executives will gauge worldwide public reaction this year to determine whether a feasible market exists for the car.
 In addition to the V12, another feature of the Project Vantage that could find its way into other Ford products is its transmission. The six-speed can shift gears automatically, or it can be shifted manually, without a clutch, using finger tip paddles on the steering wheel. The system, similar to Porsche's Tiptronic, is borrowed from Formula One race cars.
Such clutchless automatic transmissions are gaining momentum in the marketplace and are of interest to car companies like Ford because of their fuel efficiency. Unlike Europeans, Americans favor effortless automatic transmissions, particularly when driving in stop-and-go traffic. But automatics use more fuel than manuals do.
"The question is how can we make manual transmissions more accommodating but provide efficiency improvements?" said Neil W. Ressler, Ford's vice president for advanced vehicle technology. "An automatic transmission you can shift seems an attractive alternative."
The Project Vantage's suspension components are also borrowed from race cars. Their small size and light weight could provide useful lessons for production vehicles, Mr. Ressler said.
The Project Vantage uses advanced lightweight materials, including aluminum and carbon fiber, throughout its structure and in its interior.
The Project Vantage's structure is similar to that of a Formula One car in terms of occupant protection and structural rigidity. The passenger compartment is like a safety cage, constructed from aluminum in a honeycomb shape, with carbon fiber reinforcements. Chassis sections and roof pillars are made of extruded aluminum. The roof is made of carbon fiber as well. The result is a saving of 50 percent in weight from traditional materials, like steel, but a 100 percent increase in the rigidity of the structure. In addition, the Project Vantage is designed to be as stable as a race car.
Inside, the Project Vantage is trimmed not with wood, like most luxury cars, but with brushed aluminum and carbon fiber. Still, the upholstery is luxurious Connolly leather with suede. Each of the two seats is equipped with four-point safety harnesses. Matching tailored luggage fits in the trunk and interior niches.
The styling is readily recognizable as an Aston Martin, with a newly aggressive, racy look. The Project Vantage was created by Ian Callum, the Scottish designer who also developed the look of the Aston Martin DB7, introduced last year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Although the V12 Project Vantage concept vehicle is relatively economic on fuel, neither the Aston Martin's exterior nor interior brings to mind the simple life.
